DOC.HEAD: Judge Issues Restraining Order Against Alderman, Militant Group
DOC.TEXT: A judge Tuesday issued a restraining order barring an alderman who threatened to disrupt the city's annual Great Circus Parade from coming within 500 feet of the parade route. Alderman Michael McGee, censured last month by his colleagues for threatening violence if inner city problems aren't dealt with, warned Monday that he and members of his Black Panther Militia planned to disrupt the parade. McGree wrote to parade organizer Ben Barkin that parents should keep their children at home because the protest ``could get ugly.'' He indicated the city had no right to enjoy itself while its black community was convulsed with violence and poverty. The city responded Tuesday by obtaining the restraining order from Milwaukee County Circuit Judge John E. McCormick. ``The memo to Ben Barkin, in my opinion, was a threat of violence,'' City Attorney Grant Langley said. The parade annually attracts 500,000 people or more who line the two-mile route through the downtown area. It features restored antique circus wagons, marching bands, equestrienne groups, clowns and other attractions. ``We are very concerned about the potential for disruption having an effect on the animals, frightening the animals,'' Langley said, noting that McGee's unspecified disruption could involve anything from mass whistle-blowing to tossing fireworks. Langley said the temporary restraining order applies to McGee and five others named in the order, as well as all other members of McGee's Black Panther Militia and anyone else acting in concert with the alderman. McGee, censured by the Common Council two weeks ago, was unavailable when The Associated Press attempted to reach him at his City Hall office and at his home for comment. There was no answer at those telephone numbers. Doris Green, one of those named with McGee in the restraining order, read a statement at a news conference in which McGeen said it would be an honor to be arrested while protesting at the parade. McGee has repeatedly criticized the city for failing to address inner city problems. He formed the militia earlier this year and claims it has 500 members, including street gang members, who will take violent action if inner city problems aren't eased by 1995. The Common Council censured McGee June 29 after he announced he had received a sausage-poisoning threat from a militant group, causing a local company to recall thousands of dollars worth of meat products. City officials claimed that McGee invented the poisoning threat.

DOC.HEAD: Study Says Infectious Hepatitis Spreads More Quickly Than AIDS
DOC.TEXT: An infectious strain of hepatitis that can cause several liver diseases is spread even more rapidly than AIDS among gay men, according to a study announced Tuesday. The hepatitis B virus is contracted 8.6 times more easily than the human immunodeficiency virus that causes AIDS, according to a University of Pittsburgh study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association. ``Since the beginning of the AIDS epidemic, hepatitis B has been pushed in the background,'' said Dr. Lawrence Kingsley, who led the study of 1,062 gay men in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia. The virus infects an estimated 300,000 more Americans every year, and 5 to 10 percent of them will develop cirrhosis, liver cancer or chronic liver disease, the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta reported. Studies from the early 1980s have shown 50 to 70 percent of gay men carry the hepatitis B virus, researchers said. Other disease researchers said the Pitt study is significant because it dramatically shows that the hepatitis B strain is passed much more easily than the AIDS virus through sexual contact and exchange of body fluids. ``The viruses are linked in their similar patterns of spread, both by blood and both by sexual contact,'' said Dr. Joseph Melnick of Baylor University in Houston. Dr. Rebecca Van Dyke of the University of Michigan said the comparison of the two viruses proves what long was suspected by doctors who have treated gay men in the 1980s. ``I worked in San Francisco, and we had hepatitis B all over the place ... and we knew it was transmitted fairly quickly,'' Ms. Van Dyke said. She said the emergence of AIDS has made more people aware of all sexually transmitted diseases, including hepatitis B, but at the same time those at risk of getting AIDS ``may not pay attention to other diseases'' and seek treatment. The B strain is the only one of five types of hepatitis that can be prevented with a vaccine, researchers said. About 2.5 million Americans received it in 1989, and most of them were health-care workers, said the CDC's Dr. Miriam Alter. The vaccine was developed by researchers who studied gay men in New York City because the strain was so prevalent among homosexuals, Ms. Van Dyke said. The Pitt study also said anal intercourse puts men at a high risk for contracting hepatitis B. Other studies have claimed higher AIDS infection rates are linked to anal intercourse. Because hepatitis B ``is so easily transmitted, we're trying to underscore the need for safer sex, the use of condoms,'' Kingsley said.

DOC.HEAD: Summit Drafts Conditions for Future Soviet Aid
DOC.NOTE: Eds; combines pvs, adds 20th graf on World Bank.
DOC.TEXT: Western leaders gave Mikhail Gorbachev a warm endorsement Tuesday and pledged to ``help in practical ways those countries that choose freedom.'' The industrial powers ordered a study of the tangled Soviet economy and drafted conditions for sending financial aid. ``Prospects for fundamental and long-term economic aid could improve if the Soviet Union comes to a substantial change in resources from military to civilian production, and ends the support to those states which create regional conflict,'' according to a foreign language draft of the final communique. At the midway point of their three-day summit, the leaders acknowledged recent improvements in Beijing by slightly easing restrictions on aid to China. Japan said it intended to move ahead, on its own, with a $5 billion loan package. Diplomats worked late on a controversial U.S. proposal to phase out worldwide agricultural subsidies. There was no resolution as President Bush and his six summit partners met for an elegant dinner at the Houston Museum of Fine Arts. An administration official said the leaders would endose a joint effort to help Brazil save its Amazon rain forests. In a goodwill gesture to Bush, allies did not press a desire for specific goals to reduce pollutants blamed for causing the global warming of the environment. The United States strongly opposes such targets. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said the summit talks were held in ``an atmosphere of constructive help. As far as I can see there were no fights. There were some disagreements.'' But Bush told his dinner guests to put business aside. ``There is no working tonight, no communiques, no amendments and not language to be corrected,'' the president said. He improvised a brief welcome, and aides said later he had left his prepared toast in his hotel suite. Earlier, the leaders released a joint statement bidding goodbye to the Iron Curtain separating Eastern and Western Europe. They said they were ``determined to seize all opportunities to a achieve a Europe whole and free.'' By authorizing the study of Soviet needs, the leaders blunted West German efforts to organize a coordinated program of direct aid. With support from Britain and Japan, Bush insists the money would be wasted unless Gorbachev can achieve broader reforms. He also wants the Soviets to curtail Cuban subsidies and reduce spending on the military. The leaders issued a declaration allowing any of the summit nations to aid the Soviets on their own. West Germany has pledged $3.1 billion in loans and there was no discussion of putting that on hold. The United States is not willing to provide aid beyond technical assistance, but it was possible the study _ to be supervised by the International Monetary Fund and completed by the end of this year _ could lead to a more generous approach. No promises, though. ``Even if the study recommends direct aid from the West, we might still say I'm sorry,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Aside from West Germany, France and Italy have spoken up for fast aid to Moscow, and Canada is releasing some commercial credit. Foreign Minister Joe Clark of Canada told reporters ``there will probably be some announcements of fairly substantial action by some countries in the next four or five weeks.'' Looking ahead to Wednesday's wrapup communique, Bush was trying to persuade his partners to phase out agricultural subsidies, a linchpin to ongoing global trade talks. . ``America protects its agriculture ferociously,'' British foreign secretary Douglas Hurd noted. ``So does Europe, though to a lesser extent ... the Japanese protect theirs perhaps most of all.'' In their political statement, the leaders toasted ``the replacement of repressive regimes in Central and Eastern Europe by governments freely chosen by their peoples.'' Referring to the economically troubled, reform-minded government in Moscow, the leaders said, ``We commit ourselves to working with the Soviet Union to assist its efforts to create an open society, a pluralistic democracy and a market-oriented economy.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III said, ``I would hope that there would be a consensus coming out of this summit ... that technical assistance to the Soviet Union is warranted even under the circumstances that exist today'' The leaders agreed: ``Each of us stands ready to help in practical ways those countries that choose freedom, through the provision of constitutional, legal and economic know-how and through economic assistance, as appropriate.'' Even in authorizing the Soviet needs study, there was brief discord as the leaders debated which agency would lead the effort. France's Francois Mitterrand argued that the IMF's role could humiliate the Soviets by subjecting Moscow to the same financial scrutiny imposed on developing countries. The World Bank, which is to participate in the study, issued a statement saying the work would take at least a year to complete and could provide useful guidance for countries considering investing in the Soviet economy. The summit concludes Wednesday with a final statement and a series of news conferences. Vice President Dan Quayle and his wife Marilyn flew in to join the leaders for the dinner at the Museum of Fine Arts. As the leaders conferred, their spouses flew to San Antonio to tour the Alamo and other historic sites. Margaret Thatcher's husband, Denis, the only male spouse, skipped the trip. In a gesture to Japan's Toshiki Kaifu, the leaders agreed to loosen restrictions on aid to China, in recognition of its slight easing of repression. Summit countries pledged to explore whether new World Bank loans ``would contribute to reform of the Chinese economy, especially loans that would address environmental concerns.'' On the other hand, the summit refused to lift Western sanctions. ``We will keep them under review for future adjustments to respond to further positive developments in China,'' the political communique said. Marking recent developments in Moscow, the statement said: ``We welcome the intention of the Soviet Union to move towards a democratic political system, as well as Soviet attempts to reform their economy along market principles.'' The Western statement coincided with Gorbachev's success this week in reshaping control of the Communist Party in ways that will bolster newly elected officials and give the 15 Soviet republics a bigger share of power. Turning to Eastern and Central Europe, where Soviet control is being supplanted by reformist governments, the leaders welcomed ``the replacement of repressive regimes'' but singled out Romania for lagging behind. Fitzwater said this was one summit where the leaders were wrestling with the main issues themselves, not just ratifying the work of their diplomatic ``sherpas'' and other summit aides. ``The language that you see in the final communique on those issues I think will be more a product of the actual summit debate than what we've seen in many of these former years,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Eliason Named Bureau Chief in Jerusalem
DOC.TEXT: Marcus Eliason, London news editor for The Associated Press since 1988, has been named the AP's bureau chief in Jerusalem. The appointment was announced Tuesday by AP President Louis D. Boccardi. Eliason, 43, succeeds Nicolas B. Tatro, who is on leave as a journalism fellow sponsored by the National Endowment for the Humanities at the University of Michigan. Eliason joined the AP in Tel Aviv in 1968 and worked in Israel for 14 years, including assignments as Jerusalem correspondent and Tel Aviv news editor. He also worked for the AP in Paris from 1978 to 1980 and in London since 1984. Eliason, a native of Port Elizabeth, South Africa, was a reporter for the Jerusalem Post before joining the AP.

DOC.HEAD: Little Blue Hippo Sets Record for Egyptian Relic
DOC.TEXT: A small 3,500-year-old pottery hippopotamus has sold for $955,600, a record auction price for an Egyptian antiquity. The 4.25 inch-long hippo is glazed in turquoise and has lotus blossoms and a grasshopper painted on its back. Sotheby's auctioneers said only six others like it are known. London dealer Robin Symes bought the artifact on Tuesday. It was sold by Antoinette Schuster, a descendant of the late Marion Schuster, a Swiss collector. The previous top price for an Egyptian antiquity was $742,500, for a granite figure of the goddess Sekhmet auctioned in 1986. The hippo was found in 1907 at Abydos by John Garstang, an English archaeologist. It was later owned by a clergyman, the Rev. William MacGregor, who had paid 100 pounds (then $500) to become one of 10 patrons of the excavation. Hippos appear only in tombs of the Middle Kingdom period between 2040 and 1650 B.C., and their purpose is not known. Some scholars believe they symbolize rebirth or that they were simply intended to give pleasure in the afterlife.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Abortion Ban Could Prompt Reconsideration of Roe vs. Wade
DOC.TEXT: The Louisiana legislature's abortion ban, if signed into law, may provide the test that prompts the Supreme Court to reconsider its 17-year-old Roe vs. Wade decision, say advocates on both sides of the abortion debate. Anti-abortion and abortion rights groups were waiting for word from Louisiana Gov. Buddy Roemer on whether he will sign or veto the bill passed overwhelmingly after a tumultuous weekend Statehouse battle. If it becomes law, the measure would be the nation's strictest anti-abortion law and would represent a direct challenge to the 1973 Roe decision in which the court declared abortion to be a constitutional right. ``There's no question that this is a great bill for us,'' said John C. Willke of Cincinnati, president of the National Right to Life Committee, the leading anti-abortion group. ``This will stop 99 percent of all baby killing in the state of Louisiana,'' Willke said. ``It certainly is a signal to the rest of the nation.'' The bill was passed overwhelmingly Sunday night after abortion foes failed to override Roemer's veto of an even stronger abortion ban. The new bill includes provisions, demanded by Roemer, to allow abortion in cases of reported rape and incest. However, the governor said Monday he hadn't decided whether to sign or veto the latest version. National abortion rights groups were stunned by the sudden emergence of the revised bill. Kate Michelman, executive director of the National Abortion Rights Action League, called it ``the most outrageous and dangerous anti-choice bill in the nation'' and urged Roemer to veto it. Roger Evans, director of litigation for Planned Parenthood, said his group will file suit to block the measure if Roemer signs it. ``I don't see how the Louisiana law could get to the Supreme Court without forcing a frontal confrontation with Roe v. Wade,'' he added. Dawn Johnsen, legal director of the National Abortion Rights Action League, said the Louisiana bill ``could be upheld only if the court were to overrule Roe and deprive all women of the right to choose.'' Other recent cases before the Supreme Court involved more narrow restrictions, such as requiring parental notification when minors seek an abortion and limits on where and how they could be performed. The decisions in those cases chipped away at Roe without directly addressing it. State legislatures considered a number of anti-abortion bills this year after the Supreme Court's 1989 Webster decision gave states the authority to impose some restrictions. Idaho was the only other state to pass a bill as strict as the Louisiana measure, but it was vetoed by Gov. Cecil Andrus. Guam, a U.S. territory, also has passed an abortion ban, but it has been blocked by the courts. Willke said he expects the Louisiana measure, if enacted, to be challenged in court and blocked during appeals. ``Then it will go to Supreme Court, and that's two years from now, and our guess is by then we'd have big, broad smiles on our faces,'' he said. Willke said he believes the court's current membership would use a case involving the Louisiana measure to strike down all or part of the Roe decision. But he said the court's makeup could change by the time the case is heard, and predicted that could shift the decision even more in his group's direction. However, Planned Parenthood's Evans said his group believes the currently divided court would stop short of reversing its decision on abortion. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor is considered the pivotal vote in any abortion case. Johnsen, in a written analysis of the Louisiana bill, said the rape exception was too narrow because it requires a victim to report the attack within seven days. She said it goes further than the Idaho bill by imposing prison sentences of up to 10 years for doctors performing abortions, and said it could lead to prosecution of women who self-induce abortion.

DOC.HEAD: Mel Blanc's Headstone Reads `That's All Folks'
DOC.TEXT: Mel Blanc, the voice of Porky Pig, Bugs Bunny and legions of other cartoon characters, put the same signature on his life as he did on his work, says his son, who had the famous words engraved on a new tombstone. ``That's All Folks,'' reads the 5-foot white marble monument at the Beth-Olam Cemetery, near Hollywood's Paramount Studio. Those were ``the last words he ever said on-camera or off-camera,'' Blanc's son, Noel, said Monday. The headstone was set in time to mark the first anniversary of his father's death on July 10, 1989, Blanc said. The elder Blanc delivered the daffy Looney Tunes sign-off, ``That's All Folks,'' while filming a commercial for Buick automobiles with Noel when he was stricken and rushed to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center. He died about two months later at the age of 81. Blanc was the voice who gave life to hundreds of cartoon characters, including Yosemite Sam, Daffy Duck, Sylvester the Cat and other Warner Bros. creations. Even now, ``My dad is heard by 250 million people every day all over the world,'' Blanc said. ``They figure that somewhere you can turn on a television and hear him.'' The younger Blanc has carried on his father's tradition, and recently recorded Bugs Bunny singing ``Happy Birthday'' greetings to more than 1,400 different names for a computerized 900 telephone service. Nevertheless, he said, ``Nobody ever will be able to do what he has done. He created more than 1,500 voices.'' The new headstone reads: ``That's All Folks Mel Blanc Man of a Thousand Voices Beloved Husband and Father 1908-1989.''

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Senator's Third-Party Bid Favored in Connecticut Governor's Race
DOC.TEXT: Both the Democrats and the Republicans are underdogs in the Connecticut governor's race this year. Voters seem smitten with the third-party campaign of a maverick ex-senator they ousted from office just 1{ years ago. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. narrowly lost his bid for a fourth Senate term in 1988 but roared back onto the state's political scene in March, forsaking the GOP and declaring his candidacy as an independent. Poll after poll has found Weicker to be the frontrunner in the gubernatorial race, far ahead of the two congressmen who are expected to claim the Republican and Democratic nominations. But Weicker _ who created his own party, the Connecticut Party _ discounts the polls. He remembers 1988, when he was favored for re-election to the Senate and lost by 10,000 votes to Democrat Joseph Lieberman. G. Donald Ferree Jr., director of polling at the University of Connecticut, said Weicker is riding almost 20 years of statewide support, but he predicts the race will tighten as the candidates stake out positions and become better known. ``Because (voters) aren't hearing much and because Weicker has such a strong advantage in terms of familiarity, there's been very little movement,'' Ferree said. It would be a mistake to interpret the current numbers as ``hardened preferences,'' he said. This is the first time in 20 years that Connecticut Democrats aren't favored to win the governor's office. The party is foundering after Democratic Gov. William A. O'Neill was forced to raise taxes by more than $1 billion last year. O'Neill, citing ``political realities'' and saying he had no stomach for a nasty campaign, in March dropped plans to run for re-election. The Democratic frontrunner now is four-term Rep. Bruce A. Morrison, who was challenging O'Neill for the nomination. The day O'Neill dropped out, little-known state Rep. William J. Cibes Jr. announced he was jumping in. Morrison is expected to receive the party's endorsement at the nominating convention this weekend. But Cibes appears assured of getting the 20 percent of convention delegates needed to force a September primary. Many O'Neill Democrats have been cool to Morrison because of his challenge to the incumbent Democrat. O'Neill himself remains openly resentful, questioning Morrison's ability to win and refusing even to meet with him. Republicans, who have won the governor's office just once in 35 years, had thought 1990 would be their year. The party saw O'Neill as vulnerable on tax and budget issues and believed Morrison would be an easy target too, because of his liberal voting record in Congress. In their own candidate, three-term Rep. John G. Rowland, the GOP saw a brash young congressman who had won in a Democratic district and looked like the right new face. Rowland is poised to accept his party's nomination by acclamation at its July 20-21 convention. What the GOP didn't count on, though, was Weicker's candidacy. After his 1988 Senate defeat, Weicker said he was leaving politics with ``no regrets, no excuses, no blaming, no griping and no comebacks.'' In announcing his gubernatorial campaign, Weicker said he was getting back into politics because ``I miss, very frankly, fighting for Connecticut.'' Weicker, who made a brief bid for the Republican presidential nomination in 1979, was forever battling the party during his years in the Senate. He took on Richard Nixon during Watergate, and Ronald Reagan later in his career. And he was always on the outs with the state's GOP hierarchy. He says he bolted the Republican Party because 20 years of trying to lead by example didn't work. ``If I was going to run for governor, it wasn't going to be a philosophical debate with the Republicans,'' Weicker said. ``I've had that. What I wanted to spend my time on was the state of Connecticut.'' Weicker's candidacy seems to be hurting Rowland the most. The former senator has picked up endorsements from several prominent Republicans, including Mary Boatwright, a member of the Republican National Committee. A recent Weicker fundraiser in Washington featured some of his former Senate colleagues from both sides of the aisle, including former GOP senators Paul Laxalt of Nevada and Edward Brooke of Massachusetts and incumbent Democrat Tom Harkin of Iowa. Morrison and Rowland both say they could spend $4 million or more on the race. Weicker, who doesn't face the traditional need to court delegates and who has no need to boost his name recognition, hopes to get away with half as much. Ferree's most recent poll had Weicker favored by 41 percent of those surveyed, Rowland with 11 percent and Morrison with 9 percent.

DOC.HEAD: East German Officers To Swear Loyalty To Democracy
DOC.TEXT: All officers of the East German army will be required to swear allegiance to democracy, replacing their previous oath of loyalty to Communism, the country's defense minister said in an interview published today. Swearing-in ceremonies will take place throughout East Germany on July 20, Defense Minister Rainer Eppelmann was quoted as saying by Die Welt, a West German newspaper. The swearing-in ceremonies coincide with the 46th anniversary of an attempt on the life of Adolf Hitler by Col. Claus von Stauffenberg and other German army officers. Hitler was slightly injured in the bomb attack, and most of the conspirators were executed. Eppelmann said soldiers in the National People's Army are already swearing loyalty to democracy instead of the ``workers' and farmers' state,'' as East Germany called itself until the Communists were deposed last fall.

DOC.HEAD: Catholic Parents Group Says Homosexuals Should Wear Visible ID
DOC.TEXT: A group of Catholic parents in Queensland state homosexuals should be required by law to wear visible identification and be counseled on ``the depravity of their actions.'' The call for ID cards for homosexuals is part of a 10-point program presented Monday by the Queensland Association of Catholic Parents as ``modern minimum health precautions'' to help stop the spread of AIDS. The group does not have church backing. AIDS activists criticized the ID proposal, saying it highlighted the failure of AIDS education to have a significant impact on the general population. ``Why don't we just go back to Nazism and put a tattoo on our heads?'' said John Bonello, AIDS Council project officer for Townsville. The Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland will hold public hearings on homosexual law reform during the next few months. The Catholic parents' group program was described in a 50-page document submitted to the commission on Monday. Michael O'Dowd, the association's secretary, called on the state government to maintain existing anti-homosexual legislation. He described moves to decriminalize prostitution as ``stupidity in the extreme.'' O'Dowd did not say how many people belong to his organization, but claims it represents ``quite a large group of parents who want to keep traditional moral standards current.'' The association's other recommendations included quarantining AIDS carriers, compulsory AIDS testing of all male flight attendants and known homosexuals, banning homosexuals from teaching positions and jobs involving food handling, and requiring hotels and restaurants to use disposable crockery and cutlery. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome is caused by a virus that damages the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to infections and cancer. There is no known cure. It is spread most often through sexual contact, needles or syringes shared by drug abusers, infected blood or blood products, and from pregnant women to their offspring. The U.S. Surgeon General has reported that casual social contact will not transmit the AIDS virus, nor has the disease been contracted from eating in restaurants or sharing eating utensils.

DOC.HEAD: Summit Host Committee Using Defaulted S&L Property
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Perhaps it's fitting: the headquarters for the economic summit's host committee is a historic mansion now owned by the government as a result of the S&L debacle. Houston is in the heart of the thrift crisis, home to $668 million in real estate dumped on federal agencies. But President Bush, who might be considered chief landlord for all the empty office space and dilapidated storefronts, isn't showing off any of these acquisitions to his economic summit friends. There aren't any summit parties at the skating rink the government is trying to sell. Nor are there any summit-related services scheduled at the athletic club-turned church on the roll of the Resolution Trust Corp., the federal agency charged with selling $141.6 billion worth of assets acquired in takeovers of failed S&Ls. Summit guests aren't making use of the hotels the government owns in Houston, including the Comfort Inns. Dinners aren't scheduled for RTC restaurants, and no black-tie billiards matches at the government-owned pool hall. Even office space near Rice University, site of the summit meetings, remains unused. And it's doubtful the convenience stores now in government hands would be of interest to the Japanese delegation, even though a Japanese company recently agreed to take over Dallas-based Southland Corp., owners of the 7-Eleven chain. Houston has nearly 9 percent of all the S&L properties in the RTC's inventory, agency spokeswoman Theresa McCusic said. So far, 43 S&Ls in the area have failed, and at the end of April, more than 3,100 RTC properties in the city were for sale. ``The Houston regional office is the largest one we have'' in the Southwest, she said. Downtown, several high-rise buildings are available through the RTC, including a 61-year-old bank building which, ironically, has a message of more conservative banking days chiseled in stone over the entrance: ``Frugality is the mother of the virtues.'' Near Rice University, a three-story office building might have been available for meetings of the Western leaders, but the RTC catalog notes ``numerous problems, e.g. parking, HVAC (heating and air-conditioning), asbestos, fire sprinklers, electrical.'' The Kirby Mansion is in far better shape, stately and well-manicured. Unlike many of the other Houston area S&L properties, it has a tenant. The mansion has been the headquarters of the Houston Economic Summit Host Committee, a fundraising and planning group that made summit arrangements. ``I think it is a good thing (for the RTC). It gives this house visibility,'' said Peter Roussel, a spokesman for the host committee. The 36-room mansion, the last mansion in downtown, was built in 1892 by a lumber, oil and banking magnate named John Henry Kirby. The house has entertained four presidents, including Bush. From 1978 until last year, it was the headquarters of an oil company, which fell on hard times. ``It makes a statement about Houston's history and heritage,'' Roussel said. And it makes a statement about present-day Houston as well.

DOC.HEAD: City Cracks Down on Idling Drivers
DOC.TEXT: Special agents, armed with stopwatches instead of guns, are trying to clean up the city. The eight agents hit the streets Monday in a new effort to clear the air by enforcing a 1972 law against car, bus and truck drivers who leave engines idling for more than three minutes. It's part of Mayor David Dinkins' plan to let New Yorkers breathe easier. ``Nothing else that we can do will bring us an improvement in our air quality faster than obtaining general, citywide compliance with the three-minute idling law,'' Dinkins said. Department of Environmental Protection spokeswoman Tina Casey said eight tickets were issued on the first day, including four at the Jacob Javits Convention Center. All eight went to buses, she said. ``Needless to say, we're thrilled at the small number of tickets that we had to issue,'' she said. ``They must have gotten the message.'' Around noon Monday at a parking lot crowded with buses near the convention center, a group of drivers said they weren't happy with the city's enforcement plans. ``It's like an oven in there,'' said Terrence McIntosh, a driver for Short Line of Mahwah, N.J., pointing to his bus. With the temperature near 90, he said his passengers were not going to be happy to get into a hot bus. The drivers also complained that the fines _ which they, not their employer, would have to pay _ were too high. First offenders will get a ticket for $220 and the fines can go up as high as $880 for repeat offenders. ``That's just a little less than what we make,'' said Cruz Quintana, another Short Line driver. His company pays about $360 a week to starting drivers, he said. Transportation Commissioner Lucius J. Riccio called the penalties ``commensurate with the violation.'' ``We mean business,'' Riccio said. Riccio said that if the operator of a ticketed vehicle is not the owner, then the owner also is subject to a fine. ``We're talking about the air that we breathe and the environmental and health impacts of that,'' Riccio said. ``If people want to be selfish and leave their vehicles running, then that means that other people suffer.'' The law does not apply to vehicles that need the engine to operate some equipment, such as a truck mixing concrete. Richard Mendes, deputy DEP commissioner, said more than 200 summonses have been issued annually in the past for idling violations.

DOC.HEAD: No Consensus in Congress for Ending Farm Subsidies
With PM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Some members of Congress say they would go along with cutting subsidies to American farmers if President Bush persuades the Europeans to reciprocate. But others favor even stronger government supports as a defense against cheap imported food. And Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas doubts the issue will be forced upon his colleagues, even as it is a major topic on the agenda of the seven Western leaders at the economic summit in Houston. ``I would guess they aren't going to do much,'' Dole said, citing pressures on the Europeans at home to maintain the current system. But Dole, who would like to see subsidies reduced, said it is important that the issue is at least being raised. ``Give us the same markets, same opportunities, we'll win our share,'' he said of U.S. farmers' ability to compete in the world market. The government spent about $11 billion this year in subsidies that assure a certain income to producers of wheat, corn, soybeans, cotton and rice. Other government programs maintain the prices of products such as honey, wool, mohair, tobacco, and sugar without direct payments, but through market manipulation. Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., said no consensus exists in Congress on changes in the farm policy. ``But I think that most Agriculture Committee members recognize if the European countries and the others agree to reduce their subsidies over 10 years, that would be a position that would draw broad support in the Congress,'' said Panetta, who is chairman of the House Budget Committee and a member of the Agriculture Committee. In fact, farm legislation already approved by the House and Senate agriculture committees freezes subsidies which, considering inflation, has the effect of reducing income supports over the five-year life of the bill. And, a coalition of House members is preparing for a floor fight to eliminate even more taxpayer-supported farm programs. Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., who is leading that coalition, said it would be best if all nations eliminated subsidies that distort world trade. ``It is clear that some of the export subsidies in the United States should be eliminated now,'' he said. ``The Bush administration is taking the right approach, but it is an approach that also needs to be extended to the legislative arena.'' Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., takes an opposite view. He says the United States should use the same approach in agriculture as in arms negotiations _ deal from a position of strength. ``Congress on both sides of the aisle would love to get an international agreement to reduce subsidies,'' said Kerrey. ``First of all, start with a strong overall five-year farm bill.'' He led senators on the Senate Agriculture Committee who wanted to increase farm income supports, and is a strong supporter of the use of the export programs designed by Congress to bring down the price of U.S. farm products in the world market. Kerrey says President Bush's proposals for the farm bill would weaken the U.S. farm economy, sending the wrong signals to the Europeans. ``Unless he (Bush) assumes the Europeans can't read. They're saying the United States is not going to play that tough with us,'' said Kerrey. Dole said the farm bill had a log way to go before it could be viewed as specific signal to the Europeans. ``I don't think it says very much at all. We haven't agreed yet on the contents. There still is going to be a battle on the floor,'' said Dole. ``I think the fact that it's a five-year bill says we are going to continue subsidies.''

DOC.HEAD: Remarks From Leaders on Opening Day of Summit
DOC.TEXT: Here are quotations from officials of the seven nations which opened their annual economic summit on Monday: President Bush, on the goals of the summit: ``A new world of freedom lays before us. Hopeful. Confident. A world where peace endures, where commerce has a conscience and where all that seems possible is possible. So let us begin, in good faith, to set the stage for the new millennium.'' West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, on drawing Moscow into the Western economic system: ``It should be in all our interests if the Soviet Union is more strongly tied into the international division of labor. That also means connecting them to the international economic organizations and financing institutions.'' Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti, on helping the Soviet reform effort: ``There is a need to create structures so the Soviet Union will overcome its problems.'' British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, on the importance of settling trade disputes: ``The touchstone this time will be our attitude to trade.'' French President Francois Mitterrand, on the urgency of helping the Soviets: ``If we don't decide now to help the Soviet Union, there is a risk that there will be no progress, no further reform.'' Canadian Foreign Minister Joe Clark, on Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's letter to Bush before the summit started: ``What the president of the Soviet Union is asking is for the opportunity to have leaders of his economy and government sit down with experts from the West to discuss how in practical, sustainable ways the West can help reform the economy of the Soviet Union.'' Japanese Foreign Ministry director of European affairs Takehiro Togo, on Tokyo's plans to resume lending to China: ``We don't think this is something that requires a consensus of the other members. We will decide this on our own.''

DOC.HEAD: Arsenio's Keyboardist Walks Out over Dice Man
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with new 5th and 6th grafs to add Andrew Dice Clay comments. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `A planned ...
DOC.TEXT: Foul-mouthed comedian Andrew Dice Clay sparked another late-night television boycott, this time on ``The Arsenio Hall Show,'' it was announced Monday. Starr Parodi, the keyboard player in Hall's house band, refused to perform in Tuesday's show featuring the stand-up comic. ``As an employee of `The Arsenio Hall Show,' I cannot show my disapproval of Clay by turning the channel, but I can refuse to play in the band, which is a function I have performed for every guest that has appeared ... to date,'' Parodi said. Clay, who is on the talk-show circuit to promote the Wednesday opening of his feature film ``Ford Fairlane,'' is known for his expletive-laden routines that contain vulgar references to women, homosexuals and minorities. Upon hearing about the boycott, Clay said it was all a mistake and that he believed Parodi would decide to appear. ``It's a goof,'' he told an Associated Press reporter. ``She'll be there. Believe me, she'll be there. That girl is crazy is about me.'' A planned appearance later this week on CNN's ``Larry King Live'' has sparked no protest so far, said network spokeswoman Alison Hill. His appearance as a guest host on Saturday Night Live two months ago prompted a walkout by cast member Nora Dunn and a last-minute cancellation by Irish pop star Sinead O'Connor. Several groups also have vowed to picket the opening of ``Ford Fairlane'' to protest the comedian's routines. Parodi's boycott of the Hall show will consist of the musician refusing to leave her dressing room during Tuesday evening's taping, according to Hall's publicist. The syndicated program is televised at 11:00 p.m. in most U.S. cities. Parodi said she believed Clay was entitled to express himself on television, but ``as a matter of fact, his material offends me.'' Asked why Hall, who is black, would put the allegedly racist comedian on his show, publicist Dana Freedman replied, ``It is Arsenio's opinion that banning a comedian from his show...is not the way to handle the situation. Rather his preference is to deal with the comedian's attitude head on.''

DOC.HEAD: President's Son Says Probe Makes Him a `Political Football'
DOC.TEXT: The president's son, Neil Bush, contends he has been made a ``political football'' in the investigation of his role in the failure of a Colorado savings and Loan. In a series of newspaper interviews, Bush contended he had done nothing wrong in connection with the failure of Silverado Savings & Loan. Bush conceded in an interview published in The Washington Post on Tuesday that he got ``an incredibly sweet deal'' in the form of a $100,000 loan from a Denver investor that he wasn't required to repay. But he said the loan was ``totally unrelated'' to his work as a director of Silverado. Federal regulators have accused Bush of conflict of interest while a Silverado director from 1985 to August 1988. Silverado was seized by regulators in December 1988 and bailing it out is expected to cost $1 billion in tax money. The allegations against him by the Office of Thrift Supervision will be aired before an administrative law judge in Denver on Sept. 25. In an interview published over the weekend in The Denver Post, the younger Bush complained that the administrative charges against him are being pursued in a highly political atmosphere. Republicans and Democrats seek to blame each other for the savings and loan disaster, and the case against the president's son provides ammunition to the Democrats. The younger Bush said Silverado was ``doomed to die'' before he became a director because it carried $1 billion in commercial real estate loans at a time the Colorado market was faltering. Regulators say Bush failed to disclose a series of business deals with developers Ken Good and Bill Walters who defaulted on a combined $130 million in loans from Silverado. Good loaned Bush $100,000 in 1984, but forgave the loan before Bush joined the S&L's board, Bush told The Washington Post. Regulators say Bush proposed to his fellow board members that they grant Good a $900,000 line of credit. Bush told the paper that since he got the loan, the money ``was basically forgotten ... it's been dormant.'' Bush told The Washington Post there was no conflict in his vote to approve Silverado loans to Walters, who had in interest in Bush's oil business. He said he failed to mention his business connection with Walters on required conflict-of-interest forms, but said other Silverado officials knew of his ties. ``I'm sure there was a disclosure...,'' he told The Washington Post. ``That was looked into by legal counsel.''

DOC.HEAD: Energy Tax Fight is Case Study of Battles Spawned by Budget Talks
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Should stand
DOC.TEXT: Coal lobbyist John Harman recently sat down with Treasury tax official Kenneth Gideon and tried to convince him that new energy levies would be a bad idea. The only response Harman got was a poker face. He didn't really expect Gideon to take a position on energy taxes, now that President Bush has conceded that budget negotiators must find new taxes to reduce the deficit. In fact, budget negotiators say the imposition of taxes on a broad range of fuels hasn't yet come up during their talks, which resume today. But for Harman and other interest groups, the lobbying battle is on already. They've been buttonholing administration officials and members of Congress involved in the talks, deluging them with letters, petitions, studies, newspaper articles and other tools of persuasion. The brewing fight over energy taxes is a case study of the dozens of tax and spending issues that budget negotiators must decide. At stake are painful choices over who will pay for $50 billion in savings being sought for next year. ``We want to avoid these taxes, and it would be almost too late already if it comes out of the budget summit,'' said Monica McGuire, tax director for the National Association of Manufacturers. Her group, which has organized a coalition of industries opposed to energy taxes, has conducted a study that claims such taxes could add up to $20 billion a year to the deficit. The National Coal Association is trying to rally opposition to new fuel taxes among coal state lawmakers on Capitol Hill. The Edison Electric Institute, representing the nation's electric utilities, is urging Bush and the budget negotiators to reject new taxes based on fuel emissions. Institute lobbyist Judy Boddie and her allies say higher fuel taxes would hinder U.S. competitiveness, cost jobs and worsen the deficit by slowing the economy. On the other side of the issue, the National Wildlife Federation is urging its 78,000 members to write to Congress in support of carbon fuel taxes. It also is circulating a petition among other environmental groups, which will be given to participants in the budget talks. ``On behalf of our more than 8 million members we urge your support of carbon emission fees as an environmentally responsible way to reduce the federal budget deficit,'' a draft of the letter says. Members of Congress also are getting in on the lobbying act. Sens. Kent Conrad, D-N.D., and Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., who represent states that would be hit hard by energy tax increases, have gotten 35 senators to sign a letter to Bush opposing new energy taxes. ``Look at the politics,'' said Conrad. ``There's a chance to sell it as a pollution fee and dodge the tax bullet. It could come up at the last minute and develop a life of its own, and then become part of a package and be far more difficult to defeat.'' At least two types of broad energy taxes are being proposed. One would base the tax on the amount of carbon _ an air pollutant _ in the fuel. It would tax coal, petroleum and natural gas but leave nuclear, hydroelectric and solar energy untouched because they contain no carbon. Bargainers say the Bush administration and some Republican congressional leaders prefer a tax based on the amount of energy _ measured in British thermal units _ that a fuel contains. The so-called BTU tax would apply to all fuels and is believed to have a better chance of adoption. Budget negotiators say the lobbying is not likely to have a dramatic effect on their work. ``The members of the budget summit have a pretty good feel for where the hot spots are,'' said House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., one of the bargainers. ``I'm not sure the lobbying is going to change those viewpoints.''

DOC.HEAD: Postal Plan Announced for Contracting Out
DOC.TEXT: As many as 12,000 mail sorting jobs at the post office could be shifted to private companies by 1995 under a plan announced by the U.S. Postal Service. The change could save the mail agency $4.3 billion over 10 years, Assistant Postmaster General Peter Jacobson said Monday. He said that hiring private firms to do specific sorting jobs could cut postal costs by $10 to $12 an hour per employee. The announcement, though described as preliminary, comes as the agency faces contract negotiations with its major unions. The Postal Service also has a proposal for a rate increase pending. Moe Biller, president of the American Postal Workers Union, quickly denounced the announcement as a ``disgrace.'' ``They will do nothing with this but create more hostility, more upset more apprehension among the workers,'' said Biller. ``We will fight it on the beaches, on the hill, in negotiations, wherever.'' Jacobson stressed in his announcement that no current postal worker need fear for his or her job, although he said it is likely some will be changed to new duties or transferred to nearby facilities. The focus of the decision is new automated equipment that permits letters that cannot be read by machine to be viewed on television screens, where workers can type in the appropriate ZIP code, allowing the letter to be handled by machinery from then on. Test equipment will be installed by Bell and Howell in Nassau County, N.Y., and by TRW in Louisville, Ky. this fall, with 295 systems planned across the country within three years. With the remote video encoding system, the workers typing in the codes do not have to be in the post office. Thus, Jacobson said, contractors will be asked to bid on supplying workers and facilities and the post office will provide the equipment. The contracts will be based on bids on sorting volumes of mail. Jacobson said the Postal Service projects that in 1992 the average postal worker will cost $29.85 per hour, including salary and benefits. The cost for a workers in a private firm is expected to be $14.52, he said, with the cost of the building lease and telecommunications raising it to about $18 per hour. The plan is for the sorting contractor to hire people to work five or six hours daily, mostly in the evening after mail has been collected and needs to be sorted before delivery, the assistant postmaster general explained. That schedule would also cause problems if postal workers were used, he said, since they normally work eight-hour shifts. While the sorting jobs with a contractor are not necessarily full-time jobs, Jacobson said the expected mail volume will require the equivalent of about 12,000 fulltime people. The Postal Service now employs about 800,000 workers and annual attrition is about 20,000, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment Persists in Some Rural Areas
DOC.TEXT: Unemployment in rural America has eased since the harsh times of the early 1980s, but an Agriculture Department analyst says there are still pockets where jobs are scarce. Moreover, said Leslie A. Whitener of the department's Economic Research Service, the general improvement in the rural job picture apparently has stalled, at least temporarily. After declining for four years, the rural unemployment rate remained unchanged from a year earlier in the first quarter of 1990, averaging 6.6 percent. ``This may mean that non-metro (rural) employment rates are leveling off as rural areas complete their recovery,'' Whitener said. ``Or it may reflect the recent slowdown in the national economy.'' Whitener said current indicators ``do not point to a substantial weakening of the rural labor market,'' although there will probably be a ``more moderate job growth and stable unemployment rates'' for the remainder of 1990. On an annual basis, rural unemployment rose to a peak of 10.1 percent nationally in 1982 and 1983. It dropped to 6.2 percent in 1988 and 5.7 percent in 1989. Whitener said that compares with a metro unemployment rate of 5.2 percent last year. Before the slump of the early 1980s, rural rates were lower than urban rates, he said in the July issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine. ``Non-metro employment conditions are increasingly important for farmers, as greater numbers of farm families turn to off-farm earnings to supplement farm income,'' he said. According to the 1987 census of agriculture, more than half of all farm operators held off-farm jobs that year. ``While rural joblessness has declined overall, many pockets of high unemployment persist,'' Whitener said. ``Unemployment in non-metro counties in 1989 ranged from 1.2 percent in Faulk County, S.D., to 34.5 percent in Starr County, Texas.'' Also, he said, some population groups, particularly minorities and teen-agers, continue to dominate the unemployment picture. In 1989, 15.3 percent of the rural teen-agers, 12 percent of the blacks and 9.3 percent of Hispanics were without jobs. Rural black teen-agers were reported at an unemployment rate of more than 32 percent. About 2,400 of the nation's 3,000-plus counties are classified as rural. Of these, 900 or 38 percent showed the brightest employment picture in 1989. ``These counties were spread throughout the Midwest, New England, the mountain states of Nevada, Idaho and Montana, and the Eastern Seaboard states of Virginia and North Carolina,'' Whitener said. A large proportion of these low-unemployment counties depend greatly on farming, and farm-dependent counties traditionally have had lower jobless rates, he said. Even so, many of these agricultural counties have had sizable population declines and little or no employment growth in recent years. On the other hand, more than 600 counties, or 25 percent of all rural counties, had unemployment rates of more than 8 percent, one and one-half times the national average last year. ``Some of these high-unemployment counties, particularly in Texas, Alaska, parts of the Southeast and the Mississippi Delta are dependent on natural gas and oil production,'' Whitener said. Most of these counties have seen some decline in unemployment since 1986, but their rates are still high. High unemployment rates in other rural counties have been more persistent over time, he said. Mining areas of Michigan, Oregon and parts of Appalachia were hit hard during the early 1980s and have not yet fully recovered. The manufacturing, timber and resort areas of the northern Pacific and Great Lakes states also have experienced persistently high unemployment rates, largely because they depend on seasonal employment, Whitener said. ``Chronically high unemployment rates also typify the Indian reservations of the Northern Plains and the Southwest, as well as areas of the Mississippi Delta and Southeastern states with predominantly poor Hispanic or black populations,'' he said. ``Limited employment opportunities and work forces with low levels of education and training characterize many of these counties.''

Tokyo, where sirloin steak is more than $20 a pound in grocery stores, continues with the highest retail food costs, according to an Agriculture Department survey. The informal survey involved a marketbasket of items checked in May by the department's Foreign Agricultural Service in 18 world capitals. The survey has been conducted periodically for many years to show how U.S. food prices stack up against those in other countries. Cost of the Japanese grocery list of 15 items was $117.33 against 13th-ranked Washington, D.C., at $52.69. Boneless sirloin steak was $20.75 per pound in Tokyo, compared with $4.43 in Washington. The least expensive was $1.07 per pound in Buenos Aires, Argentina. Shoppers found boiler chicken at $3.82 per pound in Stockholm, Sweden, compared with $1.03 in Washington and a low of 70 cents per pound in Buenos Aires. The conversion to U.S. dollars was based on exchange rates at the time of the survey, the agency said. According to the survey, here are the costs of the food marketbasket in May in the various foreign capitals, in U.S. dollars. l. Tokyo, $117.33. 2. Stockholm, $107.23. 3. Bern, $102.24. 4. Seoul, $79.85. 5. Taipei, $78.48. 6. Rome, $69.73. 7. Madrid, $69.47. 8. Paris, $68.66. 9. Singapore, $66.27. 10. Bonn, $58.18. 11. London, $55.03. 12. Ottawa, $54.72. 13. Washington, $52.69. 14. Canberra, $44.42. 15. Buenos Aires, $36.02. 16. Brasilia, $34.07. 17. Pretoria, $33.94. 18. Mexico City, $33.82.

DOC.HEAD: Food Weighs on Summit Minds, and Not from Pangs of Hunger
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 3 grafs new to recast; pickup 3rd graf pvs: ``That desire.
DOC.TEXT: A world away, in Moscow, street vendors are lucky if they can offer puny plums and odd-looking strawberries. Consider the contrast with Houston, where summit diners today are feasting on mounds of luscious raspberries and rows of fresh shrimp. Food has been on everyone's mind at the 16th annual economic summit. For the leaders of the free world, it is a question of how to help President Mikhail Gorbachev put enough food on Soviet tables to calm growing political unrest. That desire is shared by all the summit partners, but they are divided over how to achieve it. West Germany and France favor hard cash. The United States, Japan and Britain are opposed. But Bush, mindful of Gorbachev's fragile hold on power, may well offer the Soviets help in distributing food more evenly throughout the country to alleviate the shortages which make food rationing a way of life for 287 million Soviets. In Moscow, for example, shoppers were told at the end of May that each would be limited to 4.4 pounds of meat; 2.2 pounds of sausages; 1.1 pounds of cottage cheese; 10 eggs and 4.4 pounds of bread. The decree did not specify the duration of the rationing, although such quantities are usually for one month. On Sunday night at the Astrodome complex in Houston, hosts laid on 3{ tons of barbecue meat and 1,250 gallons of barbecue sauce Sunday night at a rodeo and country music display for the leaders and several thousand guests. On Saturday night, there were 4,000 fresh oysters, 1,000 Texas bobwhite quail, 1,500 alligator tails and 60 gallons of red beans and rice spread around four museums for an extravagant gala in which guests shuttled from site to site, entertained by bands, talking parrots and art masterpieces. The event, intended for the 3,000 reporters accredited to the summit, also drew Houston's moneyed elite, who raised $10 million to host the summit. And then there's the 20,000 tons of meat and fish among some $250,000 worth of food at the Brown Convention Center, where meals will be served continuously throughout the three-day summit to reporters and officials _ for free. A pianist from the Houston symphony plays soothing notes to help the diners digest in the 100,000-square-foot hall. Outside, 11 refrigerated semitrailers store the food in the heavy heat. ``A drop of that food could save many, many lives,'' said Ytbarek Cuddus, a representative of the Eritrean Liberation Front, who is organizing a protest outside the summit site at Rice University on Tuesday. Relief organizations estimate some 1.5 million Eritreans are in danger of starving _ the result of prolonged drought and nearly 30 years of fighting to secede from Ethiopia. Demonstrators will underline their concerns that in the rush to help the new democracies of Eastern Europe, Western leaders are ignoring the poorest countries of Africa. Some Houstonians, too, are upset by the summit's bounty. Jon Matthews, host of a popular morning call-in show on KPRC Radio, said callers were irate at the free food for the media, saying ``reporters have expense accounts. They can feed themselves.'' Some suggested the money raised for the summit should have gone to feed the city's needy. The summit caterers heeded the call, in part. The Houston Food Bank, which distributes food to 400 charities in a 25-county area, said it had been promised summit leftovers.

DOC.HEAD: Metzenbaum Seeks Connection Between Bush Aide, S&L Official
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: A Senate subcommittee chairman is asking whether a former aide to George Bush used political influence on behalf of a businessman who acquired 15 insolvent savings and loans with a $1,000 investment. James M. Fail, a Phoenix insurance executive, borrowed $70 million while putting up the $1,000 of his own in December 1988 to acquire the thrift institutions, which now operate as the Dallas-based Bluebonnet Savings Bank. Fail was represented in the deal by Robert J. Thompson, once congressional liaison for President Bush when he was vice president. In a Dec. 5, 1988, letter released Monday by the Senate Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust, monopolies and business rights, Thompson pressed M. Danny Wall, then chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, to make a decision on the deal. ``Time is of the essence and, therefore, we feel compelled to ask for a decision immediately,'' Thompson wrote, addressing the letter to ``Danny'' and signing it ``Bob.'' Seventeen days later, the bank board, which has since been disbanded, voted to award the thrifts to Fail, with an estimated government subsidy of $1.8 billion in 1988 dollars. Subsequently, Fail, through Bluebonnet and his insurance companies, lent Thompson more than $500,000 _ $356,250 in a mortgage for a home in Washington and a $150,000 business loan, according to documents released by the subcommittee. Lance Morgan, a spokesman for Thompson, said payments on both loans were current. ``To what extent did Robert Thompson's political connections and personal friendships influence the outcome of the bidding process?'' asked the subcommittee chairman, Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio. Wall, in a telephone interview, said Thompson's connections played no role in the decision. He said he knew Thompson as a lobbyist, not as a friend, and had not known him when he worked for Bush. In fact, he said he knew a competing bidder, Weston Edwards, better. Metzenbaum, the only subcommittee member present during a four-hour session Monday, said he would push the panel to subpoena Fail, Thompson, Wall and others, within the week. All declined invitations to appear voluntarily. ``They have failed to show up until this point. We intend to get them here. They owe the public an explanation,'' Metzenbaum said. Fail's attorney, Stanley M. Brand, in a statement released after the hearing, challenged the subcommittee's jurisdiction to look into S&L matters. He said it was misleading to say Fail had bought Bluebonnet for only $1,000 because he had pledged his holdings as collateral for the $70 million in loans. ``It is not difficult to conclude that today's hearing was motivated by sheer political opportunism,'' Brand said, labeling Metzenbaum a ``political vigilante.'' Wall complained that Metzenbaum was presenting information ``very selectively'' and said he had declined to testify only because he wasn't given enough time to prepare. He said he was willing to present his case before the panel. In the waning months of the Reagan administration, the bank board under Wall concluded scores of bailout deals _ more than 200 in 1988, over 70 in December alone. Wall said the deals are saving taxpayers money _ outside analysts estimate $1 billion a month, compared with the cost of liquidating the institutions. Liquidation was not a practical option in any case because regulators did not have the cash to do that until Congress enacted the S&L bailout in August 1989, he said. Metzenbaum said he would continue to investigate the other transactions. ``I don't believe this is the only deal that was made that has questions surrounding it,' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Southern Command Chief Admitted to Walter Reed
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Maxwell Thurman, the field commander in charge of the U.S. invasion of Panama, is being treated for suspected leukemia at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, according to the Pentagon. Thurman, 59, will undergo additional tests ``to determine what treatment may be appropriate,'' the Pentagon said Monday in a brief statement. The four-star general is head of the U.S. Southern Command, based in Panama, and is in charge of all U.S. forces in Central and South America. The general took over the command on Sept. 30, 1989, and was dubbed ``Mad Max'' for his feisty and aggressive style. A native of High Point, N.C., and a graduate of North Carolina State University at Raleigh, Thurman has served more than 36 years in the Army. Besides his current position, he has served as the Army's vice chief of staff, its deputy chief of staff for personnel and commander of the training and doctrine unit. Thurman has been widely credited with convincing the Pentagon leadership and Bush administration to use military force in response to Gen. Manuel Noriega's regime in Panama. He played a central role in drafting the plans for the December invasion along with the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin Powell. The general was scheduled to take mandatory retirement August 1989, but Defense Secretary Dick Cheney insisted he take over the Southern Command and help with the administration's struggle to deal with Noriega in the wake of allegations the Panamanian dictator was involved in drug trafficking. At the ceremony in which he took over the Southern Command, Thurman pledged he would confront ``tyranny in all its insidious forms.'' The general made his mark as an aggressive, take-charge commander ``who didn't hesitate to work around the clock,'' said one Army source, who spoke on condition of not being identified. ``He had this reputation for driving his staff crazy because he was a bachelor and the guy never went home.'' Thurman earned high praise during his tenure at the helm of the Army's Recruiting Command at Fort Sheridan, Ill., where he worked to develop the service's well-known ``Be All That You Can Be'' campaign. The Pentagon statement said the initial diagnosis was made as the result of tests conducted on Friday and Monday at the hospital in suburban Washington. ``General Thurman has been admitted to confirm an initial diagnosis of leukemia,'' the statement said. Pentagon sources said the general was expected to remain at the hospital so that doctors could confirm their diagnosis. ``He's wasn't feeling well and had been in and out of the hospital,'' said the Pentagon source. ``The earlier tests suggested leukemia, and the more recent ones have helped confirm that.'' In Thurman's absence, the Southern Command's deputy commander-in-chief, Adm. David Chandler, will be in command, said Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams. Asked whether Thurman will be able to resume his duties in Panama, Williams replied that Cheney ``will discuss that with Gen. Thurman when the secretary returns from his NATO visit later this week.'' Cheney, who was traveling to several NATO nations such as Norway and Greece, was scheduled to return to Washington on Wednesday in order to join budget discussions.

DOC.HEAD: Western Nations to Go Their Own Way on Soviet Aid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Kaifu Says He'll Resume Aid to China, inserts 4th grafs. Will stand.
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the world's seven richest nations failed to find a common approach to shore up the sickly Soviet economy, but moved Monday toward a summit compromise allowing each country to go its own way on financial assistance to Moscow. Trade and environmental disputes, as well as Japan's unpopular campaign to ease sanctions against China, also tested the harmony as the 16th annual economic summit began its first post-Cold War session. At a dinner hosted by President Bush at a Houston mansion, the leaders focused on Soviet aid and China. Their foreign ministers, dining at a restaurant, grappled with the same issues. A U.S. official said the problems ``have not been put to bed,'' but said that some recent liberalization in Beijing will be welcomed. A Japanese foreign ministry official said Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu told the other leaders he will resume $5.2 billion in loans to China that were interrupted last year. French presidential spokesman Hubert Vedrine said ``there are still differences of opinion'' on how to deal with the Soviet aid question in a political communique to be issued Tuesday. A tentative draft, awaiting final approval by the leaders, made no direct reference to the Soviets' plight but prescribed ``economic assistance as appropriate'' to countries moving toward democracy. That leaves the door open for summit countries to act individually. ``Very good discussions,'' said President Bush as the initial talks concluded. On the overriding issue, no one was pretending the leaders had found commond ground _ but Monday's meeting seemed to eliminate any formal objections to any of the allies sending cash to Moscow. West Germany, France and Italy are ready to send direct aid to the Soviets, while the United States, Britain and Japan are pressing for additional economic reform. Canada is in the middle, extending commercial credits but not cold cash. ``It's premature to say they have settled on any one course of action,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said after the leaders' first meeting. ``Our feeling is individual countries certainly are free to follow their own dictates on these matters.'' ``We must not put ourselves in the position ... of propping up regimes that have only half-changed so we make it easier for them to avoid the full rigors of change,'' said Britain's Margaret Thatcher, emphasizing her opposition to Soviet aid. On the other side, France's Francois Mitterrand said, ``If we don't decide now to help the Soviet Union there is a risk that there will be no progress, no further reform'' of the Soviet political system. Mitterrand and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl have pushed for a $15-billion aid package. Diplomatic sources said six of the nations are inclined to maintain trade restrictions against China, with only Japan poised to end the commercial sanctions imposed after last year's anti-democracy crackdown. On economic disputes, Europeans are resisting Bush's staunch demand for phasing out farm subsidies over the next 10 years and, together with Canada, are pushing Washington for agreement on new steps to halt global warming. Putting the best face on environmental differences, Fitzwater said the leaders would pronounce general agreement on issues such as protection against pollution, preservation of forests and other global problems. Kohl disputed Bush, saying that decisive measures _ rather than more study _ are urgently needed to reduce the ``greenhouse effect,'' the gradual warming of the earth attributed to emissions from autos and manufacturing. On trade, Bush argued ``very forcefully'' for phasing out billions of dollars of agricultural subsidies but met resistance from European leaders. The White House fears that global free trade talks will collapse without a resolution of the farm dispute. Cannon salutes and military pageantry greeted the leaders of West Germany, Britain, France, Italy, Canada and Japan as they assembled on the campus of Rice University for three days of talks. In his welcoming remarks as summit host, Bush challenged his partners ``to bring a new stability and prosperity to the world by tapping the power and energy of free wills and free markets.'' The summit debate on Soviet aid was closely monitored in Moscow. Senior Soviet officials rejected Bush's reasons for resisting help for the Soviet Union. The president has expressed concerns over Soviet military spending, its subsidies for Cuba and the lack of reforms in Moscow's government-controlled economy. ``To dictate conditions to such a country as the Soviet Union, a great power, is embarrassing,'' said Gorbachev staff member Georgy Shakhnazarov. ``We aren't taking orders.'' Reporting on the summit discussion of Gorbachev's plea for aid, French spokesman Hubert edrine said, ``There were shades of differences but nobody said no.'' Gorbachev also was seeking a ``sustained economic dialogue'' between Moscow and the summit nations, winning support from Canada's Brian Mulroney. In the absence of unanimity on Soviet aid, the leaders appeared ready to send a team of Western bankers and other experts to Moscow to assess needs in transportation, marketing and other areas, diplomatic sources said. Fitzwater predicted the summit would produce a strong statement of support for reforms in Eastern Europe and for Mikhail S. Gorbachev's ``perestroika'' program of economic reforms and would recognize the need of each country to act on an individual basis in terms of direct financial assistance. Bush told Kohl he understands Bonn's desire to give unilateral support to the Soviet Union, Fitzwater said. West Germany, eager to remove obstacles to unification with East Germany, has pledged $3 billion in credits to Moscow. Bush is offering the Soviets technical assistance for transportation and agriculture and advice on developing free-market mechanisms. Staff chief John Sununu noted that the Soviets currently lose almost half their grain crop through faulty storage. Officials said the leaders would approve an assessment team to recommend applications for western assistance. Sununu said the study might be conducted by a mixture of western financing agencies, including the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. A British official said the foreign ministers, meeting separately, agreed there should be a full analysis of Soviet requirements before a joint decision on aid. At an outdoor welcoming ceremony _ airconditioned and shortened because of the unrelenting Texas heat _ Bush said, ``A new world of freedom lays before us. Hopeful. Confident. A world where peace endures, where commerce has a conscience and where all that seems possible is possible.'' ``So let us begin, in good faith, to set the stage for the new millennium,'' the president said. After the ceremony, the leaders adjourned to a cavernous meeting room for talks around a long oval table. The meeting was a prelude to free-wheeling political discussions over dinner at Bayou Bend, a stately mansion that once was the home of the late Ima Hogg, the oil-rich daughter of the first native-born governor of Texas. On two other issues unanimity was easy. The summit leaders will condemn terrorism and deplore the proliferation of missiles and nuclear, chemical and biological weapons technology. The argument over farm subsidies turned bitter at a May meeting attended by U.S. and European officials. Frans Andriessen, the community's top trade official, said in Houston that continued pressure by the United States would backfire and make it even harder to reach a compromise. Yet, Sununu said, ``It is crucial, it is critical, it should and must be done. The United States believes in that issue so strongly that we will continue to make that point to our allies.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Chamorro Calls Out Army After Bloody Clashes; At Least 3 Reported Killed
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines previous, CORRECTS injured to 100, ADDS gunfire heard, other details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MGA3
DOC.TEXT: President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro called out the army Monday night to quell protests by thousands of Sandinistas, who have blocked streets with barricades and fought her supporters with guns, fists and rocks. Gunfire could be heard in many parts of the Nicaraguan capital, but reporters could get not close because of the shooting. Police sources, who insisted on anonymity, said at least three people were killed and more than 100 injured in the unrest, which began Sunday night. Mrs. Chamorro addressed the nation on state radio and television as thousands of Sandinistas backing a week-long wave of strikes returned to the streets and, defying government orders, erected more barricades. There was some question, however, of whether the Sandinista-dominated army would support Mrs. Chamorro. In the speech, the president urged ``democratic Nicaraguans not to let themselves be provoked, and not to answer violence with violence, which has already claimed victims.'' The speech was delayed for four hours as police cleared pro-Sandinista students and workers who had seized a government broadcasting center. Mrs. Chamorro, who took office in April after handing the Sandinistas a stunning electoral defeat, said her government was committed to national reconciliation that ``ought to occur in a climate of peace and understanding, not of fear and intimidation.'' Nicaragua's economy has been battered by nearly 10 years of war between the Sandinistas and the now disbanded, U.S.-backed Contra rebels and by an economic embargo by the Reagan administration. Mrs. Chamorro accused the leftist Sandinistas of directing the nationwide strike and inciting unrest. Despite their defeat in February elections at the hands of her U.S.-backed coalition, the Sandinistas remain the country's largest political force. The strikes, which have plunged Nicaragua into chaos, were called in part to protest what unions say are massive firings by the Chamorro government. Workers also want a greater voice in setting economic policy. Daniel Ortega, who Mrs. Chamorro unseated as president, urged her government to negotiate. ``This conflict cannot be solved by force. Any attempt in that direction is an invitation to chaos,'' he said in a radio interview. The road to the international airport was blocked Monday night by barricades made of paving stones. Police using backhoes had cleared debris earlier, but the strikers blocked the road again. The demonstrators burned rubber tires and trash alongside the barricades Monday night, sending smoke billowing over the city. It was reminiscent of the 1979 revolution, when Sandinistas built roadblocks in their fight to overthrow dictator Gen. Anastasio Somoza. Electricity and water service to most of this city of about 1 million were cut off. An air traffic controllers' strike closed the airport. Mail service and operator-assisted phone calls have been suspended since last week. Strike leaders claim more than 80,000 public and private sector workers have joined the walkout, which began last week with sporadic strikes. The strikes are directed against government offices, public transportation, telephone and mail services, banks, and state-run agriculture, textile and construction businesses. Despite the reports on casualties from police sources, Dr. Gustavo Fletes, chief of the emergency ward at Lenin Fonseca Hospital, said in a telephone interview he had knowledge of only one person killed and 20 injured. Manolo Morales Hospital, another center for emergency cases, said it had no dead but only 10 injured, some of them seriously. Other private and public hospitals checked said they had no victims from street fighting. Carlos Torres, an announcer at Radio Corporacion, said four guards were wounded when a group of men armed with AK-47 automatic rifles tried to shoot their way into the privately owned broadcasting station. Torres said Radio Corporacion employees had received anonymous telephone threats saying the station would be burned down. He said Radio Corporacion went off the air shortly after the attack Monday night ``for reasons that I do not know.'' Mrs. Chamorro took office amid high hopes she could resolve the nation's economic crisis and its bitter political divisions. At least 30,000 people died in that conflict. The government suspended talks with the strikers over the weekend, saying negotiations must deal only with labor issues, not political topics. It declared the strike illegal, claiming it was politically motivated. The declaration allows the government to fire striking workers. Thousands of Nicaraguans with machetes and clubs swarmed into Managua's streets Sunday night and Monday morning to light bonfires and build barricades. The barricades kept many workers from reporting to their jobs. In the low-income eastern neighborhoods, protesters passed paving stones from hand to hand to build roadblocks and burned huge bonfires of old tires. It was in those neighborhoods that some of the most intense fighting took place during the 1979 revolution and where Sandinista support is still strong.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Billy Graham plans to preach at a crusade this weekend in his first public appearance since undergoing rib surgery in April. Doctors wanted the 71-year-old evangelist to rest longer, but Graham told his staff that ``God wants me to come to Albany,'' said spokesman A. Larry Ross.
