Graham is scheduled to speak at the Knickerbocker Arena on Friday, Saturday and Sunday, the closing nights of the eight-day Christian crusade. The Rev. Ralph Bell, who has worked with Graham for 25 years, filled in for him when the crusade opened Sunday.

Sam Kinison's bodyguard has been ordered to stand trial on charges of raping the comedian's girlfriend. Municipal Judge David Horwitz on Monday ordered Unway Carter, 22, to be arraigned Friday on rape and sexual assault charges. Carter was arrested outside Kinison's Hollywood Hills home June 21. Authorities said Kinison met the 6-foot-4, 300-pound Carter the night before the attack and hired him as a bodyguard. Kinison's girlfriend testified at a preliminary hearing Monday that Carter raped her in Kinison's home while the comedian was asleep in another part of the house. She said she grabbed a gun after the attack and chased Carter, firing several shots at him but missing. The woman, in her mid-20s, said she then fled to a neighbor's house and called police. Kinison, 36, is known for his screaming, obscenity-filled act that has brought protests from women and gay groups. He commented in passing about the case Monday during a news conference for a concert tour by singer Billy Idol. ``My suggestion to every man in America, and to every woman in America, is to keep a gun in your house,'' Kinison said. ``And especially, women, don't be afraid to use it. It will keep you alive, no matter what the law says.''

Wayne Gretzky's wife, actress Janet Jones, has given birth to their second child, an 8-pound, 6-ounce boy who was named Ty Robert. The couple also have a 2{-year-old daughter, Paulina Mary Jean. Mother and child were doing well after Monday's birth at Cedars Sinai Hospital, said hospital spokesman Ron Wise. Gretzky, 29, the National Hockey League's all-time leading scorer, played 10 seasons with the Edmonton Oilers before being traded to the Los Angeles Kings two years ago.

Foul-mouthed comedian Andrew Dice Clay is under attack from more of his peers. Clay generates ``brown shirt humor'' for an audience of teen-agers who have grown up believing that contempt for civil rights, women and gay people is condoned by the government, says fellow comedian Richard Belzer. Belzer characterized Clay as ``just a demigod who panders to the worst instincts of humanity'' during a taped interview with talk-show host Geraldo Rivera. The interview is to be broadcast Wednesday. Clay's routine is filled with sexually explicit language and disparages homosexuals and women. His performance on ``Saturday Night Live'' prompted boycotts of the program by cast member Nora Dunn and singer Sinead O'Connor. On Monday, Starr Parodi, the keyboard player in talk show host Arsenio Hall's band, announced she would refuse to perform on tonight's show featuring the stand-up comic. ``As an employee of `The Arsenio Hall Show,' I cannot show my disapproval of Clay by turning the channel, but I can refuse to play in the band,'' she said. On hearing about the boycott, Clay said: ``It's a goof. She'll be there. Believe me, she'll be there. That girl is crazy is about me.''

Tammy Wynette has been hospitalized with bronchitis but is expected to be allowed home in less than a week, a spokesman says. The singer went to the emergency room of Breech Medical Center in Lebanon, Mo., on night and was transferred to a hospital in Nashville, said Fletcher Foster, a spokesman for Epic Records in Nashville. The family asked that the hospital not be identified. Ms. Wynette, 48, canceled a performance Saturday in Branson, Mo., because of the illness.

DOC.HEAD: Greenpeace Marks Fifth Anniversary of Ship Sinking
DOC.TEXT: The environmental group Greenpeace marked the fifth anniversary of France's sabotage sinking of its protest ship, Rainbow Warrior, by presenting Gruyere cheese to the French Embassy today. To the beat of a drum, the 18 protesters also delivered to the embassy a wreath, a mock grave and a headstone marked ``F. Pereira, murdered July 1985.'' French secret agents blasted two holes in the hull of the Rainbow Warrior, a 30-year-old former North Sea cod trawler, as it was moored in Auckland Harbor just before midnight on July 10, 1985. Dutch photographer Fernando Pereira, 33, drowned as he tried to save his camera gear. Greenpeace nuclear test-ban spokeswoman Stephanie Mills said the Gruyere cheese was symbolic of Mururoa Atoll, the site of French nuclear testing in the Pacific. She said the atoll is full of holes and acts as a leaky radioactive waste dump. France has conducted 60 atmospheric nuclear tests over Mururoa and more than 120 underground tests since 1975. Four have been held in the last month; another two are expected soon. Six days after the Rainbow Warrior sinking, police arrested two of the bombers _ Maj. Alain Mafart and Capt. Dominique Prieur of the French secret service, which wanted to stop Greenpeace's anti-nuclear protests. Two months later, then-French Prime Minister Laurent Fabius confirmed that secret service agents were responsible. Defense Minister Charles Hernu resigned, and the secret service chief, Adm. Pierre Lacoste, was sacked. Mafart and Prieur pleaded guilty to manslaughter charges and were sentenced to 10 years in jail. Chief Justice Sir Ronald Davison called the destruction of the Rainbow Warrior ``a deliberate planned action of a terrorist nature.'' U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar agreed in June 1986 to mediate the international dispute over the incident. He ruled that France should apologize and pay New Zealand $7 million as compensation. He also said Mafart and Preiur should be transferred to Hao Atoll, a French military facility on an isolated island outside Europe, for three years. On July 23, 1986, they were handed over to the French, who moved them to Hao. In December 1987, Mafart returned to Paris without New Zealand's consent. The French claimed he needed medical attention for stomach pains. Then-New Zealand Prime Minister David Lange called the move an ``outrage.'' In early May 1988, just before the French presidential election, Prieur was whisked back to France, again without New Zealand's consent, amid reports she was pregnant. New Zealand filed a formal complaint to France over the agents' repatriation and asked, unsuccessfully, that they be returned to Hao. Two months ago, a three-person international tribunal ruled that France had breached terms of the 1986 settlement. France agreed to a suggestion that it set up a $2 million French-New Zealand friendship fund.

DOC.HEAD: `Die Hard 2' Packs Hard Punch at Box Office
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: In a battle of box-office heavyweights, the action sequel ``Die Hard 2: Die Harder'' starring Bruce Willis raced ahead of ``Days of Thunder'' to take the No. 1 position away from the Tom Cruise star vehicle. The performance of ``Die Hard 2,'' which reportedly cost more than $62 million to make, is impressive because the film was competing against other highly promoted films such as ``Dick Tracy,'' ``Total Recall,'' ``Another 48 HRS.'' and ``RoboCop 2.'' ``We're going to tell people that the summer just started,'' said Tom Sherak, president of domestic distribution and marketing for ``Die Harder'' maker 20th Century Fox. The sequel to ``Die Hard'' opened to robust business, grossing $21.7 million in its debut weekend despite fierce competition. Figures released Monday by Entertainment Data Inc. showed ``Die Hard 2'' collected $6 million more than ``Days of Thunder'' did in its premiere engagement two weekends ago. In second place, down a modest 31 percent, was ``Days of Thunder'' with returns of $10.7 million. It was followed by ``Dick Tracy,'' which collected $6.6 million for a 34 percent slowdown. ``Jetsons: The Movie,'' an animated family film based on the television cartoon, opened in fourth place with ticket sales of $5 million. Fifth was Arnold Scwarzenegger's ``Total Recall,'' with receipts of $4.2 million. ``Another 48 HRS.'' placed sixth with a gate of $4.1 million, and ``RoboCop 2'' followed in seventh with returns of $3.6 million, down sharply from the previous weekend of $6.4 million. In eighth was ``Ghost Dad,'' grossing $3.2 million, and ``Gremlins 2: The New Batch'' was ninth with $2.6 million. Rounding out the Top 10 was ``Pretty Woman,'' making $2.5 million. ``Pretty Woman'' has now made more than $153.6 million and is the year's biggest hit so far. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Sunday as tallied by Entertainment Data, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Die Hard 2: Die Harder,'' Fox, $21.7 million, 2,509 screens, $8,666 per screen, $35.6 million, one week. 2. ``Days of Thunder,'' Paramount, $10.7 million, 2,307 screens, $4,641 per screen, $40.5 million, two weeks. 3. ``Dick Tracy,'' Disney, $6.6 million, 2,209 screens, $3,005 per screen, $81.7 million, four weeks. 4. ``Jetsons: The Movie,'' Universal, $5 million, 1,562 screens, $3,220 per screen, $5 million, one week. 5. ``Total Recall,'' Tri-Star, $4.2 million, 1,787 screens, $2,359 per screen, $99.2 million, six weeks. 6. ``Another 48 HRS.,'' Paramount, $4.1 million, 1,850 screens, $2,194 per screen, $66.1 million, five weeks. 7. ``RoboCop 2,'' Orion, $3.6 million, 1,806 screens, $2,015 per screen, $32.6 million, three weeks. 8. ``Ghost Dad,'' Universal, $3.2 million, 1,221 screens, $2,610 per screen, $10.9 million, two weeks. 9. ``Gremlins 2,'' Warner Bros., $2.6 million, 1,810 screens, $1,459 per screen, $34.5 million, four weeks. 10. ``Pretty Woman,'' Disney, $2.5 million, 1,157 screens, $2,177 per screen, $153.6 million, 16 weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,152.43, down 385.85 points, or 1.19 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Parents Group in Middle of Debate Over Warning Labels
DOC.TEXT: A parents group is battling charges of censorship as its campaign for voluntary warning stickers on records promoting bigotry, rape and murder wins allies in legislatures and within the music industry. The Parents Music Resource Center founded by Elizabeth ``Tipper'' Gore says it is promoting truth-in-packaging to help parents and their children deal with an entertainment culture that is increasingly violent and sexually explicit. ``Part of our problem is our culture tends to look at children as miniature adults,'' said Jennifer Norwood, executive director of the parents group. ``We expect them to handle things they're not ready to handle yet at their age. Groups like 2 Live Crew are dealing with adult issues.'' But some opponents say the labels are censorship because artists and record companies are pressured to use them. The labels are ``an invitation to be prosecuted and persecuted. It's a guilty plea,'' said Dave Marsh, editor and publisher of Rock & Roll Confidential, a monthly magazine. The Arlington-based parents group has made big strides since its founding in 1985 by Gore, the wife of Sen. Albert Gore, D-Tenn. Four years ago, the Recording Industry Association of America, under pressure from the group, added warning stickers to certain albums. The association's members produce about 90 percent of the recordings made and sold in the United States. That effort led to a wide variety of warnings, some smaller than a postage stamp, before the industry settled earlier this year on a standardized sticker that reads, ``Explicit Lyrics _ Parental Advisory.'' The records with the black and white labels are due out this month. Ms. Norwood said parents in her group realize from their own experience as teen-agers that there always will be a musical generation gap. ``The purpose of rock 'n' roll has always been, to a degree, to shock parents,'' she said. But the ground rules have changed, she said. Some of today's music promotes bigotry, rape and murder, she and others charge. ``Five years ago I had transcribed lyrics and a lot of them were pretty raunchy and pretty extreme,'' said Maryland legislator Judith Toth. ``But what I'm seeing now is really something else. A lot of it is racist. A lot of it is very clearly against women. It's not just obscene. It's downright filthy.'' For example, a song by Rigor Mortis graphically describes cutting off a woman's legs, arms and head after sex. A song by N.W.A. uses a derogatory word for blacks and describes gunning them down. Opponents of labels say they inhibit artistic creativity. The American Civil Liberties Union opposes any industrywide labeling, including the ratings on movies, said Barry Lynn, ACLU legislative counsel in Washington. ``Even if they were really voluntary, if there had been no pressure to do this from anyone, there are still likely to be record stores that will not carry stickered material because of fear of protest from other pressure groups,'' Lynn said. A federal judge in Florida has declared 2 Live Crew's album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' obscene. Three members of the rap group were arrested June 10 in Hollywood, Fla., on charges of giving an obscene performance. Record stores in several states, including Virginia, have pulled the record and others like it from the shelves or made them off-limits to children. The Louisiana Legislature passed a bill Saturday that would ban the sale of labeled records to minors. Greg Werkman, general manager of the San Francisco-based independent label Alternative Tentacles, said his label has lost sales because it does not use warning stickers. He said its sales dropped about 20 percent since the stickers came out because stores are not selling the records or are putting them in areas off-limits to people under 18. ``PMRC will tell you it's voluntary,'' Werkman said. ``What they're doing is putting pressure on us, trying to turn us into bad guys.'' There is a degree of pressure, advocates for warning labels concede. ``But the pressure is being brought to bear by the hundreds of thousands of people who say they want this,'' Ms. Norwood said. Several polls have shown that about 75 percent of adults want some kind of information on records and tapes describing the contents, she said. Ava Marshall, shopping at a Richmond record store, said she thought the labels were a good idea. ``It may help with children not purchasing things with explicit sex in it,'' said Ms. Marshall, 35.

DOC.HEAD: No Indication of Roemer's Signature or Veto to Bill
DOC.BYLINE: With PM-Abortion Challenge, Bjt ^By KEVIN McGILL
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Buddy Roemer is not saying whether he will sign a bill banning most abortions, even though it was apparently drafted to his orders. Louisiana lawmakers tacked rape and incest exceptions onto the bill they passed late Sunday in an attempt to appease Roemer, who had vetoed an earlier version of the bill which did not include such exemptions. But Roemer left open the possibility of another veto. He said he was unhappy the way the bill was amended onto a gutted anti-flag burning measure only 26 hours before the legislative session's expiration at midnight Monday. ``It's unfortunate that legislation this important would be done at the last minute,'' Roemer said Monday. ``And I just want to remind everybody that an option was given by me long ago to work this thing out to the satisfaction of the vast majority in this state and its unfortunate that some, for a variety of reasons, waited until the last minute to give us a bill.'' In particular, Roemer said he objected to a requirement that rape be reported to authorities within seven days. ``The seven-day provision on rape is a problem,'' he said, although he called the measure ``a step in the right direction.'' Roemer, who is up for re-election next year, refused to say when he would act on the bill. He did not receive a copy of the bill until Monday afternoon. The new measure was drafted only when it became clear late Sunday that supporters of the previous bill could not muster a two-thirds vote in the Senate for a veto override. Like the vetoed measure, the new one would send doctors who perform abortions to jail for up to 10 years with maximum fines of $100,000. Roemer said he was troubled by the way the bill was amended to Rep. James David Cain's legislation that would have eliminated jail terms and lowered the fines under simple battery laws for people convicted of beating a flag burner. Louisiana's constitution requires that amendments to a bill be germane to the original subject matter. The language the Senate added to Cain's bill after scuttling the flag-burner provisions may fail that test, Roemer said. Roemer has 20 days to veto the bill. If he issues another veto, lawmakers would have to use a mail ballot to call themselves back into a ``veto session'' to attempt an override. No Louisiana legislature has overridden a governor's veto this century. If Roemer does not veto the bill or if a veto is overridden, the bill would become law Sept. 7.

DOC.HEAD: EPA outlines New Waste Cleanup Procedures
DOC.TEXT: The Environmental Protection Agency is issuing new hazardous waste cleanup regulations that it says could cost industry as much as $42 billion to comply with. EPA administrator William K. Reilly on Monday called the plan ``a pragmatic approach for correcting existing problems'' and said it will ensure ``to the extent practical'' prevention of releases that might threaten human health and the environment. The proposed standards and procedures, drafted to carry out requirements of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, will be published later this month in the Federal Register. EPA said the new regulations would affect 3,000 to 4,000 facilities, including several hundred owned by the federal government. The agency estimated it could cost privately owned facilities between $7 billion and $42 billion to meet the requirements. The price tag for federal facilities would total $3 billion to $18 billion, EPA said in a statement. The wide range of the cost estimates is due to markedly varied conditions from site to site involving uncertain levels of ground water monitoring and cleanup, the agency said. Industries affected would include petroleum refiners, wood preservers, metal finishers and auto manufacturers.
DOC.HEAD: Some Census Workers Lose Unemployment Benefits
DOC.TEXT: Many temporary Census workers may be ineligible for unemployment compensation when their jobs end because of a change in the law. The actual number of people affected is hard to estimate because rules for unemployment compensation eligibility vary from state to state. Neither congressional or census spokesmen would estimate the number affected. In the past, temporary census jobs have counted toward eligibility for unemployment compensation just as any other job. However, this year an appropriations bill signed by President Bush on May 25 set an April 20 cutoff on census workers getting credit toward unemployment. Temporary census work done after that date doesn't count when they are eventually laid off and apply for unemployment benefits. How that cutoff affects individual workers depends on the unemployment eligibility rules in their states. Some states, for example, require 26 weeks of work before someone becomes eligible. People who haven't accumulated that before April 20 would not be able to collect benefits.
DOC.HEAD: U.S. Announces Aid to Nicaraguan Orphans
DOC.TEXT: Orphanages in Nicaragua will receive kits for eye examinations for children and supplies to help grow vegetables as part of a $1.4 million grant from the Agency for International Development. The grant was made to Partners of the Americas, a private voluntary association that works through state chapters to provide humanitarian and developmental assistance to Latin America. The group's Wisconsin affiliate will carry out the Nicaraguan program. AID said in Monday's announcement that the grant will provide medical, psychological and nutritional care to orphans, whose country has been battered by almost a decade of war between the former Sandinista regime and the disbanded U.S.-backed Contra rebels. It will also strengthen hospitals, clinics and other institutions, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Party Chiefs Who Would Be on Politburo
With PM-Soviet-Party
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party leaders of the Soviet Union's 15 republics are expected to become members of the Politburo under new rules adopted at the party's 28th congress. They include Givi Gumbaridze of Georgia, whose republic is pushing for independence from the Soviet Union, and Pyotr Luchinsky of Moldavia and Islam Karimov of Uzbekistan, whose republics have declared themselves sovereign with the right to overturn national laws. The Kazakhstan party chief, Nursultan Nazarbaev, has spoken in favor of some limited sovereignty. Ayaz N. Mutalibov of Azerbaijan leads a republic that has been under martial law for six months, since ethnic rioting that turned into what Soviet Defense Minister Dmitri Yazov said was a revolt against Soviet power. Ivan Polozkov of Russia and Efrem Sokolov of Byelorussia are conservatives who would counterbalance reformers. The Communist Parties of Lithuania and Latvia have split, and their most progressive members chose to form separate independent parties. The conservative branches loyal to Moscow have representatives at the congress, indicating it is their first secretaries who are likely to sit on the Politburo. They are Alfreds Rubiks of Latvia and Nicolas Burakevicius of Lithuania. The Estonian Communist Party plans to split next fall. The independent faction is led by chairman Vaino Vyalyas and first secretary Enn Arno Sillari, while the loyalist faction is led by Alexander Gusev, according to the Estonian News Agency. Both Estonian factions are represented at the congress. The other republic party chiefs are Vladimir Movsisyan of Armenia, Stanislav Gurenko of Ukraine, Sappar Niyazov of Turkmenia, Kakhar Makhkamov of Tadjikistan and Absomat Masaliyev of Kirgizia.

DOC.HEAD: President's Son Says Investigation Makes Him a `Political Football'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's son Neil says he is fed up with sitting on the sideline while being publicly attacked for his savings and loan dealings and is coming out of his ``cage'' to defend himself. In an eight-page statement issued over the weekend and in a series of interviews, Bush contends he has done nothing wrong in connection with the failure of Silverado Savings & Loan and maintains he has become a ``political football'' _ a victim of political ``opportunism'' and ``press sensationalism.'' In an interview published in today's editions of The Washington Post, Bush said it would have ``been much easier'' to sign a civil decree sought by S&L regulators and ``move on in terms of just the quality of my life.'' In the consent decree, sought several months ago, Bush would have agreed to abstain from further banking activities _ without acknowledging any wrongdoing. The 35-year-old Bush said his decision to seek full exoneration rather than sign the decree has resulted in negative publicity that has ``dominated my life for six months'' and also may help Democrats gain political advantage against his father the president. Still, he said, he decided to fight ``because I know I haven't done anything wrong.'' He said he is looking forward to a public hearing on his case in September before an administrative law judge in Denver that he says will offer an unbiased, quasi-legal forum for his defense. ``I've been kind of like a little caged-in animal in an unsanitary zoo,'' Bush told the Post in an interview in his Denver office. ``Now my cage is open and I'm telling people ... what my side of the story is. And I feel good about it.'' Bush conceded in the Post interview that he got ``an incredibly sweet deal'' in the form of a $100,000 loan from a Denver investor that he wasn't required to repay if the oil business the loan was intended to benefit did not turn a profit. But he said the loan was ``totally unrelated'' to his work as a director of Silverado, even though the investor who made the investment loan subsequently was granted a line of credit from Silverado. Bush noted that the investor, Kenneth Good, made similar loans to other Denver area businessmen under similar circumstances, including one for $350,000. ``But, of course, that won't be of any kind of interest because his name doesn't relate to somebody famous,'' Bush said of the $350,000 loan. In an interview published over the weekend in The Denver Post, Bush said Silverado was ``doomed to die'' before he became a director because it carried $1 billion in commercial real estate loans at a time the Colorado market was faltering. Regulators say Bush failed to disclose a series of business deals with developers Good and Bill Walters who defaulted on a combined $130 million in loans from Silverado. Bush said the same thrift regulators from the Federal Home Loan Bank of Topeka, Kan., who approved the loans that contributed to Silverado's failure, are now trying to blame him for the thrift's collapse. ``It's self-serving. The regulators are politically motivated,'' he said. In his eight-page statement, Bush said he was seeking ``an unbiased and unpolitically motivated forum.'' ``I think the administrative law judge will provide that forum,'' he said in the Post interview. ``The system will work.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollars Falls, Stock Prices Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell to a six-week low against the Japanese yen in Tokyo today, and share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange tumbled amid uncertainty over currency and interest rates. The dollar closed at 149.60 yen, down 1.10 yen from Monday's finish of 150.70 yen. It was the lowest closing since 149.45 yen on May 28. The dollar opened today at 150.75 yen, down from 151.15 yen late Monday in New York, and ranged between 149.58 yen and 150.80 yen. The benchmark Nikkei Stock Average for 225 selected issues shed 385.85 points, or 1.19 percent, closing at 32,152.43. The index had gained 93.16 the previous day. The dollar's slide came after a fairly stable morning session. ``The slump in the afternoon session was triggered by news reports that the seven industrialized nations meeting in Houston might call for a stronger yen'' in their final communique, said Minori Takeuchi of Chemical Bank in Japan. Ms. Takeuchi said the Japanese news reports gave the market the excuse it was waiting for to dump the dollar. Dealers also cited talk of higher Japanese interest rates in the near future. This would tend to make the yen more attractive to investors. On the stock market, traders said share prices drifted lower steadily throughout the day's thin dealings. ``Investors want a better view of the yen's direction and interest rates,`` said Yoshiro Inoue of Nomura Securities. Volume on the first section was estimated at 350 million shares, down from 401.7 million shares the previous day. Declining issues outnumbered gainers 727 to 220, while 171 issues remained unchanged. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 86.74 points as of 5 p.m. (4 a.m. EDT) from Monday's close of 87.05. The yield stood at 7.250 percent, up from the previous day's 7.180 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Poll: Americans and Japanese See Each Other as Greatest Economic Power
DOC.TEXT: Americans and Japanese point to each other when asked which country will be the No. 1 economic power in the next century. The finding is among the results of a pair of public opinion polls conducted in the United States by The New York Times and CBS News and in Japan by the Tokyo Broadcasting System. The surveys, which the Times reported today, show that 50 percent of Americans say Japan will be the economic power of the 21st century, while among Japanese, 42 percent pick the United States. Thirty-two percent of Americans pick their own country, as do 39 percent if the Japanese. Big majorities in both countries have friendly attitudes toward the other. The 75 percent of Americans who say their overall feelings toward Japan are generally friendly represents an increase over the 67 percent registered in January. In Japan, 66 percent said their feelings toward the United States were generally friendly, also an increase over the 57 percent measured a year ago. Despite friendly feelings, 64 percent of Americans, up from 45 percent in 1987, say that investment by the Japanese in the United States poses a threat to U.S. economic independence. The poll in the United States was conducted among 1,084 Americans reached by phone from June 5 to June 8. In Japan, 1,468 people were interviewed in person from May 31 to June 7. Each survey had a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Earthquake Reported in Southern Sudan
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake struck a sparsely populated region in southern Sudan, earthquake monitors in neighboring Egypt said today. There were no immediate reports of damage or injuries. The quake, which measured about 6.6 on the Richter scale, jolted a jungle-covered area about 50 miles north of Juba in southern Sudan on Monday night. On May 20, the same area was hit by a quake measuring 7.5 on the Richter scale, followed by a series of aftershocks. Ezz-el-Din Ibrahim, director of the earthquake department at Egypt's National Research Institute of Astronomy and Geophysics, said the quake measured 6.6 on the Richter scale. The Hong Kong Observatory said today it had recorded the quake at 6.5 on the Richter scale. The scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. An increase of one number means that the ground motion is 10 times greater. Juba is 750 miles south of the Sudanese capital, Khartoum. The May earthquake left 31 people dead and 300,000 without shelter, according to the relief agency of the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army, which has been fighting the government since 1983. The rebels control most of the countryside in the three southern Sudanese regions. Most of the south's six million inhabitants have been displaced by fighting and famine.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``We all want change in the Soviet Union. We all want moves toward democracy. We all want more openness, more freedoms, more open markets, less military spending, a changed attitude between the Warsaw Pact and NATO allies.'' _ White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, as leaders of the big seven economies debated financial assistance to the Soviet Union.

``It's a special breed of man who wants to climb to the top of the heap in the most dangerous profession there is.'' _ Lloyd Swenson, a space history expert at the University of Houston, commenting on NASA's grounding of two astronauts for risky jet flying.
``You can never go back to yesterday by any path, and no dictatorship ... solves anything.'' _ Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, defending his reform program before the Communist Party.

DOC.HEAD: Black Community Must Improve Plight of Black Men, Panel Says
DOC.TEXT: Grim statistics point to a crisis for the nation's black men and the black community must do a better job nurturing and educating its boy children, a panel concluded at the NAACP convention. Almost one in four black men between the ages of 20 and 29 are in jail, on parole or on probation, according to a recent study by the non-profit Sentencing Project. The same study found that fewer young black attend college than are in the criminal justice system. Black men in inner city neighborhoods are less likely to reach 65 than men in Bangladesh, one of the world's poorest nations. Violence is the leading cause of death for blacks ages 15 to 25. ``If we cannot turn these numbers around, they threaten the very existence of this race,'' said Beverly Cole, director of education and health for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. The panel highlighted the first day of activities by the 3,000 delegates to the convention, which ends Thursday. In an opening ceremony, actress Esther Rolle became the first woman to be presented with the NAACP's annual Civil Rights Leadership Award. Among featured speakers will be Gov. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, talk show host Oprah Winfrey and the Rev. Jesse Jackson. Most panel members speaking Monday agreed education provided a key to salvation for black society. ``We need, as black parents, to get more involved in the education of our children,'' said John W. Diggs, an official with the National Institutes of Health. ``We've been turning over the education of our children to a white power structure.'' In the face of declining numbers of young black men in higher education, blacks must continue to fight a perception that blacks, particularly black males, are academic underachievers, the panel concluded. ``If being smart is being white, then what does being black mean?'' asked Jawanza Kunjufu, a Chicago school curriculum expert. ``If speaking right is acting white, what is being black?'' He urged black men who have been successful in business, education and other fields to be role models. In addition, more black men must enter the teaching profession, Kunjufu said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Pound Surges, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar fell in early European trading today as the British pound surged ahead. Gold prices were also lower. Foreign exchange dealers said sterling's advance appears to be driving the market and the dollar's direction hinges entirely on what the pound does. ``The dollar's weakness is being caused by sterling's strength,'' said Manfred Totzauer, senior trader at Citibank in Frankfurt. ``As long as sterling's rise continues to hold on, I can imagine the dollar staying weak.'' But Totzauer said he doesn't expect the dollar will plunge quickly. ``I don't see a dollar collapse,'' he said. Sterling continues to be lifted by speculation that the pound will join the exchange rate mechanism of the European Monetary System within a few months. In London, the pound was quoted at $1.8223, up more than 1.5 cents from late Monday's $1.8055. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 1.10 yen to a six-week closing low of 149.60 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 149.03 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: _ 1.6410 West German marks, down from 1.6495 _ 1.3846 Swiss francs, down from 1.3950 _ 5.5060 French francs, down from 5.5353 _ 1.8500 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8573 _ 1,202.50 Italian lire, down from 1,208.50 _ 1.1561 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1590 Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $357.55 a troy ounce this morning, down from $358.15 bid late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $356.00, down from $357.90 late Monday. Gold in Hong Kong fell $1.71 to close at a bid of $358.91. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $4.81 a troy ounce, from Monday's $4.86.

DOC.HEAD: Fires, Booby Traps Prompt Alerts Along Appalachian Trail
DOC.TEXT: Hikers are being discouraged from stopping or straying along a 14-mile stretch of the Appalachian Trail in Tennessee because of booby traps and suspicious brush fires. Forest Service officials blamed the incidents, including the stringing of fish hooks at eye- and hip-level across paths, on a dispute with landowners who fear their property will be seized to create a buffer along the trail. No injuries have been reported along the route that stretches 2,142.8 miles from Maine to Georgiae, and no arrests have been made. Congress has mandated that the Forest Service acquire about 500 feet on each side of the trail. But a Forest Service spokesman, Bill Sweet, said the agency does not intend to confiscate anyone's land in the dispute. Signs encourage hikers not to stop or leave the trail between Roan Mountain, Tenn., and the North Carolina border. ``Hikers have been scared by them and since we don't know what we're dealing with, that's a good thing,'' said Brian King of the Appalachian Trail Conference, a hikers federation. ``We haven't had any problems there since late April'' when a shelter along the trail was burned down, King said. No decision has been made on when the signs may be removed, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Develop Over Midwest, East
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms rumbled from the Midwest to the East Coast early today. The thunderstorms developed south of a stationary front curving through the lower Great Lakes region, producing hail and high winds from Ohio to New Jersey. Thunderstorms also ranged Monday from central Colorado through southwestern Kansas to Iowa and northern Missouri. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered from eastern Texas to the southern Atlantic Coast states. Showers were widely scattered across the northern Plains and Rocky Mountain region. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation, with fair skies over the Pacific Coast region. Temperatures were above 90 degrees Monday across much of the area from the southern Plains through the Mississippi Valley to the middle Atlantic Coast states. Temperatures in the West varied from the 60s along the Pacific Coast to above 100 in the Southwestern deserts. The high for the nation was 106 degrees at Bullhead City and Lake Havasu, Ariz. DOC.HEAD: Nuclear-Powered Ship Leaves for Seagoing Tests
DOC.TEXT: Japan's only nuclear-powered ship left port today in its first attempt to sail under nuclear power. The experimental ship Mutsu, long plagued by technical problems and anti-nuclear protests, had attempted a maiden voyage in 1974. But the bid was cut short by a radiation leak in the protective shield of its nuclear reactor. The 8,242-ton ship sailed from the Sekinehama port, 360 miles northeast of Tokyo in Aomori prefecture, under conventional power. It was not to sail under nuclear power until it was 110 miles out to sea, said Yuwao Ikezawa, spokesman of the Atomic Energy Research Institute. Police in Aomori prefecture said about two dozen anti-nuclear activists protested today's sailing by burning old tires near the port. But no major trouble was reported. Ocean trials lasting about 20 days will be conducted in an area where they will not interfere with fishing, Ikezawa said. The spokesman said the reactor would be raised to 50 percent capacity in the first week and 70 percent the following week. The reactor was tested at about 20 percent capacity last week while the Mutsu was still in port, he said. In the last 3{ months, tests were cut short five times because of technical problems. There were no radiation leaks during the shutdowns, the spokesman said. The reactor, which has an output capacity of 36,000 kilowatts, had been mothballed since the 1974 leak. When the leak occurred, the research vessel drifted for 50 days in the Pacific because residents did not want it to return to its home port. Then more protests complicated the search for a berth where it could be repaired. Institute officials have said that if these tests go smoothly, the ship will make another test voyage in August, then a year-long experimental trip. It is to be retired after the tests.

DOC.HEAD: Mobil to Pump Out Lake of Oil Below Brooklyn
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to delete extraneous reference to aquifer. Picks up 5th graf pvs., `Mobil spokesman ...'
DOC.TEXT: Mobil Oil Corp. has agreed to pump dry an underground lake of oil, gasoline and naphtha that leaked from a creekside terminal during the last half-century and collected under streets of Brooklyn. The 14.5 million gallon pool of petroleum products is larger than the amount lost in the nation's largest one-time oil spill _ the nearly 11 million gallons that leaked from the tanker Exxon Valdez off Alaska last year. While the Alaska spill fouled beaches and killed wildlife, the Brooklyn oil remains beneath the surface, floating atop an aquifer _ an underground pool of water not used for drinking. State officials said it will take years and cost tens of millions of dollars to remove the oil. Mobil spokesman Mark Cohen said Monday it was unlikely the oil, once recovered, could be used. Mobil first will try to gauge the size of the spill, then decide how many wells are needed to pump it out and where to put them. Cohen said Mobil would pay to have the petroleum products disposed of properly, but said he did not know how or where that would be done. The state believes Mobil is primarily responsible for the spill, and it may have sued had Mobil not agreed to the cleanup, said Ben Marvin, spokesman for the state Department of Environmental Conservation. ``Under this agreement, Mobil has accepted responsibility,'' Marvin said. Cohen said, ``Mobil has stated in the past that we will do whatever is necessary to remedy whatever we're responsible for. Right now we think that the problem deserves attention and we're going to do whatever we can to accelerate the cleanup. That's our primary concern.'' The oil and other petroleum products leaked from the Greenpoint terminal, a complex on Newtown Creek where fuel has been stored since after the Civil War. The leaks date at least to World War II, Marvin said. While Mobil believes the spilled fuel does not endanger health, ``The community is concerned about the problem,'' Cohen said. ``The state is concerned. Obviously it's something that shouldn't be there.'' Authorities have known of the problem at least since 1950, when gasoline fumes exploded in a sewer on Henry Street. In 1978 they size of the spill was estimated at 17 million gallons. Of that, about 2.5 million gallons have been pumped out in a cleanup program that began in 1981. No fuel is known to be leaking from the Greenpoint terminal now, although authorities cannot be certain about the condition of underground pipes, Marvin said. The terminal is still is in use, and Mobil recently paid a $500,000 civil penalty for failing to report immediately a 50,000-gallon kerosene spill there in February.

DOC.HEAD: Two NASA Shuttle Commanders Grounded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES reference to jet in lead, CORRECTS description of second plane in 8th graf, `The move ...'; ADDS graf on space shuttle astronaut killed last year.
DOC.TEXT: Two veteran astronauts, heirs to a daredevil tradition, were grounded by NASA for risky flying after one was involved in a fatal crash and another flew too close to an airliner. Navy Cmdr. Robert L. ``Hoot'' Gibson and Navy Capt. David M. Walker, both shuttle commanders, were disciplined Monday for violating Johnson Space Center flight crew guidelines. ``This is the first time we have removed crew members from flights for disciplinary reasons,'' said NASA spokesman Jeff Carr. One space expert said the pair may just have had too much of the right stuff. ``It's a special breed of man who wants to climb to the top of the heap in the most dangerous profession there is,'' said Lloyd Swenson, a space history expert at the University of Houston. Swenson said astronauts realize ``working with high-performance aircrafts in a test capacity is putting the human body as well as the human mind at risk. Unfortunately, sometimes those people who like to do those tests make an error in judgment.'' Gibson, 43, was pulled from shuttle flight assignments and barred for a year from making T-38 jet trainer flights for violating a policy that restricts high-risk recreational activities for astronauts named to flight crews, Carr said. The move followed a weekend air show race near New Braunfels, Texas, in which Gibson's stunt plane collided with another stunt plane, sending the other pilot hurtling to his death in a corn field. Gibson landed his plane safely. Walker, 46, was suspended for 60 days for infractions that included an incident last year in which the T-38 he was flying came within 100 feet of a Pan Am jetliner in a near-collision outside Washington, Carr said. Gibson had piloted an eight-day Challenger mission in 1984 and commanded a 1986 Columbia mission and a 1988 Atlantis mission. Walker piloted a shuttle flight in 1984 and was commander of Atlantis during a four-day flight in 1989. Walker did not return a call Monday. Gibson has an unlisted number. Harlan J. Smith of the University of Texas at Austin, who has taught science to astronauts, said they are risk-takers by nature. ``The work is so fascinating that they volunteer for a duty where the know the risk every time the rockets are lit, and they rather cheerfully take that risk,'' Smith said. But Smith said NASA must keep them from daredevil conduct off duty because ``an awful lot has been invested in these people.'' Swenson indicated the astronauts would understand their punishments. ``They're jet jockeys, no doubt about that. But they're also Naval officers who are used to discipline,'' he said. Swenson chronicled NASA history from 1963 to 1973, providing research for Tom Wolfe's book ``The Right Stuff'' on the Mercury astronauts. Carr said the timing of the two groundings was coincidence. The decision to ground Walker was made a week ago, but the announcement was delayed while authorities searched for a replacement for him on next year's Pentagon shuttle flight, Carr said. Air Force Col. Frederick D. Gregory will replace Walker as crew commander on that flight. Gibson, widely regarded as one of the shuttle program's most skilled fliers, was slated to command a fourth mission late next year. NASA did not immediately name a replacement. Meanwhile, the precise location of the hydrogen leak that grounded the shuttle fleet still eludes NASA engineers, but officials are looking for a test on Atlantis later this week to provide answers. A laboratory test in California over the weekend confirmed there is a problem in the design or assembly of a liquid hydrogen plumbing system on the shuttle, the space agency said. William Lenoir, NASA space flight director, said engineers plan a full-scale leak test on Atlantis on Friday or Saturday. Witnesses said space shuttle astronaut S. David Griggs was killed performing aerial stunts when his World War II vintage plane crashed in an Arksansas wheat field on June 17, 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Report: As Many as 800 May Have Died in June Clash
DOC.TEXT: As many as 800 people may have died in ethnic clashes last month along the border between the Soviet Central Asian republics of Uzbekistan and Kirghizia, a Soviet newspaper reported today. Previously, Soviet authorities had said 148 people died in fighting near the Kirghiz town of Osh on the border between the two republics. But police Maj. Gen. A.M. Kotlyarov told the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda that about 800 people could not be accounted for, the report said. Many were thought to have been wounded in the fighting, then carried by relatives into the surrounding mountains. Those who died from their wounds were buried without notification to Soviet authorities, the newspaper said. ``The scale of the crimes and their cruelty surpasses those committed in Fergana, Azerbaijan and Armenia,'' said the major, referring to ethnic clashes in other republics that have claimed hundreds of lives. Tension remains high on the border, the government newspaper Izvestia said Monday. A state of emergency was in effect in the town of Jalal-abad, where a 20-year-old Uzbek was killed over the weekend. The suspected killers were in custody, Izvestia reported, but crowds of angry Uzbeks took to the streets Monday demanding more members of their ethnic group be included in law enforcement and KGB bodies, it said. No fighting was reported, but police reinforcements sent to the area stopped a truck full of people armed with hunting rifles and knives, headed toward Jalal-abad. Both the Uzbek and Kirghiz ethnic groups are Moslem and speak Turkish dialects. The border has been the scene of repeated clashes over land and water rights, fueled by other disputes.

DOC.HEAD: Nixon Reverses Decision To Restrict Scholars' Admittance
DOC.TEXT: Former President Nixon has reversed a decision to restrict access to his library and will allow scholars of all political stripes to use its archives. Before Monday's announcement, officials at the privately operated Richard M. Nixon Presidential Library had said researchers would be screened. Hugh Hewitt, the library's director, had said for example that reporter Bob Woodward would be barred ``because he is an irresponsible journalist.'' Woodward, along with Carl Bernstein, wrote Pulitzer Prize-winning stories in The Washington Post that helped uncover the Watergate scandal and lead to Nixon's resignation in 1974. Nixon's personal assistant, John Taylor, said Monday that Nixon wants scholars wishing to use the library to be admitted ``without regard to their opinions on any subject,'' as long as they are ``qualified and responsible.'' An exhibition section at the $21 million library and museum is scheduled to be dedicated July 19 in a ceremony to be attended by President Bush and former Presidents Reagan and Ford. The archives will open in fall 1991. Taylor said library officials had been working long hours to meet the opening deadline and ``had not had the opportunity to give much thought'' to the access question. Taylor also said community and political groups will be allowed to use the library for events, which Hewitt had said would be restricted to Republican fund-raisers. ``I don't anticipate that a lot of Democratic organizations will want to host events there, but former President Nixon sees no reason why they should be excluded from doing so,'' Taylor said. Taylor said every document of importance from the Nixon administration, including many relating to Watergate, will be displayed.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Group Claims Responsibility for Shrine Arson
DOC.TEXT: A radical leftist group claimed responsibility for burning down a Shinto shrine connected with the planned coronation of Emperor Akihito in November, police said today. Monday's predawn fire destroyed the main buildings of the Gokoku Shrine in Akita, about 280 miles north of Tokyo. Akita is one of two prefectures, or states, where rice will be growceremony associated with the emperor's coronation. The Revolutionary Army, a branch of the Chukaku-ha, or Middle Core Faction, made the claim of responsibility in handbills sent today to Japanese news organizations, said a National Pn for use in a olice Agency official, speaking on condition of anonymity. A member of the radical group contacted by telephone refused to confirm or deny the authenticity of the handbills. The Chukaku-ha and other radical leftist groups oppose the monarchy and have said they will violently disrupt the coronation ceremonies. The groups particularly oppose the rice ceremony _ during which the new emperor is believed to commune with the gods _ because they claim it is a remnant of prewar nationalism. The ceremony _ called the Daijosai, or ``great food offering ritual'' _ is to be conducted 10 days after Akihito's coronation on Nov. 12. Shinto, Japan's indigenous religion, is based on nature worship, shamanism anher procedures _ never telling him of his cells' value _ while they developed Moore's cells into a self-perpetuating cell line to mass-produce GM-CSF. The Regents of the University of California patented the cell line in 1984, naming Golde and a research assistant, Shirley Quan, as the inventors. The same year, Moore sued Golde, Quan, the UC Regents and the two companies working on the product, Sandoz and Genetics Institute Inc. The suit estimated the potential value of the product as $3 billion. It said Golde and others had gotten $3 million worth of Genetics Institute stock.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's First Black Archbishop, Eugene Marino of Atlanta, Resigns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be led after archdiocese news conference, set for 10:30 a.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: Archbishop Eugene A. Marino, the nation's first black archbishop and its highest ranking black Roman Catholic, resigned his position today, a spokesman said. The Rev. Peter Dora, the Atlanta Archdiocese spokesman, said Marino cited ``personal reasons'' for his resignation. The 55-year-old archbishop, who was installed in May 1988, had temporarily relinquished his duties in May because of severe stress and a near heart attack. Marino was recuperating at a New York area resort. Dora said the Most Rev. James P. Lyke was appointed apostolic administrator, but that officials did not know when a new archbishop would be appointed. The Archdiocese of Atlanta covers 69 counties in northern Georgia with a Catholic population of more than 150,000.

DOC.HEAD: Jazz Singer Hospitalized
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with comment from doctor; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Jazz great Ella Fitzgerald was treated for exhaustion at a hospital today after becoming ill in her hotel, according to the organizer of a festival she was to headline. Miss Fitzgerald, 72, who was here for the North Sea Jazz Festival, was admitted to the Bronovo Hospital Monday and was in good condition, Dr. Clifford Booker, a physician accompanying her, told The Associated Press. Booker said hospital physicians ordered several days' rest, and Miss Fitzgerald canceled a Wednesday night appearance at a festival gala in her honor and the remainder of her European tour. ``Her condition is good, but she's extremely exhausted,'' Booker said. He said Miss Fitzgerald also was suffering from dehydration. He said she would return to the United States after her discharge. She had been scheduled to make appearances at jazz festivals in Montreux and Antibes. Booker, who described himself as a personal friend of the singer, denied initial media reports that Miss Fitzgerald, who who wears a pacemaker, was suffering from heart problems.

DOC.HEAD: More Clashes in Kenya; Moi Blames Hooligans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with new clashes, 10 reported dead in four days of rioting. Moi blaming rioting on hooligans. Pickup pvs 7th graf, `Dozens of...'
DOC.TEXT: Security forces clashed with rioters in rural areas and in neighborhoods of Nairobi today, a day after the government ordered the use of lethal force to quash spreading anti-government protests. Today was the fourth day of unrest. Ten people have died since Saturday, when police used tear gas and gunfire to break up a pro-democracy rally in the capital of this East African nation. The protests quickly spread from Nairobi to other cities. President Daniel arap Moi today blamed the riots on ``hooligans and drug addicts'' and said his government would continue hunting down instigators. He was addressing Kenyan troops who recently returned from U.N. peacekeeping duty in Namibia, Moi's comment was his first public statement on the situation. Fresh clashes between stone-throwing mobs and security forces were reported this morning in the towns of Kiambu, Nyeri and Githunguri. Violence also was reported from Kangemi and Kawangware, low-income neighborhoods on Nairobi's western edge, where residents say security forces beat people throughout the night. Nairobi's commercial district, which experienced widespread violence Saturday and smaller disturbances Sunday, appeared to have returned to calm. Two new fatalities from Monday's fighting were reported today; one man died of a bullet wound in Githunguri and another was shot and killed in the northern town of Nakuru. Monday, schools sent children home early, and Western embassies advised their nationals to avoid downtown Nairobi. Public transportation ground to a halt, and thousands of Nairobi residents, fearing new violence, fled on foot. Dozens of people have been injured since Saturday, many hospitalized with gunshot wounds, according to newspaper reports and hospital sources. An undisclosed number of people also have been arrested in the disturbances and at least five foreign journalists have been detained. Since early this year, Moi has come under increasing pressure to allow multiparty democracy in Kenya, a one-party state that was long been considered one of Africa's most stable and successful nations. Moi has said a multiparty system could lead to tribal warfare. The clashes come against a backdrop of escalating tension with the United States. On Monday, Kenya condemned the U.S. Embassy for giving temporary asylum to Gibson Kamau Kuria, a prominent opposition figure. Kuria sought refuge after the government detained dozens of opponents last week. In Washington, Herman Cohen, the assistant secretary of state for African affairs, lodged a protest Monday with Kenyan ambassador Denis Afande over the East African nation's criticism of the United States. The crackdown in Kenya has prompted a drive in Congress to freeze or cut U.S. aid in protest, Rep. Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., said Monday in Washington. The United States is a major donor to Kenya, whose economy is heavily dependent on foreign aid. Last year, the United States gave $61 million in economic aid and $15 million in military assistance, according to a study by the Heritage Foundation, a Washington-based conservative think tank. The journalists detained include an Associated Press photographer who was held from midday Saturday until midnight Sunday. On Monday, journalists for the British Broadcasting Corp., the Financial Times, the Daily Telegraph and the British television news service Visnews were held for three hours.

DOC.HEAD: Author Says Ties Tied Too Tightly Can Impair Vision
DOC.TEXT: Snappy dressers beware: A too-tight necktie can make your head swim and vision blur, says the author of a book on improving health habits. Ties that lack slack can constrict blood flow to the brain and sensory organs, said Dr. Don R. Powell of the American Institute for Preventive Medicine. He cited 1989 research at Cornell University for the necktie tip, one of 365 suggestions in his book, ``A Year of Health Hints.'' ``It can be a problem for people who have to use their eyes in an important way,'' Powell said Monday, noting that clear vision is crucial for computer operators, pilots and surgeons. Powell suggested buying shirts a half-size bigger in the neck, leaving the top button undone, tying knots loosely and loosening the tie throughout the day. He also said ``casual days'' at work, when a tie isn't necessary, would help alleviate the health problem and boost morale. He said his institute has ``casual Mondays'' and ``casual weeks'' and is discussing ``casual summers.''

DOC.HEAD: Syrian President to Visit Cairo, First Visit in 17 Years
DOC.TEXT: Syrian President Hafez Assad will visit Egypt this weekend for the first time in 17 years, officials said today. The move is another step in the thawing of relations between the Arab nations, which severed ties in December 1977 weeks after Egypt's then-President Anwar Sadat visited Jerusalem in a peace drive that led to the signing of a treaty with Israel in 1979. Syria and Egypt resumed diplomatic relations in December and Egypt's president, Hosni Mubarak, visited Syria in May to signify the end of the rift. The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Assad and Mubarak will hold talks in Cairo on Saturday and will travel to the Mediterranean city of Alexandria for further discussions on Sunday before the Syrian leader heads home. Government officials said the Mubarak-Assad talks will deal with the stalled Middle East peace process and inter-Arab relations, including disputes between Syria and both Iraq and the Palestine Liberation Organization. Assad last visited Egypt in 1973 to discuss with Sadat plans for the war they jointly launched against Israel on Oct. 6, 1973. The state-run Middle East News Agency reported that Mubarak will travel to Saudi Arabia on Wednesday for talks with King Fahd and a pilgrimage to Islam's holy shrines at Mecca and Medina. Mubarak and Fahd have been key figures in efforts to mend a breach between Syria and Iraq. The agency said Mubarak will return home from Saudi Arabia on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says He's Unlikely To Change Georgia Primary
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge hearing a challenge to Georgia's election law says it's unlikely he'll do anything to affect next week's primary because he wasn't asked to until last week. A group of black officials, led by state Rep. Tyrone Brooks of Atlanta, charged in a lawsuit in May that a 1964 rule requiring a majority vote to win an election is racially discriminatory. The plaintiffs want to change the rule so the candidate with the most votes wins, whether it's more than half or not. U.S. District Judge Richard C. Freeman said Monday that though the suit was filed in May, a motion asking him to rule in time to eliminate the majority-vote requirement in the July 17 primary was filed only last week _ ``at the last minute.'' He indicated he was not likely to agree to the move. Former Atlanta Mayor Andrew Young, who is trying to become Georgia's first black governor, is not supporting the Brooks lawsuit. But political observers say it's a strong possibility Young could win a plurality in the five-way Democratic primary but lose a runoff which would be held Aug. 7. Freeman did not indicate if he was leaning toward either side in deciding the lawsuit. But when David Walbert, an attorney representing the state, asked if today's session could be delayed a few hours, Freeman responded: ``The longer we wait, the harder it will be to get this done. ... I don't think it will be done anyway, to be perfectly frank.'' Walbert would not comment on the judge's remarks. Laughlin McDonald, an American Civil Liberties Union attorney for the Brooks group, said that suing prior to the election gives the plaintiffs the option, if the judge rules against them, of challenging the election results. The first witness in the hearing Monday was a history and political science professor from the California Institute of Technology who testified there were numerous indications that the Georgia Legislature had racial motivations in enacting the majority-vote law. J. Morgan Kousser, author of a book on Southern politics, said the law was pushed through the legislature by state Rep. Denmark Groover, a segregationist, after national civil rights legislation abolished a system that awarded candidates electoral votes by county. Kousser said there are other signs that lawmakers in 1964 wanted to keep blacks out of public office, including an attempt to stiffen the literacy test for voter registration. Walbert said the professor was relying too much on second-hand information, such as old newspaper clippings, to draw his conclusions.

DOC.HEAD: Jimmy Carter, Former Tanzanian Leader Focus On Africa's Woes
DOC.TEXT: Former President Jimmy Carter said today Africa will remain impoverished unless leaders end wars and resolve their economic woes. Carter told the 26th summit of the 51-member Organization of African Unity here that he shared Africans' concerns that aid and investment is being sent from the rich nations to Eastern Europe and Latin America, not Africa. Carter heads Global 2000, a non-profit organization that sponsors health programs and development projects in Third World countries. Speaking on the second day of the three-day summit, Carter said health care and food production programs are not being implemented in areas where there are civil wars. Peace efforts, he said, are being thwarted by the reluctance of bodies like the OAU, the United Nations and the Organization of American States to intervene in conflicts between ``revolutionary'' groups and unrecognized governments. He singled out Liberia, Mozambique, Ethiopia, Somalia and Sudan, where populations have been shattered by war. Carter lamented that national budgets in poor countries are mostly used to buy weapons and deploy large armies, gravely affecting food output and economic growth. Last year, Carter chaired inconclusive peace talks between rebel and government representatives from both Sudan and Ethiopia. Julius Nyerere, former president of Tanzania and a former OAU chairman, said Africa is the continent hardest hit by economic recession. The continent of 550 million people also suffers from economic and political domination by the wealthy industrialized north, he said. ``Africa can only survive if we pool our resources,'' Nyerere said.

DOC.HEAD: First Lady Reports She Saw Rat in White House Pool
With PM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: First Lady Barbara Bush says she once encountered a rat in the White House swimming pool. ``It did not look like a Walt Disney rat, I'll tell you that,'' Mrs. Bush told the Houston Post in an interview published today. ``I was out of that pool so much faster than I thought I could.'' Mrs. Bush, who swims daily for exercise in the heated pool, said President Bush came to her rescue during the incident a few months ago. ``I swim with a mask, and it just went right by in front of me,'' she said. ``Fortunately, George Bush was there and drowned the beast. It was horrible.'' Mrs. Bush said the confrontation with the rat was the worst experience of her 18 month in the White House. The first lady planned to take the wives of other heads of government attending the seven-nation economic summit on a tour of the Alamo and other historical sites at San Antonio, Texas. Noting the friendly crowds that greeted the Bush motorcade Monday at the start of the summit talks, Mrs. Bush said, ``I told George this was the first time I've gone that far in a car ... when everybody waved and there were no unfriendly gestures.'' ``It's so wonderful,'' she said. ``George is tickled pink.'' Mrs. Bush said she and her husband agree that foreign visitors should see more than the East and West coasts of the United States. The president told Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney at a presummit social event last weekend that ``America is not the coasts. This is America,'' Mrs. Bush said. ``Well, it is. This is what you want people to see.''

DOC.HEAD: President Says Yugoslavia May Peacefully Split Apart
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslavia's president Borisav Jovic said today the troubled Balkan country may soon hold a national referendum to decide if the nation's six republics should split into separate nations. ``The right of self-determination, including the right of secession, is a natural political right of each nationality, which no one can question,'' Jovic said in a speech to a war veteran's congress. ``This also means that each of our peoples can decide to remain in the Yugoslav community or leave it,'' said Jovic, the head of Yugoslavia's eight-member state presidency. Yugoslavia's Communist Party continues to run the country on the federal level, but its authority has been crippled since center-rignt parties won free elections in the republics of Slovenia and Croatia earlier this year. Open clashes among the republics' leaderships and rising nationalism in the nation's six republics, two provinces and numerous ethnic groups have led to fears of a civil war. Jovic said the outcome of a nationwide referendum on secession must be democratic and peaceful since the different nationalities ``will continue to live on these territories, and even if they do not remain in the same house, they must remain friends.'' He added ``I deeply believe that Yugoslavia will continue to exist because we have no better solution.'' His speech was broadcast live by Belgrade radio. Newly-elected non-communist leaderships in Slovenia and Croatia have demanded that Yugoslavia transform itself into a loose confederation of semi-independent states, which would cooperate only if common interests were involved. They have indicated that if their demands are not met by the new Yugoslav constitution, which is currently being drafted, they would secede. Communist leaders in the largest republic, Serbia, have opposed holding free elections and advocate a federal system with strong central authority. Also today, tens of thousands of ethnic Albanians continued peaceful demonstrations and strikes throughout the province of Kosovo to protest Serbia's virtual abolition of the troubled region's autonomy. Witnesses and the state Tanjug news agency said the vast majority of ethnic Albania's working for state-run companies left their jobs for a second day and peacefully paraded through the streets of Kosovo. Last Thursday, Serbian authorities disbanded the local parliament and government after 114 ethnic Albanians announced plans to declare Kosovo's full autonomy from Serbia. Both dismantled bodies were dominated by ethnic Albanians, who make up 90 percent of the province's 1.9 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Workers, Teachers Protests in East Germany
DOC.TEXT: East German trains stopped operating briefly today, and gym teachers protested cuts in funding to the physical education system that produced one of the world's mightiest Olympic teams, a news agency reported. The protests are the newest round in labor unrest following the economic merger of East Germany and West Germany. East Germany's Sports Teachers and Trainers Association called for nationwide demonstrations next week to protest the ``financial misery of East German sports,'' East Germany's ADN news agency reported today. Gym teachers claim that a lack of money could soon force the closure of a string of special sports schools that have helped produce East German Olympic athletes in areas such as track and field, swimming and skating. ``In the interest of the health of all people ... help us maintain sports as a part of a cultured society,'' said a pamphlet distributed by the group. East Germany captured 127 medals in the 1988 Olympics in Seoul. The one-hour warning strike by locomotive drivers halted virtually all rush-hour train traffic from Rostock in northern East Germany to Dresden in the southeast, ADN reported. In the western region of Magdeburg alone, 33 trains were canceled or delayed because of the strike. Similar disruptions were reported in the East Berlin area, one of central Europe's most important rail transit points. The stoppages followed Monday's deadlock in talks between the Union of German Locomotive Engineers and Apprentices and the East German railway system. Union officials had demanded compensation for the loss of some benefits under the July 1 economic merger. East Germany introduced West Germany's mighty deutsche mark as legal tender July 1 in a prelude to the expected unification of the two German states. The move unleashed a nationwide wave of industrial unrest by workers demanding the same high salaries as their West German counterparts. Experts have predicted as many as one-third of East Germany's 8,000 businesses could fold and up to half of its 8 million workers could lose their jobs as competition from West Germany begins to take its toll on the East German economy. Monday, dairy farmers protesting plans to reform East Germany's Soviet-style collective farming system dumped milk outside a government building in the southern city of Leipzig, ADN said. The farmers threatened to take their protest to East Berlin and empty an entire milk truck there unless their demands were met, ADN reported.

DOC.HEAD: Ring, A Birthday Gift, Lost When Man Loses Hold of Helium Balloons
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `The stones...', to CORRECT that woman quoted is Mrs. Turner's mother sted Turner's mother.
DOC.TEXT: Mark Turner thought it would be a nice touch to attach his birthday gift for his wife _ a diamond and ruby ring _ to a bouquet of helium balloons. But the ring was blown away by high wind when Turner attempted to bring them into the house from his car Saturday. ``When he opened the door, he went to grab them and out they went,'' Sue Ann Turner said Monday. The family contacted police and radio stations in hopes of getting back the white and yellow gold ring with its arrangement of diamonds and rubies. ``The stones were sentimental because they were from her 16th birthday and engagement,'' said Mrs. Turner's mother, Jackie Schlosser. Hope soared when a farmer near the community of Ladd notified the family that he had found the balloons in a soybean field. But the ring and birthday card were nowhere to be seen. Now, the family is trying to hire a psychic, Greta Alexander of Delavan. ``I'm hoping she will pin it down,'' Mrs. Turner said. ``She finds things all the time so maybe she'll know where to look.'' The Turners couldn't estimate the ring's worth, but they were offering a small reward, said Schlosser.

DOC.HEAD: Engineers Find Hydrogen Leak During California Test
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 5 grafs on astronaut grounding after 9th graf pvs, Other witnesses. Picks up 10th graf pvs, At his news conference.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: A precise location of the hydrogen leak that grounded the space shuttle still eludes NASA engineers, but officials are looking for a test on space shuttle Atlantis later this week to provide answers. A laboratory test in California over the weekend gave confirmation that there is a problem in the design or assembly of a liquid hydrogen plumbing system on the shuttle, space agency officials said Monday. William Lenoir, space flight director for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said the leak found in a test at the Rockwell International plant in Downey, Calif., was similar to the one detected earlier on space shuttle Columbia. But he said it did not pinpoint the precise seal, pipe or valve that is leaking. ``It looks like it's not out of line from what we saw on the pad,'' Lenoir told reporters. He called the finding ``good news.'' ``My biggest fear was that we would go through the Downey test and get no leak at all,'' said Lenoir. ``I'm encouraged.'' Lenoir and NASA chief scientist Lennard Fisk were testifying today before the Senate science, technology and space subcommittee about problems besetting NASA. While Lenoir was to be quizzed about the space shuttle leak, Fisk faced questions about why the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope was launched into orbit with a irrepairable fuzzy focus. The telescope flaw was found two weeks ago and NASA has convened an investigative board. Others witnesses at the hearing were expected to include officials of Hughes Danbury Optical Co., the firm that made the flawed mirrors on Hubble. Meanwhile, at the Johnson Space Center in Houston, two veteran astronauts were grounded for involvment in hazardous flying incidents, including one in which another pilot died. Navy Cmdr. Robert L. ``Hoot'' Gibson was grounded for a year after being involved in a collision during an air race in Central Texas. The pilot of the other aircraft crashed and died. Gibson landed safely. A NASA announcement said Gibson will not fly the space shuttle or the T-38 trainer jet for a year. Gibson had been assigned to command a shuttle mission next year, but NASA said a new commander would be selected. Navy Cmdr. David M. Walker was suspended from flying the T-38 jet for 60 days and replaced as commander of a military shuttle mission scheduled for next year. NASA took the action, officials said, because Walker flew too close to an airliner near Washington, D.C. in 1988. Air Force Col. Frederick D. Gregory will replace Walker as crew commander on the shuttle flight. At his news conference Monday, Lenoir said NASA engineers plan a full-scale leak test on Atlantis on Friday or Saturday. The test will be performed while the space shuttle sits on the launch pad and will closely duplicate the conditions that resulted in both the Columbia leak in May and the leak found on Atlantis in June. After the second leak, NASA halted space shuttle launches until the problem is fixed. The Rockwell test over the weekend used plumbing hardware called an umbilical that had been taken from Columbia after its leak was found. Engineers forced liquid hydrogen through the umbilical and maintained a pressure of 50 pounds per square inch. They then measured any hydrogen that leaked. Lenoir said the leak amounted to 5,000 to 10,000 cubic inches of hydrogen per minute. The Columbia leak in May had been about 90,000 cubic inches per minute. A hole the size of a pinhole, about 40,000th of an inch, would be large enough to create such a leak in the liquid hydrogen system, he said. For Atlantis' test, engineers at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida stripped away insulation and exposed the bare metal of the umbilical. They are installing special instruments and sensors, and attaching plastic bags to areas of the pipe assembly that could be leaking. When all is ready, hydrogen, chilled to a liquid at minus 423 degrees, will be pumped through the pipes at the rate of more than 80 gallons a minute. By analyzing gas captured by the bags and readings on the sensors, the experts hope to find the exact location of the leak. Lenoir said the ``prime suspect'' for the source of the leak is a U-shaped Teflon seal that is supposed to keep hydrogen from escaping from the disconnect joint. He said the tolerances for the seal and for the groove that holds it are extremely tight and there could be just enough of a misfit to cause a leak. If this is confirmed as the problem, Lenoir said there is a possibility it could be fixed in time for Atlantis to fly in August. But Robert Crippen, director of the space shuttle program, said engineers still have not pinpointed the leak source. ``We really do not know what the problem is yet,'' he said at the news conference with Lenoir. ``We haven't eliminated anything yet.'' While the leak test on Atlantis may give answers, Crippen warned that it could also raise more questions. ``We have not eliminated the possibility that we might have two different problems on the two different vehicles,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Hostages Escape Bank Seige
DOC.TEXT: A woman who said she wanted attention held seven bank employees hostage for more than four hours before one of them overpowered her, authorities said. Although Vicki Molina, 37, told police she had a grenade, a bomb and a gun during Monday's standoff at an NCNB branch, she was unarmed when arrested and charged with nine counts of false imprisonment. ``She had something to prove to someone, we don't know whom,'' said North Miami police Lt. Nancy McCue. ``She said she was not there to rob the bank. It was some personal problem she had. ... She said she wanted attention.'' Mrs. Molina has undergone periodic psychiatric treatment for the past 15 years and her actions were not believed triggered by any specific incident, McCue said. Witnesses said the bank manager announced there was a bomb threat and everyone should leave, but the woman insisted some employees stay behind. About 4 p.m., the hostage taker exhorted police to kill her or she would start killing the hostages. That's when bank vice president Clinton Green, 48, lunged at the woman, pinned her against the wall and allowed the hostages to escape, police said. Metro-Dade Special Response Team officers moved in and subdued the woman. She remained in the Dade County jail today under a suicide watch.

DOC.HEAD: Bankers Plead Guilty To Embezzling Money Spent at Topless Bar
DOC.TEXT: Federal prosecutors say two bankers who embezzled more than $67,000 spent more than $46,000 of the money at a topless bar. Ted W. Cook, 45, of Garden Ridge and John E. Buratovich, 33, of Kirby pleaded guilty Monday to conspiracy to defraud the government. The pleas came as lawyers prepared to select a jury and prosecutors were poised to present testimony from two exotic dancers. U.S. District Judge D.W. Suttle scheduled sentencing for Sept. 12. Federal prosecutors said Cook, former president of the suburban Garden Ridge State Bank, obtained a corporate credit card without the knowledge or approval of the bank's board of directors. Cook and Buratovich, a former vice president of the bank, were accused of using the card to buy goods and services ``of a personal and private nature.''
