The expenditures were various night clubs, restaurants and hotels, mostly in the San Antonio area, between Nov. 1, 1985, and Aug. 22, 1989, prosecutors said. FBI officials who investigated the case said that of the $67,375 the men charged on the card, more than $46,000 was spent at Ziegfeld's Gentleman's Club, a topless bar. Cook and Buratovich allegedly reported to bank directors that some officers had higher salaries than they actually received and then using the excess money to pay off the credit card.

DOC.HEAD: Brown Picks New York For 1992 Convention
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new graf 4 to raise reference to GOP site selection process; SUBS last graf pvs with contenders for GOP gathering.
DOC.TEXT: New York is Democratic Chairman Ronald Brown's choice as the host city for the party's 1992 convention, party sources say. The choice, which the sources aid Brown revealed to top aides Monday, is no surprise _ New York was Brown's favorite from the start of the search, which came down to that city and New Orleans. Brown plans to make his choice public on Wednesday in Washington. Party spokeswoman Ginny Terzano refused to comment on the sources' accounts, except to say that Brown had made his decision. The sources spoke on the condition of anonymity. The early choice of a convention site by Democrats comes as the Republican Party is just beginning its search. Houston, President Bush's adopted hometown, is among the cities seeking to host the GOP gathering. New York hosted the Democratic conventions in 1976 and 1980. Mayor David Dinkins made a strong pitch on behalf of his city's 1992 effort, beginning his lobbying last year during a party meeting in Indianapolis. New York's Madison Square Garden is too small to serve as both convention hall and media center, but the city proposed using another hall several blocks away as a work area for reporters. The city also said it could afford the $20 million commitment sought by the party, and Democratic fund-raisers in New York promised to aggressively raise money for the 1992 campaign. New Orleans, which hosted the 1988 Republican convention, was the other finalist to emerge from Brown's site selection committee. But party insiders said Brown appeared set on New York from the outset, and any hopes for New Orleans were undermined by the Louisiana legislature's passage of a strict anti-abortion measure last weekend. The Democratic Party backs abortion rights and its candidates in several 1989 elections successfully used the issue against GOP opponents. Brown said last week the Louisiana legislation was a factor in his deliberations; party sources said then that New York was the choice unless negotiations collapsed. The Republican Party isn't expected to complete its search for several months, with a decision expected in January. The search would be moot should Bush express a preference, but for now the competitors include Houston, Cleveland, San Diego, New Orleans, Miami, Anaheim, Calif., and St. Petersburg, Fla. New York also was interested in the GOP event and it was not immediately clear if landing the Democratic convention would affect that bid.

DOC.HEAD: Strikers Continue Protests, Rebuild Street Barricades
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with strikers rebuilding barricades, gunfire in the streets, other details; pickup 6th graf pvs, `The strikes...' EDITS thereafter to trim.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MGA7, NY10, NY11
DOC.TEXT: Gunfire crackled in the streets today and backers of a spreading and violent strike rebuilt street barricades that police and the army had dismantled overnight. President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro called on the army to end bloody clashes between her supporters and Sandinistas backing a week-old general strike that is the stiffest threat yet to her U.S.-backed government. At least three people were reported killed in earlier gunfire. More were reported wounded overnight but the extent of the casualties was not immediately clear. Most government ministries and state-owned businesses remained in the control of pro-Sandinista strikers today. Bonfires burned at many key intersections, and the highway to the airport was blocked by barricades of paving stones and other obstacles. Most Managuans who went to work walked. The army is dominated by the Sandinistas and it was not yet clear whether soldiers would take up arms against compatriots who have organized the crippling strikes and fought Chamorro backers with fists, rocks and guns. Armored cars patrolled the streets of Managua and gunfire could be heard during the night, but reporters could not get close to the fighting. The violence began Sunday evening and intensified Monday. Police said the dead included a man fatally shot in a clash between government supporters and Sandinistas. They said about 100 people had been injured; hospitals reported much lower casualty figures. The strikes and street violence have brought the country to a near standstill. In scenes reminiscent of the 1979 revolution that brought them to power, the Sandinistas built smoky bonfires of trash and tires all over Managua on Monday and erected barricades. A haze hung over the capital, a city of 1 million people. Electricity and drinking water were cut off in most of Managua. Mail and operator-assisted telephone calls were suspended. There was virtually no bus service, and state-run cooperatives and other agricultural installations, textile and construction plants were idle. Striking air traffic controllers shut down the the international airport and the road to Managua was blockaded by protesters. The police tore down their barricades with backhoes; the demonstrators put them up again. Mrs. Chamorro, facing the worst crisis of her 10-week-old presidency, made a nationally broadcast appeal for calm on Monday night. She begged compatriots not to answer ``violence with violence, which has already claimed victims.'' The Sandinistas, though, renewed their strike calls and warned the government was courting ``chaos and a catastrophe.'' Sandinista-controlled unions say Mrs. Chamorro is firing too many people from government jobs as she tries to reduce the budget deficit. They also object to her plans to sell dozens of state-owned companies and farms that the Sandinistas had expropriated from the wealthy. The Sandinistas held power for a decade, warring nearly all the while with the U.S.-backed Contras who sought to topple them and suffering economic hardship as the result of a U.S. trade embargo. Mrs. Chamorro's 14-party coalition unseated the Sandinists in elections Feb. 25 and the Contras disarmed last month. The Sandinistas remain the single biggest party in Nicaragua, while the president's coalition has been splintered by infighting and weakened by popular discontent over economic hardship. Sandinista-controlled unions called a strike on June 26. Spiralling walkouts paralyzed government offices and banks and curtailed services including transportation, telephones, water and power. Strike leaders claim more than 80,000 public and private sector workers have joined in the walkouts. The strikes escalated into street fighting, and that's when Mrs. Chamorro called out the army to help police restore order. In her speech, Mrs. Chamorro accused the Sandinistas of engineering the strikes and the unrest. The president's speech on state radio and television was delayed for four hours when pro-Sandinista students and workers seized a government broadcasting center. Police dispersed them peacefully after about two hours. Mrs. Chamorro said her government was committed to national reconciliation, but insisted that it occur in ``a climate of peace and understanding, not fear of intimidation.'' The Sandinistas, however, said the government would be ``directly responsible for creating chaos and a catastrophe'' if it failed to negotiate with the strike leaders. Talks broke down last week. Former President Daniel Ortega, too, urged negotiations. ``This conflict cannot be solved by force. Any attempt in that direction is an invitation to chaos,'' he said in a radio interview Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Earth First! Meeting Attracts Variety of Followers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to recast and edit. Picks up 10th graf, `The atmosphere...'
DOC.TEXT: The setting was wild but the crowd was tame as campers began arriving for an annual gathering of Earth First!, a group known for its militant approach to defending nature. ``We just wanted to learn more about Earth First!'' said chiropractor Gary Robb, who hitchhiked about 1,000 miles from Canada with his son, Travis, 15, for a week of music, dance and environmental activism in a meadow south of Cameron. Battered cars bulging with camping gear and Volkswagen buses carried aging or fledgling hippies to within half a mile of the Round River Rendezvous at Beaverhead National Forest. The campout site is in the foothills of Gravelly Range about 25 miles west of Yellowstone National Park. Up to 500 Earth First! members were expected for the 11th annual meeting of the organization. Police, wary of counterdemonstrators and the movement's reputation for civil disobedience, said they will keep an eye on the proceedings. But no officers were in sight Monday. Robert Kellog, a Forest Service law enforcement officer, said Earth First! meetings have not been a problem in the past and ``there's no reason to expect they will this time.'' Participants said they were there to learn and enjoy themselves. ``It's the camaraderie more than anything,'' said Mitch Friedman, a biologist from Bellingham, Wash. ``I'm looking forward to the workshops, but I'm really looking forward to seeing my friends.'' ``There's a big piece of wild country here and we're trying to keep it wild,'' said Philip Knight, who helped organize the Round River Rendezvous, which opened Monday. ``That's why we're here.'' Robb and his son, from Salt Spring Island in British Columbia, began hitchhiking more than two weeks ago. They painted a house in nearby Ennis to earn some traveling money, and hiked into the snow-tipped Madison Range while waiting for the event to start. The atmosphere was alternately festive and serious. At a ``first-timer'' meeting, about 75 members discussed the group's image and the hazards of environmental activism. ``Even if we are fringe, we need to get our message out: that there are people who would destroy our land for a greasy dollar bill,'' said Bob Kasper, a mail carrier from Madison, Wis. ``Ours is not an evil group that is trying to destroy the country.'' Some Earth First! publications have advocated ``monkey-wrenching'' _ acts of sabotage against those who develop the nation's wildlands. But members say the group takes no official stance on such activity and that its members are mostly involved in acts of civil disobedience. A workshop on non-violent protest tactics is on the agenda. Earth Firsters have chained themselves to tree-crushing machines in Texas, blocked logging roads in Washington, and occupied road-building equipment in Arizona. This summer in Northern California, more than 50 have been arrested for blockading sawmills and picketing government offices to protest the cutting of old-growth redwoods. Some authorities say the group is more destructive when nobody's looking. Two activists were injured May 24 in Oakland when a pipe bomb exploded in the back seat of their car. Last year in Arizona, three other activists allegedly cut through the leg of an electric transmission tower, and the FBI claimed they were practicing for an assault against nuclear facilities in California and Colorado. Earth First! co-founder Dave Foreman also was arrested on charges that he helped plan the scheme. All four have denied the charges; Foreman faces trial in September.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Murder Army Major
DOC.TEXT: The head of the joint chiefs of staff judicial department was shot to death while driving through this capital, authorities reported today. The Modesto Ramirez Front _ urban commandos of the leftist rebel army battling the government _ claimed responsibility for Monday night's assassination of Maj. Carlos Figueroa in telephone calls to local radio stations. The guerrillas did not say why Figueroa was selected as a target. Also today, judicial authorities reported the arraignment of former immigration director Col. Maximiliano Leiva, who is accused of heading a ring that helped smuggle Chinese nationals bound for the United States. Leiva was removed from his post and detained last weekend following the discovery of 52 Chinese _ 50 from mainland China and two from Taiwan _ in a house in an affluent residential neighborhood. The Chinese reportedly paid $20,000 to authorities in several countries for false documents.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Parliament Opens First Session Without President
DOC.TEXT: Bulgaria's first multiparty parliament in 44 years held its inaugural session today in the absence of former President Petar Mladenov, who resigned after admitting he proposed using force to crush pro-democracy protests. The opening ceremony was held in a wood-paneled hall in this ancient Bulgarian capital, about 150 miles northeast of Sofia. Mladenov resigned Friday under mounting public pressure for suggesting in December that tanks be used to disperse some 50,000 anti-Communist demonstrators. His departure came less than three weeks after his party of reformed Communists won the country's first free elections in 58 years. Mladenov was instrumental in last year's ousting of Communist strongman Todor Zhivkov. Prodded by popular demonstrations, Mladenov then played a key role in reforming the party, now known as the Socialist Party. His departure has weakened the ruling Socialists and created a constitutional vacuum. The Grand National Assembly's first task will be to agree on a presidential candidate and on how to elect him. There is no precedent for electing a president in Bulgaria's parliamentary history. The 400-member parliament may either decide to elect the president or call a referendum. The ceremonial opening session, held in sweltering heat, was adjourned after only 40 minutes and will be resumed on July 17 at the parliament building in Sofia. The meeting was inaugurated by Yosif Petrov, at 81 the oldest deputy. In a brief speech, Alexander Lilov, chairman of the Socialist Party, said: ``The time of the totalitarian parliament is over. Now is the time of the democratic parliament.'' But Lilov also criticized protesters. ``We are against chaos and destabilization in the country,'' he said. ``Everyone has the right to protest, but everyone has also the obligation to work.'' Police and special security forces patrolled the area outside the meeting, but there were no incidents.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Red Cross Failed To Disclose Possible AIDS Contamination
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to ADD that the 230 cases occurred in the Washington area; Red Cross failed to review 380 cases of errors and accidents; UPDATES with Red Cross today saying no one available to respond.
DOC.TEXT: The American Red Cross failed to notify federal authorities about 230 cases in which patients may have contracted AIDS through contaminated blood transfusions, a newspaper reported today. In at least four cases, patients died as a result of contaminated blood, but the federal Food and Drug Administration was not informed, The Philadelphia Inquirer said. The newspaper report did not say how many of the 230 cases involved people actually getting AIDS. The newspaper said it obtained a report of an FDA inspection of the Red Cross' national headquarters in Washington, D.C., that was carried out between April 26 and May 25. It said the agency found that the Red Cross lacked procedures ``for reviewing and tracking transfusion-associated AIDS cases by national (headquarters) to assure all regions are submitting the initial reports and follow-up reports are complete.'' The FDA report also said that national Red Cross officials have not updated their procedures for handling error and accident reports since July 1981, calling those procedures inadequate. The FDA report said the 230 cases occurred in the Washington, D.C., area and that there were also 380 cases where national Red Cross officials failed to review reports of errors and accidents at Red Cross blood centers nationwide. The newspaper did not indicate what years the cases occurred. Blood and blood components have been screened for AIDS antibodies since March 1985. Under federal law, the FDA may require the Red Cross to correct the deficiencies, or either suspend or revoke its license to collect and distribute blood. Errors at Red Cross blood centers around the country ranged from potentially dangerous donors not being excluded to the release of blood that initially tested positive for AIDS antibodies but was later found to be negative, the newspaper said, quoting from the FDA report. A subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee has scheduled a hearing Friday to investigate the safety of the American blood supply. The Red Cross supplies more than half of all the blood used by American hospitals. Its 54 regional centers collect and distribute more than 6 million units of blood. Diane Powers, spokeswoman for the Red Cross in Washington, said this morning that no one was available to respond to the report. Other officials said a staff meeting was under way this morning at which the report was discussed.

DOC.HEAD: Norwegian Arrested By Soviets at Border
DOC.TEXT: Soviet guards seized a Norwegian man Tuesday in the second arctic border incident between the two countries in less than a week, Norwegian authorities reported. The man waded across the Grense Jakobselv river into Soviet territory, probably while fishing, said Hugo Overgaard, the Norwegian border commissioner. The man was not publicly identified. Tourists often inadvertently violate the border by wandering across the shallow river, Overgaard told the Norwegian news agency NTB, ``but it has been a very long time since one was arrested.'' Wayward tourists are customarily returned to their home country, Overgaard said. The man could face a fine of up to $395 in Norway. On Thursday, Norwegian fisherman Werner Pedersen claimed a five-man Soviet border patrol shot at him and chased him 110 yards into Norwegian territory. He was not injured. The Soviets said Pedersen was fishing on their side of the river and was chased back into Norway. Overgaard told newspapers that a Norwegian re-enactment of the incident supported Pedersen's claim. Norway protested the incident to the Soviets over the weekend.

DOC.HEAD: Vandal Throws Paint on Statue in Pope's Church
DOC.TEXT: A man dressed as a priest Tuesday tossed a container of red paint on a statue of St. Paul inside the basilica of St. John in Lateran, the pope's church as bishop of Rome. Two church custodians chased the man but he managed to escape, the Italian news agency ANSA said. Church officials covered the statue with a tarpaulin and refused to discuss the incident. The press office at the Vatican said an unknown vandal also recently splashed three statues with paint at St. Paul's Basilica in Rome.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Seeking Person Who Shot Well-Known Crocodile
DOC.TEXT: Wildlife officials Tuesday were investigating the shooting of a 14-foot crocodile named Old Slimy, whose disappearance has outraged tour operators on the Daintree River. The crocodile, one of the largest known on the river, was regularly seen for nearly 10 years, said Lee Lafferty, manager of the Daintree River and Reef Cruise Center in northern Queensland state. It was estimated to be 15 to 20 years old. But it has not been sighted since it was shot Saturday afternoon, shortly after a tour vessel had shown the reptile to a group of tourists. ``Some mindless hoon snuck up on the croc and shot it,'' Lafferty said. A National Parks and Wildlife Service spokesman said the offender could face a fine of up to $4,800, 12 months in prison or both. Tour operators and some bus companies offered a reward for information leading to the culprit's capture, said Margaret Patterson from the Daintree River Train. ``It had been here so long that it is like losing a member of the family, everyone is really upset,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Exile Turns Down Government Offer to Release Him to House Arrest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Bosch turning down offer. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `Justice Department...'.
DOC.TEXT: Militant Cuban exile Orlando Bosch today rejected a government offer to trade prison for a restrictive house-arrest program that would return him to his family after the past 14 years in jails. Bosch said the offer would require him to tell the FBI of any contacts with Cuban exile groups that advocate violence, said his daughter, Myriam. ``He's willing to agree to all of the conditions except that one,'' Ms. Bosch said. ``He's not going be an informant. The FBI can do their own work.'' Ms. Bosch said her father informed his attorneys of his decision this morning, and they were to notify immigration officials. A source with the Justice Department said the government will not negotiate the offer. ``Bosch won't accept the conditions, and he won't be released unless he does,'' the source said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The proposal presented to Bosch by immigration officials Monday night was a departure for the Justice Department, which has maintained for years that the anti-Castro activist would continue his terrorist ways if released. ``He's just not prepared to send a message out that he's an informant,'' said attorney Henry Adorno. ``He believes that lists are kept by people like Joe McCarthy and Fidel Castro.'' On Monday, Bosch's wife, Adriana, had criticized the conditions for his release, but appeared to encourage him to accept the deal, calling the conditions ``better than jail.'' The 63-year-old former pediatrician suffers from ulcers and declining health after years in Venezuelan and U.S. jails. The conditions would have required Bosch to wear an electronic monitoring device, remain at home for 21 hours a day, keep a log of visitors and allow his telephone to be monitored, said Richard Smith, director of the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service in Miami. Smith said Bosch also would be subject to unannounced searches and lie detector tests, and if instructed, must present himself for deportation within 72 hours. ``They're just messing with his head,'' Myriam Bosch said. ``Knowing how they work, I think they probably did this knowing my father would not accept it.'' Justice Department spokesman Dan Eramian in Washington said the government decided to offer Bosch parole for humanitarian reasons, but will continue the two-year effort to deport him. Thus far, 31 nations have refused to accept him. The offer appeared to be an attempt to resolve what has become a cause celebre for Miami's staunchly anti-Castro Cuban exile community, which has held rallies and demonstrations on his behalf. Bosch has been held since 1988, when he was arrested for parole violations and for reentering the country illegally. According to CIA documents, he ran bombing runs on Cuba in the early 1960s. In 1968, he was convicted in a bazooka attack on a Polish freighter at the Port of Miami and sentenced to 10 years in prison. He was paroled in 1972 and fled the country in 1974 after he was subpoenaed to testify in an inquiry into the killing of a Miami exile leader. Accused of masterminding the 1976 bombing of a Cuban jetliner that killed 73 people, Bosch spent 11 years in Venezuelan jails. He denied involvement in the bombing and was acquitted in three separate trials. The parole conditions would require Bosch to wear an electronic monitoring device, remain at home for 21 hours a day, keep a log of visitors and allow his telephone to be monitored, said Richard Smith, director of the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service in Miami.

DOC.HEAD: Opponents of Collaboration Honored On Vichy's 50th Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: France observed the 50th anniversary of the formation of the collaborationist Vichy government Tuesday and honored the Parliament members who opposed Marshal Philippe Petain's ascension to power. Petain, a grandfatherly World War I hero, was installed as all-powerful leader of the Vichy regime by a 569-80 vote on July 10, 1940. Three of the legislators who voted ``no'' survive, and two attended commemorations at Vichy's Grand Casino, where the vote was taken. Maurice Montel, 90, and Emile Fouchard, 88, were joined by Parliamentary Affairs Minister Jean Poperen. Poperen said the 80 lawmakers, acting ``with lucidity and courage, against all the appearances and the evidence of the moment, have earned the eternal recognition of the nation.'' Vichy's mayor, Claude Malhuret, described the votes against Petain as ``one of the first acts of resistance in our country.'' Malhuret also said France should be vigilant in countering a resurgence of racist and anti-Semitic rhetoric ``such as we heard before the war.'' Petain, who signed an armistice with the Germans on June 22, was 84 at the time, but widely respected across France. He was convinced Germany would win the war and that France had no alternative but to cooperate with Hitler. France's government, including Parliament members, had fled from Paris as German forces approached, going first to Tours on June 10, then to Bordeaux on June 14 and two weeks later to Vichy, a tranquil health spa. On July 10, the parliamentary majority adopted a text which said: ``The National Assembly gives all power to the government of the Republic, under the authority and the signature of Marshal Petain, for the purpose of promoting a new constitution of the French state.'' Of the 80 legislators who opposed Petain, 31 were incarcerated or put under house arrest during the war, two were killed and five died in captivity. Since the war, Vichy has struggled to live down its association with Nazi collaboration. In the 1930s, the town ranked as France's No. 1 mineral springs resort. Now it ranks 14th, and unemployment in the town of 30,500 is estimated at 15 percent. Malhuret described as ``irritating'' the link between Vichy and the collaborationists. ``If the town of Vichy was partly responsible, it would be less irritating,'' he told the French news agency Agence France-Presse. ``But that isn't the case. Nobody in Vichy went out in search of the government and the assembly.'' The Vichy government received little in return for its collaboration, exporting goods and labor to Germany in exchange for the privilege of running day-to-day administrative affairs. Only two-fifths of France was under Vichy's jurisdiction, the rest was occupied territory. In August 1944, as Allied forces swept through France, Petain fled Vichy and was arrested, then was allowed to leave for Switzerland. He returned voluntarily to France in April 1945, was tried for treason and sentenced to death. Charles De Gaulle commuted the sentence to life imprisonment and Petain died in 1951 on the Isle of Yeu, off France's Atlantic coast. In Paris, officials of the French Communist Party on Tuesday celebrated the 50th anniversary of an appeal by the outlawed Communist underground for resistance against Petain. Communist legislator Andre Lajoinie said the men who isssud the appeal represented ``the first resistance base on national territory.'' A radio appeal for Frenchmen to resist the Nazis had been broadcast from London on June 18 by De Gaulle.

DOC.HEAD: Ship Sets Sail Years After Radiation Leak
DOC.TEXT: Sixteen years after a radiation leak halted its maiden voyage, the experimental ship Mutsu set out Tuesday for its first attempt to sail under nuclear power, officials said. Technical problems and anti-nuclear protests that complicated anchorage and repair arrangements for Japan's only nuclear-powered ship accounted for the delay. Local police said 23 anti-nuclear activists protested the Mutsu's planned test by burning old tires on nearby shores as it sailed from Sekinehama port in Aomori prefecture, 360 miles northeast of Tokyo. The 8,242-ton ship used an auxiliary boiler as it headed for an area about 108 miles off the Pacific coast, said Yuwao Ikezawa, spokesman of the Atomic Energy Research Institute. Tests of its nuclear reactor were to start Friday, and a series of ocean trials lasting about 20 days will be conducted in an area where they would not hinder fishing operations, Ikezawa added. He said the reactor's output would be raised to 50 percent of full capacity in the first week and to 70 percent for another week to make sure the reactor was working properly. Before this year, the Mutsu's 36,000-kilowatt reactor had not been used since a leak was discovered in its protective shield just after it set out in 1974 for its maiden voyage. The ship was launched in 1969. After that leak was reported, the research vessel drifted for 50 days in the Pacific before residents of its home port in Aomori prefecture allowed it to return temporarily. After extensive repairs and remodeling of parts including the defective shielding, the ship had been anchored at Sekinehama since 1988. Institute officials have said that if the forthcoming tests go smoothly, the ship will make another test voyage in August and then a yearlong experimental voyage to collect data for possible future development of nuclear-powered commercial vessels. Following the tests, the Mutsu is to be retired.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty Denounces Worldwide Rights Abuses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Embargoed by source for release at 8 p.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: Using torture, murder and mass arrests, governments trampled the human rights of tens of thousands of people in 1989 to suppress conflicts stemming from ethnic or nationalist tensions, Amnesty International said. Despite democratic revolutions in Eastern Europe, reform in South Africa and signs of change in some black African countries, Amnesty's annual world survey of human rights painted a grim picture. Its report was to be released Wednesday. Cases cited in the human rights group's 138-country report ranged from children tortured in Iraq to a Spaniard sentenced for burning the flag; from alleged racial bias in American capital punishment to the jailing of Malawi's only neurosurgeon for criticizing the president; from death squads in El Salvador to draft refusers in Western Europe. The theme of this year's report was ``the suppression of ethnic and nationalist groups,'' which Amnesty said has often ``served to entrench bitter conflicts, dimmed prospects for dialogue and added to the toll of suffering and death.'' The survey saw this pattern in countries including Somalia, Ethiopia, Sudan, Sri Lanka, India, Burma, Indonesia, the Soviet Union, Yugoslavia, Tibet, Chad, Mauritania, Israel, Iran, Iraq, Turkey, Bulgaria, Guatemala and Brazil. ``Around the world, particularly where the tensions erupted into violence, tens of thousands of people became victims of security operations resulting in `disappearances' and extrajudicial executions,'' the report said. ``The conflicts ranged from local disputes over the cultural rights of distinctive ethnic groups through to full-scale confrontation over demands for autonomy or secession,'' it said. The demands were often non-violent, but in many instances, violent attacks or armed insurgency were dominant features, the report said. Amnesty International said it recognized that governments faced complex situations and, in some cases, armed groups which kidnapped, tortured and murdered opponents. But it said: ``None of these factors can every justify or excuse a government violating the basic human rights of any of its citizens or those over whom it exercises control.'' It said police and military forces in several western hemisphere nations dramatically increased their attacks on political opponents in 1989. In Eastern Europe, it said, new governments have emptied their prisons of dissidents, but it said dissenters are still harshly treated in Albania, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia. In the Middle East and North Africa, it said, killings, mass arrests and torture of political opponents continued, but there were also some signs of improvement. Governments in Asia have resorted to mass killings, torture, detentions and unfair trials to repress mass opposition movements, the report said. ``Prisoners of conscience in Asia ranged from a Buddhist monk in Vietnam to a 52-year-old doctor in Indonesia,'' it said. At least 1,000 people were killed and thousands were wounded when troops fired on crowds of unarmed protesters and bystanders in Beijing in June 1989 to suppress pro-democracy demonstrations, the report said, adding that ``an atmosphere of terror'' prevented any accurate count of the number of deaths. ``Dozens were publicly reported to have been sentenced to death or to terms of imprisonment after summary and unfair trials, and there were reports of secret executions,'' the report added. Only a few dozen executions in connection with the protests were reported publicly, but unofficial sources estimated several hundred people were executed secretly in Beijing after June 4, 1989, the report said. Thousands of people were arrested and held incommunicado, the report said. This year, Chinese authorities have announced the release of at least 784 prisoners. On a positive note, Amnesty International noted the release of political prisoners in Benin, Ethiopia, Somalia, South Africa and Namibia, and significant reductions in executions in South Africa and Nigeria. But in some cases, relaxations soon gave way to renewed repression, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Urged to Stay Away from Kenya
With AM-Kenya
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said Tuesday that it is advising American citizens to defer all non-essential travel to Kenya because of anti-government protests there. A department statement said recent demonstrations, accompanied by looting and clashes between police and rioters, have made conditions unsafe for travelers. While the largest demonstrations have occurred in the Nairobi area, the potential exists for disturbances elsewhere, the statement said. Americans who must travel to Kenya were advised to contact the American Embassy or Consulate on arrival. The protests began Saturday, when police used tear gas and gunfire to break up a pro-democracy rally in Nairobi, the capital of the East African nation.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty International Highlights Repression, Ethnic Tension
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Embargoed by source for release at 8 p.m. EDT.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-World Rights, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International's annual world survey of human rights highlighted these instances of ethnic or nationalist tensions being met by government repression: _ Thousands of Sri Lankans were reported to have ``disappeared'' or were summarily executed by government troops and paramilitary allies fighting an armed Tamil rebellion. _ In Somalia, 46 members of the Issaq clan, including children, reportedly were murdered by government soldiers in July. Similar reprisals were reported against members of the Ogadeni clan after a rebellion by Ogadeni soldiers. _ Forty-two members of the Dinka and Nuber communities in Sudan reportedly were summarily executed in October, and members of the Dinka, Nuber, Nuer and Shilluk communities have suffered gross human rights violations ``solely because of their ethnic origin.'' _ Twenty people were killed when Soviet troops broke up a peaceful demonstration in Tbilisi, Georgia in April, and police and troops assaulted an unarmed crowd of about 1,000 people in the western Ukraine in October. _ An unknown number of Tibetans were killed and more than 1,000 arrested when Chinese troops broke up an independence demonstration in Tibet in March 1989 and imposed martial law. Amnesty International said there were many reports of torture involving beatings, electric shocks and hanging by the arms. _ Israeli troops killed more than 260 unarmed Palestinians in the occupied territories, and 13,000 Palestinians were held in prisons or detention camps. _ Kurds have been subject to brutal treatment in Iraq, Iran and Turkey, the report said. Seven Kurds who surrendered to Iraqi authorities during an amnesty in February were executed, the report said, and Kurds were victims of a wave of secret executions in Iran that ended in January 1989. _ The report challenged the tactics used against the Irish Republican Army's armed campaign to drive Britain out of Northern Ireland. Amnesty International renewed its demand for judicial inquiries into several killings of IRA suspects by British security forces, claiming they were not adequately investigated.

DOC.HEAD: Recipe for a Book: Eisenhower's Cooking
DOC.TEXT: Next to the cover page of this book is a photograph of President Eisenhower's five-star tie with a stain circled and a note informing inquiring readers what the stain is. The stain came from Ike's vegetable soup _ and the recipe can be found on page 40 of this oversized 118-page volume. ``Ike the Cook,'' by Edward and Candace Russoli, includes 32 recipes by the nation's 34th president, and many anecdotes about his culinary skills, which apparently were considerable. It also has 172 photographs, including many with Eisenhower donning an apron or eating some of his own creations. From a young Kansan cooking squirrel during a camp out, to an Army officer who believed food was part of a soldier's paycheck and finally to a kitchen-wise president, the Russolis tell the story of Eisenhower' life _ through food. Ed Russoli admits it is a novel approach to a presidential biography. ``We're using food as a vehicle throughout the book,'' he said in a telephone interview. Russoli is himself a gourmet cook and one-time owner of an Italian restaurant in his native Allentown, Pa. The recipes in the book came from Secret Service agents who guarded Eisenhower, Columbia University in New York _ where Eisenhower briefly served as president _ and from the Eisenhower Library in Abilene. In fact, Eisenhower's recipe for homemade vegetable soup created quite a stir when it was published in a 1948 campus cookbook at Columbia University while Eisenhower was president. ``He later said he got more reaction from his recipe for vegetable soup than anything else he said while president of Columbia,'' Russoli said. The ``secret ingredient'' in Eisenhower's recipe was adding about a tablespoon of nasturtium stems to the soup, the authors say. The book is being published this year in conjunction with the 100th anniverary of Eisenhower's birth. The dinner tables of presidents also prompted last year's ``The White House Family Cookbook,'' written by Henry Haller, executive chef at the White House for five first families, and Virginia Aronson. It tells such tid-bits as what President Nixon ate for his final White House breakfast (poached egg and hash), how the Fords scrimped to help fight inflation (no first courses and few desserts), and the recipe for the ``monkey bread'' the Reagans eat at holidays. The Eisenhower book gives a curious reader a look at the president's palate. For example, Eisenhower was a firm believer in the values of red meat, and he believed that it prevented stomach trouble. ``His diet called for beef every day, and when on vacation he revealed that he might eat it 12 times a week because he loved having little breakfast steaks,'' Russoli said. ``Steak in general was on Ike's top 10 list.'' The president also liked to grill 3-inch steaks by placing them directly on white-hot coals. Russoli said he began researching the book in 1986 while working on yet on another volume _ this one about Republican presidents and their dietary habits. That book, called ``Grand Old Party Fare'' includes hundreds of the favorite recipes of 17 Republican presidents and seven GOP also-rans. That book will be completed soon, Russoli said. The recipes in the book vary from the basic Kansas ``Squirrel Stew with Leftovers'' to ``Sergeant Moaney's Ontario Northland Railway Roast Wild Goose,'' a recipe fit for White House receptions. And there's also the World War II favorite, ``In-a-Pinch Baked Beans.'' Ike's interest in cooking was a godsend to White House reporters, the book says. ``Kids and pets in the White House were always good copy, but a cooking president was sensational,'' the Russolis wrote. ``Quotes like `I mix my batter at night and let it stand until morning' perked up even the most blase veteran newsmen who were sure they had heard everything before.''

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Attack Plan to Reopen Plutonium Facility
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf, bgng, Mary Kayne... to UPDATE with 2 grafs of department comment
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Energy's plan to reopen a plutonium production plant as part of a nuclear cleanup program ``is like saying we need crack houses to fight drug addiction,'' an environmental group said today. The Institute for Energy and Environmental Research said in a study commissioned by the Hanford Education Action League of Spokane, Wash., that the plant on the department's Hanford Reservation in Eastern Washington is unsafe. The study also said that closing the 35-year-old plant could save $300 million to $400 million over the next 10 years. Timothy Tomastik, a public affairs officer for the Energy Department, said an environmental impact study of the plan to restart the plant is under way. Tomastik said he had not seen the study, but the organization's news release ``made it sound like we are trying to make the restart ... completely a cleanup operation, which is totally untrue. We have never maintained that at all.'' The plant was closed in December 1988, because of what the study described as environmental and safety concerns. In a five-year environmental cleanup plan issued last week, the department said the plant is needed to dispose of Hanford's remaining nuclear fuel rods. The plant, known as PUREX, is a nuclear reprocessing facility that extracts plutonium and uranium from the used rods for use in nuclear weapons and research. Approximately 2,100 tons of highly radioactive used rods are now stored in pools of water on the Hanford Reservation and some are leaking radioactivity into the water, the environmental group said. ``Saying that plutonium production at PUREX is needed for environmental cleanup is like saying we need crack houses to fight drug addiction,'' said Scott Saleska, staff scientist with the environmental group and chief author of the study. The organization said storing the rods under a dry inert gas such as helium or argon might be the safest way to handle them until a long-term disposal plan is worked out. Failing this, the study said, storage in capsules in water basins ``is likely to be preferable on environmental grounds'' to the existing plan. ``It is true that the existing situation with Hanford's used nuclear fuels is a real mess _ but that is largely because DOE ignored the situation and let the problem fester, instead of encapsulating the leaking fuel a decade ago,'' Saleska said. The study recommended that funds for the PUREX operation be canceled. It also recommended authorizing the $4 million to $5 million that Westinghouse, the principal contractor for the plant, has estimated that it would cost to encapsulate the rods. In a report issued July 3, DOE said it would cost about $6 billion in each of the next five years to store and clean up waste from nuclear weapons plants. This is nearly 50 percent more than had been estimated earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Off-Course Skydiver Lands on Moving Car
DOC.TEXT: A skydiver missed his target and landed feet first on a passenger car, smashing the windshield but suffering only bruises, a newspaper reported Tuesday. Ragnar Hoen told the Oslo newspaper Verdens Gang he assumes his insurance agent won't question his claim, but the deep footprints on the hood and roof of his car may raise some eyebrows. Hoen was driving at 50 mph Saturday near the airport at Skien, 62 miles southwest of Oslo, when the skydiver landed feet first on his car's hood, the newspaper said. ``I saw a pair of feet and somebody's rear end in my windshield and then it went bang. I had no idea what I had hit until I stopped and looked back at the parachutist in a ditch,'' Hoen said. The 20-year-old skydiver, not named in the report, suffered bruises and told the newspaper he planned to jump again Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Former W.Va. Governor Sentenced to Prison for Corruption
DOC.TEXT: Former Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. was sentenced today to five years and 10 months in prison for mail fraud, extortion, filing false income taxes and obstruction of justice. U.S. District Judge Walter Hoffman also fined Moore $170,000. The three-term Republican governor had faced up to 36 years in prison and $1.25 million in fines for crimes involving his 1984 campaign and his 1985-89 term in office. Hoffman sentenced Moore to concurrent terms of five years for extortion, six months for mail fraud and two years on each on two tax fraud counts. Moore received an additional 10 months for obstruction of justice in blocking a federal grand jury investigation into corruption in his administration. The longest-serving governor in West Virginia history was ordered to report to a federal prison in Petersburg, Va., on July 31. Hoffman held a hearing before the sentencing to go over disputed facts regarding Moore's May 8 guilty pleas, which the judge on Monday refused to let the former governor withdraw. Moore, 67, claimed he was pressured by federal prosecutors who gave him only 24 hours to consider a plea bargain. Hoffman said Moore failed to provide new information to justify the change. Hoffman today also said he saw no proof for prosecutors' contentions that Moore failed to cooperate in an ongoing two-year investigation into public corruption. The U.S. attorney's office also told Hoffman that Moore failed to accept responsibility for the crimes. ``He can't suck it up and say, `I did it,''' Assistant U.S. Attorney Joe Savage said. ``If there is one thing missing from that man, it's remorse.'' Also at issue were the sources of $100,000 Moore admitted funneling into his 1984 campaign fund. Savage said Moore has identified the sources for only $20,000. Moore's lawyer, William Hundley, said the $20,000 is all Moore can recall. Moore, who was indicted April 12, admitted extorting $573,000 from coal operator H. Paul Kizer of Beckley in return for a $2.1 million refund from the state's Black Lung Fund, which provides benefits to coal miners. Because Moore was never tried, some facts in the case came out for the first time in court today. Savage said Moore took a car on a test drive from a St. Albans dealership, never returned it and didn't pay for it. Hundley said Moore drove the car to the garage at the governor's mansion and parked it there. He did not move it after that. After Moore lost the 1988 election to Democrat Gaston Caperton, Tim Love, president of C&O Motors, contacted Moore and said he wanted money for the car, according to testimony from an Internal Revenue Service agent. Moore asked Love how much money he wanted. Love said $10,000. Moore replied that the car was now used and he didn't want to pay the full price, the agent said. Telephone messages to Love at the dealership weren't immediately returned today. Moore, a former six-term congressman who also served as governor from 1969 to 1977, is the second West Virginia governor to be convicted on federal charges. W.W. ``Wally'' Barron, a Democrat who served from 1961 to 1965, was convicted of bribing the foreman of a jury that acquitted him of bribery in 1968. Moore was acquitted in 1976 of extorting $25,000 from a financial holding company trying to get a state bank charter.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators: Nightclub Fire was Arson
DOC.TEXT: The fire that destroyed the landmark Gilley's country-western nightclub has been ruled arson, authorities said. Pasadena Fire Marshal Bill Yearout declined to reveal how or where Thursday's fire broke out. He said arson investigators have several leads and don't want to release details while the investigation continues. Gilley's had been closed since March 1989 because of a legal dispute between country-western singer Mickey Gilley and his one-time partner in the nightclub, Sherwood Cryer. Fire officials say souvenir hunters are taking pieces from the ruins of the building where the movie ``Urban Cowboy'' was filmed.

DOC.HEAD: Restaurateur Says He and Barry Smoked Opium
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs with editing.
DOC.TEXT: A Washington restaurateur testified today that he and Marion Barry smoked opium several times and that the two men repeatedly snorted cocaine at the mayor's home. ``I was always there for Mr. Mayor,'' Hassan Mohammadi testified at Barry's trial on drug and perjury charges. The Iranian-born Mohammadi said opium is a commonly used drug in that country and that the two men smoked it by putting the drug on the back of a spoon and warming it with the flame from a plumber's torch. They inhaled through a straw and part of a coat hangar tube in order to ``get the maximum smoke out of it,'' said Mohammadi. In July 1989 during a crab feast at Barry's house, Mmohammadi testified, the mayor asked ``if I had anything.'' Mohammadi said he did. The two went upstairs in Barry's home and ``we did some lines'' of cocaine ``inside the bathroom'' next to the main bedroom, said Mohammadi. Last November, just before Thanksgiving, Mohammadi said, Barry used cocaine in the basement of his own home, and also used it on other occasions at his own home. Mohammadi said he warned Barry about going to hotels after a public furor and criminal investigation in December 1988 of the mayor's visits to convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis at the Ramada Inn. ``You just have to slow down and you have to know who you are dealing with,'' Mohammadi said he cautioned the mayor. ``He said he is not going to go to any more hotels,'' Mohammadi said. ``I was a true friend for Mr. Mayor,'' Mohammadi testified at one point. ``I was always there for Mr. Mayor.'' Mohammadi testified that the two men boarded a pleasure boat moored at a marina in February 1989, and Barry ``did two lines'' of cocaine. On Monday, Mohammadi said he delivered cocaine to Barry in the mayor's office, gave it to him on 30 other occasions and snorted the drug with him several times on a 1987 trip to the Bahamas. Mohammadi said Barry never paid for the drugs. Mohammadi also said he paid for the hotel stay of Barry's female companion on the trip to the Bahamas and that the mayor helped himself to a $3,000-to-$4,000 pile of gambling chips that Mohammadi had purchased. ``How many times since you have known the defendant'' have you furnished him with drugs? Assistant U.S. Attorney Richard Roberts asked the witness. ``I would say about 30 times, maybe more,'' said Mohammadi, who was given a grant of immunity that bars using his own testimony against him. Did he ``ever force'' Barry to use the drugs? Roberts asked Mohammadi. ``Not at all,'' replied the restaurant operator, who said it was Barry who brought up the subject of cocaine. The mayor would ask ``are you loaded?'' said Mohammadi. He said he first witnessed Barry use cocaine in 1985 in an upstairs office above Pardi's restaurant, owned by the family of Mohammadi's wife. Using a rolled-up bill, Barry inhaled two lines of cocaine after a nightclub owner put the drug out on a table, said Mohammadi. After one coke-snorting session at Mohammadi's apartment, Barry carried what remained of the drug out of the bathroom, the witness said. ``I said `Mayor ... don't drop it''' as Barry put the cocaine in his breast pocket, Mohammadi testified. He said Barry even showed up at the restaurant in a four-wheel-drive vehicle during a snowy day in November 1987. ``I can't get anything because of the snowstorm,'' Mohammadi said he told the mayor. When they were in the Bahamas, Mohammadi said, they snorted cocaine together several times and Barry inserted the drug in marijuana cigarettes and smoked it, something Mohammadi said he hadn't seen before. ``They call it M.B. specials,'' Mohammadi said the mayor told him. Barry gestured to his groin and told the businessman that a Marion Barry special ``will go right down to the bottom,'' suggesting the drug is an aphrodisiac, Mohammadi testified. Barry is charged with 10 misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession, one misdemeanor count of conspiracy and three felony counts of lying to a federal grand jury about his alleged involvement with drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Behind the Show of Unity, Real Differences
With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: From a friendly class photo to a high-minded declaration on world peace and prosperity, public shows of harmony come easy to the economic summit partners. But major items on the agenda set each apart from the others. That goes double for the United States this time. President Bush stands in the minority in arguing against Western aid to the Soviet Union, and he's greatly outnumbered in refusing to set new goals for cutting global pollution. But that didn't shrink Bush's smile as he and his six summit partners marched shoulder-to-shoulder through an extravagant ceremony Monday. Harmony, after all, is a chief priority of these summits. After some choreographed posing for news cameras, the leaders disappeared into a Rice University hall for two hours of formal talks. Then it was back before the cameras, this time for the traditional group photograph and some light-hearted banter. It was clear before the Houston summit began that Bush would not be converted to the majority view on providing emergency financial aid to Moscow. So the real challenge behind the scenes was to find a way to move the issue down the diplomatic road, to leave it for later when the publicity stakes were lower. The U.S. position on aid to Moscow illustrates how, on some issues, each summit country has special reasons for marching to a different drummer. Bush says the American public won't accept giving money to Moscow until Gorbachev ends Soviet support for Cuba, a communist nation that is a political thorn in the American side but of relatively little concern to most of the other summit countries. On the key environmental issue at the summit _ how to respond to the threat of global warming caused by polluting industrial plants _ Bush worries that European and Canadian ideas on cutting pollution could damage the U.S. economy. Perhaps the most telling case of national interest concerns Japan. On the one hand it is alone among the participating countries in wanting to resume lending to China. The others in Houston say China has not moved far enough toward democratic reform. And yet Japan is staunchly against aiding the Soviet Union, agreeing with Bush that it's better to wait for more democratic reforms. History explains why Japan takes what appear, on the surface, to be contradictory stances. While the Japanese have a tradition of close business ties to China, they are still bitter that Josef Stalin seized the Kurile islands from them after Tokyo was defeated in World War II. Taizo Watanabe, the Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman, said Tokyo has a unique perspective on China, and that this special experience explains why it wants to resume lending despite the Chinese crackdown last year on a pro-democracy movement. ``We know more than anyone about what is going on there,'' said Watanabe. France, too, travels a lonely path on at least one summit issue. It wants the rich Western governments to forgive more of the foreign debt of the world's poorest nations. The U.S. position, accepted by most of its summit partners, is to consider debt relief only on a case-by-case basis. For West Germany, aid to the Soviet Union is the issue that sets it apart from the United States and several other nations in Houston, together with its push for more ambitious goals in cutting global pollution. The Germans face a unique political challenge in trying to win Soviet acceptance of NATO membership for a reunified German nation. The Bonn government has decided to do this by encouraging a huge Western aid program for Moscow, and by extending generous loans on its own. As with most tough issues put on the economic summit agenda, these problems won't be fully resolved in Houston. But, if past practice holds, the leaders will find a way to keep their differences from spoiling their show of unity.

DOC.HEAD: NY Doc Receives Yummy Award
DOC.TEXT: Some awards hang on the wall. Some just collect dust. But how many people can say their award is yummy? Dr. Joe Kramer can. Kramer received 1,000 pints of ice milk Tuesday from Ben & Jerry's ice cream company for his longtime community service. Kramer immediately turned around and invited children from his poverty-and drug-plagued Lower East Side neighborhood to a block party where he shared his palatable prize. ``I can't believe it when people come through like this,'' the 65-year-old Kramer said. ``This is going to make a lot of kids very happy.'' The kids feasted on reverse chocolate chunk, coffee almond fudge and sweet cream and cookies, just a few of the Vermont-based company's new line of reduced fat, reduced cholesterol ice milk. The honor, called Ben & Jerry's 1,000 Pints of Light Award, was given in conjunction with the non-profit Giraffe Project. The award is being given in seven major U.S. cities this summer to people who ``stick their necks out to make the world a better place,'' said David Hathaway of Ben & Jerry's. Recipients are nominated by their community. Kramer gave up a successful suburban practice 22 years ago and set up shop in the Lower East Side. His office is daily filled with patients suffering from illnesses caused by drug abuse, poverty and violence. He treats many for free.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Throws Out Lawsuit Against William Kunstler
DOC.TEXT: A judge ruled that subway gunman Bernhard Goetz cannot sue activist lawyer William Kunstler for libel for calling him a ``walking timebomb'' and a racist. In dismissing Goetz's libel suit Monday, state Justice Beatrice Shainswit said Kunstler's 1989 remarks were his ``overall views as he sees the case he has brought on behalf of Mr. Cabey.'' Darrell Cabey was one of four youths Goetz shot on a subway in 1984. Goetz, who is whiote, said the black youths were trying to rob him. They said they were panhandling. Goetz was acquitted on the most serious charges but was convicted of illegal gun possession. He served 8{-months in prison. Cabey was left paralyzed from the waist down by a bullet that shattered his spine. His $500 million lawsuit against Goetz is being handled by Kunstler. Goetz's suit also alleged Kunstler made libelous remarks in a 1987 poem, but the judge dismissed that charge because it was filed after a one-year statute of limitations had expired. The poem said Goetz shot the four without provocation.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Cubans Seek Refuge in Czechoslovak Embassy
DOC.TEXT: Seven Cubans, including five opposition activists, have sought refuge in Czechoslovakia's Havana Embassy, the state CTK news agency reported today. CTK's French-language service said the activists entered the embassy to demand Czech guarantees that they could leave Cuba for a planned weeklong visit to Czechoslovakia beginning July 15. The visit was to be part of a tour of Europe and the United States ``aimed at spreading the aims and programs of the Cuban opposition movement,'' CTK said. It did not elaborate. Zdenek Smrkovsky, a foreign ministry official in Prague, said the five men walked inside the embassy through the main door on Monday without incident. He said as far as he knew, there were no other cases of people seeking refuge in any other embassies in Havana. He said the men ``did not seek political asylum.'' Two more Cubans, who claimed to be students, climbed over the embassy's fence later and did ask for political asylum, CTK said. Cuban police then cordoned off the street leading to the mission, the news agency said. It identified the two as Igor Campana and Alejandro R. Lugo. Yugoslavia's Tanjug news agency quoted an unidentified spokesperson at the Cuban Foreign Ministry as saying the five opposition leaders ``must leave the embassy or stay there as long as the diplomatic mission would have them.'' He was quoted before the last two people entered the embassy. The activists belong to the Cuban Human Rights Committee, the Cuban Christian Democratic Movement and other opposition groups, CTK said. Cuba and Czechoslovakia were close allies before last winter's democratic revolution swept Czechoslovakia's Communist regime from power.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Attack Plan to Reopen Plutonium Facility
DOC.TEXT: An Energy Department plan to restart a plutonium-production plant to reprocess used nuclear fuel rods would create unnecessary radioactive waste and increase the danger of an explosion, an environmental group said Tuesday. The Institute for Energy and Environmental Research, in a study commissioned by the Hanford Education Action League of Spokane, Wash., recommended that the plant, on the department's Hanford Reservation in Eastern Washington, be permanently closed. The plant was completed in 1955 and used to extract uranium and weapons-grade plutonium from spent fuel rods from the N-reactor, a nuclear power-production facility. Both plants were shut down in 1988 because of safety concerns. About 2,100 tons of used fuel rods are stored in two tanks. One has leaked and been repaired but could leak again, releasing radioactive material, the study said. The department has asked Congress for $34 million in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 to restart the plutonium-production plant next year. Arjun Makhijani, a scientist with the environmental group and one of the study's authors, told a news conference, ``We think reprocessing is a dangerous technology in itself and you should not be creating liquid waste.'' The study said that the process would increase the risk of an explosion in the waste tanks. Makhijani conceded that this risk ``might be small'' but said it should be guarded against because ``the consequences would be huge.' The department and Westinghouse Hanford Company, the principal contractor for the plutonium plant, have denied that a resumption of processing would increase the risk of an explosion. Timothy Tomastik, a public affairs officer for the department, said an environmental impact study of the restart is under way. Tomastik said he had not seen the study, but, he added, the organization's news release ``made it sound like we are trying to make the restart ... completely a cleanup operation, which is totally untrue.'' The study also said leaving the plant closed could save $300 million to $400 million over the next 10 years. The environmental organization said a five-year environmental cleanup plan issued by the department July 3 indicates the plant is needed to dispose of Hanford's remaining nuclear fuel rods. ``Saying that plutonium production at (the plant) is needed for environmental cleanup is like saying we need crack houses to fight drug addiction,'' said Scott Saleska, staff scientist with the environmental group and chief author of the study. The organization said storing the rods under a dry inert gas such as helium or argon would be the safest way to handle them until a long-term disposal plan is worked out. Failing this, the study said, storing the rods in capsules in water basins ``is likely to be preferable on environmental grounds'' to the existing plan. It recommended authorizing the $4 million to $5 million that Westinghouse has estimated it would cost to encapsulate the rods. The institute said the study was financed by a grant from the Washington State Department of Ecology.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Eulogizes Snyder
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson eulogized Mitch Snyder today for his work on behalf of the homeless and told mourners at Snyder's funeral, ``we will not surrender, the work continues.'' Jackson was joined by Mayor Marion Barry and entertainers Martin Sheen and Cher at a funeral service attended by about 1,000 people at the shelter for the homeless founded by Snyder. Barry attended during the noon recess of his trial at the nearby U.S. District Courthouse on drug and perjury charges. Jackson urged the crowd to continue Snyder's work, saying, ``We will not surrender, the work continues.'' The crowd responded by chanting, ``Mitch, Mitch.'' ``Hug someone next to you and say I love you,'' Jackson told the mourners. Margaret Moore, who lives in a shelter about two miles from the one where Snyder's funeral was held, said earlier, ``I always liked what he did.'' ``I didn't know anything about homeless people until I became one _ I thought they all were bums. But I listened to him, and it helped me to learn that the homeless are people, too.'' Moore, who lost her apartment last month because she used rent money for drugs, said Snyder's commitment to the downtrodden helped her regain control over her life. ``He made you feel like you were somebody,'' Moore said quietly. ``I never met him, but it was clear from seeing him on TV what he felt for the homeless _ a lot of love. Real Christian-like.'' Snyder, 46, was found hanged last Thursday inside his room at the shelter, an apparent suicide. A note nearby outlined difficulties he was having in his relationship with Carol Fennelly, his companion and co-worker for 13 years. ``He was a great man, perhaps a bit too selfless,'' said Ronald Williams, a volunteer at Snyder's shelter. ``He learned how to love everybody but himself.'' Inside the shelter, security guard Mike Hughes remembered Snyder as someone ``who gave everyone a chance.'' ``You came here, and as long as you didn't get a fat head and get lazy, you could get a chance _ Mitch was someone who gave everyone a chance,'' said Hughes, who came to the shelter five months ago after a drug problem cost him his job, his marriage and his apartment. Now, Hughes works in the shelter's kitchen and then pulls a shift as a security guard at night. ``Another thing _ Mitch would always be real friendly, ask you how you are doing,'' Hughes continued. ``But if you used or sold drugs, you were out. In the last few months, they've made real headway getting rid of crackheads here.'' Outside the shelter, Williams ushered quiet bands of mourners from the heat into the air-conditioned shelter basement where the viewing was held. ``We're expecting about 3,000,'' Williams said. ``It's going to be a long day.'' Snyder's death will be a blow to the homeless movement, but it also may serve as an inspiration, Williams said. ``I think ... it is going to make people who have become a bit complacent stand up,'' Williams said. ``Sometimes it takes a jolt to make you realize that you have to do a lot yourself, and he was the prime example of how one man can make a difference.''

DOC.HEAD: Club Wants to Convert Former Mortuary Into Haunted House
DOC.TEXT: The Kiwanis Club wants to lease a former mortuary owned by the city and convert it into a haunted house for Halloween. But one city commissioner has a response ready: boo. The Kiwanis Club will take its plan to the commission Wednesday. ``We've had enough problems over that property as it is without making a joke out of it,'' Commissioner Cathy Anderson said. ``We have enough skeletons in the closet in Hollywood already.'' The Mediterranean-style home, built in 1924, was the site of the Johnson-Foster Funeral Home for 30 years. The city paid $1.5 million earlier this year to buy it for the Art and Culture Center. The purchase sparked an investigation by the Broward County State Attorney's Office, which filed a non-criminal charge against the former city attorney of violating the state's open government laws. Anderson said a widow who had her husband's funeral at Johnson Foster told her she also found the proposal ``very distasteful.'' Jared Anton, head of the Kiwanis Club's Halloween committee, said the club did not intend to cause a controversy. Club members simply thought the 12,000-square-foot home would offer plenty of parking and an ideal location for a haunted house, he said. ``I wouldn't insult anyone by having coffins and corpses in there,'' he said. ``It'll have moaning and witches and a cauldron and all that.''

DOC.HEAD: Leaders to Consider New World Bank Loans for China
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates in top 6 grafs with draft declaration, picking up in 2nd graf pvs, The issue
DOC.TEXT: Western leaders will take a step toward resumption of World Bank loans to China, according to a draft of the Houston economic summit's final political declaration. The leaders of seven major industrial nations _ six Western democracies and Japan _ were to call for exploration of additional international loans to promote reforms in China, the draft said. The World Bank has approved only $580 million in loans to China in the past year, all linked to human need. At a post-midnight briefing, a Japanese government spokesman had said Japan's prime minister, Toshiki Kaifu, told other leaders at a working dinner session that his country would gradually lend more than $5 billion to China. But the draft declaration does not address that issue. In general, it reaffirms a position taken by the seven countries at their 1989 meeting on holding back economic cooperation with China but also taking into account changes that have taken place since the violent suppression of the pro-democracy movement last year. The issue of resuming assistance to China dominated a working dinner session among the leaders at the Greek-style Bayou Bend mansion at the end of the summit's first day Monday, said Japanese foreign ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe. The seven nations participating in the summit all suspended aid and loans to China last year after condemning the bloody suppression of pro-democracy demonstrations and the arrest of suspected dissidents. ``We believe that assistance would support economic and political reform in China,'' said Kaifu, according to the foreign ministry. The Japanese loans are to be for irrigation, infrastructure and other non-military projects that will be open to international bidding and not necessarily built by Japanese companies, the spokesman said. ``We are not doing this for the benefit of our country,'' Kaifu was quoted as saying. The Japanese government has said it believes the economic stability of China is essential to regional stability. Japanese officials have been talking about the possibility of restoring the final third of the $15 billion loan agreement but did not confirm that such action would be taken until the Bayou Bend meeting. Watanabe said the summit leaders ``almost unanimously recognized'' that China must not be allowed to drift into isolation. The spokesman declined to disclose any comments by participants other than Kaifu. He said, however, that some leaders drew a comparison between Japan's plan to restore loans to China and its refusal to give economic assistance to the Soviet Union. Others, he said, viewed this as an unreasonable comparison because there is no danger of the Soviet Union drifting into isolation. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and French Prime Minister Francois Mitterand have been pushing for economic assistance to Moscow. President Bush and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher oppose aid to the Soviets but have not opposed bilateral action by Japan to help China. Others attending the dinner session at the 29-room mansion donated as a museum by the late philanthropist Ima Hogg included Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti and Jacques Delors, president of the Commission of the European Communities. Watanabe, who has held several sessions with reporters to explain the Japanese position on summit issues, said progress on human rights and political reform in China will be closely monitored as the loans are restored. The Japanese made no attempt to get other summit leaders to join in a resumption of assistance to China, he said, maintaining that Japan's historic and geographic closeness to China give it a better understanding of developments in the country. ``We are not almighty ... but we may know more about certain aspects,'' he said. The Chinese have made progress in lifting curfews and releasing political prisoners and those in China's government who support reforms need to be encouraged, he said. He said the loan committed to by former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita `is not something which can be sort of thrown away.''

DOC.HEAD: Death Row Inmate Convicted Again in Rape-Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A mentally retarded man whose death sentence was thrown out by the U.S. Supreme Court was convicted a second time in the slaying of a 22-year-old woman. Johnny Paul Penry, 34, was tried again because the Supreme Court said evidence of his mental retardation should have been considered in deciding his punishment. The jury's verdict was announced Monday after 2{ hours of deliberations. Testimony in the punishment phase begins Wednesday. Penry has been on death row for the 1979 slaying of Pamela Moseley Carpenter. Mrs. Carpenter was raped, beaten and stabbed in the chest in her Livingston home on Oct. 25, 1979. She was able to give a general description linking Penry to the attack before she died. In addition, Penry gave two written confessions and made three incriminating statements, all of which were admitted into evidence. Defense lawyers contended that investigators took advantage of Penry's mental impairments _ whether they meant to or not _ to get the confessions. ``I've never been satisfied he is guilty, and I'm still not,'' said defense attorney John Wright. ``But we're still alive, so we'll fight another round'' in the punishment hearing. Penry has an IQ estimated at between 50 and 60 and the reasoning capacity of a 7-year-old.

DOC.HEAD: Precede HOUSTON
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 11 grafs new with tour of Mission San Jose, editing changes; pickup pvs 10th graf bgng, On Monday; Joci in 6th graf is CQ.
DOC.TEXT: As world leaders at the seven-nation economic debated the world's future, their spouses toured this historic city for a glimpse of Texas' past. First Lady Barbara Bush led the summit wives on a 20-minute tour of Mission San Jose, one of five old Spanish missions still standing in San Antonio. The fort-like stone mission was built in 1720 by a Franciscan priest for teaching Christianity and European culture to the Indians. Mrs. Bush's guests included France's Danielle Mitterrand, Canada's Mila Mulroney, Italy's Livia Andreotti and Japan's Sachiyo Kaifu. Britain's Denis Thatcher, the only male summit spouse, skipped the tour. Hannelore Kohl, wife of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, and Marie Delors, wife of European Commission President Jacques Delors, did not accompany their husbands to Texas. After touring the mission, the women went to a private luncheon at the home Joci and Joe Straus, Jr., longtime friends of the Bushes, followed by a tour of the Alamo and the renovated Majestic Theater. At one time, San Antonio was a contender as the economic summit site, but it lost out to Houston, President Bush's adopted hometown. The Alamo is the site of the historic 1836 battle between the Mexican army and men led by Col. William Travis who were fighting for Texas' independence from Mexico. Mexican Gen. Santa Anna's troops greatly outnumbered the Alamo's defenders, who were besieged for 14 days before the Mexicans attacked. All 189 of Travis' men were killed. The incident gave birth to the battle cry, ``Remember the Alamo!'' used by other Texans who fought for freedom. After visiting San Antonio, the spouses were returning to Houston, where they planned to tour the Texas Medical Center on Wednesday, the final day of the summit. On Monday, the spouses were guests of Betty and Hugh Liedtkes, close friends of the Bushes, for a dinner in the upscale Memorial neighborhood in Houston. Liedtke is a wealthy oil man who knew Bush when the president was in the oil business in Texas before entering politics. The menu included quail, gazpacho soup, shrimp creole remoulade, poached snapper and asparagus. Dessert was called Strawberries Summit. Bush and Liedtke met years ago in West Texas while both were in the oil business, and they helped form Zapata Petroleum. Eventually, the company's investors spilt, although Liedtke and Bush remained friends. Liedtke is the former chief of Houston-based Pennzoil Co., the oil company that won an $10.3 billion judgment in 1985 from Texaco Inc. over Texaco's takeover of Getty Oil Co. Pennzoil later settled for $3 billion. Liedtke is still chairman of Pennzoil's board.

DOC.HEAD: Asteroid Passes a Mere 3 Million Miles From Earth
DOC.TEXT: An asteroid sped past Earth at a comparatively tiny distance of 3 million miles today, scientists said. The asteroid, estimated at 300 feet to 1,000 feet in diameter, made one of the closest crossings of Earth orbit observed in 50 years, the Jet Propulsion Laboratory said. The rocky object, dubbed 1990 MF, was located on June 26 by JPL planetary scientist Eleanor Helin at Palomar Observatory. Helin heads the Palomar Planet-Crossing Asteroid Survey, a project to systematically search for asteroids crossing near Earth. The asteroid was 8 million miles from Earth and traveling approximately 12,500 mph when spotted. It was then tracked last week by Arecibo Observatory in Puerto Rico and by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Deep Space Network at Goldstone, Calif. Initial calculations indicate the asteroid has an elongated orbit of 161 million miles and takes two years and four months to complete each orbit. Scientists continued to track it from Siding Spring, Australia; Mount John Observatory, New Zealand; the Infrared Telescope Facility at Mauna Kea, Hawaii; and Harvard observing station at Oak Ridge, Mass. The asteroid brightened and accelerated as it approached Earth. It was expected to surpass 22,000 mph at closest approach. The JPL sky survey team has found 39 near-Earth asteroids since beginning the program in 1973.

DOC.HEAD: Atlanta Fires School Superintendent
DOC.TEXT: The school board has fired its superintendent, citing a lack of ``mutual trust and cooperation.'' Superintendent J. Jerome Harris emerged from the executive session of the board Monday night and refused to comment other than to say he had been relieved. School Board President D.F. Glover said Harris had been fired, effective immediately, although he will still receive his $112,500-a-year salary until his contract expires in 1992. Lester W. Butts, a special assistant to Harris and the principal of Douglass High School, will take over as interim superintendent. Since he was hired Aug. 1, 1988, from the New York City system to replace Alonzo Crim, Harris's tenure was marked by continued controversy. Teachers complained he was harsh and arrogant, but his run-ins with the school board were more critical. In December, the board gave Harris until Jan. 31 to renew his state superintendent's certificate, which he did. He also was criticized for failing to disclose that an assistant superintendent had been accused of plagiarizing a doctoral dissertation. In March, he was questioned by the board for spending $400,000 on consulting fees during a six-month period. ``The board regrets the need to take this action but has concluded a change in leadership must be made,'' Glover said in a statement. ``The school system has not had the sense of teamwork which is necessary to achieve and sustain progress, and there has not been a good working relationship between the board and the superintendent based on mutual trust and cooperation.''
