DOC.HEAD: Leaders Ponder Soviet Aid After Pumping Billions Into Eastern Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates thruout to make quotes conform with official communique
DOC.TEXT: Western leaders today welcomed the political and economic change that has swept Eastern Europe and urged Romania to join its neighbors in adopting reforms. ``Europe is at the dawn of a new era,'' President Bush and leaders of six other rich democracies said in their final political communique. ``We welcome enthusiastically the profound and historic changes sweeping the (European) continent,'' the leaders said on the second day of their annual economic summit. They said they will use every opportunity to push for a united and free Europe and expressed pleasure at the impending merger of the two German states, which they said would offer a ``major contribution'' to stability. They urged Romania, where there has been violent repression of anti-government demonstrators, to join in the ``positive trend'' under way in neighboring countries. The Western nations already have promised billions of dollars in loans, food and other assistance to Moscow's once-staunch allies in Eastern Europe. But they are still undecided about what to do for the Soviet Union. Their decision could be crucial for Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, who is trying to save his embattled economic reform program of perestroika. A year ago, at their summit in Paris, the leaders tapped the European Community, the 12-nation trading bloc, to find ways to help Poland and Hungary, which were just beginning to revamp their backward economies. Since then, the community has scrambled to bring together two-dozen Western countries and drum up commitments of more than $12 billion in a variety of aid for Poland and Hungary. The assistance ``is making a major contribution'' to reviving the stricken economies of Poland and Hungary, said the community in a report on the year-long program. ``It has underpinned a radical stabilization program in Poland, which might otherwise have proved too risky, and helped both countries to begin modernizing their economies,'' it said. Because of the riches promised by the program, other nations in Eastern Europe have appealed for help. Last week, the foreign ministers of the Group of 24 _ the Western nations taking part in the program _ admitted Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, East Germany and Yugoslavia. Romania was temporarily refused membership because of the recent violent repression of anti-government demonstrators there. No specific sums were promised to the new members, but their addition to the program will likely mean billions of dollars in help. To gain admittance, the emerging democracies must commit themselves to the rule of law, respect for human rights, introduce multi-party political systems, hold free and fair elections, and impose economic reforms. ``Leaders in Central and Eastern Europe who seek radical change in their countries' political and economic systems, accept the conditionality attaching to (Western) assistance as a spur to reform,'' said the community's report. ``It is also a guarantee to their peoples that the international community is paying close attention to the respect for political and economic freedom in their countries,'' it said. In setting conditions, Western officials hope to avoid pouring money into the economies only to have it squandered. They contend loans granted to Poland in the 1970s were wasted because of a poorly functioning economy. Poland now is having problems paying back its foreign debt of about $40 billion. East European officials say the toughest part of their work is changing their centrally planned economies into the free-market models practiced in the West. To do that, the countries must start from scratch. They have to phase out government subsidies to farmers and others, stabilize prices, strengthen their virtually worthless currencies and allow private citizens to own property. They also must create banking systems and develop labor markets, complete with social security measures. ``These are welcome, indeed indispensable, changes but they may well create transitional problems,'' said the community's report. The Soviet Union could try to buy more goods from Western nations, rather than its neighbors in the East, it said. ``A further contraction in trade among the East Europeans could exacerbate economic difficulties just as the reform process enters a critical phase,'' the report said. Such drastic changes will likely cause, at least temporarily, higher unemployment and falling living standards. ``The removal of subsidies and of guaranteed lifetime employment will test the social fabric and the libertarian values of the peoples involved,'' the report said. The Western nations want their money to be used to overcome some of these obstacles.

DOC.HEAD: Italy Preparing to Ferry Out Albanians Now in Embassies
With PM-Albania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES urgent series, ADDS byline; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Albania is negotiating with the United Nations for Italy to evacuate by boat the thousands of Albanians who have sought refuge in nearly a dozen embassies in Tirana, the Foreign Ministry said today. Italy has begun preparations to ferry the asylum-seekers from Albania's Adriatic port city of Durres to either Brindisi or Otranto on the Italian coast, said a ministry spokesman. A representative of U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar was in Tirana, the Albanian capital, negotiating the departure procedures with the Albanian government on behalf of the embassies where Albanians have taken refuge. ``We hope the operation can begin by the end of the week,'' said the official, speaking under the ministry ground rule of anonymity. There are more than 5,000 Albanians in the various embassies. About 800 are in the Italian Embassy and more than 2,000 are believed to have taken refuge in the West German Embassy. The Italian government was working on contracting commercial vessels to bring out the Albanians, the Foreign Ministry official said, adding he expected that several trips would have to be made to evacuate them all. The first 51 Albanians allowed to leave departed by plane and landed in Czechoslovakia today. Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel sent his official airplane to Tirana for the refugees. The asylum seekers began taking refuge in the embassies on June 28 in a bid to escape Europe's last Communist bastion. Some dodged police bullets as they climbed over embassy gates. In a telephone interview with the Italian news agency AGI, Italy's ambassador in Tirana, Giorgio De Andreis, said today the embassy had completed the paperwork to obtain exit permits for the Albanians in his embassy. He said the situation inside was calm because the Albanians ``finally see the light at the end of the tunnel.'' ``Nothing is decided yet. We hope to resolve it soon.'' He told the news agency that most of the Albanians in the embassy consider Italy only the first leg of their emigration and want to go on to the United States, Canada and Britain.

DOC.HEAD: State Court Upholds Colorado's English-Only Law
DOC.TEXT: The state Supreme Court has rejected a challenge to Colorado's official English law, which Hispanic opponents call insulting and discriminatory. The challenge to the 1988 ballot initiative did not address the official English issue directly, but questioned the way election laws are applied. ``The proponents of English only were shown repeatedly to have racial motives involved in their movement,'' said attorney Kenneth Padilla, who represented plaintiff Rita Montero. ``They had an election which should never have been held.'' Montero, a member of the National Coalition Against English Only, alleged that Secretary of State Natalie Meyer improperly allowed backers of official English to collect new petition signatures after failing to present enough valid ones by deadline. But Meyer barred opponents from challenging the new signatures, saying the challenge wasn't timely, the lawsuit said. The high court on Monday ruled 6-3 that state regulations affecting voter initiatives should be read liberally, to prevent thwarting the public's right to create laws. The law, which was approved by 64 percent of voters, amended the Colorado constitution to declare English the state's official language. Sixteen other states have similar laws. Proponents of the law said their main goal was to force the government to use English, but the governor of Colorado and mayor of Denver issued executive orders allowing the government to provide official information, such as voting regulations, in English and Spanish. The law has been blamed for some instances of discrimination against Hispanics and Asian immigrants in Colorado, including one where a public school bus driver ordered students to stop speaking Spanish on the bus. Montero said she was unsure whether the coalition would continue to challenge the law. State Rep. Barbara Philips, who sponsored the initiative, was unavailable for comment. But Philips' lawyer, Shannon Robinson, said the ruling defends people's access to the ballot. ``They're not saying it's unconstitutional. Nothing about the amendment itself warrants reversal,'' she said. ``We feel the election laws were properly qualified by the secretary of state and they (opponents) had their day in court.''

Baker Meeting With Foreign Minister Postponed For Health Reasons
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's push for Mideast negotiations was delayed Tuesday as Israel sent word its foreign minister was not well enough to meet next week in Paris with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. The foreign minister, David Levy, is recovering at home from surgery for a circulatory ailment. Levy's physicians concluded after Baker proposed the meeting that his health would not permit him to travel to France, the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said. Baker, attending an economic summit meeting here, called again for Israeli negotiations with Palestinian Arabs. He said all seven democracies assembled here had concluded such talks offered the ``greatest potential'' for a Mideast settlement. U.S. efforts to promote negotiations went into a tailspin in March with the collapse of the Israeli government over Baker's formula for the negotiations. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir objected to Arab-sponsored provisions to include Palestinians deported from the West Bank and others with homes in East Jerusalem. The Israeli leader viewed the provisions as a challenge to his nation's retention of the entire city of Jerusalem as its capital and advancing Arab demands to recover the West Bank. But now that Israel has formed a new government the Bush administration is eager to try again. Baker has met in Washington with Egyptian Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid and wrote Levy last Thursday proposing the Paris meeting. Baker already had plans to go to the French capital for sessions on Germany and a talk with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. His letter to Levy complimented the foreign minister as a ``problem-solver'' while describing himself as one, as well, diplomatic sources said. At the same time, Baker restated the provisions that Israel had opposed. Spokswoman Tutwiler stressed Levy's health was the only reason for not holding the meeting. She said Baker would try to reschedule it later.

DOC.HEAD: Accomplishments of the Party Congress; What Remains to be Done
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Here is a look at the accomplishments of the 28th Communist Party congress after eight days, as well as what remains to be done:
ACCOMPLISHMENTS: Mikhail S. Gorbachev was re-elected as party leader Tuesday in a one-sided race against Siberian strike leader Teimuraz Avaliani after seven others who were nominated backed out.

Gorbachev won a critical power struggle Monday for a virtually new Communist Party Politburo, with delegates voting to require the body to include the general secretary, his deputy and the first secretaries of the 15 Soviet republics.
Gorbachev rebuffed attempts Sunday by delegates to evaluate each member of the Politburo, getting them to agree instead to pass judgment on the entire Central Committee and the Politburo as a whole.

Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic, warned party traditionalists Friday that if they didn't reform, they will end up like Communists in Eastern Europe: facing prosecution for ruining society.
Regional party leaders on July 4 accused Gorbachev's leadership of cowardice and indecision, but the speakers themselves displayed no new ideas and no alternative to re-electing him party leader.
Kremlin hard-liners, led by conservative Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev, on July 3 launched fierce attacks on Gorbachev's reforms in the economy, politics, the military and foreign policy.

On the first day, July 2, Gorbachev attacked bureaucrats for hindering his reforms. He admitted that the leadership made mistakes during his tenure but also blamed the ``heavy legacy'' of previous leaders.

WHAT REMAINS TO BE DONE: _ Elect a new Central Committee, which in turn will choose a new Politburo. _ Elect a deputy general secretary, a new post that some delegates said would be filled by a Gorbachev protege. _ Adopt a platform for the Communist Party.

DOC.HEAD: Gore Says Two Leaking Fixtures Were Installed Despite Failing Testing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs with editing.
DOC.TEXT: Two plumbing fixtures were installed on the space shuttles despite failing initial tests for leaks, Sen. Al Gore, D-Tenn., said today. They were among seven such fixtures that did not pass tests, he said. Gore said the hydrogen plumbing fixtures, called umbilicals, were tested with liquid nitrogen using a simulated spacecraft part on one side. When the units failed the test they were retested in another way, he said. NASA spaceflight Director William Lenoir denied that the parts failed the test. He said retesting in a different manner was a normal part of the procedure. Lenoir said the umbilicals were first tested against what isunit which simulates where the umbilicals would called a slave be attached to the space shuttle orbiter. ``The slave unit is not flight hardware, therefore it is more likely to be the source of a leak than is the flight hardware,'' said Lenoir. He denied that the test was redesigned in order to assure that the umbilicals would pass. When leaks were detected in the first test, Lenoir said, the slave unit was removed and a blank plate was substituted. This was done, he said, because it was assumed the leak was from the rnings were $2,000, or $30 an hour, after expenses. That compares to the $7 an hour from the legitimate jobs that 75 percent of the probationers reported holding. ``We came to this study from an employment perspective,'' said Karen Hastie Williams, chairwoman of the Committee on Strategies to Reduce Chronic Poverty, one of the groups that commissioned the study. ``We hoped to identify employment and training strategies to convince drug dealers to end their involvement in the underground economy and join the legitimate work force.'' But, conceded economist Peter Reuter, ``Even creation of considerably higher paying legitimate jobs probably wouldn't get us very far. Dealers would still have smaller total incomes than they can earn now by supplementing their regular wages with drug selling. Also, many of them have expensive drug habits.'' Reuter, the report's principal author, said in an interview that, while most street-level sales were by blacks, the availability of drugs in Washington affects not just the city's predominantly black population. ``Our figures show that there are 79,000 cocaine addicts in the Washington metropolitan area and over 78 percent of them live in suburban areas,'' he said. ``Therefore, a lot of people who are involved in drug transactions may not be black, but are suburban whites who come into the city to make purchases and who take the drugs back to their communities for sale or use.'' While a typical city street dealer's earnings aren't enough to finance flashy cars and lavish lifestyles, it is the image of such luxuries that draw many young men into selling drugs, Reuter said in an interview. ``People such as Rayful Edmond III (a convicted city cocaine kingpin) send the wrong messages to many people who are considering getting involved in selling drugs. They see that people like Edmond, who was able to create a large illegal drug organization, living what they believe to be a high lifestyle _ but they never see the downside, the consequences that can result from such activity.'' Edmond, on trial on a murder charge, has already been sentenced to life in prison without parole on a string of drug convictions. The study found that dealers active at least two days a week face a 22 percent chance of going to prison, a 7 percent chance of severe injury and a 1.4 percent chance of being killed _ a fatality rate 100 times that of the general work force. Given those risks, the report said, ``long periods of steady earnings are unlikely to be common.'' Looking at black men born in 1967, the study found that up to one in six had been charged with selling drugs by the time he turned 20. For the future, the researchers said, ``the ratio is likely to be closer to one in three before that age group reaches 30.'' The study held out some hope among the youngest group surveyed _ the 387 ninth and tenth graders. While one in six was selling drugs, only about 11 percent were using them. ``That could mean that anti-drug messages may be getting through to the younger population in the city,'' Reuter said, adding, however, ``The downside is that many juvenile sellers are involved in other delinquency-related offenses.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a text of the statement on transnational issues given Tuesday at the 1990 economic summit of industrialized nations: Terrorism= We, the heads of state or government, reaffirm our condemnation of terrorism in all its forms, our commitment to make no concessions to terrorists or their sponsors, and our resolve to continue to cooperate in efforts to combat terrorism. We demand that those governments which provide support to terrorists end such support immediately. We are determined not to allow terrorists to remain unpunished, but to see them brought to justice in accordance with international law and national legislation. We welcome the recent release of several hostages, but remain deeply concerned that hostages are still being held, some for more than five years. Their ordeal and that of their families must end. We call for the immediate, unconditional and safe release of all hostages and for an accounting of all persons taken hostage who may have died while being held. We call on those with influence over hostage-takers to use their influence to this end. We note with deep concern the continuing threat presented to civil aviation by terrorist groups, as demonstrated by such outrages as the sabotage of civil aircraft over Lockerbie, Scotland, on Dec. 21, 1988, above Niger on Sept. 19, 1989, and over Colombia on Nov. 27, 1989. We reiterate our determination to fight terrorist assaults against civil aviation. Accordingly, we will continue our cooperation to negotiate a convention requiring the introduction of additives into plastic explosives to aid in their detection. We pledge to work to strengthen international civil aviation security standards. Consistent with this objective, we note the importance of making available training and technical assistance to other nations. We support initiatives undertaken through the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) regarding this issue. We will work together with ICAO to expand such assistance.

Non-proliferation= We discussed the threat to international security posed by the proliferation of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons, and of ballistic missile weapons delivery systems. With regard to nuclear proliferation, we take special note of the recent declaration issued by the European Council in Dublin on that subject. That document underscored the great importance attached to the maintenance of an effective international nuclear non-proliferation regime and the need to make every effort to contribute to strengthening non-proliferation and encouraging the participation of further countries in the regime. The Treaty on Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) is an important element of that regime. We further endorse the EC's call for all states to apply IAEA safeguards on as universal a basis as possible. We also urge all nuclear suppliers to adopt nuclear export control measures equivalent to the Nuclear Suppliers Group Guidelines. Whether NPT parties or not, we commit ourselves to working actively to secure a satisfactory outcome to nuclear non-proliferation discussions in the forthcoming months, including those at the Fourth Review Conference of the NPT. We hope that these discussions will contribute to the achievement of as broad a consensus as possible in favor of an equitable and stable non-proliferation regime. Such a regime should be based on an indispensable balance between the non-proliferation of arms and the development of peaceful and safe uses of nuclear energy. The global community has focused for decades on nuclear proliferation, especially when combined with advanced missile delivery systems. Today we also face new and growing problems from the proliferation of chemical and biological weapons. With regard to chemical and biological proliferation, we commit ourselves to pursue efforts to prevent the diversion of chemical precursors at a national level, as well as in the relevant Western fora. We similarly commit ourselves to be vigilant about the danger of potential diversions in the field of biological technologies. We endorse a complete ban on chemical weapons, through an effective and verifiable treaty, as the only long-term guarantee against the proliferation of chemical weapons. We believe an important step toward achieving such a treaty was made in the recent U.S.-Soviet agreement on destruction and non-production of chemical weapons and the recent declaration of intent by NATO states to become original signatories to the Chemical Weapons Convention. We reiterate our determination, first expressed at the 1989 Paris Conference on Chemical Weapons, to redouble the effort at the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva to resolve the remaining issues and to conclude the Convention at the earliest date. We also urge all states to become parties as soon as it is concluded. Similarly, as the 1991 Review Conference on the Biological Weapons Convention approaches, we call on all nations that have not become party to the Convention to do so and to participate in confidence-building measures designed to strengthen its effectiveness. We wish to highlight the importance of dealing with the related threat of ballistic missiles capable of delivering nuclear, chemical and biological weapons. We note especially the contribution of the Missile Technology Control Regime (MTCR) to our joint efforts to control missile proliferation. We applaud the recent decisions of additional nations to adhere to the MTCR, and we call upon all nations to observe the MTCR Guidelines.

DOC.HEAD: Pageant Officials Upset Because Miss Washington Lives in Oregon
DOC.TEXT: The flaw with Miss Washington 1990 lies not in her intelligence, talent or beauty. It's in her hometown _ which happens to be in Oregon. Local contest officials in Washington contend that Lynnae Marie Thurik should be declared ineligible because she didn't spend enought time in the state. Contestants have been known before to hop states in the pageants that lead to Miss America. This year's rules for the national pageant require contestants to either have lived in the state for six months, be attending school there or work there a minimum of half of a full work week. Thurik, who is busy working out, studying and giving mock interviews in preparation for the Miss America pageant on Sept. 8, said she was clearly eligible for the contest. ``I wouldn't have been on the stage if I wasn't qualified,'' she said Tuesday in a telephone interview from Vancouver, Wash., just across the Columbia River from the her home in Lake Oswego, a Portland suburb. Thurik, 26, sells advertising for Oregon-based This Week magazine, and her territory includes Clark County, Wash. Patti Belik, president of the Washington State Association of Local Scholarship Pageants, said Monday that her group asked national pageant officials to examine Thurik's sales logs to see how much time she actually spent in Washington. ``Going back two years in issues, there is very, very little in This Week from Clark County,'' Belik said. Phyllis Goldhammer, head of the Miss Washington Scholarship Pageant, said Thurik qualified for Miss Clark County by employment and her enrollment in photography and fitness courses at Clark College, a two-year school in Washington. Miss America officials in New Jersey would not confirm that they had received the association's letter, and referred all questions to the Miss Washington office. Thurik, who graduated in 1986 with a degree in fine arts from Pacific Lutheran University in Tacoma, said she has entered 14 pageants and has competed for Miss Oregon three times, finishing as second runner-up last year. She said winning Miss America has been her dream since age 5. ``Ever since I was a child I looked up to her and molded my life after her. I would not even steal a cookie from the cookie jar because I told myself Miss America would not do that,'' she said. Last year's Miss America winner, Debbye Turner, won the Miss Missouri pageant, but her home was actually in Jonesboro, Ark., said Larry Webber, chairman of the board of the Missouri contest. He said Turner qualified as a full-time student at the University of Missouri-Columbia. ``It's not uncommon at all,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Re-Elected Party Leader
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to move up reference to this being first time general secretary elected by congress, changes order of Gorbachev quotes in acceptance speech, deletes erroneous reference to congress ending; Picks up 10th graf, `The top ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB1,6, LaserColor MOSB2
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev handily won re-election Tuesday as Soviet Communist Party leader from a congress that assailed him for eight days but concluded the party could not survive without him. Although opposition appeared to melt away as the delegates considered electing a new general secretary, a sizable anti-Gorbachev sentiment was evident in the balloting. Delegates at the 28th congress of the Soviet Communist Party voted 3,411 to 1,116 to keep Gorbachev as general secretary. His opponent, Teimuraz Avaliani, a Siberian party leader, received 501 votes to 4,026. Under congress' rules, delegates are required to take a separate vote on each candidate. It was the first time a general secretary was elected by a congress and not a plenary meeting of the Central Committee. Gorbachev nodded silently at the results, but did not smile as the delegates responded to his victory with loud applause. In a brief acceptance speech, the 59-year-old president and party leader expressed ``gratitude for enormous support and trust'' the congress had placed in him. ``I thank you for this,'' he said. He said he would take into account the criticism leveled against him and would take ``the most serious, far-reaching conclusions'' from it. He then adopted a serious tone of voice and said: ``You elected me after hearing my positions. I take my election as support for my positions.'' Many had expected the congress could pose a challenge to Gorbachev. But delegates approved Gorbachev's proposal to reorganize and expand the party Politburo, transferring greater power to the government that Gorbachev heads. The top party job carries no fixed term of office. But the meeting changed party rules to require that the general secretary be elected by a congress, which traditionally meets every four or five years, rather than by the Central Committee, which meets several times a year. The change will make it harder for opponents to oust Gorbachev as party leader, a post he has held since 1985. In March, Gorbachev was elected to a five-year term as president with authority newly strengthened at his initiative. Gorbachev was nominated as general secretary in a secret vote at the Grand Kremlin Palace, a short walk from the hall where the congress is being held. He received warm applause as he stepped up to the congress podium to accept the nomination. ``I carry the most responsibility for what has been done,'' he told the delegates, accepting the nomination. ``You have the possibility, you have a lot of information, it's right that you should decide.'' Gorbachev and seven others were nominated for the top Communist Party post. Amnog those nominated from the floor of the congress for the party leader's post were Interior Minister Vadim A. Bakatin, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Gorbachev adviser Alexander N. Yakovlev. All withdrew their names except for Gorbachev and Avaliani, party leader in the Siberian city of Kiselyovsk. ``I do not see a stronger, more experienced'' candidate than Gorbachev, Shevardnadze said. Vladimir Kalyuta, a worker from the coal-mining region of Kemerovo, nominated Gorbachev on behalf of the congress' Council of Representatives, a committee made up of delegates from major geographical regions. Avaliani, 58, was also head of a strike committee in a labor protest for higher pay and better working conditions in the Kuznetsk Coal Basin last summer. The nomination of the stocky, white-haired Avaliani came on the eve of a one-day miners strike protesting the government's inability to fulfill promises it made to end last year's strike. Miners are demanding the government resign. In his address, Avaliani said he favored continued government control of key enterprises and supports strikes only on a case-by-case basis. Although nominations were open to the floor, conservatives did not nominate Politburo hard-liner and key Gorbachev critic, Yegor K. Ligachev. ``The congress did not nominate him. That says it all,'' said Moscow party boss Yuri Prokofiev. Asked if he thought Ligachev's political career was over, Prokofiev replied: ``Yes, I think so.'' Prokofiev told reporters that Vladimir Ivashko, president of the Ukraine, the Soviet Union's second-largest republic and a key agricultural and energy-producing region, was the favorite for the new post of Gorbachev's deputy. Selection of Ivashko could be a bid to quiet separatist trends in the Ukraine. At the opening of Tuesday's session, Gorbachev lashed out at his conservative critics. ``You can never go back to yesterday by any path, and no dictatorship ... solves anything,'' he said, jabbing his hands in the air for emphasis. ``If any of the delegates came to the congress with the hope of returning the party to old conditions, comfortable or uncomfortable, this is not a question,'' he said. ``They were seriously mistaken.'' More than 40 percent of the 4,700 delegates to the congress are officials in the party apparatus.

DOC.HEAD: Texas TV Reporter is Freed from Promise of Confidentiality
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Karem replied...', to CORRECT Price to Priest.
DOC.TEXT: A television reporter told a judge the name of a confidential source today and was immediately freed from the jail where he had served two weeks of a six-month contempt of court sentence. ``I want to see my wife and my son and have a pizza and beer,'' said KMOL reporter Brian Karem, moments after he was freed by State District Judge Pat Priest. Karem was jailed June 27 for refusing to say who arranged a telephone interview with jailed capital murder suspect Henry Hernandez. Hernandez and his brother, Julian, are charged in the March 1989 shooting death of a San Antonio police officer, Gary Williams. Karem today identified the source as Deborah Ledesma, a cousin of the Hernandez brothers. He said he decided to reveal the name after Ms. Ledesma, who now lives in California, agreed to relieve him of his promise to protect her identity. During today's hearing, Priest asked Karem about the extent of Ms. Ledesma's involvement. When told she had simply arranged the interview, Priest said, ``I don't understand then, what would be the need for anonymity on her part. ... She never had anything to do with the statements that you ran on the air, is that correct?'' Karem replied, ``Yes.'' Then Priest said, ``He is released.'' Karem's attorney, Larry Macon, said he and other lawyers obtained a telephone deposition Monday night from Ms. Ledesma, who has been living in Santa Clara, Calif., since May 1989. In the deposition, the woman confirmed that she helped arrange a three-way telephone conversation that also involved Karem and Henry Hernandez, Macon said. Attorneys in the murder trial of the Hernandez brothers have said they need to know who arranged the interview to assure a fair trial and determine whether the interview should be admitted as evidence. Henry Hernandez said in the interview that he shot the officer in self-defense. In a telephone interview carried live by KMOL Monday night, Karem indicated he would be out of jail soon, and contended that the defense has known for some time who the source was. ``I'm kind of upset that it took 13 months for the district attorney and the defense to do their job. They've been playing a game,'' he said. Earlier Monday, the Supreme Court voted 7-2 to reject Karem's emergency request that he be freed pending his appeal of the judge's contempt order that led to his jailing.

DOC.HEAD: Electricity Fails During Energy Debate
DOC.TEXT: A debate on energy fizzled in the Bihar state legislature when the lights went out in the house, according to news reports Tuesday. The Times of India said debate on budget allocations for the state Energy Ministry was postponed because of the 110-minute electrical failure in Patna, about 550 miles east of New Delhi. The legislature's chairman, Umeshwar Prasad Verma, adjourned the 320-member house for the day Monday because of the ``near darkness,'' it said. Power failures are common in India, but emergency power normally is supplied to state legislatures and ministers' homes. It was not immediately known why emergency line in Patna did not work.

DOC.HEAD: Victim Was 88, Accused Killer is 95
DOC.TEXT: A 95-year-old man who is believed to be the oldest murder defendant in city history is back in the apartment building where he allegedly bludgeoned a neighbor to death. The slaying of 88-year-old Norma Marks has tenants at the building on Manhattan's Upper West Side demanding the immediate jailing of Oliver Barre. He was arrested after being found covered with blood on the floor of the dead woman's apartment on June 16, authorities said. Barre told police he beat Mrs. Marks to death with a metal pipe in self-defense. He was released without bail by two judges over the protests of residents and the prosecution. ``I was quite concerned to have a person in that condition walking around the building,'' said Cyla Guerwicz, a 23-year resident. ``He could snap at any moment. It's a reasonable concern.'' More than 140 residents signed a petition demanding Barre go to jail pending his trial. The petition said they ``feared for their collective safety and well-being.'' Barre, a Navy officer during World War I, was released on his own recognizance by Criminal Court Judge Laura Drager, who also turned down prosecution requests that he be held for psychiatric tests. Another judge ordered Barre to hire a round-the-clock home attendant to keep an eye on him. Barre told a police officer who responded to the slaying that Mrs. Marks was a murderer who had poisoned 15 to 20 people in the building, court documents indicated. Barre, who had minor scratches, claimed Mrs. Marks had tried to strangle him and she was killed in self-defense, the document said. Mrs. Marks was struck repeatedly with a metal pipe, suffering a fractured skull, jaw and ribs along with massive cuts and bruises. Two officials of the prosecutors office dismissed Barre's defense, as well as a published report that the killing was prompted by a love triangle involving a third woman, age 86. The officials spoke on condition of anonymity because the case is before a grand jury. The Manhattan district attorney's office says it knows of no one older than Barre ever charged with murder in the city. Assistant District Attorney Bridget Brennan told acting state Supreme Court Justice George Roberts on Tuesday that the grand jury could decide on an indictment by the end of the week. Barre, who appears solidly built, attended the brief court session in a wheelchair. Wearing a baseball cap that read ``U.S. Submarine Veterans,'' he sat silently as Brennan addressed the judge. Defense attorney John B.B. Lewis, assisted by a nurse, pushed his client out of the courtroom and into an elevator without commenting on the case. The attorney also did not return a phone call to his office.

DOC.HEAD: Houston's Power Set Relegated to B-Team Seats at Summit Dinner
DOC.TEXT: It was the dinner party of the year, the hottest ticket in town, but Houston's power set found itself playing social second-fiddle at Tuesday night's official summit dinner. The local moneyed set were relegated to the wings until after the hickory-grilled veal medallions were served on Tiffany-designed china to President Bush, his fellow summiteers and top government officials, including Vice President Dan Quayle. Most of Houston society, which griped early on about too much business and too few parties at the economic summit, was simply left out. Bush, who calls Houston his home town, invited about 80 power brokers, contributors and friends to the Fine Arts Museum for after-dinner entertainment and a chance to mingle with the mighty. Quick social diplomacy by Bush kept feathers from getting too ruffled over the lack of a meal. ``The president sent word early this was to be a substantive meeting, a serious meeting,'' retired bank president Ben Love, said of the dinner. ``I have not heard anyone in Houston question to what degree we are to participate in anything. That is the call of the president,'' said Love, a major contributor to Houston's host committee. Those lucky enough to even make the B-list were mostly Republican heavyweights and business tycoons. Socialites weren't invited. ``It was ridiculous for them to think they'd be invited,'' said Houston Chronicle society columnist Maxine Messenger. ``This is a three-day business meeting, not a social playground.'' Mexican restaurant maven Ninfa Laurenzo, a Bush friend, said she planned to wear a conservative black silk suit to the after-dinner entertainment because ``It's not a sparkling-type evening. It's sparkling in its own way.'' And as far as missing out on the meal? ``We have plenty of tacos, thank God,'' she said. ``I think its just an honor to be in the same room with all these world leaders.'' County Judge Jon Lindsay was one of only 14 Houstonians to make the A-list for dinner because he's both the elected head of Harris County government, and a Bush friend. ``Other than being a member of the exclusive group (of Western leaders) itself, this is the next best thing,'' he said. Lindsay said his wife planned to wear the same dress she wore to a dinner last Friday. ``No one knows her at this dinner, so no one's seen the dress before,'' he said. ``We are excited, needless to say,'' Lindsay said. ``This is a great event for a little ol' guy like me.''

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor: Defendants Formed `Partnership in Crime'
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Noriega's longtime personal banker and five co-defendants formed a ``partnership in crime'' to launder $32 million in drug profits through worldwide financial transactions, a prosecutor said Tuesday. The defendants _ five Bank of Credit and Commerce International employees plus a Colombian airplane broker _ knew the huge sums of cash they were trying to disguise were proceeds of cocaine sales but didn't care, Assistant U.S. Attorney Mark Jackowski said in closing arguments. In fact, they even offered helpful laundering hints to an undercover agent to skirt ``Ladea'' _ which stood for the Drug Enforcement Administration, he said. ``From the evidence there should be no doubt in anyone's mind the funds that were picked up on the streets of this country were from the sale of cocaine,'' Jackowski told the jury in summing up the government's case in the six-month trial. A U.S. Customs agent posing as a well-connected, high-stakes launderer during a two-year sting told the bankers his clients were dope dealers who ``don't like mistakes,'' Jackowski said. Drugs smuggled into the United States were sold on the streets and the cash was converted into certificates of deposit that first were used as collateral for loans, then to pay them off as they matured, the government maintained. The drug profits, hidden through these elaborate transactions involving BCCI subsidaries in Panama, Luxembourg, France and Switzerland, eventually were to wind up back in the hands of drug dealers to finance the next haul, according to prosecutors. ``What the government must prove is that the defendants acted in bad faith ... and that they didn't do so by some kind of mistakes or accident,'' the prosecutor told jurors. ``What it really is is a partnership in crime,'' Charged with conspiring to launder drug profits for the Medellin cartel and with various laundering counts are five officers of the Luxembourg-based BCCI, including Amjad Awan, banker for deposed Panamanian leader Noriega. On trial with Awan, who was Miami-based assistant director of BCCI's Latin American division, are Askbar A. Bilgrami, a director of BCCI's Latin American Division; Syed Aftab Hussain, BCCI's operations officer of the bank in Panama; Sibte Hassan, an officer in the Paris branch; Ian Howard, French country manager based in Paris; and Rudolf Armbrect of Medellin, Colombia. The bankers claim they never intentionally violated the law and were entrapped by the undercover agent. The six defendants face a possible penalty of five years on the conspiracy count plus 20 years on each of the 30 laundering charges. All are charged with conspiracy and various combinations of laundering.

DOC.HEAD: Earnings, and Risks, Run High on Washington's Streets
DOC.NOTE: For Release 6 p.m. EDT
Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 8th graf pvs, But, conceded, with Washington income figures. Makes pvs grafs 14-15, The study, new grafs 6-7.
DOC.TEXT: A typical young, poorly educated black man selling drugs on the streets of the nation's capital can count on earning $2,000 a month _ tax free, the Rand Corporation said Tuesday. Not enough for a ``Mercedes or great fortunes,'' but more than four times as much an hour as drug dealers can expect to make from legitimate jobs. Researchers based their conclusions on information supplied by the city government about the 24,000 people arrested for selling or possessing drugs from 1985 through 1987; interviews with 186 men aged 18 to 40 who said they had been involved with drugs and were on probation during that time; and a survey of 387 boys aged 15 to 18. The report estimated that, in 1987 alone, an estimated 24,000 city residents were selling drugs on the street. For the three in eight who were dealing daily, the median monthly earnings were $2,000, or $30 an hour, after expenses. That compares to the $7 an hour from the legitimate jobs that 75 percent of the probationers reported holding. The study found that dealers active at least two days a week face a 22 percent chance of going to prison, a 7 percent chance of severe injury and a 1.4 percent chance of being killed _ a fatality rate 100 times that of the general work force. Given those risks, ``long periods of steady earnings are unlikely to be common,'' the report said. ``We came to this study from an employment perspective,'' said Karen Hastie Williams, chairwoman of the Committee on Strategies to Reduce Chronic Poverty, one of the groups that commissioned the study. ``We hoped to identify employment and training strategies to convince drug dealers to end their involvement in the underground economy and join the legitimate work force.'' But, conceded economist Peter Reuter, ``Even creation of considerably higher paying legitimate jobs probably wouldn't get us very far. Dealers would still have smaller total incomes than they can earn now by supplementing their regular wages with drug selling. Also, many of them have expensive drug habits.'' The estimated median income of street-level drug dealers was higher than the average $12,898 retail-trade workers made in 1987-88, according to the city government. Construction workers made $24,879, on average, while service-industry workers made $26,545. The average annual salary for all private-sector workers was $25,857, while government employees made $32,118. Reuter, the report's principal author, said in an interview that, while most street-level sales were by blacks, the availability of drugs in Washington affects not just the city's predominantly black population. ``Our figures show that there are 79,000 cocaine addicts in the Washington metropolitan area and over 78 percent of them live in suburban areas,'' he said. ``Therefore, a lot of people who are involved in drug transactions may not be black, but are suburban whites who come into the city to make purchases and who take the drugs back to their communities for sale or use.'' While a typical city street dealer's earnings aren't enough to finance flashy cars and lavish lifestyles, it is the image of such luxuries that draw many young men into selling drugs, Reuter said in an interview. ``People such as Rayful Edmond III (a convicted city cocaine kingpin) send the wrong messages to many people who are considering getting involved in selling drugs. They see that people like Edmond, who was able to create a large illegal drug organization, living what they believe to be a hig lifestyle _ but they never see the downside, the consequences that can result from such activity.'' Edmond, on trial on a murder charge, has already been sentenced to life in prison without parole on a string of drug convictions. Looking at black men born in 1967, the study found that up to one in six had been charged with selling drugs by the time he turned 20. For the future, the researchers said, ``the ratio is likely to be closer to one in three before that age group reaches 30.'' The study held out some hope among the youngest group surveyed _ the 387 ninth and tenth graders. While one in six was selling drugs, only about 11 percent were using them. ``That could mean that anti-drug messages may be getting through to the younger population in the city,'' Reuter said, adding, however, ``The downside is that many juvenile sellers are involved in other delinquency-related offenses.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Leader Predicts Monrovia Will Fall By Week's End
DOC.TEXT: Liberian rebel leader Charles Taylor said Tuesday his forces will refuse to observe a cease-fire and predicted he would capture the city of Monrovia by the end of the week. Taylor, speaking in a telephone interview with the British Broadcasting Corp., was responding to published reports that he had accepted a cease-fire and the rebels' march on the capital was suspended. ``There will be no cease-fire,'' Taylor said. Taylor, whose men appear to have made little progress since reaching the outskirts of Monrovia a week ago, said his National Patriotic Front is ``progressing carefully because of the massive loss of life.'' ``We are only proceeding with caution while we evacuate people into safety zones ... to receive food and medical treatment,'' he said. ``This is why we have not stormed the capital as we should.'' He conceded the final assault was taking a long time, saying: ``I understand that and I regret the long time. But if we were to move in and tear that city apart the whole world would be jumping all over us.'' He added: ``My troops are exchanging fire right now in Monrovia. ... I think that Monrovia should be down by the weekend.'' The French news agency Agence France Presse, which has a reporter with the rebels, reported Tuesday that the insurgents were executing members of President Samuel Doe's Krahn tribe and members of the Mandingo people, accused of supporting Doe. A pool report filed by correspondents in the besieged Liberian capital said government troops continued to kill suspected rebel supporters. A 19-year-old man was bundled into a car and taken to a beach where soldiers slit his throat, the report said. The six-month conflict, which began with Taylor's invasion from Ivory Coast on Dec. 24, has become a tribal war. Doe's forces were accused of killing hundreds of civilians from the Gio and Mano tribes, the main rebel support base. The rebels have accused Doe's administration of being corrupt. Taylor said the rebels were sending a delegation to peace talks in Freetown, Sierra Leone, to hear what mediators from the Economic Community of West African States are proposing. The talks were scheduled to open Tuesday, but the rebel delegation failed to arrive, probably because of transport problems. The economic community group reportedly has proposed introduction of a multinational, African peacekeeping force in Liberia to oversee new elections. Taylor has opposed that. ``There will be no foreign soldiers landing on one inch of Liberian soil,'' Taylor said. He said some members of the economic community mediation team were supporting Doe, and had sent him weapons. Doe, meanwhile, reportedly has agreed to resign, but only after a stable, interim government is set up. Liberian Information Minister Emmanuel Bowier, in Freetown for the mediation talks, said Doe had no intention of being driven out of Monrovia by the rebels, but would step down in favor of a national unity government. The government would have to include all sides in the conflict, Bowier said. The plan reportedly also rules out Taylor heading the transitional government. The rebel said, ``There will be no interim government that is not headed by Charles Taylor.'' The rebels have refused to accept a cease-fire until Doe resigns and leaves the West African nation.

DOC.HEAD: It's the Law: Professors in Pennsylvania Must Be Fluent in English
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Robert P. Casey has signed a law intended to help college students better understand their instructors. The law, signed Monday, requires colleges and universities to certify to the state that their instructors are fluent in English. Sen. Vincent Fumo, who sponsored the measure, has said that students have been complaining that they cannot understand some of their college instructors.

DOC.HEAD: Fish Kill Occurs Behind Arco Plant
DOC.TEXT: State water officials are searching for the cause of a fish kill in a river behind an Arco Chemical Co. plant where 17 workers died last week in an explosion and fire. Although an exact count had not been completed, Texas Water Commission spokesman Bill Colbert said, ``Quite a few fish were noticed drifting in the water or along the shore near Bear Lake, an inlet of that river.'' Colbert said Monday the commission was awaiting test results of water samples from the San Jacinto River to determine the cause of the fish kill. But preliminary tests pointed to a combination of factors, including a sudden change in water temperatures and the possibility of caustic substances such as firefighting foam in the water. First reports of the kill came several hours after a fire and explosion late Thursday decimated an area the size of a city block at the plant, Colbert said, and a field evaluation was initiated the next day.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Companies Had Lower 1987 Tax Rate than Families
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts new grafs 7-8, IRS Commissioner, with Goldberg testimony
DOC.TEXT: Foreign companies operating in the United States chalked up $686 billion in U.S. sales in 1987 but paid a far lower federal income tax rate than the average middle-income family, the Internal Revenue Service said Tuesday. The U.S. subsidiaries together paid $5.6 billion in tax, a rate of less than 1 percent of their income. By contrast, the typical $35,000-a-year family paid at the rate of about 10 percent during the same period, according to IRS estimates. The IRS submitted the new information to the House Ways and Means oversight subcommittee, which for nine months has been investigating the extent of tax dodging by some of the nearly 45,000 foreign companies that operate subsidiaries in this country. The subcommittee zeroed in on 36 U.S. distributors of foreign cars, motorcycles and electronics, which accounted for a combined $35 billion in retail sales in 1986. ``Some of the companies investigated have been operating in the United States for years and have never sent a check to Uncle Sam for one thin dime in corporate income taxes,'' said Rep. J.J. Pickle, D-Texas, chairman of the subcommittee. ``They have failed to pay taxes despite the fact they have profited from selling billions of dollars of cars, motorcycles, stereos, televisions, VCRs, microwaves and other products to the American consumer,'' Pickle said. IRS Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. agreed that foreign corporations may be substantially understating their tax liability. ``But you can't jump too fast,'' he said. ``There may be other causes,'' such as corporate structure and an inordinately high number of new _ and, thus, less profitable _ companies among the foreign-controlled subsidiaries. He agreed with the subcommittee investigators' conclusion that the IRS often is outmanned by corporate experts in such complex cases. He asked Congress for the authority to hire expert witnesses without competitive bidding and urged higher pay scales for IRS employees. Subcommittee investigators said the main factor in the companies' ability to avoid taxes was ``transfer pricing'' _ a practice in which a subsidiary typically pays an artificially inflated price for goods purchased from its overseas parent. The result is a lower taxable profit in the United States. Government officials have known for some time that foreign-owned companies generally pay a considerably lower tax rate than domestic corporations. About $13 billion of additional taxes assessed against U.S. subsidiaries because of transfer pricing is pending in appeals at the IRS and in the courts. Members of Congress are eyeing that money _ and even greater amounts they say could be obtained with stiffer enforcement _ as one way to cut the federal budget deficit. ``Before Congress acts to raise taxes on the average citizen in order to reduce the deficit, we should be sure that U.S. subsidiaries are paying their fair share of the current tax load,'' Rep. Richard Schulze, R-Pa., said at the hearing Tuesday. Congress acted last year to strengthen the IRS's hand in investigating non-compliance by foreign corporations. A pending bill would go even further. Pickle's investigators found that: _Over a 10-year period, more than half the foreign companies they investigated paid little or no U.S. income tax. _One electronics distributor paid more than $150 million in taxes over six years. A second company with similar products, assets, receipts and distribution operations paid no tax at all. Both are U.S. subsidiaries of foreign corporations. The difference: transfer pricing. _For tax purposes, one company sold television sets to an outside distributor for $150 but charged its own distributor $250. One foreign carmaker charged its U.S. distributor $800 more than its Canadian distributor. _Some foreign-owned subsidiaries have engaged in kickbacks and imposed illegal freight and insurance charges as part of their tax-avoidance schemes. _One electronics company grossed $4 billion over seven years and reported tax liability of $15 million. Over 10 years, the IRS told investigators, the company paid no tax because it used operating losses to get refunds of what little tax it had paid during profitable years. _Ten of the 18 car distributors investigated grossed $38 billion in 1987 and paid $366 million in tax, again less than 1 percent. But when operating losses are carried back, the rate will drop even lower. The IRS said that while Japanese-controlled companies accounted for 27 percent of receipts of U.S. subsidiaries in 1987, they paid only 21 percent of the taxes. British-controlled subsidiaries had 15 percent of the sales but paid 31 percent of the taxes. West German-owned companies rang up 9 percent of sales and paid 7.7 percent of the taxes.

DOC.HEAD: Coalition Says More Funds Needed to Stop Deaths from Consumer Products
DOC.TEXT: A coalition of consumer, health and insurance groups said Tuesday that more federal leadership and money are needed to help prevent 600,000 deaths that result each year from consumer products. In releasing a status report, the Coalition for Consumer Health & Safety said 80 percent, or more than 480,000, of those deaths involved cigarettes and alcohol. Stephen Brobeck, chairman of the coalition, said that ``while there are hopeful trends, many improvements are needed.'' ``Particularly discouraging is the recent rise in motor vehicle and household product deaths. And the two most dangerous products _ cigarettes and alcohol _ still take a horrendous toll,'' he said. ``Federal agencies must increase their efforts in all of these product areas. To do so they must be adequately funded,'' said Brobeck, executive director of the Consumer Federation of America, which formed the coalition. Brobeck did not say how much money should be added to the effort overall. But with respect to the Consumer Product Safety Commission, he said its $35 million budget for this year should be increased to $75 million. ``Politically that won't happen, but it should,'' he said. More money also needs to be channeled to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and to combat AIDS and alcoholism, Brobeck said, but he did not specify how much. The report focused on seven areas of concern: motor vehicle safety, home and product safety, cigarette smoking, indoor air pollution, food safety and nutrition, alcohol consumption and AIDS. Among the findings: _47,093 people were killed in motor vehicle accidents in 1988, an increase of 1.5 percent from 1987 when 46,390 died on the nation's roadways and a 0.6 percent rise from the previous year's toll of 46,087. _Falls were the leading cause of fatal accidents in the home, accounting for 6,500 deaths in 1988. Fires were the second-ranked cause, followed by suffocation, poisoning, firearms and drownings. _Cardiovascular disease, one of the key factors for which is diet, killed nearly 1 million Americans in 1987, while nutritional deficiencies caused a reported 2,890 deaths in the United States that year. _Cigarette smoking was responsible for 390,000 deaths in the United States in 1985. Between 1965 and 1987, the proportion of American adults who smoked dropped by 40 percent for men and 21 percent for women. About 49 million Americans still smoke cigarettes. _Alcohol was involved in 90,991 deaths in 1986, up from 88,935 the previous year. The coalition of 37 groups includes 16 insurance companies and associations as well as health groups, such as the American Academy of Pediatrics and the American College of Preventive Medicine, and consumer groups like the Center for Science in the Public Interest.

DOC.HEAD: Self-Proclaimed Mercy Killer Among Those in Prison Security Move
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `His attorney ...' to CORRECT name to Bradley
DOC.TEXT: An 80-year-old man serving a life sentence for shooting his ailing wife to death has been moved to a tougher prison as part of a general crackdown on prison security. Roswell Gilbert, whose mercy killing defense after the March 1985 shooting drew widespread publicity, was moved from the medium security Lawtey Correctional Facility to a top security prison at Lake Butler, said H. Edward Sands, assistant superintendent at Lawtey. Last month, Donald Dillbeck, serving a mandatory life sentence in the murder of a policeman, walked away from a work-release program and was charged with killing a shopper outside a Tallahassee mall. In response, Gov. Bob Martinez ordered inmates who are serving a type of sentence that rules out early parole to be put in top-security prisons. Among them was Gilbert. His attorney, Bradley Stark, said Gilbert's health could be endangered by the stress of moving to another prison. ``It's pretty clear to me Roswell Gilbert shouldn't be in prison. And secondly, if he is going to be in prison, he shouldn't be in maximum security,'' Stark said. Gilbert suffers from lung and heart diseases and has undergone surgery for bladder and urinary tract infections since he was imprisoned, Stark said. On March 4, 1985, Gilbert, a retired engineer, shot and killed his wife, Emily, in what he said was act of love, a mercy killing to end her suffering from Alzheimer's disease. He was convicted of first-degree murder and sentenced to life in prison, with a minimum of 25 years in prison. His case was dramatized in a made-for-television movie.

DOC.HEAD: Italy To Ferry Refugees Out of Albania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with Albanian officials' comments, report of Albanian escape, details, source saying operation could begin Thursday. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `In a...'; SUBS last 5 grafs with 2 grafs to tighten.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PRA10, LaserColor PRA6
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Albanians seeking asylum in foreign embassies in Tirana will be ferried to Italy under an agreement being worked out between Albania and the United Nations, the Foreign Ministry said Tuesday. ``We hope the operation can begin by the end of the week,'' a Foreign Ministry spokesman said in Rome. He spoke on condition of anonymity. Another source said it could begin as early as Thursday. A representative of U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar was in the Albanian capital, Tirana, negotiating the departure procedures on behalf of the almost a dozen embassies where Albanians have taken refuge, he said. Under the agreement, the asylum-seekers would be ferried from Albania's Adriatic port city of Durres to either Brindisi, about 85 miles away, or Otranto on the Italian coast, the spokesman said. The Italian government is working on contracting commercial vessels to bring out the Albanians, the official said, adding he expected that several trips would have to be made to evacuate them all. The Italian Red Cross was preparing to provide assistance to refugees arriving in Italy. Although foreign diplomats have estimated the number of Albanians in the embassies at 5,000, the Italian spokesman said there are about 3,000, including about 800 in the Italian Embassy. More than 2,000 are believed to have taken refuge in the West German Embassy alone. The asylum-seekers began taking refuge in the embassies on June 28 in a bid to escape Europe's last hard-line Communist regime. Some dodged police bullets as they climbed over embassy gates. The Albanian ambassador to Italy, Dashnor Dervishi, said Tuesday the Albanians in all the embassies were free to go. ``The problem is resolved,'' he told a reporter, without referring to the news that Italy is preparing to evacuate the asylum-seekers. ``If there is a delay it's because of the governments that maintain these people like guests,'' Dervishi said. He described those seeking asylum as ``hooligans.'' The first 51 Albanians allowed to leave Tirana landed in Czechoslovakia Tuesday. Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel sent his official airplane to Tirana for the refugees. Italian officials reported Tuesday that six Albanians who fled their country in a small boat were picked up in the Adriatic during the night by a West German sailboat after their outboard motor failed. They were brought to Lecce. Capt. Francesco Nistri of the port captain's office said the six, aged 21 to 25, described themselves as political dissidents and added they want to go to West Germany. In a telephone interview with the Italian news agency AGI, Italy's ambassador in Tirana, Giorgio De Andreis, said the embassy has completed paperwork to obtain exit permits for the Albanians in his embassy. He said the situation inside was calm because the Albanians ``finally see the light at the end of the tunnel.'' ``Nothing is decided yet,'' he said. ``We hope to resolve it soon.'' He told the news agency that most of the Albanians in the embassy eventually want to go on to the United States, Canada and Britain. Conditions in the dozen or so embassies harboring the Albanians continued to be grim. Food, water and medicine were in short supply because the Albanian leadership refused to allow foreign aid to reach the missions. A baby was born Saturday in the West German Embassy, the most crowded, and Czechoslovak officials said they had heard of a second birth there. In Prague, the arriving Albanians were apparently unwilling to talk about their experiences. They evaded reporters' questions upon arrival, saying they feared for the safety of relatives back home. Some shouted, ``Long live Havel!'' before boarding buses at the airport for a dormitory. One Albanian who made his way to Yugoslavia told reporters that despite modest reforms, the Albanian government still was oppressive and economic hardship was a part of daily life. Ari Ferhate Gjani, 36, told Yugoslavia's state Tanjug news agency that police had been ordered to cease stopping people on the street without reason. Still, he said, many Albanians, especially the young, longed for more freedom. Many other Albanians seeking to emigrate have said they seek better economic conditions. Antonio Bernardi, an Italian sales representative returning from a business trip from Tirana, told a reporter at the Yugoslav border crossing that many of the asylum-seekers were teen-agers or people in their early twenties. Despite a police cordon around embassy row, parents of the youths were allowed near the missions ``to try and persuade them to return home,'' Bernardi said. Bernardi, who said he was a frequent traveler to Tirana, said the capital's streets appeared peaceful away from the embassy district. Albania's Communist leader, Ramiz Alia, began this year to institute some economic reforms in the nation of 3.2 million and sought to establish limited ties with other countries. For 45 years, travel for average Albanians has been virtually impossible, but a package of new regulations entitles all Albanians over age 16 to have a passport.

DOC.HEAD: Creator Of Kellogg's `Snap, Crackle And Pop' Characters Dies at 88
DOC.TEXT: Vernon Grant, creator of the Kellogg's cereal characters Snap, Crackle and Pop and a longtime magazine and book illustrator, has died. He was 88. He died Monday at a nursing home, where he had been for several weeks. ``He was right up there with Norman Rockwell in the number of covers he designed,'' said Linda Williams, chairwoman of the Vernon Grant-Art Advisory Committee with the Museum of York County. The nursing home would not release a cause of death, but Ms. Williams said he had been in declining health since he broke his hip some months ago. Grant was born in Nebraska in 1902, and moved with his family to California when he was a teen-ager. He studied at the University of Southern California, and later at the Art Institute of Chicago. In 1932, a gnome figure he drew of Santa Claus landed on the cover of Ladies' Home Journal and was a smashing success. A year later, inspired by a radio commercial for Kellogg's Rice Krispies, he created the gnomelike characters of Snap, Crackle and Pop. He submitted drawings to the company's ad agency. Overall, he designed 187 magazine covers from the 1930s to the '50s, and illustrated children's books. In 1947, Grant and his wife, Elizabeth, moved to her hometown of Rock Hill to raise their family and farm 600 acres. While living in South Carolina, he developed a strain of grass and became known for his conservation methods. Grant is survived by his wife, a son and a daughter.

DOC.HEAD: Walker's Close Call Was Just One Incident, NASA Official Says
With AM-NASA Troubles, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The chief of the astronaut corps said Tuesday that shuttle commander David M. Walker was suspended for more than flying his jet trainer within 100 feet of a Pan Am airliner. ``It was an incident that was considered, you might say it was one of the more severe incidents,'' Donald R. Puddy, director of flight crew operations, said in a telephone interview from Houston. ``At the same time it was not the only one and not necessarily the principal one.'' He declined to elaborate, saying only that the space agency had become concerned about ``some things in the manner which he was flying.'' Walker, a Navy captain who had flown in space twice, was replaced on a Defense Department mission set for March 1991 and suspended for 60 days from flying NASA's T-38 jet trainers. At the same time, NASA announced a one-year suspension for Navy Cmdr. Robert L. Gibson, who took part in a civilian air show race last Saturday in which a pilot was killed. The suspensions are the first for NASA in nearly 30 years of manned space flight. Neither Gibson nor Walker has had any public comment about the suspensions, which were announced Monday. Puddy said he had ``no reason to believe that Dave is not going to stay with the program and no reason to believe he will not eventually be put back on T-38 flying status.'' He said he had not talked with Gibson. ``My personal feeling is that other members of the astronaut corps understand that there was a violation of policy and they also understand we had to take the action,'' said Puddy. Until two years ago, NASA had no written guidelines for astronaut behavior and tolerated some dangerous outside activities. Gordon Cooper, one of the Mercury Seven astronauts, was fond of fast cars and was about to make his professional driving debut when NASA stopped him. Four-time space flyer James Lovell fractured his arm and shoulder while skiing. Apollo 7 astronaut Walter Cunningham fractured a vertebra on a trampoline. In 1988, however, Puddy issued an order prohibiting astronauts in training for flight from taking part in ``risky recreational activities ... where there exists exposure of major, or even fatal, injury.'' He cited examples: ``Auto, boat, airplane or motorcycle racing; parachute jumping; and snow skiing.'' Gibson, a three-flight veteran, was considered to be one of NASA's star commanders. Walker has a reputation as a hell-raiser. One space veteran said, ``He's in the old mode of the Mercury astronauts. He likes flying fast and he likes to race people.'' The National Transportation Safety Board has not completed its investigation of the Walker incident, which occurred May 15, 1989, as he was flying his T-38 to Dulles International Airport to take part in a White House ceremony. The pilot of the Pan Am Airbus reported the incident as a near collision. NTSB spokesman Michael Benson said that the ``factual report'' of the incident is due in about a week and that the board's ruling on the probable cause of the incident will follow. The NTSB also is investigating the airshow death at New Braunfels, Texas. The safety board is particularly interested, said Warren Wandel, supervisory air safety investigator in the Dallas-Fort Worth regional office, because it was the third air show fatality in four weeks in his region. There have been seven deaths in seven accidents nationwide this year. NASA's astronaut corps has 85 members; 62 of whom are in training for 12 future shuttle flights. ``The rationale for our rules is to preserve the assigned crews,'' said Puddy. ``We do not have enough people in the astronaut office to provide backups for every single crew member for all aspects of training.'' It is been just over a year since astronaut S. David Griggs was killed while performing aerial stunts in his World War II vintage plane at an airshow. At the time, NASA spokesman Jeff Carr said the agency could not police the astronauts. ``You can't lock these guys in their houses,'' he said. ``These guys have thousands of hours flying experience. They take a greater risk driving down the Gulf Freeway in Houston than by flying.'' Air Force Col. Fred Gregory, who has been assigned to take Walker's place on the 1991 mission, said it's easy for astronauts to stray from the rules. ``All of us are pilots and all of us are very aggressive pilots,'' he said. ``It's sometimes difficult for us to separate our outside activities and our piloting skills and just the thrill of flying. It's unfortunate in this particular case. ``Both Dave Walker and Hoot Gibson are terrific pilots, but this is just a temporary activity and basically it's a wrist slapping. Sometimes we have to do it to get somebody's attention.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's Defeated Challenger Has Defiant History
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Teimuraz Avaliani, the long-shot challenger to Mikhail S. Gorbachev for leader of the Communist Party, led Siberian coal miners in a strike last summer and has a history of challenging central authority. Alone among seven people nominated to face Gorbachev, Avaliani refused to withdraw his candidacy. For his trouble, he was buried in a Gorbachev landslide. Despite his rebellious background, Avaliani was cautious in a speech before the vote. The nearly 4,700 delegates to the 28th congress of the Soviet Communist Party listened quietly as the white-haired Avaliani, wearing a gray suit, no tie, and a white shirt open at the collar, said strikes were not always the best means of resolving disputes. ``When people don't have any clothes to wear, when they have tried everything, and have appealed two or three times to the highest authority and (the authorities) don't do anything, I don't see any choice in this country but to strike,'' he said. But conditions varied by region, he said, and ``I have different approaches to the strike movement in different concrete situations.'' He also advocated a strong army, KGB and police, recommended a gradual rather than an abrupt shift to a market economy, and said major businesses should remain under government control rather than private ownership. On security issues, he said that ``the army, police, KGB and so forth should be strong. ... In no case should the government allow uncalled for attacks on them.'' Gorbachev sat impassively through the speech, leaning on the green felt dais with his arms crossed, and intently watching Avaliani. The former strike leader received little applause and few votes. Under the Soviet system in which voters cast positive and negative ballots for each candidate, Avaliani received 501 votes for and 4,026 against. Gorbachev received 3,411 votes for and 1,116 votes against. Avaliani first entered the national scene early last year, when a central newspaper reported that in the early 1970s, he had written to then Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev, suggesting that he resign. Instead, Avaliani was forced out of his job as a plant director in the Kuznetsk Basin of Western Siberia, the second-largest Soviet coal field. In March 1989, Avaliani was elected to the Congress of People's Deputies, the national parliament that selected from its members the Supreme Soviet legislature and this March voted Gorbachev a new five-year term as president. A year ago, Avaliani led a regional strike committee in the Kuznetsk Basin, leading negotiations in which the government gave in to virtually all the strikers demands. He is popular in Kuznetsk, and on April 4 was elected first secretary of the Communist Party organization in Kiselyevsk. Alexei Solovyev, a member of the strike committee, said in a telephone interview that miners were surprised at the moderate tone of Avaliani's speech. ``I think that he betrayed our principles consenting to run for this high position,'' said Solovyev, whose committee is organizing a one-day protest strike Wednesday in defiance of pleas from Gorbachev and the party congress. ``I am sure that this will have a negative effect on his prestige down here,'' he said in a telephone interview from the town of Kemerovo in the Kuznetsk Basin.

DOC.HEAD: Magistrate Skirts Rules to Ease Sentencing of Underage Drinkers
DOC.TEXT: A magistrate who believes the legal drinking age should be lowered skirted sentencing rules to let a group of underage drinkers off the hook. District Justice Jacob Williams ordered youths cited for underage drinking to perform 30 hours of community service. A state law requires a 90-day drivers license suspension for the first underage-drinking offense. ``I am going to get hung by the bosses in Harrisburg for doing this,'' Williams said after sentencing Monday. ``I believe the penalty is too stiff a sentence for what they have done. It is not my prerogative to second-guess the legislators, but the sentence is too stiff.'' Cynthia Scopetti, a spokeswoman for Mothers Against Drunk Driving, disagreed, claiming alcohol-related accidents among 16- to 20-year-olds had decreased since the law was passed in 1988. ``MADD agrees that the pain of losing a driver's license is hard on a youth, but it is a small price to pay when you compare it to even the loss of one life,'' she said. Sixty-six youths were charged with underage drinking after a rock concert at the Civic Arena in June. Williams has disposed of about 20 cases by throwing out the charges or declaring the defendant guilty but not recording the verdict, thereby skirting the mandatory sentence. About 40 cases are pending. Williams said the drinking age should be lowered from 21 to 18, because ``when they are 18 or older we give them the right to vote and serve in the armed services.''

DOC.HEAD: San Francisco Supervisors: `Protect Artists' Rights'
DOC.TEXT: The city's Board of Supervisors has condemned the federal criminal investigation of an artist who photographs naked children. ``This resolution lets the nation know that this city does not support the attack on the First Amendment rights that artists are experiencing in this country,'' Supervisor Terence Hallinan said at Monday's meeting. The resolution, approved 9-2, urges the U.S. attorney's office to drop its investigation of Jock Sturges, a 43-year-old San Francisco photographer whose collection includes black and white pictures of ``naturists,'' children and adults who prefer to go without clothes. It also urges the San Francisco district attorney's office to drop criminal charges against Sturges' film developer, Joseph Semien. Semien was arrested in April and charged with two felony counts of possessing child pornography with intent to distribute and 10 misdemeanor possession counts after he picked up photos from Newell Colour, a professional film developing lab. According to police records, a lab employee reported Semien to the FBI after he brought in negatives showing naked girls aged 9 to 11. Sturges has not been charged, but he is the target of a federal grand jury probe. Hallinan, who wrote the resolution, cited pending obscenity charges against the Cincinnati Contemporary Arts Center and its director for displaying Robert Mapplethorpe photos of naked children and the National Endowment for the Arts' recent withholding of funds for art it considered offensive. Sturges argues that his pictures of naked children are artistic, tasteful and taken with the consent of their parents. Many of the pictures were taken at California beaches where the ``naturists'' gather.
