DOC.HEAD: Textron Settles for $17.9 Million in Helicopter Suit
DOC.TEXT: Textron Lycoming agreed Tuesday to pay the government $17.9 million to settle a fraud investigation focusing on the company's problem-plagued Coast Guard helicopter engines. The settlement is the largest ever reached under the Justice Department's ``whistleblower'' lawsuit program. Robert C. Ballew, a procurement official for the prime manufacturer of the Coast Guard HH-65A Dolphin helicopters, will receive $2.7 million for his role in filing the original suit against Textron in May 1988. Textron, based in Stratford, Conn., was under investigation for providing engines that failed to meet their operating specifications and for fraudulently billing the Coast Guard for repair work, according to the Justice Department. The helicopters are used in search-and-rescue and drug interdiction missions. Former Coast Guard Commandant Paul Yost once referred to the engine as ``a lemon.'' Separate investigations by the National Transportation Safety Board have shown, according to published reports, that at least 14 deaths are attributable to failures of the LTS-101 engine, manufactured by Textron's Lycoming Williamsport, Pa., plant. The engine is used in private helicopters as well as air ambulances, commercial choppers and Air National Guard helicopters. ``This settlement sends a clear message that the government will simply not tolerate fraud perpetrated against the American taxpayer,'' said Stuart Gerson, assistant attorney general for the Justice Department's civil division. Textron also agreed to maintain the engines and supply parts for the next six years and be paid a fee based on the engine flying time. That provision could save the Coast Guard an estimated $60 million, according to the Justice Department. ``This arrangement will increase Textron Lycoming's incentive to improve the engines' longevity, since Textron Lycoming will now bear the costs of the replacement parts,'' Gerson said. The two-year government investigation showed that the engines were operating at higher temperatures than was called for in their initial design. As a result, the engines were deteriorating faster than expected. The engine was supposed to fly for 2,400 hours between overhauls. It usually lasted less than 600 hours before expensive repairs were required. The probe also turned up evidence that Textron charged the Coast Guard for work related to repairing engine defects even though the Coast Guard had stated it would not pay the charges. Textron issued a written statement that admitted no wrongdoing. But the company said it hoped to normalize relations with the Coast Guard and pledged to maintain ``the reliability and mission availability of the engines.'' Textron said it had set aside money for the settlement and that the $17.9 million payment will have ``no material impact'' on the company's bottom line. Ballew, 43, of Fort Worth, Texas, worked for Aerospatiale Helicopter Corp., a French firm that makes the Dolphin. He said in a telephone interview that he filed the suit because he feared he could be sent to jail when Aerospatiale was unable to cure problems with the engines supplied by Textron. Under a Civil War-era law, whistleblowers can sue on behalf of the government and are entitled to a portion of any settlement. Ballew's share amounts to 15 percent of the total.

DOC.HEAD: Critics Suggest Peru Gov't Involvement in Rebel Prison Break
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Miguel Castro Castro name is correct
DOC.TEXT: Opposition politicians said Tuesday the prison escape of one of Peru's top guerrilla leaders was ``highly suspicious'' and suggested the possibility of government complicity in the breakout. Victor Polay, a leader of the pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement, and 47 other suspected members crawled to freedom early Monday through an elaborate block-and-a-half-long tunnel built under the Miguel Castro Castro prison in northeastern Lima. Polay, whose brother-in-law, Paul Caro, is health minister, escaped 18 days before the administration of President Alan Garcia is to leave office at the expiration of its five-year term. Alberto Fujimori is president-elect. The Garcia government has been hobbled by high inflation and a protracted guerrilla war, primarily involving the Shining Path, a violent Maoist organization that operates mainly in the northern and eastern Andean highlands. Criticism of the prison escape was quick: Senator-elect Alberto Borea of the center-right Fredemo coalition said, ``It's quite a coincidence that in the government's final days the terrorist Victor Polay should escape. He was a close friend of many Aprista Party members (and) I find it highly suspicious.'' Polay, 38, is the son of one of the founders of the center-left Aprista Party now headed by Garcia. In the early 1970s Polay studied in Europe with Garcia. Leftist congressman Manuel Dammert called on Interior Minister Agustin Mantilla to resign. ``It's unheard of that one of the most dangerous terrorists in the country has escaped from what is supposed to be the country's most secure prison,'' Dammert said. Former Interior Minister Gen. Luis Cisneros said in a television interview Monday night he learned that police intelligence personnel had information six weeks ago that there would be an attempted breakout. He called the mass escape ``inexplicable.'' Police captured Polay on Feb. 3, 1989. He was facing charges of terrorism in connection with the deaths of more than 100 policemen and his trial was expected to conclude in a few weeks. The day after his arrest he received a private visit by then-Prime Minister Armando Villanueva. Villanueva was roundly criticized over the visit, which he said he did as a friend of the Polay family. Investigators said the six-foot-wide escape tunnel was built nearly 20 feet underground. They said it had its own lighting and ventilation system and probably took six to 10 months to build. The exit opened into an adobe shanty 500 feet from the prison walls. Neighbors said a young couple who lived in the house have disappeared. In statements to the press Garcia called the escape ``scandalous,'' and promised a complete investigation of corrections department personnel who were on duty. Police said Monday night they had detained 20,000 people in a massive sweep through Lima for the escapees. Most were later released. The Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement took up arms against the government in 1984 and is believed to have about 1,000 combatants. In January three Tupac Amaru guerrillas assassinated former Defense Minister Enrique Lopez in the parking lot of a Lima shopping center. In October the group kidnapped Hector Delgado, a prominent businessman who was an adviser to Garcia. Delgado was released in April, but no details of the negotiations surrounding his release were released. Some officials and newspaper editorials suggested Tuesday that Polay could have been allowed to escape as part of a trade that also involved Delgado's freedom. The Tupac Amaru group takes its name from an 18th Century revolutionary who led a successful revolt against Spanish colonial rule in the Andes, which run north to south through Peru. In a communique distributed Monday the guerrillas pledged to continue their fight after Fujimori takes office on July 28.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Who Made False Rape Accusation Appeals Unorthodox Sentence
DOC.TEXT: A woman who falsely accused a man of raping her is appealing an unorthodox perjury sentence that requires her to pay for advertisements apologizing to the man. The appeal, filed Monday in Dawson County District Court, claims that Elizabeth Irene Richardson's sentence violates her rights to free speech, due process and protection from cruel and unusual punishment. The sentence also is an improper delegation of judicial authority and not a permissible condition of probation, the appeal said. Ms. Richardson, 24, accused Gary Nitsch, 44, of raping her in September 1988. He was arrested and charged with sexual assault. Ms. Richardson testified that Nitsch raped her, but the case was dropped for lack of evidence. Word later reached authorities that Ms. Richardson told friends the rape was a hoax. She was convicted of perjury in February. County Attorney John Marsh said the woman's motives centered on trying to get the attention of her husband, a truck driver who was often away from home. A hearing has been set in county court July 17 before the same judge that sentenced Ms. Richardson. She will ask District Judge John Murphy to suspend her sentence and allow her to remain free on bail until the Nebraska Supreme Court rules on her appeal. Murphy ordered Ms. Richardson to apologize to Nitsch in a half-page advertisement in every newspaper and a prime-time spot on each radio station in this county of about 22,000 in central Nebraska. The media campaign was expected to cost about $1,000. She also was sentenced June 8 to 180 days in jail and placed on two years' probation. Tod McKeone, Ms. Richardson's attorney, said he has found no precedent to support the appeal. ``We've got a long way to go,'' he said. ``Since we had to file the appeal 30 days after the sentence, there was not enough time to dig in and find favorable precedent. You just have to hope you run into some things, too, that will help.''

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Puts Courtesy Over Protocol
With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl put courtesy over protocol Tuesday when he came to a doorway abreast of Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti. The two leaders were at the back of the pack of summit leaders who ambled into the faculty club at Rice University for lunch. Protocol strictly dictates most comings and goings, with those longest in office entitled to come last and depart first. Andreotti only became Italy's prime minister last July 30, while Kohl has led the Federal Republic for eight years. When Andreotti got to the door of the Cohen House, he held back for a moment to let his German colleague pass. Kohl, a bear-sized man who towers over the Italian prime minister, would have none of it. He bowed and gestured for Andreotti to go ahead. Andreotti demurred. Kohl insisted. Finally, the Alphonse-Gaston routine ended. Andreotti went first. Kohl followed.

Houstonians, constantly told by their summit guests that it's hot, got word Tuesday morning that one famous world capital was even hotter. Washington had a high Monday of 96 degrees while, the Houston Post noted, ``All Houston could muster was a measly 94.''

A local artist miffed that President Bush wasn't interested in personally accepting a portrait of himself made out of straw did what any citizen might do _ he issued a press release. But his distribution was unorthodox _ he left it under windshield wipers of cars parked at the convention center serving reporters at the economic summit. Rajan Koshy wrote to the White House with the offer earlier this year. Thanks, but the president's schedule is full during the economic summit, the White House wrote back in June. ``This is the story of an ordinary American's effort to generate public interest to save an endangered art form from extinction,'' the press release said. A straw art exhibit is under way at a University of Texas medical library in nearby Galveston.

The four tables at which summit conferees are wrestling with the world's economic issues were specially built for the occasion at a cost of $479,500. Each has a maple center, surrounded by American cherry and supported on a steel frame, said designer Wayne Braun of Houston's Planning Design Research Corp. The tables were made in Houston of wood from 100-year-old trees, the cherry from Pennsylvania and the maple from Michigan. Braun said his firm plans to give the largest table, 10 feet by 40 feet and weighing 4,453 pounds, to the president and will sell the others.

DOC.HEAD: Major Earthquake Strikes Southern Sudan Near Juba
DOC.TEXT: A major earthquake struck a sparsely populated jungle region of southern Sudan but there were no immediate reports of damage or casualties, officials said Tuesday. It was the second earthquake in the Juba region in less than two months. Military intellegence officials said the ``extent of damage or loss of life has yet to be determined in view of the remoteness'' of the area hit by the tremor. In Cairo, Ezz-el-Din Ibrahim, director of the earthquake department at Egypt's National Research Institute of Astronomy and Geophysics, said the quake struck Monday afternoon and measured 6.6 on the Richter scale. ``It had the capability of causing widespread damage,'' he said. Officials at the Hong Kong Observatory said Tuesday the earthquake measured 6.5 and its epicenter was in an area about 56 miles north of Juba in southern Sudan. United Nations officials said the temblor did not cause damage in Juba, but no information was available on the surrounding areas. The same region was struck by an earthquake measuring 7.5 on the Richter scale on May 20. The relief agency of the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army, said the May earthquake left 31 people dead and 300,000 without shelter. The rebels have been fighting the government since 1983. Thirty of the dead perished when their homes slid into the Nile River.

DOC.HEAD: Rat Startled Mrs. Bush; President `Drowned the Beast'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs top 3 grafs, raising quote
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush says an enormous rat swam by her in the White House pool recently but President Bush came to her rescue and ``drowned the beast.'' The rat she encountered in the incident several months ago ``did not look like a Walt Disney friend, I'll tell you that,'' she said in an interview published by newspapers in Houston and San Antonio on Tuesday. Mrs. Bush, who was back in Texas for the economic summit, said her husband came to her aid at the outdoor pool. ``I swim with a mask, so as it went right by in front of me _ I mean, it was enormous,'' said Mrs. Bush, a mile-a-day swimmer. ``Fortunately, George Bush was there and drowned the beast. It was horrible.'' The White House grounds attract rats, she said, ``because we're surrounded by parks and people drop food.'' Or, she theorized it was an effort to get rid of the rodents that may have led this one to find its way into the White House pool. ``They put some stuff out that only bothered rats, and what it did is make them very, very thirsty. And this rat went for the biggest water it saw,'' she explained. She also credited her English springer spaniel Millie with helping reduce the local rat population. For a long time afterward, she said, she insisted that her guards check to make sure there wasn't a rat ``in hiding'' before she entered the pool. On another subject, she said her husband was ``absolutely exhausted'' when he got to Houston Friday night from the NATO summit in London. But she added that they have both been delighted by the warm reception Houstonians have given their international guests. After viewing the friendly crowds along a motorcade route to Rice University, ``I told George that this is the first time I've gone that far in a car back and forth where everybody waved and no unfriendly gestures,'' she said. She said Houston's heat was not too much for the summit spouses. ``All of these ladies have been in hot places before,'' she said. ``I've been to Malaysia on state trips and you just learn to glow in public. ... How much are they outdoors? Nothing. Twenty minutes at the most.'' Mrs. Bush took several of the spouses to San Antonio on Tuesday for a tour of the Alamo and other sights. The White House released a full transcript of Mrs. Bush's interview Monday by the Houston Chronicle, the Houston Post, the San Antonio Light and the San Antonio Express News.

DOC.HEAD: Wyoming's 100 Birthday Celebrated With Renactment, Buffalo Burgers
DOC.TEXT: A century of statehood was celebrated Tuesday in Wyoming with free Buffalo burgers and a reminder that the state was the first to give women voting rights. Under mostly sunny skies state officials and dignitaries in Cheyenne re-enacted the statehood ceremonies led in 1890 by Francis E. Warren, Wyoming's last territorial governor and its first elected governor. The thousands who jammed the Statehouse lawns to watch the event cheered time and again at the mention of women's rights. Gov. Mike Sullivan, reciting Warren's speech, generated cheers when he got to the section noting that Wyoming's Constitution granted ``free and equal suffrage to its citizens, regardless of sex.'' That section had troubled U.S. senators who on June 27, 1890, were shocked by the idea that this frontier territory seeking admission into the Union wanted to give women the right to vote. A senator from Alabama said women were too dainty to dabble in politics. But when the issue came to a vote the Senate gave its approval 29-18. On July 10, 1890, President Benjamin Harrison signed the bill admitting Wyoming to the Union as the 44th state _ and the first to grant women the right to vote. This rich history was lost on 9-year-old Steve Miller of Cheyenne, who came downtown at 6 a.m. so he could be first in line for one of the 10,000 buffalo burgers being given away free. Five hours later, Steve had a burger, pickles, and potato chips on his plate and he found a spot on the lawn to enjoy the meal. He would have gone back for seconds but, ``They got to serve the other people,'' he said matter-of-factly.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 19th graf, `In the ...' to CORRECT reference to G-24 Ministerial, sted G-34.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a text of the political declaration issued Tuesday at the 1990 economic summit of industrialized nations: Securing Democracy: 1. We, the leaders of our seven countries and the representatives of the European Community, salute the men and women around the world whose courage and wisdom have inspired and brought about the historic advances of democracy we have witnessed over the past year. As we enter the final decade of this century, which we intend should be a decade of democracy, we reiterate our commitment to support the strengthening of democracy, human rights, and economic reconstruction and development through market-oriented economies. We emphasize the important opportunity provided in this forum for representatives from Europe, Japan, and North America to discuss critical challenges of the coming years. 2. Europe is at the dawn of a new era. We welcome enthusiastically the profound and historic changes sweeping the continent. The London Declaration on a Transformed North Atlantic Alliance provides a new basis for cooperation among former adversaries in building a stable, secure, and peaceful Europe. We are determined to seize all opportunities to achieve a Europe whole and free and recognize the European Community's contribution to that effort. We applaud the unification of Germany, which is a tangible expression of mankind's inalienable right to self-determination and a major contribution to stability in Europe. We welcome the replacement of repressive regimes in Central and Eastern Europe by governments freely chosen by their peoples. We applaud the introduction of the rule of law and the freedoms that are the bedrock of a democratic state. We urge Romania, following recent events, to adhere to the positive trend taking place in other countries of Central and Eastern Europe. 3. We welcome the intention of the Soviet Union to move toward a democratic political system, as well as Soviet attempts to reform their economy along market principles. We commit ourselves to working with the Soviet Union to assist its efforts to create an open society, a pluralistic democracy, and a market-oriented economy. Such changes will enable the Soviet Union to fulfill its responsibilities in the community of nations founded on these principles. We are heartened by indications that a constructive dialogue is under way between the Soviet government and the Baltic states, and we urge all sides to continue this dialogue in a democratic spirit. 4. The advance of democracy accompanied by market-oriented economic reforms is not just a European phenomenon. Since we last met, we have witnessed the spread of democratic values in many parts of the world. In Asia, there are encouraging signs of new political openness in Mongolia and Nepal. In the Philippines, the government continues to engage in courageous efforts to consolidate democracy. We acknowledge some of the recent developments in China, but believe that the prospects for closer cooperation will be enhanced by renewed political and economic reform, particularly in the field of human rights. We agree to maintain the measures put into place at last year's summit, as modified over the course of this year. We will keep them under review for future adjustments to respond to further positive developments in China. For example, in addition to existing lending to meet basic human needs, we will explore whether there are other World Bank loans that would contribute to reform of the Chinese economy, especially loans that would address environmental concerns. 5. In Africa, we hope that Namibia's attainment of independence and democracy will be a positive example for freedom, pluralism, and market-oriented economic reform throughout the continent. We also welcome the positive developments that have taken place in South Africa, especially the launching of talks between the government and representatives of the black majority. We hope this will lead to a peaceful transition to a non-racial democracy and the complete dismantlement of the apartheid system. We will continue to support this process and we call on all parties to refrain from violence or its advocacy. 6. In Latin America, we welcome the re-establishment of freedom and democracy in Chile. We applaud the recent fair and free elections in Nicaragua, as well as progress on the path to peace through dialogue in El Salvador and Guatemala. We encourage the efforts of the Panamanian government to re-establish democracy and the rule of law. We note with satisfaction the positive evolution in Haiti. We hope that Cuba will take steps to join the democratic trend in the rest of Latin America. 7. While we applaud the reduction of ideological conflicts that have divided much of the world since the end of the Second World War, we note with deep concern the reemergence of intolerance affecting ethnic and religious groups. We agree that such intolerance can lead to conflicts, which can threaten fundamental human rights, as well as political and economic development. 8. We reaffirm our commitment to the fundamental principles we seek to realize in our own societies, and we underscore that political and economic freedoms are closely linked and mutually reinforcing. Each of us stands ready to help in practical ways those countries that choose freedom, through the provision of constitutional, legal, and economic know-how and through economic assistance, as appropriate. In drawing from our different constitutional and historical experiences, we stand ready, individually and jointly in relevant fora, to: _ Assist in the drafting of laws, including bills of rights and civil, criminal and economic framework laws. _ Advise in the fostering of independent media. _ Establish training programs in government, management, and technical fields. _ Develop and expand people-to-people contacts and exchange programs to help diffuse understanding and knowledge. In the same spirit, the recent G-24 Ministerial agreed to extend its assistance in Central and Eastern Europe in parallel with progress in political and economic reform. We agree the challenge facing the industrialized democracies is to continue the effort already under way in Europe while expanding efforts to support political reform and economic development in other parts of the world. We call on our people and the people of other democracies to join in this great endeavor.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Parliament Opens First Session Without President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with parliament is first freely elected in 58 years, students continue protest, anti-Turkish demonstrations, prosecutor sets date for conclusion of Zhivkov investigation. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Bulgaria's first freely elected Parliament in 58 years faced a constitutional crisis on Tuesday as it convened its inaugural session without a president. Petar Mladenov resigned the presidency last Friday after admitting he suggested in December that tanks be used to disperse tens of thousands of demonstrators rallying against communist power. Mladenov had been instrumental a month earlier in toppling Bulgaria's hard-line leaders, but the Communist Party remained in control of the government. The party later renamed itself the Socialist Party. Meanwhile, the student protesters who forced Mladenov's resignation continued a sit-down strike in front of the presidential palace in Sofia, the capital. The students, camped in about 150 tents near the palace, said they had collected nearly 9,000 signatures on petitions demanding the new president be a non-Socialist and that Premier Andrei Lukanov resign, the official BTA news agency said. The petitions also called for a public and televised trial of ousted Communist strongman Todor Zhivkov. The students began their sit-in to protest alleged manipulations in last month's parliamentary elections, in which the Socialists won a majority of seats. The new parliament's opening ceremony was held in a wood-paneled hall in this ancient Bulgarian capital, 150 miles northeast of Sofia. The opening session, a ceremonial affair held in sweltering heat, was adjourned after only 40 minutes and will resume July 17 at the parliament building in Sofia. It was opened by Yosif Petrov, at 81 the oldest deputy. In a brief opening speech, Alexander Lilov, chairman of the Socialist Party, said: ``The time of the totalitarian parliament is over. Now is the time of the democratic parliament.'' But he added: ``We are against chaos and destabilization in the country. Everyone has the right to protest, but everyone has also the obligation to work.'' As the Parliament convened, three small right-wing nationalist parties organized demonstrations in Veliko Turnovo and other cities to protest the representation of ethnic Turks in the legislature. BTA said anti-Turkish protesters staged five-minute strikes in the northern city of Razgrad and the southern city of Kurdzhali, where almost half the population are ethnic Turks. The news agency said nationalist demonstrators also staged a two-hour blockade of the highway linking Ruse near the Romanian border and the Black Sea port of Varna. The protesters were demanding the new parliament invalidate the election of 23 ethnic Turkish deputies representing the Movement for Rights and Freedoms. They accused the primarily ethnic Turkish party of cherishing ``pan-Turkish and pan-Islamic aspirations,'' BTA said. The party's leader, Ahmed Dogan, who was attending the opening parliamentary session, refused comment on the protests. The Movement for Rights and Freedoms is the third largest party in the 400-seat Grand National Assembly, or parliament. The Socialists have 211 seats and the Union of Democratic Forces, the main opposition coalition, have 144. The Grand National Assembly's first task will be to agree on a presidential candidate and elections. There is no precedent for electing a president in Bulgaria's parliamentary history. The Parliament may either decide to elect the president or call a referendum. Mladenov's departure came less than three weeks after his party of reformed Communists won the elections. Mladenov was instrumental in the ousting of Zhivkov. Prodded by popular demonstrations, Mladenov then played a key role in reforming the party. His departure has weakened the ruling Socialists and created a power vacuum. In another development, the chief prosecutor's office announced that it will complete its preliminary investigation of Zhivkov on July 18. The prosecutor would then have one month to decide whether to put Zhivkov on trial, and, if so, set a date for the proceedings. Zhivkov has been under investigation for alleged abuse of power, incitement to ethnic hatred and misappropriation of state property. One of the ousted leader's defense attorney's protested the announcement of a date for concluding the investigation, saying it created the impression that Zhivkov's defense is being ignored.

DOC.HEAD: Summit Leaders Salute Political Changes in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Western leaders paid tribute Tuesday to East Europeans who have overthrown repressive regimes to bring about political and economic changes on their continent. They urged troubled Romania to follow the example of its neighbors. President Bush and the leaders of six other rich democracies attending their annual economic summit hailed the moves in Central and Eastern Europe toward democratically elected governments and free-market economies. ``Europe is at the dawn of a new era,'' they said in a political statement. ``We welcome enthusiastically the profound and historic changes sweeping the continent.'' They said they wanted to ``seize all opportunities to achieve a Europe whole and free'' and welcomed the drive toward unification of the two German states. The German merger, they said, should contribute to stability in Europe. The leaders called on Romania ``to adhere to the positive trend'' unfolding in neighboring countries. The Bucharest government has been accused of complicity in the recent violent repression of anti-government protestors. They said they were ready to give fledgling democracies needed constitutional, legal and economic advice and financial assistance ``as appropriate.'' The leaders' remarks underscored their efforts to aid the countries in Eastern Europe as they pull away from the Soviet Union, long their main support. At last year's summit in Paris, Bush and his counterparts asked the European Community, the 12-nation trading bloc, to fashion an aid program to encourage the changes unfolding in Poland and Hungary. In just a year, two-dozen wealthy nations, including the United States, France, West Germany and Japan, have promised to give more than $12 billion in loans, technical advice and food supplies to Poland and Hungary. Reacting to appeals from other East European countries, they agreed last week to draw Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia into the program. Romania was temporarily denied membership because of the political repression there. It's not known how much the West will be able to raise for the four new additions to the aid program but help will likely be substantial. In a report on the program, the community's executive body said the assistance ``is making a major contribution'' in helping the sick economies of Poland and Hungary. ``It has underpinned a radical stabilization program in Poland, which might otherwise have proved too risky, and helped both countries to begin modernizing their economies,'' it said. In handing out the aid, the Western nations insist that the new democracies commit themselves to the rule of law, respect for human rights, introduce multi-party political systems, hold free and fair elections, and impose economic reforms. ``Leaders in Central and Eastern Europe who seek radical change in their countries' political and economic systems, accept the conditionality attaching to (Western) assistance as a spur to reform,'' said the community report. ``It is also a guarantee to their peoples that the international community is paying close attention to the respect for political and economic freedom in their countries,'' it said. The money is designed to help East European officials change their outdated economies from centrally planned ones to free-market systems. To do that, the governments must build from the ground up. They need to get rid of government subsidies to farmers and others, stabilize prices and bolster worthless currencies. They must develop banking systems and labor markets. The community said in its report that the changes are indispensable but may well lead, at least temporarily, to higher unemployment and reduced living standards.

DOC.HEAD: Miners Strike in Soviet Far East
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet coal miners walked off the job early Wednesday in a 24-hour strike aimed at pressing the government to resign and the Communist Party to give up its privileges. Strike committee spokesman Alexei Solovyev said miners struck in the Kuznetsk coal basin of western Siberia as the new day began. In Donetsk, center of the eastern Ukraine's coal-mining region, strike committee organizers fanned out to boost support among miners for a one-day strike and rally Wednesday. In a telephone interview from Kemerovo, Solovyev estimated 300,000 miners would walk out in western Siberia. He said 61 of 130 mines would strike for the entire day, and the rest would strike for part of the day. Workers from 20 major industrial enterprises will join them, he said. In Donetsk, strike leaders presented demands that the government of Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov resign; that Communist Party representation be eliminated at factories and mines, in the KGB, army and police; that political education classes for young children be eliminated; and that party property be nationalized. Organizers said about half the Donetsk area's 250 mines would strike on Wednesday, and the rest would show support by sending representatives to a demonstration in Donetsk. At a rally Tuesday night attended by about 150 miners, strike organizer Yevgeny Moiseyev asked them to support him in ``putting the party on trial.'' A handwritten notice calling for Ryzhkov's resignation was posted on a bulletin board next to official notices about mine activities. Workers at the Kalinin and Panfilovsky shafts in the Donetsk basin, in the eastern Ukraine, voted this week to evict party representatives from mine offices. The Postfactum news service, affiliated with Moscow radio, reported that 12 of 13 mines in the Vorkuta area of the Soviet Far North voted to join the walkout. Miners from all three regions walked out last summer, demanding more pay and improved vacation benefits, better housing and better supplies of consumer goods. Miners say the government has not fulfilled its promises to improve conditions for them. The strike came during the Communist Party's 28th Congress in Moscow, and a day after Teimuraz Avaliani, a leader of last year's strike in the Kemerovo region, stood against Mikhail S. Gorbachev in the election for party leadership. Gorbachev easily defeated Avaliani, and Solovyev said Avaliani's candidacy would hurt his popularity among miners who are highly critical of the Communist Party. ``I think that he betrayed our prinicples consenting to run for this high position,'' Solovyev said. ``I am sure that this will have a negative effect on his prestige down here.''

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Produce Heavy Rain In Pennsylvania
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms dumped heavy rain on parts of central Pennsylvania early Tuesday, with scattered storms from Kansas to Illinois. The storms dumped one to two inches of rain by Tuesday afternoon in Armstrong County, Pa., where 5.1 inches fell Monday. Showers and thunderstorms developing along the same stationary front that was operating in Pennsylvania were scattered from Kansas through Missouri and Iowa to Illinois during the early afternoon. Norfolk, Neb. received 1\ inches of rain during the six hour period ending at 2 p.m. EDT. Widely scattered showers and thunderstorms ranged from the lower Mississippi Valley to the southern Atlantic Coast states, and along the central Gulf Coast, with showers and thunderstorms rather numerous in southern Florida. Key West received more than 1{ inches of rain. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation, with sunny skies west of the Rockies. Temperatures warmed into the 90s from the southern Plains to the southern and middle Atlantic Coast region, with readings near 100 degrees in South Carolina. The temperature at the airport in Raleigh-Durham, N.C., reached 97 degrees, setting a record high for the date and the hottest day so far this year. The high of 99 in Greensboro also broke the record for the date. Afternoon temperatures were in the 70s and upper 60s across Michigan. Temperatures in the West at midday varied from the 60s along the northern and central Pacific Coast to the 90s in the southwestern deserts. The low for the nation this morning was 39 degrees at Yellowstone Park, Wyo.

DOC.HEAD: Nazi-Era Collaborator Revisits Scene of Crime in France
DOC.TEXT: French war criminal Paul Touvier visited a Jesuit college on Tuesday where his pro-Nazi militia imprisoned seven Jews before executing them during World War II. Touvier, 74, who worked closely with Lyon Gestapo chief Klaus Barbie during the occupation, left his prison cell near Paris under armed guard to visit his former headquarters. The tour was ordered by Jean-Pierre Getti, the magistrate gathering evidence to prosecute Touvier on charges of crimes against humanity. Touvier and other witnesses, some wearing hoods to conceal their identities, together toured the grounds of the college that served as a militia detention center in mid-1944. One charge accuses Touvier of responsibility in executing seven Jewish detainees on June 28, 1944. The prisoners were shot in nearby Rilleux-la-Pape in reprisal for a Resistance raid. On Monday, Robert Nathan, whose father was arrested on May 19, 1944, by Touvier and executed three months later, asked Getti to open up a new charge of crimes against humanity against Touvier. Touvier was arrested during the liberation of France, but escaped. He was twice convicted of war crimes and sentenced to death in his absence. Under a 20-year statute of limitations, those sentences could not be carried out. In 1973, he went into hiding after new charges were raised and was not found until police arrested him in May 1989 at the St. Francis Priory in Nice. The priory was run by followers of Archbishop Marcel Lefevbre, the fundamentalist priest excommunicated from the Roman Catholic Church. Touvier denies responsibility for killings, torture and sending suspects to the Gestapo during the war. He also denies blowing up a synagogue in 1943. Barbie was convicted in 1987 of crimes against humanity and is serving a life sentence in France. Getti questioned Barbie and others last month.

DOC.HEAD: Journalist Released From Jail After Revealing Source
LaserPhoto SA5
DOC.TEXT: A television newsman jailed for refusing to identify a confidential source emerged free from a courtroom Tuesday after giving the judge his source's name. The source released KMOL-TV reporter Brian Karem from his promise of confidentiality Monday night, Karem said, after the U.S. Supreme Court declined his second request to be freed. ``I want to see my wife and my son and take a day off and eat some pizza and drink some beer and never wear orange again,'' Karem said after his release. The 29-year-old broadcast journalist, who wore an orange uniform during his two weeks in jail, was held in contempt of court and sentenced to six months in jail for refusing to say who helped arrange a telephone interview last year with jailed murder suspect Henry David Hernandez. Hernandez and his brother, Julian, are charged in the March 1989 shooting death of a San Antonio police officer. Henry David Hernandez told Karem that he shot policeman Gary Williams in self-defense. Lawyers in the Hernandez case said they needed to know who arranged the interview to determine whether it could be admitted as evidence. Karem on Tuesday identified the source as Deborah Ledesma, a cousin of Hernandez's. He handed over a notebook page containing names and phone numbers of those who helped set up the interview. The reporter said he would do it again if it meant keeping a promise to a source. ``I didn't intend to prove anything. I just intended to keep my promise, so I kept my promise,'' he said. State District Judge Pat Priest questioned the woman's need to remain anonymous, then freed Karem from the contempt citation. Outside the courtroom, Karem kissed and hugged his wife Pam. Their 18-month-old son Zachary, who had been carried out of the courtroom when he shouted ``Daddy, Daddy, Daddy'' and waved at Karem, slept in a stroller. Karem accused lawyers in the Hernandez case of using him to do their investigative work. ``The press should be the last place that prosecutors and defense attorneys go to seek their information _ not the first,'' Karem said. ``They never tried anyone else before they came to me.'' Defense attorneys and prosecutors grilled Karem about whether Bexar County Sheriff Harlon Copeland helped arrange the interview. Although Copeland's name was in his notes, Karem said he did not speak with him directly in setting up the phone conversation. Last week Copeland said he tracked down Karem's source and correctly identified her. But Karem had refused to confirm Ms. Ledesma was his source. Ms. Ledesma, now living in Santa Clara, Calif., told attorneys Monday she arranged a conversation in March 1989 between Hernandez and Karem. Karem said that was one of two phone conversations he had with Hernandez that night. Karem said he agreed to keep Ms. Ledesma's name secret because she feared some of Hernandez's family members. ``She didn't want her name attached to it, and she even said she didn't want her employer knowing I was talking to her,'' Karem said. Karem lost two Supreme Court bids to remain free while he appealed the contempt of court citation. His appeal of the citation, which was still before the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, now becomes moot.

DOC.HEAD: Asteroid Passes Only 3 Million Miles From Earth
DOC.TEXT: An asteroid hurtled across Earth's orbit at a distance of only 3 million miles Tuesday _ a close encounter on the astronomical scale, planetary scientists said. The asteroid, dubbed 1990 MF, made one of the closer crossings of Earth orbit observed in the last 50 years. It had been tracked since Jet Propulsion Laboratory planetary scientist Eleanor Helin discovered it on June 26. The rocky object's diameter was estimated at 300 feet to 1,000 feet and it was projected to have accelerated to 22,000 mph at its closest approach. Helin, head of the Palomar Planet-Crossing Asteroid Survey, said there are a dozen asteroids that are considered to have come relatively close. The closest was last year when an asteroid passed at a distance of 460,000 to 480,000 miles from Earth. An earlier one was just under 500,000 miles. The 1990 MF asteroid is among 10 in the 3 million-mile range. ``These are all close encounters astronomically,'' Helin said.

DOC.HEAD: Political Unrest Shakes African Nations
With AM-Kenya, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The anti-government protests in Kenya are the latest in a string of political explosions that have rocked Africa in recent months, turmoil touched off by opposition to single-party rule, rising food prices and skyrocketing foreign debt. Here is a look at recent developments:
DOC.HEAD: IVORY COAST
DOC.TEXT: Protests in March against austerity measures and corruption grew into violent anti-government demonstrations demanding that President Felix Houphouet-Boigny relinquish his 30-year monopoly on power. The protests forced him to order legalization of political parties other than his own Democratic Party. The Ivory Coast constitution allows opposition, but those who have tried to activate such political groups have been harassed and their groups have been refused registration on technical grounds.
DOC.HEAD: ZAIRE
DOC.TEXT: President Mobutu Sese Seko has offered reassurances that he will not reverse his surprise decision to convert the Central African nation to a multiparty system. In a message to the National Assembly, he promised political reforms announced April 24 would proceed, but warned he would not tolerate disorder. The Zairean leader, who has held absolute power since 1965, surprised the country by appointing a transitional government to oversee elections to install a democratic government within a year.
DOC.HEAD: GABON
DOC.TEXT: On May 21, the Gabon government installed a multiparty system. National elections are scheduled for September. President Omar Bongo has ruled Gabon, an oil-exporting country with a population of 1.2 million, since 1967. He declared a one-party state in 1968 and has been re-elected unopposed four times, most recently in November 1986. Following a failed coup attempt in October 1989, and student protests in January and February, his Gabon Progress Party pressed for a multiparty system.
DOC.HEAD: ZAMBIA
DOC.TEXT: On July 1, a failed coup followed five days of the bloodiest urban violence in Zambia's history, triggered by student rioting over food price increases. The students also demanded a Western-style democracy. At least 23 people were slain, most of them looters, according to officials. At least 34 students were detained. The Bembas, Zambia's biggest tribe, wield most economic, political and military power, but like other Zambians many have become disenchanted with rising unemployment, steep inflation and top-level corruption. President Kenneth Kaunda heads the United National Independence Party, the only legal political movement in Zambia since a one-party state was imposed in 1972.

DOC.HEAD: Survey: Californians Don't Eat Enough Cancer-Fighting Fruits, Veggies
DOC.TEXT: The image of the health and diet conscious Californian was debunked Tuesday by a new study that shows two-thirds of state residents don't eat enough fruits and vegetables. ``It's part of the myth of California,'' state Health Director Kenneth Kizer said. ``People are just not aware of the link between diet and cancer. If people make the link, their consumption of fruits and vegetables does go up. ``(Now), they're eating too many Fruit Loops and not enough fruit salads.'' With the produce section of a supermarket as a backdrop, Kizer released the 1989 California Dietary Practices Survey two years after the state launched a ``five servings a day'' educational program. Health officials say people should increase their consumption of dietary fiber, which helps prevent cancer, by eating at least five servings of fruits or vegetables each day. But the survey found that fewer than two out of three Californians actually do so. One out of five doesn't eat any fruit during an average day, the report found, and 27 percent eat no vegetables. ``Californians are really not much better than the rest of the nation when it comes to their diets,'' said Karen Bunch, director of the survey research team. ``We do eat more fruit than the rest of the nation, but not more vegetables.'' Nationwide, 45 percent of Americans don't eat fruit or drink juice during the day, and 22 percent don't eat vegetables or salads, Ms. Bunch said. Californians also appear to be less informed than the rest of the nation about the importance of eating fruits and vegetables as part of a healthy diet, the survey found. Forty percent of Californians surveyed said they don't believe that what a person eats can affect their chances of getting cancer, compared to 33 percent in a nationwide survey in 1987. The report concluded that fruit and vegetable consumption increased with education, income and knowledge about the link between diet and health. ``Too many Californians are not aware of the link between diet and cancer,'' Kizer said, adding that 150,000 Californians die each year from diseases related to a poor diet. He said 35 percent of cancers can be prevented by eating more fruits and vegetables, as can 20 percent of heart diseases. Even when Californians do eat fruits and vegetables, they don't show much imagination: their diets don't normally include some of the more exotic varieties now available in supermarkets. Of those who eat fruits and vegetables, the No. 1 choice was orange juice (28.3 percent) and green salad (28.6 percent), the survey found. In order of popularity, the top 10 fruits consumed included orange juice, bananas, apples, peaches, oranges, cantaloupes, plums, watermelon, apple juice and nectarines. For vegetables, the top 10 list, in order of popularity, included green salad, potatoes, tomatoes, lettuce, mixed vegetables, corn, carrots, broccoli, green beans and onions. ``People are just not in the habit of eating right, and when they do eat fruits and vegetables they eat the same things,'' Bunch said. ``It took Kiwi fruit 10 years to catch on. There are so many varieties out there. I mean, it's not like boring oat bran.'' The telephone survey, conducted from May through September 1989, randomly questioned 1,000 California residents about what they had eaten during the previous 24 hours. The survey has a 3 percentage-point margin of error.

DOC.HEAD: Nunn Plan Would Cut Military By 285,000 to Meet Budget Cuts
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Armed Services Committee chairman, facing demands for deeper cuts in defense than he has proposed, has laid out an alternative that calls for a cut of 285,000 military personnel, congressional sources said Tuesday. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., in closed-door sessions with members of his panel, suggested the deep personnel cut to illustrate the impact on the military from significant reductions in defense spending. Nunn has argued the money would have to come from personnel and readiness to meet budget cuts many Democrats have demanded, saying the reductions couldn't come from major weapons systems where the money is spent over several years. To meet the defense total of $294 billion approved by the Senate Budget Committee and its chairman, Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., Nunn said the nation's armed forces that currently total 2.1 million would have to be reduced by 285,000, said sources, who requested anonymity. However, to meet Nunn's defense figure of $297 billion, the cut in personnel would total 100,000, the sources said. If approved by the committee later this week, the full Senate will then be forced to choose between Nunn's budget with its smaller cut in personnel or the package based on Sasser's defense total. The Senate is expected to consider the two bills just prior to the August recess. The committee began crafting defense legislation for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The process has been delayed by the inability of White House and congressional negotiators to agree on how to reduce the federal budget deficit by $50 billion, and at the same time decide on a 1991 defense total. Without a single figure for the military, Nunn decided that the committee would draw up two bills _ one to his total and another to the amount approved by the Senate Budget Committee. In the meetings with his panel, Nunn spelled out for lawmakers how an additional $3 billion cut would result in nearly three times the reduction in personnel, said the sources, who requested anonymity. The panel is also weighing proposals that would slash President Bush's $2.2 billion request for the program to place MX nuclear missiles on railroad cars, said congressional sources. The plan currently before the Armed Services Committee calls for $548 million in research and development money and elimination of the $1.3 billion in procurement and $269 million in military construction. Meanwhile in the House, where congressional sources say committee action on the defense bill may be delayed until September, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., met with the panel's chairman, Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., to discuss whether the budget summit would hold up work on the defense bill. Foley, in an interview with reporters, said he wants to see the authorization bill completed before the August recess and prior to defense appropriations legislation.

DOC.HEAD: Moore Sentenced To Five Years, 10 Months, Fined $170,000
DOC.TEXT: Former three-term Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr., convicted of corruption and characterized as remoreseless by prosecutors, was sentenced Tuesday to five years and 10 months in prison and fined $170,000. Moore, 67, pleaded guilty to charges of mail fraud, extortion, obstruction of justice and filing false income taxes during his 1984 and 1988 campaigns and during his third term, from 1985-89. He lost the 1988 reelection bid. He was ordered to report to the Federal Correctional Institution near Petersburg, Va., by July 31. U.S. District Judge Walter Hoffman on Monday had refused to let Moore withdraw his guilty pleas. ``No governor or other public official of that responsibility has ever been convicted for election fraud of this scope,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Joe Savage said before sentencing. ``Arch Moore is a criminal,'' he said. ``If there is one thing missing from that man, it's remorse.'' Moore, a Republican who also was governor from 1969-1977, and a U.S. congressman for 12 years, appeared stoic during the sentencing and later declined comment. An appeal is pending, said defense attorney William Hundley. U.S. Attorney Michael Carey said Moore likely will serve at least 2{ years before being considered for parole. ``I think it sends a very clear message,'' Carey said. ``If you violate the public trust, you go to jail.'' Carey's investigation into state government corruption also has netted the convictions of five legislators, three lobbyists and a state Senate aide. Moore pleaded guilty May 8 to extorting $573,000 from coal operator H. Paul Kizer in return for a $2.1 million refund from the state's Black Lung Fund, which provides benefits to coal miners. Moore also pleaded guilty to trying to block a federal grand jury investigation into corruption in his administration. And he admitted filing false income tax returns in 1984 and 1985 and defrauding the state of his salary and benefits by funneling $100,000 in illegal cash payments into his 1984 campaign, to buy votes. Hoffman sentenced Moore to five years for extortion, six months for mail fraud and two years each for the tax fraud charges, all concurrent. Moore also got 10 months for the obstruction of justice charge, which carries that mandatory prison term. Hundley said Moore's corruption involved campaign-funding violations, not raids on the treasury, and added, ``I submit he served well and honorably.'' Moore is the second West Virginia governor to be convicted on federal charges. W.W. ``Wally'' Barron, a Democrat who served from 1961-1965, was convicted of bribing the foreman of a jury that acquitted him of bribery in 1968. He served three years and four months of a 12-year sentence. Moore was acquitted in 1976 of extorting $25,000 from a financial holding company trying to get a state bank charter. Hoffman rejected a separate state petition seeking to recover $4 million from Moore because of his corruption, saying the petition was filed too late. Before sentencing, Moore was subpoenaed by the state Bar, which is seeking to annul his law license. He also will lose his $1,738.23-a-month pension. Moore's 1988 campaign chairman, John Leaberry, was charged Tuesday with filing a false income tax return for 1988. Leaberry, who has cooperated in the government's case against Moore, is expected to plead guilty.

DOC.HEAD: Official: Won't Allow U.S. Troops Ever to Operate in Colombia
DOC.TEXT: A government official said Tuesday that Colombia will never allow U.S. troops to conduct anti-drug operations on its territory, saying such ``Rambo-type actions'' were better suited for American cities. Foreign Minister Julio Londono made his remarks in a radio interview with the RCN network in response to an article in the July 16 issue of Newsweek. The Newsweek article said the U.S. Southern Command, based in Panama, was drawing up contingency plans for U.S. troops to play a support role in a dramatic series of anti-drug strikes aimed at crippling the cocaine cartels in Peru, Bolivia and Colombia. However, the magazine said such raids were unlikely to happen anytime soon _or possibly ever _ because of opposition in Congress and the State Department's reluctance to offend Latin American countries. Colombian news media interpreted the Newsweek article as suggesting U.S. troops might be used in Colombia. But Londono said Colombia was opposed to any U.S. military intervention, and said Washington could best assist in the drug war by helping the local economy. ``... Where these Rambo-type actions are needed is in the big North American cities where big distribution centers are found and drugs are sold on street corners with the knowledge of American authorities,'' Londono told RCN. ``If any (U.S.) aid is needed, it should be in the form of paying fair prices for our export products and avoiding import taxes on our agricultural and industrial products,'' he added. Newsweek said the military's contingency plans called for the forces of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia to attack local cartel targets. While U.S. forces would not be used in actual strikes, all the logistics, planning, training and support would be provided by the Americans, the magazine said. The magazine, quoting an unidentified intelligence source, said the Pentagon has plans to use U.S. special forces to capture Colombian drug lords on orders from President Bush. Colombia has a deep-rooted sensitivity to a U.S. military presence dating almost 90 years to the construction of the Panama Canal. Panama was long a part of Colombia, but in 1903 the United States backed a group of rebels who established a separate republic and signed a treaty for construction of the canal. The U.S. government has repeatedly demonstrated over the years that it understands Colombia's sensitivity about any U.S. military role here. Last year, President Bush sent Bogota $65 million worth of military aid for the anti-drug war. The U.S. military transport planes flying in the equipment stayed only a few hours in Bogota, and the 150 American military technicians spent a few days in Colombia to help set up the equipment and train troops in its use. Even so, the Colombian news media ran several stories about the presence of U.S. troops in the country at the time.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Grants Injunction Blocking Learnfare in Milwaukee Schools
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Tuesday suspended part of a Wisconsin experiment that cuts the welfare benefits of families whose children skip school, ruling that record-keeping errors have resulted in cruel treatment. An recent audit of the program showed that some families were being wrongly penalized because of poorly kept school attendance records. A lawsuit against the program said one family was evicted from its home and others had to turn to food pantries for food. U.S. District Judge Terence T. Evans ordered the suspension of Learnfare in Milwaukee public schools at least until an improved system of recording school absences in the state's largest city was devised. ``It is an experiment with worthy goals of attempting to reduce welfare dependency and provide incentives for children to stay in school,'' Evans wrote in his ruling. But recipients of Aid to Families with Dependent Children ``should not be made homeless and hungry in the name of social experimentation,'' he said. Evans granted a preliminary injunction requested by the advocacy group Legal Action of Wisconsin on behalf of six Milwaukee families whose AFDC benefits were cut by Learnfare. The injunction applies only to the 3,200 teen-agers attending Milwaukee Public Schools who have lost or are in danger of losing AFDC benefits under Learnfare. State officials said the program would continue elsewhere in the state. Learnfare, authorized by the Legislature in 1987, allows the state to cut a family's monthly AFDC benefits if a school reports a student has been consistently absent without excuse. Penalties average about $100 a month for an average family receiving $517 a month in benefits. The program applies to teen-agers, but Gov. Tommy G. Thompson has received permission from the federal government to expand it to include elementary school students. Thompson said late Tuesday the injunction was not a judgement of the merits of Learnfare, but of administrative problems in Milwaukee's public schools. ``There's no question Learnfare is a good program. It's working,'' he said. ``What's wrong is .. some very poor record keeping. I'm just happy the injunction was granted in the summertime.'' The Milwaukee lawsuit filed in December charged the program violates the Social Security Act and the U.S. Constitution. It named as defendants the state Department of Health and Social Services and the Milwaukee County Department of Social Services. It cited problems with the administration of Learnfare, especially attendance-keeping procedures in the Milwaukee Public Schools, and the state's appeals hearing process. Evans said he would lift the injunction if the state and Milwaukee County remedy their problems with monitoring school absences. Legal Action attorney Patricia DeLessio said 1,600 to 2,000 Milwaukee students are sanctioned each month under the program. She said Evans' injunction did not address all of the legal challenges of Learnfare pending in the courts. ``We focused on the immediate administrative problems which I would describe as glaring,'' she said. ``It means welfare benefits will not be cut any longer.'' Assembly Speaker Thomas Loftus, a Democrat who is challenging Thompson in this fall's governor's race, predicted the injunction would put a halt to Learnfare. ``I think it will stop it dead in its tracks for the foreseeable future,'' Loftus said.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Director's Wife Flew on Government Planes for Free, Report Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 9th graf pvs, The payment, to ADD that six trips paid for were official trips; picks up 10th graf pvs, Justice Department
DOC.TEXT: The wife of FBI Director William S. Sessions accompanied her husband on 17 official trips aboard government aircraft but paid for only one flight, according to a report released Tuesday. Alice Sessions accompanied her husband on a variety of business trips from Washington to destinations including Key West, Fla.; Williamsburg, Va.; San Francisco; and New Orleans, from Aug. 11, 1988 through July 31, 1989, said the report by the General Accounting Office. While it didn't question the propriety of the trips, the watchdog unit of Congress criticized the Justice Department for failing to study the cost of using aircraft seized from convicted criminals to transport Sessions and Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. The GAO said it believed the department could save money by leasing planes. FBI spokesman Robert Davenport said Mrs. Sessions did not reimburse the agency for the trips because she was accompanying her husband on official business. Davenport said Mrs. Sessions did pay the FBI $280 to cover one leg of a trip that included a stopover in San Antonio, Texas, for personal business. Sessions made 36 trips, generally to visit FBI field offices and to make speeches to judicial and police groups. Thornburgh made 39 trips during the period aboard the government-owned aircraft, mainly to give speeches and attend meetings. Five months after the GAO began its study, Thornburgh reimbursed the Justice Department $2,128 for eight trips his wife took on the government planes, the report said. The payment included $1,371 for six official trips that Mrs. Thornburgh took during the 12-month period reviewed by GAO, the report said. Thornburgh also repaid the government $1,032 in 1989 for personal trips he and his family members took aboard the aircraft. Justice Department policy does not require Mrs. Thornburgh to pay for trips on official flights ``if there is an empty seat and the government would incur no extra cost,'' said department spokesman Dan Eramian. ``Mrs. Thornburgh preferred, in the exercise of an abundance of caution, to reimburse the government for the trips,'' Eramian said. In a letter to the Justice Department, Rep. Bob Wise, D-W.Va., criticized the agency for failure to adopt a travel policy, particularly regarding ``issues such as what constitutes an `official purpose' or `official function' and when non-official passengers should be permitted to fly on government aircraft.'' Wise, who asked for the report, said seven months have elapsed since he was told a policy was being drafted. Eramian said a policy will be adopted, adding: ``It would have been silly to put something together until we saw what the GAO recommendations were.'' The GAO study said the Justice Department failed to follow government guidelines when comparing the cost of using government aircraft seized from convicted criminals with the cost of using leased planes to transport Thornburgh and Sessions. The Justice Department's own analysis, conducted after the GA0 began its study, showed that the government was saving $500,000 a year to use the seized aircraft instead of leasing planes. ``If we had leased an aircraft and spent an extra half million a year, we would have received a larger dose of criticism,'' Eramian said. The GAO report noted concern for the security of both Thornburgh and Sessions, quoting from a 1989 Justice Department memo stating that the attorney general had been the subject of 13 threats during his first six months in office. The report also noted that the FBI had received reports last year that Thornburgh had been targeted by Colombian ``hit squads'' after Colombia resumed extraditing accused drug lords to this country.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Talks Resume With Goal of August Completion
DOC.TEXT: White House and congressional budget negotiators resumed their closed-door talks on Tuesday with bargainers hoping to complete a deal by Congress' August recess but unsure they can do so. Separately, the Bush administration renewed its call for a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget. A week before the House is scheduled to vote on the proposal, Democrats predicted they would defeat it. The budget talks, aimed at finding enough tax increases and spending cuts to save at least $50 billion next year, had been on hold since lawmakers began their Independence Day break on June 29. The negotiations got off to a slow start. Tuesday's morning session was abbreviated because White House budget chief Richard Darman testified at a House hearing on the balanced budget amendment. At a lunch with Senate Republicans, Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan said that a multi-year deficit-reduction package would help lower interest rates, participants said. Proponents of serious cuts in the government's $150 billion annual shortfalls have long argued that a major benefit would be lower interest rates. Some participants in the talks fear that unless they shake hands on a deal by the lawmakers' August break, Congress' budget work could extend into an unusual post-election session. But bargainers said they still had much work to do. ``I'd be very brave indeed if I told you we've approached a number,'' said negotiator Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn. Darman told the House Judiciary Committee's economic and commercial law subcommittee that the administration supports passage of a balanced budget amendment by the House. A vote is set for next Tuesday. Darman argued that the costs of many federal programs are being passed on to future generations in the form of government borrowing, which must be repaid. ``Although the voters of the present are extremely well-represented in our democratic system, the voters of the future are not,'' he told the subcommittee. But panel Chairman Jack Brooks, D-Texas, complained that the amendment requires a balanced budget without addressing how to achieve one. ``It's written in the words of Genesis, `Let there be a balanced budget,''' said Brooks. No. 3 House Democratic leader Rep. William H. Gray III, D-Pa., predicted that conservatives supporting the balanced budget measure would fall short of the two-thirds vote needed for approval of a proposed constitutional amendment.

DOC.HEAD: Two Palestinians Killed; Abie Nathan May be Charged with Illegal Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Police said they fired on a crowd of about 200 Palestinian protesters Tuesday near Shuafat refugee camp on the northern outskirts of Jerusalem, killing one teen-ager and wounding two. Police spokesman Uzi Sandori said the demonstrators blocked the main road near the shantytown of about 8,000 Palestinians and began hurling stones at passing vehicles. ``They then assaulted an outpost manned by three policemen who fired tear gas, rubber bullets and finally live ammunition to drive them back,'' he said. Doctors at Jerusalem's Mokassed Hospital said 16-year-old Mumzer Zuhdi Musa Adabed was brought in dead with a gunshot wound in his chest _ the 724th Palestinian killed by Israeli security forces or civilians since the 31-month-long revolt began. Forty-four Israelis have also been killed. In the occupied West Bank, a Palestinian identified as Salim Salah Khuly, 24, was found stabbed and beaten to death near Tulkarum. Residents said the victim was suspected of collaborating with Israeli authorities. The army confirmed the death but blamed the slaying on internal strife between rival Palestinian clans. Since the revolt began in December 1987, at least 233 Palestinians, including Khuly, were killed by fellow Arabs, most as suspected collaborators, drug dealers or prostitutes. In other developments Tuesday: _The attorney general ordered police to press charges against Israeli peace activist Abie Nathan for allegedly meeting with leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization in violation of Israeli law, Israel television said. _Doctors advised Foreign Minister David Levy to delay his meeting with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III in Paris next week pending an improvement in his health. Levy, 52, underwent surgery following a mild heart attack last month. Baker has sought for months to arrange Israeli-Palestinian negotiations, but his efforts have been deadlocked by Israel's insistence on excluding the PLO from talks. Israel views the PLO as a terrorist group. _Police announced the arrest of Israelis Eli Vanunu, 33, and Nir Ephroni, 27, for the 1984 murder of Omar Ahamad Uda, an Arab gas station attendant. They said the killing apparently was to avenge the death of an Israeli female soldier, believed killed by Palestinian nationalists. An informed Israeli source meanwhile said Israel supplied intelligence information to Washington indicating that an elite military unit within the PLO was behind the May 28 bombing at a Jerusalem vegetable market that killed one Israeli and wounded nine. Defense Ministry spokesman Dan Naveh declined comment and officials in Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's office said they knew of no such information. The bombing came two days prior to a failed speedboat attack on Israeli beaches by a splinter PLO faction. PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat refused to condemn that raid, leading to suspension of the 18-month-old U.S.-PLO dialogue, launched after Arafat renounced terrorism. The Israeli source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the bombing was the action of Force 17, a military unit set up by Arafat. The source said this information was passed on to the United States and likely played a role in President Bush's decision to cut off the U.S.-PLO dialogue.

DOC.HEAD: Quotes from Communist Party Congress in Moscow
With AM-Soviet Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Here are some quotes from the Soviet Communist Party Congress held Tuesday in Moscow.
``I maintain only one thing: The policy that I have chosen I will pursue, and for me the biggest prize is that my homeland will live.'' _ Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
``It is an illusion to think that after all dissenters, all who do not wish to be drive belts and cogs of the apparatus, quit the party, it will retain all the property of the Soviet Communist Party and the associated authority. It will not be so. ... The party will be bankrupt, obliged to repay its debts to the people, if only with its property.'' _ Boris N. Yeltsin, president of the Russian Federation.
``I don't see another force other than the party which could bring progress to our country.'' _ hard-liner Yegor K. Ligachev
``Our Russian thirst for blood is showing. It's stupid and ugly and inhuman.'' - Inna Dementyeva, a Moscow delegate.
``You can never go back to yesterday by any path, and no dictatorship ... solves anything. If any of the delegates came to the congress with the hope of returning the party to old conditions, comfortable or uncomfortable, this is not a question, they were seriously mistaken.'' _ Gorbachev.

DOC.HEAD: Police Plan for 5th Attack By Zodiac Gunman
DOC.TEXT: Police perusing demonology books as they prepare for a feared attack Thursday by the Zodiac gunman say he may have learned some of his victims' birthdays from Census data or Social Security forms. All four of the shootings by the gunman so far have been in the early morning hours on a Thursday. The last one came three weeks ago Thursday, and the previous spacing of the attacks has led police to focus on this Thursday. ``Tomorrow night is a target night,'' Police Department spokeswoman Suzanne Trazoff said Tuesday. All of the gunman's victims were defenseless at the time they were shot. Two walked with canes; one was inebriated; one was a homeless man sleeping on a Central Park bench. Three victims survived the attacks; a fourth died. He has promised in letters to police, the New York Post and CBS to kill 12 people, one for each sign of the zodiac. His four victims, all men, have been a Scorpio, a Gemini, a Taurus and a Cancer. The gunman scrawled the symbols for his victims' astrological signs on each of the letters he mailed after the attacks. Increased police patrols were scheduled citywide to try to stop the gunman from stalking his fifth victim. ``We feel that there is some significance with tomorrow night and the police department will be taking precautions and certain measures,'' said Chief of Detectives Joseph Borrelli. The astrological pattern of the shootings has police searching through books on astrology and demonology. Authorities also have consulted experts in the occult. The homeless man, 30-year-old Larry Parham, who was the most recent victim, recalled telling a stranger his birth date two days before he was shot June 21, Borrelli said. The other two surviving victims couldn't recall being asked their birthdays by strangers. Police said the gunman may have gotten access to the birthdays any place where applications are filled out, such as bank tellers' windows or government offices. Borrelli also raised the possibility the gunman might have gotten information from Census takers. More than 50 suspects were questioned and eliminated so far during the investigation, Borrelli said. ``I can't tell you that we're now close to a ... a bona fide, legitimate suspect yet,'' the detective chief added. Trazoff refused to discuss specifics of the increased patrols or to comment on which part of the city has been targeted by the 50-detective Zodiac Task Force as the site of a fifth shooting. ``Obviously, to tip our hand would be counterproductive,'' she said. Psychological profiles of the victims have been run through an FBI computer, descriptions from two people have produced sketches of the gunman, and some 1,800 calls have been made to a 24-hour hot line. Still, detectives remain unsure how the gunman knows his victims' astrological signs. The gunman, who claimed to be the same ``Zodiac'' who terrorized San Francisco during the late 1960's and early '70s, is believed to have gotten his ideas from a 1986 book called ``Zodiac,'' which details the San Francisco killings. But the New York gunman, who began his six letters to the media with the same phrase used in letters by the San Francisco gunman _ ``This is the Zodiac'' _ was not believed to be the same man. Author Robert Graysmith tells of how the San Francisco killer stalked mostly young couples, attacking them near bodies of water, mostly on Saturday nights during a full moon. A man who called himself the Zodiac sent letters to local newspapers claiming responsibility for as many as 37 killings and taunting the police to catch him. Despite an intense manhunt in the Bay area, the San Francisco Zodiac was never captured.

DOC.HEAD: Bosch Rejects Offer for House Arrest Program
DOC.TEXT: Militant Cuban exile Orlando Bosch rejected the restrictive conditions the government had placed on an offer to end his 14 years in prison, and federal officials said Tuesday the terms were non-negotiable. The government had proposed a restrictive house-arrest program that would allow officials to monitor Bosch's telephone conversations and require him to log the name and address of visitors. ``He's willing to agree to all of the conditions except that one,'' said Bosch's daughter, Myriam Bosch. ``It's a matter of dignity. He's not going to be an informant. The FBI can do their own work.'' Ms. Bosch said her father notified his attorneys of his decision, and they contacted immigration officials. Bosch has become a cause celebre for Miami's staunchly anti-Castro Cuban exile community, which has held rallies and demonstrations on his behalf attended by leading politicians. Bosch spent 11 years in a Venezuelan prison for allegedly masterminding the 1976 bombing of a Cuban jetliner that killed all 73 people aboard. In 1968, he was convicted in a rocket attack on a Polish freighter in Miami and sentenced to 10 years in prison. Justice Department spokesman Dan Eramian acknowledged that a lawyer for Bosch had a ``number of questions'' about the terms of the proposed parole. ``I see very little room to wiggle,'' Eramian said. ``If he has questions, we will be happy to explain the conditions to him.'' Another source with the Justice Department said the government will not negotiate the offer. ``Bosch won't accept the conditions, and he won't be released unless he does,'' the source told The Associated Press. George Yoss, an attorney for Bosch, said he expected discussions with federal officials in Washington to continue Wednesday. Bosch's family criticized the two-page list of conditions for the release of the 63-year-old former pediatrician, who suffers from declining health after years in Venezuelan and U.S. jails. The conditions would require Bosch to wear an electronic monitoring device, remain at home for 21 hours a day and allow his telephone to be monitored. Bosch also would be subject to unannounced searches and lie detector tests, and if instructed, must present himself for deportation within 72 hours. Bosch has been held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center south of Miami since 1988, when he was arrested for parole violations and for re-entering the country illegally.

DOC.HEAD: Suit Says Lessons Have Anti-Minority Slant
DOC.TEXT: A federal suit filed Tuesday on behalf of eight black children claims they are victimized by a school system that teaches minority pupils they are inferior to whites. The class-action suit filed in U.S. District Court asks the court to find New York City's curriculum racially discriminatory, said Joseph Fleming, lawyer for the eight children. The defendants are U.S. Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos, New York State Education Commissioner Thomas Sobol, New York City Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez and the city, state and federal boards or departments of education. Children suffer irreparable damage from a ``curriculum of exclusion'' that ``literally teaches that people of African, Latino and Asian descent have made no significant contribution to the development of civilization,'' said Bob Law, a radio talk show host who helped organize the lawsuit.
