Even at its most benign, the schools' ``Euro-centric bias'' sends negative signals to nonwhite children, for example referring to Duke Ellington as a ``bandleader'' but Leonard Bernstein as a ``maestro'' or ``orchestra conductor,'' Law said. The lawsuit demands the school system adopt ``a multicultural curriculum which includes the existence, true participation and contributions of African Americans and other nonwhites in world and American culture, sciences, history, arts and other areas of human endeavor.'' David Powell, father of plaintiffs Rashida, 13, and Hasani, 9, said Hasani ``doesn't like history because he says he doesn't see himself there, only white people.'' Law told a news conference the suit was filed because Sobol is stalling on implementing recommendations of his own task force, which advocated a multicultural approach to education in a report last year. Sobol accepted the task force findings but backed off in the face of ``high-profile resistance'' from two professionals asked to review the report, Law said. They were Diane Ravitch, a professor at Columbia University's Teachers College, and historian Arthur Schlesinger, a professor at City University. Law said Ravitch called the suggested reforms ``ethnic cheerleading.'' Law, whose night talk show is broadcast on stations around the country, used it to help get plaintiffs to come forward. The eight children, ages 8 to 14, attend public schools in the boroughs of Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens. Schlesinger, called for comment, said, ``I'm sympathetic to the purposes behind the suit, but I don't think this is the way to go about organizing a curriculum.'' Ravitch's secretary said she could not immediately be reached. Chris Carpenter, spokesman for the state Education Department in Albany, said Sobol and the Board of Regents agree with the task force's basic ideas and have not changed course because of opposition. ``We see extremes on both sides and we're trying to chart a course down the middle,'' Carpenter said. ``We want revision to have intellectual and scholarly integrity, and that'll take time.'' Fernandez spokesman James Vlasto said Fernandez would have no comment on the suit, which he had not seen. But Vlasto added that since taking office this year, Fernandez has championed the idea of multicultural education. Etta Fielek, speaking for Cavazos in Washington, said the department was unaware of the suit and does not comment on litigation.

DOC.HEAD: Radio Shack Dealer To Stand Trial for Videotaping Employees Having Sex
DOC.TEXT: A Radio Shack dealer on Tuesday was ordered to stand trial for inviting his teen-age employees to have sex with their boyfriends in the back room of his store and videotaping their activities. Howard R. DeYoung, who operates the electronics store in Dorr, 15 miles south of Grand Rapids, allegedly made the room available after work to female workers, who were minors, said Detective Rick Cain of the Allegan County Sheriff's Department. He provided them with sexual aids, pornographic magazines and alcohol, Cain said. DeYoung, 38, allegedly used electronic surveillance equipment to make sexually explicit photographs, videotapes and audio recordings of as many as 20 area teens who used the room over the last 2{ years, Cain said. DeYoung was ordered to stand trial on three charges of child abusive commercial activity, a felony punishable by up to 20 years in prison, and three counts of electronic eavesdropping, punishable by two years in prison and a $2,000 fine. Defense lawyer Larry Woods has maintained DeYoung's innocence. He is scheduled to be arraigned in Circuit Court Friday. It's not alleged that DeYoung sold or distributed the tapes. Three former female employees testified Tuesday they had no idea their activities were being recorded. ``He told us that we could go in there to be alone,'' one said. The three women all are now older than 18. They testified that DeYoung invited them to use the room after hours and provided keys to the store. The room was equipped with sofa bed, a large-screen television with a satellite dish that received pornographic stations and videocassette recorder, the women testified. Though not all of the three cameras in the room were hidden, DeYoung told the women that the surveillance camera was not working. The cameras, all aimed at the bed, were set up to activate when the room's door was opened, Cain said. Search warrants for DeYoung's home were issued last month after one of the women found tapes marked with employees' names. She played one with her name on it and turned it over to police. ``These girls are devastated,'' Cain said. ``They always thought he was being a nice person.''

DOC.HEAD: Restaurateur Says He and Barry Smoked Opium, Took Cocaine
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 2 grafs to add Dick Gregory attendance at trial as Barry guest
DOC.TEXT: A Tehran-born restaurateur said Tuesday that he repeatedly smoked opium with Marion Barry but warned the mayor that he should ``slow down'' and be cautious in his drug use. Appearing for a second day at Barry's drug and perjury trial, Hassan Mohammadi also testified that the mayor snorted cocaine several times in his own home. He said Barry started snorting cocaine on boats after the mayor's hotel room visits became the focus of a police drug probe in December 1988. Barry's defense team depicted Mohammadi in cross-examination as a man willing to say anything to avoid being deported to Iran. The witness admitted that he has been placed on a ``blacklist'' by the current regime in Iran because he had worked for the Iranian government before the Shah was overthrown. ``I was a true friend for Mr. Mayor,'' Mohammadi told the court. He said he warned Barry, ``You just have to slow down and you have to know who you are dealing with,'' at the time police were investigating Barry's visits to the room of Charles Lewis at the Ramada Inn in Washington. Lewis later pleaded guilty to charges of conspiracy to deal cocaine. ``I would tell him, `Mr. Mayor, enough is enough,''' said Mohammadi. ``He said he is not going to go to any more hotels,'' Mohammadi said Barry told him. While the criminal investigation was going on, Barry had Mohammadi start meeting him on boats. Barry and a female companion snorted cocaine in February 1989 aboard a pleasure boat moored at a marina, said Mohammadi. Later, in the summer, Barry had Mohammadi again meet him on a boat, where the mayor snorted some lines of cocaine in the bathroom, said the restaurateur. Mohammadi testified that a woman he knew as ``Miss T'' was frequently Barry's female companion when drugs were being used. In one incident, Miss T wasn't interested in taking opium and so she snorted cocaine instead, said Mohammadi. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson issued a bench warrant for the woman, Theresa Southerland, when she failed to appear in court due to a scheduling mixup with Southerland's lawyer. Jackson told the jury she would be in court Wednesday. On hand for Tuesday's session, was comedian-activist Dick Gregory, who attended the trial as Barry's guest. Barry is allowed four guest seats in the courtroom and has invited other high-profile blacks, including Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan and Rev. George Stallings, a breakaway Catholic priest. Mohammadi has testified that he furnished drugs to Barry at least 30 times and that the mayor never paid for them. Mohammadi said he told Barry repeatedly that ``I am not looking for any favors.'' Mohammadi, who immigrated from Iran in 1972, met Barry at a District of Columbia party at the Democratic National Convention in San Francisco in 1984. Mohammadi lied to police in February 1989 by denying that the mayor was involved with drugs, the restaurateur testified. Mohammadi then reported back to Barry on what questions the police had asked. ``I covered wherever I could,'' said Mohammadi. ``I was a true friend for Mr. Mayor; I was always there for Mr. Mayor,'' he testified. The restaurateur said he started cooperating with the government after Barry was arrested Jan. 18 in an FBI sting because ``everybody came from the woodwork. I did not have any choice.'' Others had implicated the restaurateur, Mohammadi said. Mohammadi testified that he and the mayor smoked opium by putting the drug on the back of a spoon and warming it up with the flame from a plumber's torch. They inhaled through a straw and part of a coat hanger in order to ``get the maximum smoke out of it,'' Mohammadi said. The two first used opium together in February 1988 at Mohammadi's apartment, he testified. At the mayor's urging, Mohammadi one time pulled the opium-laden spoon out of his car and they smoked the residue, the restaurateur testified. In July 1989 during a crab feast at Barry's house, the mayor asked ``if I had anything.'' Mohammadi said he did. The two went upstairs in Barry's home and ``we did some lines'' of cocaine in the bathroom next to the main bedroom, said Mohammadi. The mayor used cocaine on several other occasions at his home, including last November just before Thanksgiving, Mohammadi said.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 18 Dead in Kenya Disturbances, Rural Areas Affected
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS five grafs after 15th graf `The comments' to UPDATE with Kenyan Embassy reaction to U.S. travel advisory. Pickup 16th pvs, `Moi says...'
DOC.TEXT: Stone-throwing mobs battled riot police in rural areas Tuesday, and President Daniel arap Moi blamed the anti-government riots on ``hooligans and drug addicts.'' Eighteen have died in four days of violence. The State Department said in Washington Tuesday it was advising American citizens to delay all non-essential travel to Kenya because of the unrest. Nairobi, the scene of widespread violence over the weekend, appeared calm. The violence followed last week's detentions of Kenya's most prominent supporters of political pluralism. Five of them were detained under public securit statutes that allow them to be held without charge indefinitely. One opposition politician held was Kenneth Matiba. His daughter, Susan, said in an interview in Kenya on Britain's Channel 4 TV News Tuesday night: ``There is widespread discontent in the country. ... The economy is very depressed. ... There is a widespread feeling that mismanagement and corruption in the government have gone beyond any acceptable level. People have been unable to express their opinion in any way.'' The program said Ms. Matiba and her mother were beaten up when their house was broken into on June 13. It did not say where in Kenya she interviewed. Kenya, a one-party state, has long been considered one of Africa's most stable and successful nations. Since early this year, however, Moi has come under increasing pressure to allow a multiparty system. Clashes between mobs and security forces were reported Tuesday in and around the towns of Kiambu, Nyeri and Githunguri, all north of Nairobi, where riot troops fired on suspected demonstrators. Violence also was reported in Kangemi and Kawangware, low-income neighborhoods on Nairobi's western edge, where security forces beat people indiscriminately, according to residents. Some residents, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they were beaten by police, who then robbed them of money and valuables. A spokesman for Moi's office said 15 people had been killed and 61 wounded in the disturbances, which began Saturday when police used tear gas and guns to halt a pro-democracy rally. At least three of 10 deaths confirmed independently were not included in the government breakdown. The government did not identify those killed, and it was not immediately clear if the other seven deaths confirmed independently were in the official figure. Moi, in comments to Kenyan troops back from U.N. peacekeeping duty in Namibia, blamed the riots on ``hooligans and drug addicts'' and said his government would continue hunting down instigators of the violence. The comments, his first public mention of the violence, followed a government order Monday empowering police to use whatever force necessary to quell the disturbances. In Washington, the State Department issued a statement saying the recent demonstrations, accompanied by looting and clashes between police and rioters, have made conditions unsafe for travelers. The Kenyan Embassy in Washington responded with a statement Tuesday expressing understanding for U.S. concerns and offering reassurances that the government would do everything possible to ensure the safety of Americans in Kenya. It said the situation in Kenya was returning to normal ``following a few isolated incidents by looters and hooligans.'' ``We are confident that the United States will reappraise and remove its temporary advisory,'' the embassy statement said. ``The government of Kenya is confident that the good, friendly relationship that exists between the Republic of Kenya and the United States of America will contribute to the quick and expeditious resolution of this matter.'' Moi says that because there are about 40 tribes in Kenya, a multiparty system would result in tribal-based parties leading to ethnic divisions and even tribal One prominent lawyer under threat of arrest for his criticism of the government, Paul Muite, has gone into hiding. Another, human rights lawyer Gibson Kamau Kuria, has sought refuge at the U.S. Embassy in Nairobi. On Monday, Kenya condemned the U.S. decision to give Kuria asylum, and also accused the United States of fueling the pro-democracy movement and interfering in internal affairs. The United States protested the charge in a meeting in Washington Monday between the assistant secretary for African affairs, Herman Cohen, and Kenya's ambassador in Washington, Denis Afande. Tuesday morning, two large artillery guns were parked across the street from the U.S. ambassador's residence. By noon, the guns had been removed.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 65 Killed At Soccer Match, Diplomats Say
DOC.TEXT: Security forces opened fire on a crowd at a soccer game in Somalia after ``provocateurs'' began stoning the president, a Somali official said Tuesday. Diplomatic sources said at least 65 people were killed, but the Somali government said only three people died. Unofficial fatality estimates in Friday's shootings in Mogadishu, the Somali capital, range as high as 109, according to one diplomatic source, who said 65 people were confirmed dead at the city's Digfer Hospital. More than 100 people were seriously injured, another source said. But Abbudllahi Farah Barre, first secretary at the Somali Embassy in Rome, insisted only three people were killed in the stadium shooting. He said he did not have exact figures on the number of injured. He said security forces opened fire after ``some provocateurs'' began throwing rocks at President Mohammed Siad Barre. He said the security forces first fired in the air, then on the crowd as it continued to throw rocks and began to pelt security officers. On Saturday, the Somali Ministry of Labor, Sports and Social Affairs dismissed the incident as a ``chance accident'' and said it had sent condolences to the victims' families. It also said three people were killed. The ministry blamed the incident on crowding and said people had been hit by bullets when security forces fired ``high into the air'' to maintain peace. International telephone connections to Somalia were not working Tuesday and it was not immediately possible to contact anyone in Mogadishu. Somalia is an impoverished nation on the Horn of Africa. In recent years, the government steadily has lost control of much of the nation's countryside to insurgencies and warring clans. Siad Barre has ruled the predominantly Moslem nation since seizing power in a coup in 1969.

DOC.HEAD: Former Romanian Tourism Minister Asks Political Asylum
DOC.TEXT: A spokeswoman for Switzerland's refugee agency said Tuesday that Mihai Lupoi, 37, a former tourism minister in Romania's post-revolution government, has asked for political asylum. He applied last Thursday, she said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Lupoi gained prominence when he declared that the army was on the side of the Romanian people during the December uprising that ousted dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Ceausescu was executed on Dec. 25 along with his wife, Elena. Lupoi was appointed tourism minister in Ion Iliescu's National Salvation Front government. The French-language newspaper Tribune de Geneve said he stepped down in February and fled Romania after he was accused of helping to organize anti-government demonstrations. It said shots were recently fired at Lupoi's vehicle. The paper said Lupoi and his wife, Magdalena, arrived in Switzerland last Wednesday. Their 1-year-old son was not with them, it reported.

DOC.HEAD: Zaire Opposition Demands Mobutu Resign
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of two opposition parties demanded on Tuesday that President Mobutu Sese Seko resign and make way for the introduction of a multiparty democracy. The demand came as a pay strike by government employees paralyzed most public services in the capital. ``Like the colonial dicatorship, the Mobutu dictatorship should pack up its bags and disappear forever,'' read a statement by leaders of the Union for Democracy and Social Progress. The party said Zaireans should use every legal means to drive Mobutu out. The Unified Lumumbiste Party said it was determined to force Mobutu to leave. Nguz Karl I Bond, a former foreign minister who formed a third opposition party, the Republican Independents, said a national conference should be held to discuss the transition to democracy. He said the conference also could select a transitional government. Mobutu was accused of delay after promising to permit opposition parties and to guide this former Belgian colony toward multiparty rule. His security forces were accused of attacking student critics of his regime. Belgium froze new aid to Zaire after security forces were accused of killing 50 to 150 students in the copper region capital of Lubumbashi. An inquiry by Parliament, controlled by Mobutu's Popular Movement for the Revolution, found the Lubumbashi region governor and other high officials responsible for the student killings. Mobutu said they will be brought to justice, but refused to allow an international investigation. Mobutu said last week that Zaireans will vote in January to choose which three parties will be permitted to contest elections next year. Zaire, the former Belgian Congo, gained independence in 1960. The central African nation has a population of more than 32.5 million.

DOC.HEAD: Neil Bush Denies Wrongdoing as Silverado Director
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's son Neil, a former director of the failed Silverado Savings and Loan, said Tuesday he and the thrift were victimized ``by a system that was doomed to fail, has failed, and will continue to fail.'' Bush, who served as a director from 1985 to August 1988, was interviewed before being advised the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. was gearing up to file a lawsuit charging that he and other directors acted improperly as board members. ABC News reported Tuesday night that the federal government's lawsuit will claim Silverado's losses were due in part to negligence on the part of Bush and others. The suit will claim the directors did not act responsibly when they approved dozens of questionable loans, ABC reported. Bush told ABC he was not aware of the pending lawsuit. But he told The Associated Press he had performed properly, and that all loans that came before the directors were for projects previously approved by others more knowledgeable than he. Bush said the Silverado case was insignificant compared to abuses found elsewhere in the nation's thrift disaster, which is expected to cost taxpayers more than $300 billion. The Silverado failure is expected to cost $1 billion in tax money. He said thrift regulators from the Federal Home Loan Bank of Topeka, Kan., who approved the loans that contributed to Silverado's failure, are trying to blame him for the thrift's collapse. ``It's self-serving. The regulators are politically motivated,'' he said. Bush said what angers him ``as a taxpayer and a citizen is that there's a system out there that, in retrospect, was doomed to fail ... that the federal government insured deposits up to $100,000 and made our financial service industry a socialized industry, guaranteeing the business activities of S&Ls.'' With deregulation, he said, many in the S&L industry tried to grow out of problems and were doomed to fail. ``And it has failed, and it will continue to fail,'' he said. ``The only winners are the large corporations that end up buying these organizations for incredible terms.'' ``The taxpayers are the ones getting screwed in this process,'' he said. ``They are angry _ and they should be angry.'' Bush said he might have been apprehensive, if not doubtful, about certain loans approved by Silverado management if it weren't for several factors: ``One, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board had approved the structure of the loans and the deals that were made that are now being questioned by the same self-serving bureaucrats who are trying to make the case against Silverado. ``Second, we had legal counsel look at every deal and transaction to see that it fell within the regulatory rules that existed, and thirdly we had accountants every year sign off and give Silverado a clean bill of health. At every step of the way we had good advice,'' he said. ``Unfortunately, in an economy that absolutely collapsed, it didn't matter how good the appraisal was in 1985.'' Bush said, ``Every institution that had a greater than 25 percent concentrate in real estate assets in its portfolio has failed in Denver.'' During his time as a Silverado director, he said, ``every investment made was thoroughly reviewed by (Silverado's) staff. I was an outside director and showed up once a month.'' Moreover, he said, the board made some modifications and approved most loans unanimously.

DOC.HEAD: Figure in Mail Bomb Probe Arrested on Other Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to add background and details; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Walter Leroy Moody Jr., the target of a federal probe into two fatal mail bombings by an avowed racist, was arrested Tuesday with his wife on apparently unrelated charges. A spokeswoman in the U.S. attorney's office said Moody and Susan McBride Moody were charged with conspiracy, obstruction of justice, subordination of perjury, bribery of a witness and tampering with a witness. The Moodys' home in Rex, Ga., was thoroughly searched last year by federal agents investigating a series of mail bombings, including two that killed a federal judge in Birmingham, Ala., and a civil rights lawyer in Savannah. Letters that claimed responsibility for the bombings attributed them to a racist hate group. Bruce Harvey, a lawyer representing Moody, said Tuesday's charges were not related to the bombing investigation. The Moodys were charged with trying to illegally induce the federal court in Macon to issue a writ of error that would vacate Moody's 1972 federal conviction for unlawful possession of a pipe bomb. Moody, 56 a self-employed literary consultant, was convicted in 1972 after a pipe bomb went off in his home, injuring his then-wife, Hazel. Moody spent two years in federal prison. Tuesday's indictment said the Moodys persuaded witnesses to sign false declarations and give false testimony to vacate the charges in hearings at the U.S. District Court in Macon. The witnesses, Julie Linn West and her mother, Joanne Ekstrom, of Atlanta, provided an alibi for Moody by saying they knew the Macon bomb was planted by someone other than he. The two women were relocated by the government in April after Miss West recanted her testimony and claimed that Moody paid her to lie in court proceedings, according to the Atlanta Constitution. The indictment said it covers activities during the period from 1986 to 1988 as well as February and March of this year. The search of the Moodys' home took place in February. Prosecutors claimed at the time of his conviction that Moody planned to send the pipe bomb to an Atlanta auto dealer who had repossessed his car. If convicted, Moody could be sentenced to up to 69 years in prison and face fines of up to $1.2 million. Mrs. Moody, 28, faces up to 64 years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Testing Upheld for 538,000 Airline Employees
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court Tuesday upheld the random drug testing of an estimated 538,000 airline employees and air traffic controllers, saying public safety needs outweighed the employees' privacy rights. The ruling by the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals is one of several appellate decisions in the last year allowing random testing in safety-related and other sensitive jobs. The Supreme Court has denied hearings to employee groups appealing the earlier rulings, and has not yet ruled itself in a random drug-testing case. But the high court's decision last year upholding drug testing of Customs Service employees seeking promotions to certain jobs that involve drug enforcement or guns was the basis of Tuesday's appellate ruling. ``The government interest in preventing drug use by persons holding safety-sensitive positions in the aviation industry is at least as compelling as the interest in preventing drug use by Customs officers,'' wrote Judge William Norris in the 3-0 decision. He also said the Federal Aviation Administration provided evidence of some drug use by commercial airline employees, including treatment of a number of flight crew members for cocaine overdoses or addiction and the presence of drugs in the bodies of two pilots after crashes. No similar evidence was offered by Customs officials, who justified their testing program as a deterrent to future drug use, Norris said. Bob Marx, spokesman for the U.S. Department of Transportation, said the department was particularly pleased with the ruling because two other major drug-testing cases, involving truckers and pipeline workers, are are before the 9th Circuit. ``We consider random drug testing to be most effective way of keeping the transportation industry drug-free,'' Marx said. The FAA's program, implemented at the end of 1988, requires random urine testing of at least half the employees each year in safety-related jobs in commercial aviation. They include pilots, flight attendants, instructors, flight testers, aircraft dispatchers, maintenance crews, security personnel and air traffic controllers. Employees who test positive for illegal drugs after a confirming retest and medical review are removed from their jobs. The tests are conducted without advance warning. Other drug-testing programs involving the same employees, including pre-employment testing and testing based on reasonable suspicion of current drug use, were not challenged in the lawsuit. The suit by employee unions did not dispute that most of the jobs were safety-related but argued that unannounced, random testing, without individual suspicion of drug impairment, intruded unnecessarily on employees' right to privacy. The constitutional ban on unreasonable searches ``requires that the government not be able to conduct suspicionless searches on people who are basically presumed to be guilty of no wrongdoing, beyond those searches that can be fairly characterized as minimally intrusive,'' such as highway checkpoints, said Walter Kamiat, a lawyer for the unions. ``The fact that somebody's safety-sensitive doesn't justify anything that the state wants to do to them. ... The issue is, what is the test and how intrusive (is it) into their privacy, sense of dignity?'' The court agreed that the fact that the drug testing was random and unannounced made it more intrusive, but said it was not enough to outweigh the government interest in an effective testing program for safety-related employees.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 10 grafs new with World Bank statement, editing changes; pick up 4th graf pvs, In addition xxx
DOC.HEAD: World Bank Says Soviet Study Could Take Longer Than Foreseen
DOC.TEXT: A thorough study of Soviet economic needs, as proposed Tuesday at the Houston economic summit, would take longer than foreseen by the summit leaders, the World Bank said. In a decision that eased a dispute over whether to provide emergency aid quickly to Moscow, the seven summit countries said a group of international financial institutions, including the World Bank, would study Soviet economic requirements. They said the study, to be supervised by the International Monetary Fund, is to be finished by year's end, officials at the summit said. The World Bank, however, said a meaningful study would take more time. ``A study of this nature would take a long time _ a year or so _ and could provide a useful basis for countries considering providing investment capital,'' it said. The bank also said that because the Soviet Union is not among its 151 members, the bank's directors in Washington would have to approve the bank's participation in the study. France, Italy and West Germany have pushed during the Houston summit for a joint Western package of financial aid to Moscow. They say that to wait would risk ending all momentum toward democractic reform in the communist country. The United States, backed by Japan, argues that Moscow should make more economic and political reforms before it gets Western cash. The U.S. delegation pushed for Western technical assistance that would not include cash or financial credits. As part of a technical aid program already under way, the United States has sent central bank officials and other financial experts to Moscow to advise Soviet government officials on ways of developing a banking system and other capitalist institutions. Soviet officials also have come to Washington to consult on technical economic matters. In addition, if the Soviets drop barriers to emigration, the United States could waive the Jackson-Vanik amendment, thereby permitting normal trade between the two countries. That step, in turn, could be followed by U.S. trade credits and the easing of high technology exports. The Soviets may act on the emigration question in September. President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev set in motion this type of cooperation at the summit in Malta last December. Ed A. Hewitt of the Brookings Institution, a think tank, said U.S. experts could aid the Soviets in overcoming such problems as getting food to the market place. About a third of all Soviet food rots before reaching the dinner table because of inadequate transportation or storage facilities, he said. Both Hewitt and Richard Feinberg, vice president of the Overseas Development Council, strongly support a major role for the World Bank and International Monetary Fund in helping the Soviets. Financial stabilization and structural changes are sorely needed in the Soviet Union and are precisely the areas the bank and the fund have been set up to deal with, Feinberg said. The Soviets have indicated a desire to join the two Washington-based institutions. The United States traditionally has opposed Soviet membership but officials said the U.S. position may be reassessed.

DOC.HEAD: Adventurer Goes Bob-Bob-Bobbing Across Atlantic
LaserPhoto NY31
DOC.TEXT: Scottish adventurer Tom McClean says he has rowed and sailed across the Atlantic Ocean four times, but the voyage he began Tuesday is unique: this time his boat is a bottle. McClean, 47, came up with the gimmick to raise $800,000 for the National Children's Homes, an organization that cares for 11,000 orphans in Britain. ``I thought it'd be a good idea to have a message in a bottle,'' said McClean, an orphan himself from age 2, just before pushing off at 12:46 p.m. from a West Side pier. He expects to bob his way to Falmouth, England, in about 28 days. The 37-foot steel bottle has a diesel engine with a top speed of about four knots, a little faster if the sail is up, McClean said. An automatic pilot will steer the bottle, which was built by a friend. McClean will be traveling alone _ no mother boat _ but will be in contact via radio with a team on shore and his family in Fort William, Scotland. ``The most difficult thing is the first week, just getting used to it, and especially if you have bad weather,'' he said. Should he encounter any storms, ``then you throttle back and have a sleep'' in the four-poster bed onboard, he said. McLean also has navigation books and adventure stories to keep himself amused and small projects to work on. The trip is sponsored by the British Ty-phoo Tea Co. McClean set a world record for rowing across the Atlantic in 54} days in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Irish Prime Minister Still Hopeful Keenan Will be Freed
LaserPhoto LON16
DOC.TEXT: Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey said Tuesday he is still hopeful teacher Brian Keenan will soon be freed by his Lebanese kidnappers. After Iran's official news agency said Saturday that a European will likely be freed soon, a source close to the Syrian army command said it would probably be the 39-year-old Belfast-born teacher, who holds Irish and British citizenship. Haughey told the Dail, or Parliament, that his government was making ``appropriate preparations'' in the event of Keenan's release but he had no new information. In Belfast, Keenan's sisters, Elaine Spence and Brenda Gillham, have their bags packed to fly to Damascus, the Syrian capital, if there is any confirmation of his release. ``Everything looks good but we could still be terribly disappointed as we have been before and we have to try somehow to prepare ourselves for that. It could change so quickly,'' said Mrs. Gillham, who was celebrating her 47th birthday. ``If it wasn't Brian I would naturally be disappointed but still happy if someone came out. It would be a mixture of tears and joy. In any case, if someone is released it would be one step towards Brian being free,'' she said. Iran is reported to be pushing hard for the release of a hostage in appreciation for aid it received after the June 21 killer earthquake. The Irish Red Cross flew the first Western relief plane into Tehran after the devastating earthquake that killed 40,000 people. Three Irish parliamentarians visited Tehran shortly before the quake and held talks about Keenan with Foreign Ministry officials. On their return to Dublin, they condemned the imprisonment of more than 300 Lebanese Shiites in the Khiam jail in south Lebanon. Release of these prisoners has been a major demand by the Shiite Moslem groups believed to be holding 16 Western hostages. The hostages are six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Irishman and an Italian. Longest held of the hostages in Terry A. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Keenan, a bachelor, was kidnapped April 11, 1986, on his way to the University of Beirut where he taught English. He was traveling on an Irish passport but had left it home that day. No group claimed responsibility for holding him. But when American hostage Frank Reed was freed on April 30, he said he was held with Keenan and British journalist John McCarthy, who he described as both fit and well.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Rejects Amnesty Allegations
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Ministry rejected Amnesty International's criticism of Israel's handling of the Palestinian uprising as ``incomplete and misleading'' and based on information from politically motivated sources. In its global survey released Wednesday, the human rights organization said many Palestinian victims in the uprising died ``in circumstances suggesting excessive use of force or deliberate killings.'' About 25,000 Palestinians were detained, often without charge or trial, and by year's end over 13,000 were still jailed, Amnesty said. It said thousands of Palestinians were beaten and kicked, sometimes for refusing to remove roadblocks and paint over anti-Israeli graffiti. ``There were reports of torture and systematic ill-treatment of political detainees, including beatings on various parts of the body, hooding, deprivation and confinement in coffin-sized cells,'' said the organization, which has its headquarters in London. In its response, the Justice Ministry said Amnesty failed to give an adequate picture of violence in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, where Palestinians have carried out a 31-month-old uprising against Israeli occupation. The territories, home to 1.7 million Palestinians, were captured from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war. The ministry said Amnesty's report ``omits that during 1989 there were 41,161 public disturbances, 359 cases of arson, 734 attacks using Molotov cocktails, 12 grenade attacks and 80 shootings'' in the occupied lands. These resulted in 385 Israeli civilians and 909 soldiers being hospitalized, it said. ``As a result of these omissions, Amnesty International's portrayal of the intefadeh (uprising) in the administered areas is incomplete and misleading,'' the ministry said. Amnesty ``relies heavily on politically motivated sources'' in describing cases of Palestinian detainees, it said. The Justice Ministry did not directly respond to the Amnesty statement that 260 Palestininans were killed by army gunfire during 1989, but it denied Israel carried out deliberate killings. According to figures compiled by The Associated Press, 724 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians during the uprising. An additional 233 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaboration with Israel. Forty-four Israelis have been slain by Palestinians. The army also dismissed Amnesty's allegation of ``excessive or indiscriminate'' force by soldiers. An army spokesman said that in maintaining law and order in the territories, Israel ``seeks to find the proper balance between security and humanitarian requirements.'' Soldiers have strict orders on the use of force and faced penalties for violations, said the spokesman, who cannot be identified by name under army regulations. ``Force may be used to stop violent activity and to overcome resistance to arrest,'' he said. ``Force is prohibited as a form of punishment or to deliberately inflict injuries. ``While some excesses have occurred, these have been unacceptable departures from policy and have been dealt with accordingly.''

DOC.HEAD: Dowaliby Sentenced to 45 years In Daughter's Murder
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of murdering his 7-year-old daughter and staging a break-in to conceal the crime was sentenced Tuesday to 45 years in prison. Cook County Circuit Judge Richard Neville sentenced David Dowaliby to 40 years for murdering Jaclyn Dowaliby and five years for concealing the homicide. Before his sentencing, Dowaliby once again tried to persuade the judge that he did not kill his daughter. The 33-year-old former construction foreman contends an intruder broke into his home and kidnapped his daughter. ``She had a right to live,'' Dowaliby said. ``Who would kill an innocent child? An animal. A monster. That's not me.'' Dowaliby was convicted by a jury May 3. His daughter's body was found in a wooded area four days after she was reported missing in September 1988. ``David Dowaliby is definitely going to prosecute an appeal,'' said Dowaliby's attorney. Ralph Meczyk. ``He is numb.'' During the trial in May, Neville ordered charges against Dowaliby's wife, Cynthia, dropped because of a lack of evidence. Mrs. Dowaliby has crusaded to prove her husband's innocence, and to regain custody of the couple's two other children, currently living with relatives. ``David is an innocent man,'' she said Tuesday. ``This is a travesty of justice and it should be stopped.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Recalls Hoses for Picnic Cookers
DOC.TEXT: A manufacturer of outdoor picnic equipment on Tuesday recalled hoses for 30,000 smoker-cookers because of possible fire hazards. The Coleman Co., Inc. recalled the hoses that connect to the propane gas tanks of its ``Cookin' Machines'' because they may loosen from the valve connection after repeated use, said the Consumer Product Safety Commission. ``If the hose should loosen when the valve is turned on, fuel may leak from the hose and could present a risk of personal injury or property damage if ignited,'' the agency said. There have been at least five reported incidents of loosened hoses causing fire damage, said the CPSC. The potentially hazardous hoses are installed on cookers manufactured by the Kansas-based company between November 1987 and March 1989. Consumers should discontinue use of the cookers immediately and contact Coleman at 1-800-835-3278 for instructions on free replacement of the hoses.

DOC.HEAD: Sikh Extremists Assassinate Moderate Punjab Leader, Three Aides
DOC.TEXT: Militant Sikh separatists shot to death a moderate Sikh leader, his two bodyguards and their driver on Tuesday in the northern state of Punjab, police said. Balwant Singh, 61, a former finance minister in Punjab and a leading industrialist, was assassinated as he returned home from his factory near the state capital of Chandigarh, they reported. Police blamed Sikh extremists fighting for an independent homeland in Punjab, a rich farming region bordering Pakistan. The separatists say the Hindu-dominated government discriminated against Sikhs. Sikh gunmen also were blamed for killing six other people across the state on Monday night, United News of India said. The deaths bring to 1,342 the number of people killed by Sikh extremists in Punjab this year. In the neighboring state of Jammu-Kashmir, Indian border guards on Tuesday killed six Moslem militants who were trying to cross over into Pakistan in the Kupwara region, about 50 miles northwest of Srinagar, the state capital. Elsewhere in Kashmir, Moslem separatists killed three Moslems and a Hindu man in separate incidents, said state government officials, who cannot be identified under briefing rules. At least 716 people have been killed in Kashmir since Jan. 20, when the government launched a crackdown on separatists fighting for an independent Kashmiri state. Indian officials say the Moslem separatists receive weapons and training in Pakistan. The Pakistani government denies it. Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan meanwhile met Iraqi President Saddam Hussein in Baghdad on Tuesday as she continued a tour aimed at gaining support in other Moslem countries for her Kashmir policy. Officials accompanying her said she would seek support for taking up the Kashmir issue at an Islamic foreign ministers' conference in Cairo this month. Pakistan wants Indian Kashmiris to be allowed to decide their own future through a U.N.-sponsored plebiscite. India insists that Jammu-Kashmir remain part of India. In Punjab, Ashok Kapoor, a deputy police superintendent, gave this account of the assassination: Three men in a car drew alongside Singh's escort car and opened fire with automatic rifles. The escort vehicle hit the rear of Singh's car. In the confusion the attackers fired another burst, killing Singh and the other occupants of his car. Singh, leader of the moderate Akali Dal-Badal Party, was the chief architect of a 1985 accord with the federal government that sought to fulfill Sikh demands for more autonomy in Punjab. Sikh extremists opposed the accord, saying it did not meet their demand for independence. They targeted Singh and other Sikh moderates involved in the accord. Extremist violence led the Indian government to impose direct federal rule on Punjab in May 1987. Sikhs comprise 2 percent of India's 880 million people but make up a slight majority in Punjab. Hindus comprise 82 percent of the population nationwide.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Consult Allies on Response to NATO Non-Aggression Offer
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze has asked his Warsaw Pact colleagues to prepare a joint response to NATO's offer of a non-aggression declaration, East Germany's foreign minister said Tuesday. The minister, Markus Meckel, told reporters after meeting with North Atlantic Treaty Organization officials that he received a letter from Shevardnadze on Monday. In it, he said, Shevardnadze solicited proposals for a Warsaw Pact response regarding what form a non-aggression declaration should take. He said the same letter was sent to the foreign ministers of the other Warsaw Pact countries _ Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Romania and Bulgaria. Meckel said Shevardnadze suggested in his letter that NATO representatives be invited to attend some Warsaw Pact meetings, perhaps those of its consultative political committee. However, NATO sources who requested anonymity said the alliance would be reluctant to accept such an invitation since it would legitimize the Soviet-led military alliance in its present form. At last week's summit in London, leaders of the 16 NATO countries proposed that the Warsaw Pact and NATO sign a joint declaration in which both alliances would declare they no longer are adversaries. They also invited Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other Warsaw Pact leaders to address the NATO council of ministers in Brussels and appoint ambassadors to NATO. Also on Tuesday, Czechoslovakia invited members of NATO's political committee to visit Prague. Earlier in the day, Meckel proposed limiting the size of the unified German army to 300,000 troops, down from a current total of 635,000 in East and West Germany. ``I have the impression this is acceptable to NATO,'' said Meckel, the fifth Warsaw Pact foreign minister to visit NATO headquarters in Brussels in recent months. West Germany's military now totals 465,000 troops and East Germany's about 170,000. Within the West German coalition government, proposals for troop ceilings for a unified Germany range from 320,000 to 380,000.

DOC.HEAD: Mohawk Warrior Given 10-Month Sentence For Resisting Raid
DOC.TEXT: A Mohawk activist convicted of leading armed resistance to a federal gambling raid last summer at the St. Regis Indian Reservation was sentenced Tuesday to 10 months in jail. U.S. District Judge Neal McCurn imposed the sentence on Kakwirakeron, also known as Arthur Montour, after rejecting the federal prosecutor's recommendation for a jail term of a year or longer. McCurn also rejected the defense's plea to give Kakwirakeron six months probation. ``I do not beg for mercy. Whatever sentence you wish to impose, I accept _ but not as a criminal,'' Kakwirakeron said at the conclusion of a gripping 15-minute oration before he was sentenced. ``It is not criminal to stand up and defend your people,'' said Kakwirakeron, who called himself ``a prisoner of an undeclared war on the Mohawk nation.'' About 35 supporters, including Kakwirakeron's wife, Verna, began shouting obscenities at McCurn as the judge left the courtroom. A tearful Kakwirakeron removed the warrior's feather and spiritual beads he wore during the two-hour hearing and hugged his crying children and friends before being escorted from the courtroom by federal marshals. Kakwirakeron, 47, was convicted April 10 of conspiracy and forcibly impeding the execution of federal search warrants during the July 20 raid at St. Regis. He was found innocent of using a dangerous weapon to turn back FBI agents, a more serious felony charge. Authorities accused Kakwirakeron of leading a group of heavily armed Mohawks who set up a barricade outside two reservation casinos and refused to let authorities pass. The presence of the casinos has been at the center of a leadership dispute among the Mohawks for more than a year. In May, two Mohawks were killed in a gunfight between pro- and anti-gambling factions, prompting New York and Canadian authorities to seal off the reservation for nearly three weeks to restore peace. Tribal and state officials are negotiating an agreement that would allow regulated gambling.

DOC.HEAD: State High Court Refuses to Look at Appeal of Brawley Lawyer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT to grand jury investigation, sted trial
DOC.TEXT: New York's highest court Tuesday refused to hear lawyer Alton Maddox' appeal of his suspension for obstructing the state's investigation into the Tawana Brawley abduction case. Miss Brawley claimed she was abducted and raped by six white men in 1987, when she was 15. After a much-publicized investigation, a grand jury concluded in 1988 that she made up the story. A state appeals court suspended Maddox in May after he refused to appear before the court's disciplinary committee in its investigation of the Brawley. On advice from Maddox, attorney C. Vernon Mason and the Rev. Al Sharpton, a black civil rights activist, Miss Brawley didn't cooperate with police or grand jury investigations. Maddox claimed authorities were engaged in a racist cover-up. Attorney General Robert Abrams filed complaints with a judicial panel in 1988, accusing Maddox of making baseless claims against Abrams and other officials in the case. Maddox couldn't be reached for comment Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Political Parties Threaten Strike Over Return of Ex-Officials
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Contents of 9th graf may be offensive to some readers.
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Ten political parties have threatened to call a general strike unless the government arrests two former high-ranking officials accused of anti-democratic violence. In a joint statement, the political parties called for the arrest of former Army Maj. Gen. Williams Regala and former Defense and Interior Minister Roger Lafontant. Otherwise, the parties said a one-day general strike would take place Wednesday, according to independent Radio Haiti-Inter. The re-emergence of Regala and Lafontant in Haiti last week heightened fears of an organized attempt to disrupt presidential elections scheduled for Nov. 4. Regala was the alleged mastermind of the 1987 election day massacre in which thugs supported by the army shot and hacked to death at least 34 voters at polling stations. He was retired from the army in 1988 and has lived in the United States since then. On Friday, the independent Electoral Council denounced Regala's public reappearance, saying it ``heralded the return of other henchmen of violence.'' Lafontant headed the dreaded National Security Volunteers, popularly known as the Tonton Macoutes, the secret police force set up by the dictator Francois ``Papa Doc'' Duvalier, who died in 1971. He was regarded as the power behind Duvalier's son, Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc,'' who fled into exile in February 1986. On Monday night, independent Tele-Haiti retransmitted a 1986 CBS-TV report in which the Rev. Leroy Antoine, a Roman Catholic priest, said he was beaten for four hours in Lafontant's presence, forced to eat his own excrement, covered with syrup and dumped on an ant heap. Lafontant, interviewed on the same CBS program, denied the accusation. Government prosecutor Bayard Vincent issued a warrant for Lafontant's arrest on Saturday, the day the former official arrived from neighboring Dominican Republic where he had lived in exile since 1986. But the warrant presumably had not been served by late Monday. The 19-member Council of State, which governs alongside President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, issued a statement Monday denouncing Lafontant and Regala as ``threats to public peace'' and demanded they be arrested and tried. In a radio interview Saturday, Lafontant, a physician, denied he had ever carried out crimes against the people and said he had no intention of interfering with the upcoming elections. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot's civilian caretaker government was brought to power March 13, after a popular uprising toppled military ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Discards Prepared Toast, Says `Have a Good Time' ^Eds: Inserts new graf 3 with White House explanation for dropped toast.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush discarded a prepared toast and simply welcomed his economic summit partners to a glittering dinner Tuesday night with the admonition, ``We just want you to have a very, very good time.'' In brief opening remarks before dinner at the modernistic Brown Pavilion of the city's Museum of Fine Arts, Bush told his 110 guests, ``There is no working tonight, no communiques, no amendments, no language to be corrected.'' A White House press aide said later the president skipped the formal toast because he had left his notecards back at his hotel. Bush, Vice President Dan Quayle and their wives greeted the guests at the door of the museum and led them to a side gallery for an hour of cocktails before sitting down to a dinner of roast medallion of veal, chilled yellow tomato soup, sweet corn pudding and other delectables, topped by a dessert of cobbler of Cherokee blackberries. Bush sat between British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Danielle Mitterrand, wife of the president of France. The president's table was placed next to a full-length portrait of Alexander Hamilton painted by John Turnbull in 1792. The crowd included not only the presidents, prime ministers and their spouses, but Texas Gov. Bill Clements and a small sampling of Houston's elite, including the heads of three universities and Mayor Kathy Whitemire. Some 80 other prominent Houstonians, including captains of business, summit organizers and others, came in just for the after-dinner drinks and entertainment provided by comedian Michael Davis, country singer Ricky Skaggs, singer Marilyn McCoo, actress Cicely Tyson and mezzo-soprano Fredrica Von Stade. The White House press office distributed an advance text of a toast in which Bush briefly reviewed the astonishing events since the last economic summit in Paris, including the collapse of the Berlin Wall. The president said part of the credit for those changes had to be given to ``four decades of purpose and perseverance from the peoples and the nations represented in this room.'' ``I raise a glass: To friendship. To freedom. To the spirit of the old West. And to the promise of the new West, that permanent alliance of the great democracies,'' Bush's prepared toast said.

DOC.HEAD: United Parcel Fuels Delivery Vans With Natural Gas
DOC.TEXT: United Parcel Service announced Tuesday it would fuel a small experimental fleet of delivery vans with natural gas in a fresh attempt to fight smog in the city with the nation's dirtiest air. ``UPS has taken the initiative in converting their fleet to this alternative fuel source that has proven to be an effective combatant to the pollutants that destroy the quality of our air in Los Angeles,'' Mayor Tom Bradley said in a statement lauding the program. ``I congratulate the commitment of this company.'' In a pilot program, the carrier will operate a fleet of 20 vehicles on natural gas supplied by the Southern California Gas Co. If successful, the entire Los Angeles UPS fleet of more than 2,000 trucks will be converted in the next five years. ``We are looking forward to pursuing this effort in Los Angeles and to sharing the knowledge we gain with the city and its citizens,'' said Siro DeGasperis, a UPS spokesman. ``We feel that our efforts will contribute to a safer and healthier environment in the Los Angeles basin,'' he said. The program follows one in New York in which 10 UPS vans were converted to natural gas with the help of the Brooklyn Union Gas Co. Each of the 10 vehicles cost $3,000 to $3,500 to convert to natural gas. The New York fleet that took part in the program reduced its carbon monoxide production by 85 percent, nitrogen oxide by 25 percent, carbon dioxide by 23 percent and hydrocarbons by 13 percent. Drastic measures have been taken to ease smog in Los Angeles, which has more than 7.5 million vehicles and suffers the nation's worst air pollution. Air quality regulators approved a plan last year calling for 40 percent of cars and 70 percent of trucks in the region to run on cleaner fuels by 1998. Unocal Corp. is offering free smog checks and emission control tune-ups for pre-1975 cars at participating Unocal 76 stations. Shell Oil Co. is selling SU 2000E gasoline in nine smoggy cities including Los Angeles and San Diego. The gas reduces polluting emissions. Los Angeles has a smog snitch hotline for motorists to call in license plate numbers of cars that spew noxious emissions from tailpipes.

DOC.HEAD: State Attorney General Accused of Felony Theft by Deception
DOC.TEXT: A county prosecutor asked a judge Tuesday to charge the state attorney general with felony theft for allegedly wining and dining private guests on the taxpayers' tab and falsifying expense claims. In a 55-page affidavit, Pulaski County Prosecutor Chris Piazza asked Little Rock Municipal Judge Marion Humphrey to approve a felony theft by deception charge against Attorney General Steve Clark. Humphrey said he would rule Wednesday on whether there is probable cause to file the charge in Pulaski County Circuit Court, and on a motion by Clark's lawyer to keep the investigative file closed for fear the publicity could influence any trial. The lawyer, Bill Bristow, said Clark would plead innocent if the charge is filed. Clark, attorney general for 12 years, withdrew from the gubernatorial race in February after the Arkansas Gazette reported on discrepancies in his expense reports. Piazza's affidavit outlines 56 cases in which state police accuse Clark of charging the state for meals or drinks with guests, including judges and fellow attorneys general, who said either they weren't present or that private matters were discussed. The affadavit, which covers July 1986 to Feb. 9, says police found 86 transactions billed to the state for a total of $8,448.27 in expenses unconnected to state business. Felony theft by deception carries a maximum penalty of five to 20 years in jail and a $15,000 fine, Piazza said. ``Steve Clark executed an unauthorized control of property that belonged to the state of Arkansas and that property amounted to more than $2,500,'' making the alleged crime a felony under state law, Piazza said. Bristow said Clark would be unavailable for comment Tuesday. Clark didn't return messages left at his office, and calls to his home went unanswered. But Bristow said earlier that Clark had been willing to plead guilty to a misdemeanor charge for falsifying his office expense records. ``There is a statute in Arkansas which makes it a Class B misdemeanor if you make any kind of false entry in a public record. If you make a mistake in the public record that statute would, in my judgment, apply,'' Bristow said. He said Clark ``strenuously, heatedly'' denied committing a felony, and said he doubted Clark would resign. Bristow said he couldn't discuss specifics of his talks with Piazza, but indicated Piazza held out for a felony plea. ``I have told them my views about what took place in this matter _ that Mr. Clark has indicated that there was some record-keeping mistake, but he was not guilty of taking any kind of money,'' Bristow said in a telephone interview. The state attorney general is not required to itemize expenditures. Clark has said he went beyond the law to be more accountable, but made mistakes when he tried to itemize expenses 60 and 90 days after the fact.

The United States has the largest number of billionaires, but Donald Trump is no longer among them. The new Forbes magazine list of the world's billionaires includes 62 American individuals and 37 U.S. families. John Werner Kluge remained the richest American, according to Forbes. The founder of broadcasting's Metromedia is worth an estimated $5.2 billion. Trump was bounced from the list as the value of his real estate and airline empire plummeted. Forbes put his net worth last year at $1.7 billion. In April, the magazine said, he was worth about $500 million. Some sources peg it even lower.

Three months ago, East Germany's new democratic government invited Jews worldwide to return to the land where they once faced Nazi persecution. Since then, hundreds of Soviet Jews who say they are facing a resurgence of anti-Semitism at home have taken the government up on its offer and are seeking sanctuary on German soil. Now, the government says Soviet Jews may not qualify for refugee status under the immigration laws East Germany is likely to enact as it merges with West Germany. ``We are no longer a state that can decide its own affairs,'' said Gabriela Lubanda, an official in the foreigner affairs office of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere.

Margaret Moore used to think of the homeless as bums. Now, homeless herself, she is willing to stand on line in temperatures approaching 100 degrees to pay her respects to Mitch Snyder. ``I always liked what he did,'' said Moore, who lives in a shelter about two miles from the one in which Snyder's body lay for viewing on Monday. ``I didn't know anything about homeless people until I became one _ I thought they all were bums. But I listened to him, and it helped me to learn that the homeless are people, too.'' Snyder's funeral was being held today outside the 1,200-bed Community for Creative Non-Violence shelter that the militant advocate for the homeless had help found.

Both the Democrats and the Republicans are underdogs in the Connecticut governor's race this year. Voters seem smitten with the third-party campaign of a maverick ex-senator they ousted from office just 1{ years ago. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. narrowly lost his bid for a fourth Senate term in 1988 but roared back onto the state's political scene in March, forsaking the GOP and declaring his candidacy as an independent. Poll after poll has found Weicker to be the frontrunner in the gubernatorial race, far ahead of the two congressmen who are expected to claim the Republican and Democratic nominations. But Weicker _ who created his own party, the Connecticut Party _ discounts the polls. He remembers 1988, when he was favored for re-election to the Senate and lost by 10,000 votes to Democrat Joseph Lieberman.

A parents group is battling charges of censorship as its campaign for voluntary warning stickers on records promoting bigotry, rape and murder wins allies in legislatures and within the music industry. The Parents Music Resource Center founded by Elizabeth ``Tipper'' Gore says it is promoting truth-in-packaging to help parents and their children deal with an entertainment culture that is increasingly violent and sexually explicit. ``Part of our problem is our culture tends to look at children as miniature adults,'' said Jennifer Norwood, executive director of the parents group. ``We expect them to handle things they're not ready to handle yet at their age. Groups like 2 Live Crew are dealing with adult issues.'' But some opponents say the labels are censorship because artists and record companies are pressured to use them.

Mikhail S. Gorbachev handily won re-election Tuesday as Soviet Communist Party leader from a congress that assailed him for eight days but concluded the party could not survive without him. Although opposition appeared to melt away as the delegates considered electing a new general secretary, a sizable anti-Gorbachev sentiment was evident in the balloting. Delegates at the 28th congress of the Soviet Communist Party voted 3,411 to 1,116 to keep Gorbachev as general secretary. His opponent, Teimuraz Avaliani, a Siberian party leader, received 501 votes to 4,026. Under congress' rules, delegates are required to take a separate vote on each candidate. It was the first time a general secretary was elected by a congress and not a plenary meeting of the Central Committee.

A top NASA official on Tuesday denied an assertion by Sen. Albert Gore Jr. that critical plumbing connections were installed on two space shuttles even though the parts had failed a leakage test. Gore, a Tennessee Democrat, said two umbilicals, which carry supercold hydrogen rocket fuel onto the spacecraft, were among seven plumbing fixtures that failed initial tests but were tested a second time, using a different method, and passed. Gore said the umbilicals had leaked when tested with liquid nitrogen and connected to a simulated spacecraft part. NASA spaceflight director William Lenoir said that the umbilicals had not failed and that the second round of tests was normal.

Savings and loan bailout officials approved a policy Tuesday they hope will save taxpayers' money by selling insolvent thrifts before the institutions lose value during months of government control. In a major strategy shift, the board of the Resolution Trust Corp., created last summer to clean up the S&L industry, voted 4-0 to adopt a program to find buyers for weak thrifts before, rather than after, they fail. Previously, failed S&Ls were declared insolvent by the Office of Thrift Supervision, an arm of the Treasury Department, and turned over to the RTC. Later _ sometimes more than a year later _ the trust corporation provided government assistance to new investors to acquire the thrift. RTC Chairman L. William Seidman contends that simply declaring an institution failed reduces its value because depositors withdraw money and key employees find other jobs.

Police perusing demonology books as they prepare for a feared attack Thursday by the Zodiac gunman say he may have learned some of his victims' birthdays from Census data or Social Security forms. All four of the shootings by the gunman so far have been in the early morning hours on a Thursday. The last one came three weeks ago Thursday, and the previous spacing of the attacks has led police to focus on this Thursday. ``Tomorrow night is a target night,'' Police Department spokeswoman Suzanne Trazoff said Tuesday. All of the gunman's victims were defenseless at the time they were shot. Two walked with canes; one was inebriated; one was a homeless man sleeping on a Central Park bench. Three victims survived the attacks; a fourth died.

DOC.NOTE: $Adv17
For release Tues PMs, July 17, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Puppy Love Conquers Rikers Tough Guys
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Like wallflowers at a junior-high dance, the Rikers Island inmates hung back. Maybe they knew their streetwise facades were about to be punctured by puppy love. For two hours, these teen-agers could almost forget the manslaughter, kidnapping or car theft charges that landed them behind bars. Instead, they played with seven visiting dogs and cats, a rare touch of tenderness provided monthly by volunteers from the Animal Medical Center. ``My friends think I'm totally nuts, but it's not dangerous as people perceive it,'' said Edith McBean, the center's outreach coordinator, who goes to Rikers with Casey, a Jack Russell terrier puppy, and Keen, a Labrador retriever. ``For those two hours, the machismo is dropped; they're just little boys,'' said Diane Smith, coordinator of volunteer visits for the Rikers health services unit. The goals of these visits, which started three years ago, are to decrease depression, stress and loneliness and to improve self-images, social skills and self-control. The inmates, ages 16 to 19, were chosen because their families and friends don't visit. ``Even though they're not family, it's something. These people go out of their way,'' said James, a 19-year-old inmate who dreams of becoming a mechanic and having a cat. ``It makes you feel open, good inside. It gets your mind away from the problems you've got. It makes you feel special.'' ``We're coming in without an agenda _ we're not writing a paper, not there to save souls,'' said Susan Cohen, a therapist on the Animal Medical Center staff. ``Pets are an icebreaker. Otherwise, what would we say to them: `Do you come here often?''' The results haven't been analyzed, but at least one effect is evident. ``There are a lot of fights among the adolescents: slashings and stabbings, that sort of thing,'' said Smith. ``Once they're put into a relaxed mood, there's less of a chance of fighting _ at least, that day.'' On a recent night, 10 volunteers arrived in an ebullient conga line, cats yawning and dogs yapping as they passed through four security checkpoints. Some are employees of the medical center, some are volunteers there, and most bring their own pets. Toys, water bowls, dog treats and bags of cookies were piled in the otherwise-dismal visitors' room. The five dogs raced around, wagging, sniffing and barking. At first, the 16 inmates huddled in knots of three or four. Under the gaze of uniformed officers, the volunteers fanned out, helping the pets introduce themselves. The two cats were coaxed from their carriers and gently placed on laps. The prisoners, eyes filled with uncertainty, masked their vulnerability with bravado. Several bragged that they'd once owned the meanest dog on the block. Some teased the dogs, holding toys or food out of reach. ``I tell them to knock it off in a nice way. They stop, maybe after you've said it five times,'' said McBean. Eventually, everyone started to relax. ``It's nice to see how they soften up,'' she said. The beefiest inmates zeroed in on the brawny dogs, like Teddy, an Appenzeller brought by Debra Liccardi, a dog walker, and Nick G. Hayden, vice president of a real estate company. ``Teddy's got a tough-looking appearance that a lot of guys at prison love,'' said Hayden. Hayden and Liccardi have been going to Rikers for five months with pets they borrow from her clients. She gets the inmates acquainted with the dogs; he talks to them about other things. ``It's a matter of sitting there and listening,'' said Hayden. ``They're all extremely polite. It's sometimes hard to keep in perspective that they're not all saints.'' At least until he hears their stories. ``One kid attempted murder a couple of times; another was in for possession of a 9mm-gun, an Uzi and vials of crack. I'm sure if I'd seen him on the street, I'd have known he was trouble and walked away,'' Hayden said. ``But I sat there, talking to him for an hour.'' Some inmates sat quietly, stroking the more tranquil pets, as they spoke with the volunteers. ``I like to observe them; they have their own little world,'' said Danny, 19. ``I wonder what they think about us.'' ``There are times you do get lonely,'' confessed Jamar, 18. ``I miss my family, girlfriend, brothers and sister.'' ``My brothers are facing hard time; I pray for them every night,'' said James. ``After a visit (from the animals), it's hard when you go back to the house.'' It wasn't long, though, before James went back. An officer bellowed; the inmates filed out. The dogs, panting, sprawled on the floor; the cats hid beneath blankets in their carriers. A corrections worker searched for the key that would return the visitors to freedom. ``You spend a couple of hours, and feel like you do something good for them,'' said Hayden. ``But you leave very confused, frustrated.'' Still, he concluded, ``If we can get one guy out and keep him out, I think it's worth it.''

DOC.HEAD: Are Referendums Democratic? Let's Put It to a Vote!
An AP News Analysis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Substitutes for the regular column by Walter R. Mears, vacationing
DOC.TEXT: You're a legislator, facing tough decisions. Bound to be controversial, sure to set barn fires no matter how you decide. Then someone has a bright idea: let the people decide. Put the issue on the ballot and put the question to the people. What could be more democratic? Is that buck-passing? Or is it direct, participatory democracy? Yes it is and yes it is, said Patrick B. McGuigan, an Oklahoman who has been keeping track of ballot propositions at the conservative Free Congress Foundation for years. Yes, said McGuigan, when legislatures put issues on the ballot ``it becomes a way for legislators to avoid doing what we elect them to do.'' And, yes, said McGuigan, ``it is an expression of confidence in ourselves.'' He said it makes citizens more involved in everyday politics, more aware of the issues. ``Every meaningful criticism that can be made against the initiative process has an exact corollary in every other aspect of our democratic system,'' he said. In any event, ballot-box lawmaking is a growing phenomena. Twenty-six states and the District of Columbia allow referendums (issues referred to the people by the legislatures) or initiatives (issues on the ballot at the initiative of voters), but only about a dozen states use these processes with much regularity. In 1988, voters decided on 229 statewide issues. They ranged from repealing a gun control law in Maryland (no dice, said the voters) to discouraging tobacco use by increasing cigarette taxes 25 cents in California (that passed despite a $15 million industry campaign against it). This year, even more issues are likely to be voted upon, including tax limitation issues, tax increases for specific purposes and measures to limit the terms of legislators. You can argue for it: it is direct democracy. You can argue against it: Citizens are called to make decisions without having heard the pros and cons. They don't have to consider priorities (voting money for the homeless might take money from the sick or the schools). They can be influenced by expensive advertising campaigns mounted by special interests. Thomas Cronin, a Colorado College political scientist and author of ``Direct Democracy: The Politics of the Initiative, Referendum and Recall,'' is a middle-of-the-roader. Like McGuigan, he sees both sides. If citizens don't know what they're voting on, legislators often don't either, he said. They pass a lot of bills in a frantic final burst; they spend about a third of each session amending or otherwise repairing measures passed the previous session. And they are influenced by political action committees, lobbyists and special interests, too. On the other hand, Cronin's research found that 10 percent to 15 percent of the voters who go to the polls (often only 50 percent of the electorate) do not vote on ballot issues ``and another 10 percent really don't know what they're voting on.'' ``So the answer is that both of these processes ought to be of concern,'' he said. ``Why do we have referendums? It's because our system has become far less democratic in practice tha in the textbooks. In the ideal type of world, we would not have to resort to initiative-referendum campaigns because we would have such responsible, responsive legislatures they wouldn't be necessary.'' Cronin finds that elected officeholders, scholars and journalists tend to be opposed to direct democracy devices. They think the issues are too complicated, that issues first should be aired at hearings, that compromises _ the essence of democracy _ can't be molded by a citizen facing a yes-or-no choice. The argument comes down, Cronin said, to philosophy. It is a case of the populists, who think the people always know best, vs. ``parentalists,'' who think papa knows best. He notes that voters sometimes use the ballot to strike back at big government: Massachusetts voters vetoed both a mandatory seat belt law and a salary increase for state legislators one year. McGuigan and Cronin share a concern about what happens when too many issues crowd themselves onto the ballot. In 1988, so many questions were on the California ballot that express lines were created for voters who promised to spend only five minutes marking their ballot. Cronin said the growth in ballot issues is a result, too, of the way incumbents have become almost undefeatable. ``Regular elections in America are increasingly meaningless,'' he said. ``Ninety-five percent of incumbents at the state and national level get reelected routinely. In Colorado, only once in the 1980s did a state senator get defeated. That's not untypical.'' ``If we have no turnover, no real competition, then the people with a grievance have two choices _ form a PAC if they have lots of money, or get their issue on the ballot if they don't.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: Mike Feinsilber has covered issues in government since 1968.
