DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Overhaul of Asbestos Payment Trust
DOC.TEXT: In an attempt to break a legal gridlock over compensating victims of asbestos-related diseases, a federal judge is seeking to consolidate tens of thousands of lawsuits into one giant class action case. U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein on Monday also ordered a complete overhaul of the financially ailing Manville Corp. trust fund created to compensate victims of diseases such as lung cancer and mesothelioma. But Weinstein said the only possible solution to ``this wasteful, inefficient war over asbestos'' may be to group all of some 90,000 outstanding cases into one class-action lawsuit before him. The judge asked lawyers for about 40 defendant companies and thousands of victims exposed to asbestos on the job to agree on a converting the cases. That would remove cases from the dockets of 500 state courts and all 96 federal courts. ``The courts ... are now so overloaded with drug cases and other matters that the extra burden of asbestos litigation is seriously interfering with the administration of justice in this country,'' Weinstein said. Consolidating the cases also would sharply reduce payments to plaintiffs lawyers, who have received as much as 40 percent of compensation payments to victims. Asbestos, a white mineral with natural heat-resistance and insulation properties, was widely used in shipbuilding, construction and other industries for decades. Lengthy exposure has been found to cause cancer and other serious and often fatal diseases. In his order, Weinstein also temporarily froze all payments by the Manville trust, citing a ``severe cash shortage ... constituting a judicial emergency.'' Included in the stay are payments of any settlements, court judgments and legal fees. Ongoing court cases are not affected. He ordered that the trust, created in 1988 as part of Manville Corp.'s bankruptcy court reorganization, be restructured and refinanced by Aug. 6 to allow quicker payments to the neediest victims of asbestos-related disease. The Manville Personal Injury Settlement Trust is out of cash to pay new claims and has said that people who file claims now may not get paid until well into the 21st century. The cash shortage has been induced by more cases, larger payouts and quicker settlements than expected. To date, the trust has paid $974 million to settle more than 22,300 cases, an average payment of about $43,000 per claim. Weinstein is involved in the asbestos saga because he is supervising, along with a state judge, 579 cases consolidated for trial involving former workers of the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Weinstein called for a new method to compensate workers and their families who were most seriously injured by asbestos diseases and need money immediately. He supported installment payments to victims to maximize the trust's available funds. ``Those workers and their families who were most seriously injured must secure compensation immediately,'' Weinstein said. That would replace the system developed in bankruptcy court that pays victims on the basis of when they file a claim rather than the nature of their disease, one of the most highly criticized features of the trust. On refinancing, Weinstein suggested several steps, including hundreds of millions of dollars in loans or advances from Manville; sale of control of Manville by transferring the trust's assets; or the trust buying the entire company. As part of its Chapter 11 reorganization, Denver-based Manville placed $2.5 billion in assets, mostly stock, into the trust. The company also agreed to contribute $75 million annually starting in 1991 plus 20 percent of annual net income from 1992 until all claims are paid. The trust effectively controls 80 percent of Manville. Weinstein supported an injunction prohibiting asbestos victims from directly suing Manville, a measure he hinted at recently, because ``the value of the trust depends upon a healthy, viable corporation.'' David Austern, general counsel for the Washington-based trust, said he would ask the trustees whether to object to the stay of payments. According to court documents, the trust has on hand $93.2 million to pay $112.8 million in claims already settled. That money is frozen by the judge's order.

DOC.HEAD: Marlboro Maker Threatens Suits Against Trademark Use on Kid Products
DOC.TEXT: Critics say the maker of Marlboro cigarettes is blowing smoke with its new advertising campaign that warns candy, toy and apparel manufacturers against using its trademarks on products aimed at children. The campaign by Philip Morris USA, the nation's biggest cigarette company, whose brands also include Virginia Slims, Benson & Hedges and Parliament, was disclosed Monday amid a crescendo of health-related complaints against smoking. The critics said the move against unauthorized use of cigarette brand logos on candy cigarettes and video games was a diversionary tactic designed to distract attention from what they say are subtle industry efforts to hook youngsters on tobacco. They also said the $500,000 Philip Morris pledged for the five-year campaign pales next to what it spends promoting its tobacco products. ``It's nothing but a PR effort,'' said Dr. John W. Richards, president of Doctors Ought to Care, a physicians' group trying to reduce teenage smoking. Anti-smoking forces have succeeded in getting smoking banned on most domestic airline flights and in many public spaces and are clamoring to extend a ban on broadcast advertising to print and promotions such as sporting events. Critics also have accused the tobacco companies of marketing their products to children or or tolerating others' use of distinctive cigarette logos on products for youngsters. Tobacco companies vigorously have denied those charges, saying their marketing efforts are aimed at adult smokers. But there have been embarrassing incidents in recent months. A video game maker, for instance, used a version of the Marlboro logo as part of the background for its racing game until it was discovered and Philip Morris objected. Tobacco companies also confirmed they once paid to have their products placed in movies popular with teens. John R. Nelson, vice president of corporate affairs for Philip Morris, told a news briefing on Monday that the company had taken 1,100 ``actions'' to stop unauthorized use of its cigarette logos over the past decade, with about 10 percent of those cases involving products aimed at children. But he said the company has been able to take those actions, which range from letters by Philip Morris lawyers to lawsuits, only after being notified that the logos are being used. He said the new ad campaign, starting in August in 16 journals read widely by lawyers and those in the toy, candy, video and apparel businesses, should make Philip Morris' position known in advance of products hitting the market. The company has prepared two ads, each listing the company's cigarette names and logos. One ad says ``Cigarettes Are Not for Children!'' while the other says ``If You Use These Trademarks, We'll See You in Court.'' ``We don't want products created for kids carrying our logos,'' Nelson told reporters. Nelson defended the amount earmarked for the five-year campaign, saying $500,000 was sufficient to reach through trade journals the people making children's products. According to Leading National Advertisers, Philip Morris spent $277.4 million on cigarette advertising in 1989. Others have estimated the industry as a whole spends more than $3 billion a year on all types of tobacco promotion. Nelson said there were no plans to beef up the company's six-person trademark enforcement division to support the goals of the new ad campaign but said that division has no budget cap on what it may spend. He said the company decided last year it no longer would allow use of its cigarettes in movies following controversies about placing Marlboros in a ``Superman'' movie and Lark cigarettes in a James Bond film. He said Philip Morris notified leading product placement companies that it no longer will pay for such placements and would deny permission if asked. But he added there was little the company could do to stop incidental use of its brands in films. The new ad campaign won't quiet tobacco's critics. Joe Tye, president of a group called Stop Teenage Addiction to Tobacco, said he doubts the industry wants to discourage young people from smoking. He estimated people under 18 bought $1.25 billion in tobacco products last year. ``They are trying to come up with something to distract from what they are really doing _ trying to get kids to smoke by associating with it with athletics, excellence, independence, maturity, good times and good fun,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Says Corporate Name Changes Fell Off in First Half
DOC.TEXT: A foodmaker whose bananas were more familiar than it was did it. So did a bedding company better known for a mattress brand. An investment partnership with all too familiar name did it in what appeared to be a chance to make people forget. They all changed their corporate names in the first half of the year. United Brands Inc. became Chiquita Brands International Inc., Ohio Mattress Co. is now known as Sealy Corp. and Ivan Boesky & Co. LP became CX Partners LP. But despite these striking examples of new company calling cards, a survey released Monday said the volume of corporate name changes fell 9 percent in the first half of 1990 compared with a year earlier. The consulting firm Anspach Grossman Portugal Inc. said the 697 corporate names changes in the first six months of 1990 was down from 767 in the first half of 1989. It was the fewest changes for the period since there were 579 in the first half of 1986. Joel Portugal, a principal in the identity consulting firm, said the decline reflected an overall decline in general business activity. First-half name changes peaked at 931 in early 1988. The latest drop-off occurred despite an increase in the number of name changes stemming from mergers and acquisitions. That was the single biggest category of name change explanations, totaling 367 changes, or 53 percent of the total, compared with 351 a year earlier. Prominent among merger-related changes were 61 resulting from government-assisted actions related to the thrift industry. Elective name changes accounted for another 125, down from 139 a year earlier, while divestitures accounted for 93 changes, down from 108. Elective changes included United Brands' change as well as the switch of International Minerals and Chemical Corp. to Imcera Group and AMCA International's change to United Dominion Industries. Other reasons included 44 due to sale of assets, 34 for corporate restructuring, seven for changes to a holding company configuration, eight for leveraged buyouts or spinoffs and 19 for assorted other reasons. Portugal said companies have become more sophisticated in recent years about name changes. He said two decades ago, executives often would change a company's name in an effort ``to prime the pump'' and boost sales. But he said modern executives make changes ``for substance, not appearances sake'' and said the falloff in name changes this year may indicate that companies don't feel their business has changed enough to warrant a switch. ``With less changes taking place in business, there is less reason to communicate a change,'' he said. But he said some companies sought to disassociate themselves from names that became infamous in the 1980s. In addition to the change at the investment firm headed by Ivan Boesky, a central figure in Wall Street's biggest inside trading case, Portugal noted that Campeau (U.S.) Corp. became Federated Stores Inc. in the first half. In the face of financial problems, Portugal noted Campeau changed its name ``to an already well-established and respected name in the financial and retail communities.''

DOC.HEAD: Contract Talks Between Eastern, Pilots Union at Impasse
DOC.TEXT: A 30-day cooling-off period began today after contract talks between Eastern Airlines and the Air Line Pilots Association reached an impasse. The latest round of talks started in mid-May, several weeks after a federal bankruptcy court in New York appointed Martin Shugrue as a trustee to take control of Eastern from Frank Lorenzo. Lorenzo is chairman of Continental Airlines Holdings Inc., then called Texas Air Corp., the parent of Eastern. After the 30-day period, the ALPA pilots could legally vote to strike Miami-based Eastern. But such a move likely would have little effect, since most of the 1,900 pilots at Eastern currently are non-union. Flight attendants and ALPA pilots at Eastern walked out in sympathy with the Machinists union in March 1989 but called off their strikes last November. Most of the pilots were replaced by non-union hires and only a few hundred ALPA fliers remained at Eastern through the strike or later returned to work there. Many former Eastern pilots still are out of work. An ALPA strike vote ``would be a non-event,'' Eastern spokeswoman Karen Ceremsak said Monday in Miami. She said the company would work toward a negotiated settlement in the next 30 days. E.J. Breen, a member of the Master Executive Council of ALPA for Eastern, acknowledged that a decision to strike wouldn't shut down the airline. He warned, however, that it could hamper the carrier's operations. An impasse was declared Monday after the talks in Washington broke off in early in the day. The Master Executive Council rejected what was described as the company's final contract offer. A federal mediator proposed arbitration, a stronger measure than mediation, but Eastern refused the offer _ setting in motion the cooling-off period. Later, at a hearing before U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland in New York, Eastern withdrew its earlier request to the court to impose a new contract on the ALPA pilots. ``Eastern has consistently slammed every door in the pilots' face,'' said John Mazor, an ALPA spokesman. In a statement, the pilots union called the contract terms offered by the company ``onerous at best.'' The two sides also are at loggerheads over the issue of non-working pilots returning to Eastern and the order of preference they should be given in going back. In addition, ALPA objects to Eastern's insistence that the union's lawsuit against Continental Airlines Holdings be dropped as a condition of reaching a labor agreement. ``When Martin Shugrue took over as trustee of Eastern, he said that labor peace was essential to Eastern's survival,'' the ALPA statement said. ``Apparently that was just a stalling tactic, because what we're seeing is simply a continuation of the Lorenzo approach to labor relations.'' Nevertheless, the union said, it was prepared to continue negotiations with the company throughout the cooling-off period. Eastern has been operating under bankruptcy court supervision since March 9, 1989, five days after the start of the strike.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Buyout Group Says 5 Banks Willing To Lend
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp.'s unions are still seeking financing commitments for their proposed $4.38 billion acquisition of United Airlines, although five major banks have expressed a willingness to become the lead lenders. ``We are talking to a lot of people,'' a source close to the labor group said. Those includes other banks and aircraft suppliers, said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The unions have disclosed the names of five major U.S. banks that have indicated an interest in lending money for the deal. The development advances the union group toward its goal of securing financing for the buyout by an Aug. 9 deadline. But none of the banks has yet signed a loan agreement, and they are insisting that a portion of the financing come from non-banking sources such as aircraft suppliers, said the union group source. ``I'm not aware that anything has been signed,'' the source said Monday. ``They have expressed a willingness to participate.'' The five New York-based banks are Citicorp, Chase Manhattan Corp., Bankers Trust New York Corp., Manufacturers Hanover Corp. and Chemical Banking Corp., United's pilots union said Saturday in a tape-recorded telephone message to its members. The banks ``will be both participating in and leading the syndication of the financing,'' according to the message. The unions need about $4.5 billion to complete the cash portion of the $201-per-share buyout, refinance existing debt and provide working capital for the airline. The five banks are expected each to offer about $500 million, or a total of $2.5 billion. UAL's stock rose $4.37{ to $157.12{ Monday in composite trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The buyout group, which includes United's pilots, machinists and flight attendants, supplied the names of the banks to UAL's board of directors last week in a progress report, the union source said. The Wall Street Journal reported Monday that the board pressed the unions to provide evidence of progress after the unions asked the board to hold off on placing a large order for new aicraft, a request the board subsequently honored. The union source would say only that the unions supplied the bank names to UAL's board after learning the board was readying the jet order. The buyout group is talking with a variety of suppliers, including aircraft manufacturer Boeing Corp. and jet engine maker General Electric Co., about possibly investing in the buyout in return for a note or nonvoting preferred stock in the airline. The union group also has named three people who would become directors of an employee-owned UAL. They are Robert Lanigan, chairman of Owens-Illinois Inc.; J. Richard Munro, chairman of the executive committee of Time Warner Inc.; and Donald Perkins, a former chairman of Jewel Food Stores Inc., a unit of American Superstores Inc. The board agreed in April to the buyout proposal, which would make UAL the world's largest employee-owned company. Two of the banks named by the unions, Citicorp and Chase Manhattan, were the lead banks in an earlier, failed buyout bid led by UAL's management and pilots. That $6.75 billion deal collapsed in October, precipitating a 190-point plunge in the stock market, when other banks balked at financing it partly because of opposition by United's machinists.

DOC.HEAD: Philly Exchange to Extend Trading Hours
DOC.TEXT: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange, the first U.S. securities market to introduce evening trading in foreign currencies, says it will remain open 20{ hours to do more trading in Pacific Rim countries. The new hours, an increase of 6{ hours, are longer than any other foreign currency exchange, spokeswoman Nancy Himmelreich said Monday. The Philadelphia exchange, the oldest in the country, is known for the buying and selling of the Australian dollar, British pound, Canadian dollar, German mark, European currency unit, French franc, Japanese yen and Swiss franc for future delivery. The exchange is where trading in foreign currency options originated; about 250 people now participate in that business. The only hours it will not conduct foreign currency trading are from 2:30 p.m. to 7 p.m. EDT. During standard time, it will open and close an hour earlier. The trading day for 1,800 stocks runs from 9:30 a.m. through 4 p.m., coinciding with the New York Stock Exchange, with an extra 10 or 15 minutes. for the 140 stock options and four index options it handles. The Philadelphia Exchange in September 1987 became the first U.S. securities organization to introduce evening hours for foreign currency options to accommodate increasing demand from the Far East. In January 1989 it added early morning hours for the European market.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Upholds State's Penny Stock Fraud Law
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has ruled that Georgia's penny stock law _ considered the toughest in the nation _ is legal and will not adversely affect legitimate brokers. In an order filed late Monday, U.S. District Judge Jack Camp said the public interest in having a strong anti-fraud law outweighed Pacific Southern Securities Inc.'s contention that it would be irreparably harmed by the law. The company claimed that the law violated its constitutional rights to due process, equal protection and commerce and that the state law was pre-empted by federal legislation. Gerald Schechter, president of Colorado-based Pacific Southern, had testified in a hearing last month that he could not do business in Georgia under the law. Schechter said his firm has more than 1,200 Georgia customers. ``Regulating abuses in the penny stock industry is a legitimate state government interest,'' Camp said in his order. ``Limiting the effect of the regulations to firms that deal almost exclusively in penny stocks is not an irrational or arbitrary exercise of government power.'' The new law, which went into effect July 1, includes several provisions to protect investors, including a three-day ``cooling off'' period during which deals to buy the stocks can be canceled. The law also requires dealers to undergo training to ensure they know about what they are selling, and the secretary of state is given increased power to impose penalties on violators, including civil fines of up to $500,000 for each offense. The law passed the Legislature overwhelmingly following a series of hearings, organized by Georgia Secretary of State Max Cleland, where investors made allegations of widespread abuse in the penny stock industry. Penny stocks are low-price, high-risk securities that authorities say are easily subject to fraud. The securities are not listed on stock exchanges, and reliable information on their value is not readily available to investors. Federal officials say penny stock fraud causes investors to lose $2 billion annually. ``The reason we have this law is because ... there were significant abuses to the public,'' said George Shingler, of the attorney general's office, who represented Cleland.

DOC.HEAD: Securities and Exchange Commission Probing Western Union
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether Western Union filed false financial reports in connection with its recapitalizatiion registration. In an amendment to the registration filed Monday with the SEC, Western Union said that on May 28, the commission ordered an investigation of the period from April 1986 to March 1989. It said the SEC had advised it of the investigation in September 1989. The federal agency said it was looking into whether Western Union filed untrue or misleading reports or falsified books and records. It also is investigating whether certain officers, directors or other personnel made misleading statements about financial statements or Western Union's financial condition; any plans or proposals regarding the possible sale or divestiture of Western Union's major assets; the company's accounting entries, procedures, and policies; and the liquidity, capital resources and results of operations. In response, Western Union said it ``believes that its financial statements, including the timeliness of asset writedowns, have been in compliance with generally accepted accounting principles and that its public disclosures during this period were accurate in all material respects.'' ``Western Union cooperated fully with the commission in connection with the inquiry and intends to cooperate fully with the commission in connection with the investigation,'' the company said. Spokesman Warren Bechtel was not in his office Monday and his secretary said the company would make no further comment. Western Union is a financial services and paper-based messaging business.

DOC.HEAD: Sony Regrets DAT Lawsuit After Worldwide Standards Worked Out
DOC.TEXT: Sony Corp. expressed regret today that it was being sued for allegedly promoting illegal record copying after measures had been worked out to limit the ability of new tape equipment to make copies. At a meeting of the National Music Publishers Association in Los Angeles Monday, it was announced that an estimated 45,000 songwriters had filed a class action lawsuit against Sony, claiming its digital audio tape machines encouraged copyright violations. A Sony spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the company had not yet received official word from the U.S. Federal Court in New York where the case had been filed, or from the plaintiffs. But ``it didn't come as a surprise,'' the spokesman said, adding that music copyright holders had indicated they might take legal action aimed at preventing the new recording devices from going on sale. Unlike current analog tape recording equipment, digital technology provides for distortion-free recording of music from compact discs, and of subsequent generations of DAT cassettes. The Sony spokesman said it was regrettable that the songwriters should choose to sue just as the U.S. Congress was beginning to debate legislation and after an international consensus had been reached on preventing the new technology from violating musicians' copyrights. Last summer, record and audio industry groups around the world agreed on a worldwide standard for DAT equipment that clears the way for widespread marketing but limits the machines' ability to make repeated copies of CDs and other recorded material. They agreed that the machines would include a system that adds a ``flag'' signal to the tape when music from CDs is recorded to prevent any additional copies being made. The Sony spokesman said the agreement had worked to the mutual benefit of DAT manufacturers, record makers and consumers. ``It would be a disadvantage to U.S. consumers if it were taken away,'' he said. Sony and its American affiliates, though not the only producers of DAT technology, were the only firms named in the lawsuit. Sony leads the field. Japanese companies, the principal makers of the new machines, have sold DAT equipment in Japan and Europe since 1987. But they had refrained from selling in the United States until last month because of opposition by the U.S. record industry and a delay in receiving permission from their own government.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Lower at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices were lower at midday Tuesday, bogged down by a poor outlook for British corporate profits. There was little news to attract investors to the market at the moment, dealers said. The corporate sector was battered by a further batch of profit downgradings by brokerage firms while sterling's strength continued to cloud the outlook for earnings growth from international stocks, dealers said. Shortly after midday in London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 8.7 points, or 0.4 percent, at 2,328.8. Volume was a modest 318.4 million shares at midday, compared with 217.7 million shares at the same time Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Instruments Seeks To Enforce 13-year Old Chip Patent
DOC.TEXT: Five semiconductor makers illegally are using a process patented by Texas Instruments Inc. 13 years ago, the company claims in complaints filed in court and with the International Trade Commission. ``TI is taking these actions to prevent the unauthorized use of its technology and protect the significant investments the company has made in development of intellectual property that is used in integrated circuits around the world,'' company general counsel Richard J. Agnich said after Monday's filings. The lawsuit, filed in U.S. District in Dallas, says Integrated Device Technology Inc. in Santa Clara, Calif., Analog Devices Inc. of Norwood, Mass.; Cypress Semiconductor Corp. and VLSI Technology Inc., both of Sa Jose, Calif.; and LSI Logic Corp. of Milpitas, Calif., are violating a 1977 patent. The suit asks for unspecified damages. A companion complaint filed with the trade commission says the five companies also are importing and selling semiconductors made using the process without licensing. The actions are the latest in the Dallas-based company's 4-year-old campaign to benefit from its technological advances, which are protected by more than 5,000 patents. Among the company's breakthroughs was the invention of the computer chip in 1958. TI has earned $574 million in royalty income since 1987, when it first challenged nine Asian companies for using the same process, which involves covering computer chips with plastic. One of the accused companies suggested the lawsuit is a farfetched bid to grab revenue. ``Texas Instruments has been demanding some incredibly high royalty rates,'' said Jack Menache, general counsel at Integrated Device Technology Inc. ``I guess they're not making any money from operations.'' Menache said officials of his company met with TI representatives in December to discuss the patents, but no negotiations have been held since. Menache said the process TI claims rights to ``a process that's been around for a long, long time.'' Officials at the other four companies said they would have no immediate comment. A TI engineer is credited with co-inventing the integrated circuit in 1958. Today, the company is the No. 2 U.S. manufacturer of computer chips behind Motorola Inc. It wasn't until 1986, however, that the Dallas-based computer company began enforcing patents. ``Prior to that you did not have a legal system whose environment was that conducive to intellectual property,'' said TI spokeswoman Terri West. ``In order to remain competitive, a company must receive a fair return on a research and development investment and that means protecting your intellectual property,'' she said. Most of the royalty income so far has come from the patent covered in the lawsuits. In 1986, TI won claims that one Korean and eight Japanese semiconductor manufacturers were illegally using the process. In addition, TI last year won a Japanese patent on the 1958 integrated circuit. One estimate puts income from that patent as high as $290 million in 1991 alone. In addition to the plastic-encapsulation patent, the lawsuit claims the five companies are violating a related patent and that VLSI and Cypress Semiconductor are violating two other patents.

DOC.HEAD: UTC Plans Spaceport in Australia
DOC.TEXT: United Technologies Corp. plans to build and manage a commercial spaceport in northern Australia, a move that would put the aerospace giant at the center of the emerging international space-launch industry. The Bush administration gave informal approval Sunday to a plan in which a UTC subsidiary, USBI Co. of Huntsville, Ala., will design and develop the spaceport in Cape York, Australia. The base will be used to launch U.S. satellites on Soviet-built Zenit rockets for telecommunications customers worldwide. If completed, UTC's venture would represent the first time a private company has built a spaceport. All previous spaceports have been built by government military or space agencies. Bush administration officials delayed approval of the project for more than a year as they weighed concerns about the transfer of sensitive U.S. space technology to the Soviets. U.S. rocket makers such as Martin Marietta Corp. and McDonnell Douglas Corp. opposed the plan, fearing competition from government-subsidized Soviet rockets. ``The delicate problem for the government was how to promote all the sectors of the U.S. space industry _ the satellites, the launchers and the launch complexes _ while recognizing we're in a world market,'' said Joel Johnson, vice president for international affairs at the Aerospace Industry Association in Washington. When USBI has received formal U.S. approval, it will begin negotiating with the Australians on a final design of the spaceport, said Don Mirth, a senior vice president at USBI. He said USBI expects to employ about 70 workers in the design phase, about 300 to supervise construction of the spaceport and about 200 to manage the launch facility when it begins operating in the mid-1990s.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT

DOC.TEXT: A federal judge ordered a complete overhaul of the financially ailing Manville trust fund created to compensate tens of thousands of victims of asbestos-related disease nationwide. Using sharply critical language, U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein also supported but did not order on Monday a global settlement of an estimated 130,000 claims filed by asbestos victims dating to the 1940s.

Leaders of the world's seven richest nations have opened summit talks divided over aid to the Soviet Union but pointed toward a compromise allowing each country to go its own way. Diplomatic sources also said Monday that six of the nations were inclined to maintain trade restrictions against China, with only Japan poised to end the commercial sanctions imposed after last year's anti-democracy crackdown.

Standing apart from its summit partners, the Bush administration renewed its opposition to any concrete guide for reducing pollutants blamed for warming the earth's atmosphere. Shortly before the seven-nation summit formally opened, White House chief of staff John Sununu reiterated American worries that efforts to curtail polluting emissions sharply would hamper economic growth.

Americans took out $3.9 billion more in consumer credit than they paid off in May, or 10 times the amount incurred only a month earlier, the government reports. The Federal Reserve said Monday that consumer credit increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.5 percent, up from the previous month's 0.6 percent. Net new debt in April totaled $390 million.

A federal jury convicted two traders on commodity fraud charges in a partial verdict returned in the first trial stemming from an FBI sting operation at the world's two largest futures exchanges. A third trader was acquitted Monday on two commodity fraud counts. The commodity fraud charges were among the least serious against the traders. U.S. District Judge Ann C. Williams declared a mistrial on scores of other charges, including a racketeering count against one of the defendants. The jury deliberated 11 days before announcing it could not reach a decision on the other charges.

Five major U.S. banks have expressed a willingess to become the lead lenders for a $4.38 billion employee acquisition of United Airlines, the union-led buyout group says. The development advances the union group toward its goal of securing financing for the buyout by an Aug. 9 deadline. But none of the banks has yet signed loan agreements, and they are insisting that a portion of the financing come from non-banking sources such as aircraft suppliers, a union group source said Monday.

Contract talks between Eastern Airlines and the Air Line Pilots Association have reached an impasse, triggering a 30-day cooling-off period, the two sides say. The latest round of talks started in mid-May, several weeks after a federal bankruptcy court in New York appointed Martin Shugrue as a trustee to take control of Eastern from Frank Lorenzo. Lorenzo is chairman of Eastern parent Continental Airlines Holdings Inc., the former Texas Air Corp. The 30-day cooling off period begins today, the two sides said Monday.

A French investor accused of insider trading on Rorer Group Inc. securities has settled the charges with federal officials, the Securities and Exchange Commission has announced. Without admitting or denying wrongdoing, Robert Rossi agreed to pay nearly $1.45 million in alleged illegal profits plus interest. The settlement disclosed Monday was approved by a federal judge in New York on July 3.

A Japanese developer, Yoshiaki Tsutsumi, again topped a list of the world's richest people, but the annual tally has one conspicuous deletion this year: Donald J. Trump. But despite the financial troubles of the New York developer, the United States continues to contain the world's largest number of billionaries _ 62 _ according to estimates released by Forbes magazine. In addition, there are 37 U.S. families with fortunes over $1 billion, Forbes says in its July 23 issue, released Monday.

The stock market crept ahead Monday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 9.16 to 2,914.11 on top of Friday's 25.74-point gain. Bond prices lost ground on signs of unexpected economic strength. The dollar finished mixed in light domestic trading. Cotton futures prices fell sharply; energy futures rallied; sugar plummeted; precious metals were lower; grains and soybeans were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Ford, GM Extend Incentive Programs
DOC.TEXT: Incentive programs offered by Ford Motor Co. and General Motors Corp. will be extended and in some cases increased into August and September, automakers say. GM said Monday that incentives on Chevrolet cars and trucks will be extended until Sept. 26. Cash rebates will range from $500 to $1,500 on a variety of cars and light trucks, including the new four-door S-10 Blazer sport-utility vehicle. GM also said incentives on some Oldsmobile cars and the division's Silhouette minivan would be offered until Aug. 2. Rebates are between $1,000 and $2,500 on Oldsmobiles, depending on model. Meantime, Ford Motor Co. said incentives for some Ford-brand cars and trucks and Lincoln and Mercury cars would be extended until Aug. 8 and Sept. 26, respectively. Ford rebates range from $600 to $1,500, and Lincoln and Mercury rebates range from $700 to $2,000. Some low-interest financing packages also are available.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Governor Unsure of Record Labeling Bill's Constitutionality
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to recast, moving up reference to sales ban and deleting non-word `objectional.' SUBS penultimate graf to delete `host' as a verb.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Record Labeling Bjt. This also moved on general new wires.
DOC.TEXT: A bill requiring the music industry to label records with questionable lyrics, and not sell such records to minors, may not be constitutional, Gov. Buddy Roemer said. Roemer said he favors warning labels for recordings with themes of rape, murder, suicide, incest, illegal drug use, child abuse and satanic worship, but would prefer that the industry adopt a voluntary program. The governor said he did not know whether he would sign the measure, which also bans the sale of labeled records to minors. Although the labeling bill passed both chambers of the Legislature with more than the two-thirds vote needed to override a veto, the legislative session ended Monday night and a veto would kill it until the next session, which begins in April. Roemer has 20 days to decide on the bill after it reaches his desk. Roemer told a news conference Monday that serious legal questions about the bill's constitutionality had to be balanced against concerns about the content of some recordings. Most of the industry was acting responsibly, but ``some portions of the industry produce pure trash,'' he said. ``Parents don't know that until they are brought home and played.'' Roemer said he preferred a voluntary program, similar to the ratings system adopted by the movie industry. ``We'll all be better off,'' he said. Under the legislation, record manufacturers would be required to label recordings with objectionable lyrics. Retailers would be subject to misdemeanor criminal penalties for selling labeled recordings to those under 17. In May, the recording industry unveiled a voluntary labeling system aimed at halting state campaigns for mandatory labeling. Industry spokesmen said every legislature except Louisiana's pulled back their bills while the voluntary program was tested. The voluntary program went into effect this month, and labeled recordings already are showing up in stores, said Mike Cutshaw, an attorney representing the National Association of Recording Merchandisers. Last week, Capitol Records promised to provide legal help to store operators who are threatened with arrest for selling its recordings that bear labels warning consumers of sexually explicit lyrics. The producers of the Grammy Awards show have said such a law would scuttle Louisiana's chances of playing host to the event. Also, backers of a proposed Grammy Hall of Fame in New Orleans say the law would end their project and cost the city $100 million a year. The legislation would not take effect until 1992. Rep. Ted Haik, the bill's sponsor, has said that if the industry implements its voluntary program, he would push for repeal of the law.

DOC.HEAD: British Publisher Forced to Put Shares on Market
DOC.TEXT: British publisher Robert Maxwell has been forced to put his stake in Bell Group Ltd. back on the market under terms of an out-of-court settlement with the National Companies and Securities Commission. The Federal Court on Tuesday ratified the order to dispose of the 14.9 percent holding in the group, declaring Bell director David Aspinall was in breach of takeover regulations when he originally acquired the shares. Australian financier Robert Holmes a Court is believed to be among potential bidders interested in the parcel of more than 54 million shares in the group, which owns the West Australian newspaper. The stock will be tendered at a confidential reserve price. If a buyer cannot be found at or above the price agreed with the NCSC, then the shares will be returned to Maxwell. Commission officials alleged Aspinall had breached the takeover code in his original purchase of a 16.57 percent Bell holding because he was deemed to be an associate of the company's 74.5 percent parent, Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd. The order to put the shares back on the market resulted from an out-of-court settlement Tuesday among the NCSC, Aspinall and Maxwell.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Compromise Hinted at Houston Summit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops 7 grafs new including Hurd comments, Hills and Andriessen meeting; picks up pvs 4th graf bgng, The Bush; SUBS pvs 8th graf bgng, ``The president, to make 2nd reference to Carla Hills. This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Prodded by British officials, economic summit negotiators renewed efforts today to resolve differences over President Bush's proposal to abolish billions of dollars in foreign farm subsidies. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills was meeting later in the day with Frans Andriessen, the top trade negotiator for the European Community, to discuss ways to break their stalemate over the farm subsidy question. Afterwards, aides to summit leaders were expected to meet late into the night in their search for a trade compromise to include in the final summit communique that will be issued Wednesday. British officials urged compromise. Britain is a member of the European Community but doesn't have as big a stake in the subsidy issue because it has fewer and smaller farms than their summit partners. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd warned today that failure to reach agreement could be extremely damaging to long-term global prosperity. ``This negotiation will not succeed unless we are all prepared to go for a compromise,'' he said in a BBC interview. While fights over the arcane language of trade agreements usually are left to subordinates to settle, this dispute has attracted the attention of the leaders of seven major industrial democracies because of the huge stakes involved. The Bush administration believes that the United States' best hope of resolving its $100 billion trade imbalance is to expand export opportunities for U.S. farmers and businesses by liberalizing the rules governing world trade. Freer global trade also holds out the promise of providing an economic lifeline for struggling new democracies in Eastern Europe and Latin America by expanding the markets for their goods. But it is far from clear whether the trade talks, known as the Uruguay Round for the country where they began in 1986, will succeed, given entrenched positions in such areas as agriculture. The talks are being conducted by the 97-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world body that governs trade. Before coming to Houston, Bush said that without fundamental reform in agriculture, the United States would walk away from the Uruguay Round. Bush aides said Monday that the president has been taking a tough line in Houston in his discussions with summit colleagues. ``The president has been doing a very good job to indicate why agriculture is the lynchpin to these negotiations,'' Ms. Hills said. Bush brought up the trade negotiations in a string of one-on-one sessions with world leaders and then devoted a part of the first formal session Monday to talking about agriculture. Bush is ``making the point very forcefully to his summit partners that this is an enormously important activity,'' Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter told reporters, calling Bush's discussions a ``motivating session'' to get the Europeans engaged. In discussions with Jacques Delores, president of the European Community's executive body, Bush took a tough stance, telling Delors that the political leaders needed to exhibit political courage to resolve the issue, an EC official said. ``It was tough. It was frank,'' the official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Bush also discussed the farm dispute in separate meetings with French President Francois Mitterrand and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, the two European leaders with the strongest opposition to total elimination of farm subsidies. Kohl, however, indicated that in his discussions he believed a compromise proposal on the agricultural issue represented a good starting point to trying to resolve the issue. The document, drawn up by Aart de Zeeuw, a former Dutch official who is chairing the agricultural negotiations, strikes a middle-ground between the defensive EC position and the aggressive U.S. stance. In the summit's opening session, Kohl told the other leaders that there was a critical need to insure a successful conclusion of the trade talks, being held under the auspices of the 97-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. He told the leaders that the summit needed to ``give the negotiators ... a positive signal and a political orientation that we all jointly stand for strengthening the GATT.'' Yeutter said Kohl's stance was ``mildly encouraging'' with other officials suggesting that it could represent a breakthrough if other European nations follow West Germany's lead. Hills told reporters that the United States hoped to achieve a commitment from the summit countries to use the de Zeeuw paper as the basis for working out a final agreement on agriculture. In addition to phasing out farm subsidies, the United States has an ambitious goal of expanding global trade rules to include about $1 trillion in trade not now covered by the GATT The U.S. proposal would result in the elimination of barriers to trade in the high-growth area of banking and other services, where U.S. companies are extremely competitive. American negotiators are also pushing to extend GATT rules to cover better enforcement of trade and copyright piracy, which is estimated to cost American companies $60 billion in lost sales each year. Agriculture is seen as the key to the whole U.S. package because Third World countries have balked at agreeing to the proposals on expanding GATT coverage unless they win expanded markets for their farm products.

DOC.HEAD: Government Plans Retrial in Commodity Fraud Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, ``It is... to CORRECT total number of counts on which verdicts were reached to 30 sted 10; picks up 4th graf, The panel... SUBS 6th graf, The jury... to CORRECT number of counts against Mosky on which jury was deadlocked to 55; picks up 7th graf, Independent trader...
DOC.TEXT: After a partial verdict in the first trial stemming from an FBI commodity sting operation, the government plans to try again to prove that three traders conspired to cheat customers. In addition to a racketeering charge that stumped a U.S. District Court jury, prosecutors also plan to refile scores of fraud charges against the defendants. ``It is our intention at this point to go forward with the remaining charges,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Mark Pollack said after the jury ended 11 days of deliberations by returning verdicts on only 30 of 116 counts. The panel convicted two traders on commodity fraud charges and acquitted a third. U.S. District Judge Ann C. Williams, who presided over the nearly two months of proceedings, declared a mistrial on the counts the jury didn't resolve. Robert D. Mosky, 34, a floor broker portrayed by prosecutors as the leader of a fraud scheme in the Merc's Swiss franc futures pit, was found guilty of seven counts of Commodity Exchange Act fraud, the least serious charges against him. The jury acquitted him of 20 commodity, mail and wire fraud charges and deadlocked on 55 other counts, including a racketeering charge. Independent trader Danny L. Scheck, 28, was convicted of one count of commodity fraud. The jury could not reach a verdict on 19 other counts against Scheck. David Zatz, 43, another independent trader in the Swiss franc pit, was acquitted on two commodity fraud counts. The jury could not decide 12 other counts against Zatz. Each commodity fraud count carries a maximum prison sentence of five years and a $100,000 fine, prosecutors said. The men were the first group of commodities traders to stand trial on charges resulting from a continuing FBI probe of corruption at the Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade, the world's biggest commodity futures markets. Two other groups _ 13 soybean traders from the Board of Trade and 15 Japanese yen traders from the Merc _ go on trial in September. Assistant U.S. Attorney James Fleissner is not working on those cases but said their structure probably would be similar. ``We have certain kinds of evidence. The agent will testify about what he saw. The people who are testifying as cooperators will testify about what they saw. We will play tapes,'' he said. In all, 48 people have been indicted since last August. Sixteen have pleaded guilty to reduced charges, including two Swiss franc traders who testified against Mosky, Scheck and Zatz. U.S. Attorney Ira Raphaelson, asked how Monday's verdict might affect the trials of other indicted traders, said, ``It doesn't mean anything.'' But defense lawyers said the partial victory was a serious blow to the government's investigation. Mosky's lawyer, Elliott Samuels, had argued during the trial that the prosecution represented an ``overzealous'' and ``outrageous'' government attempt to enforce vague trading regulations arbitrarily. ``I'd like to think the jury was disturbed about the government's theory,'' Samuels said after the verdicts were announced. Alan Blumenthal said that as far as his client, Zatz, was concerned, the government didn't convince the jury any laws had been broken. ``They were presented comprehensive evidence, and there was no finding of proof,'' Blumenthal said. ``As it stands right now, my client is innocent.'' The Chicago Merc's board of governors will discuss what action, if any, to take against the convicted traders during a meeting Wednesday, said Merc spokesman Andrew Yemma. In the trial, which began May 8, the government contended the defendants conspired to cheat customers by changing the prices at which customer orders were executed or through pre-arranged and off-market trades that prevented the orders from being offered in the open, competitive market. A futures contract is an agreement to buy or sell a commodity _ in this case a quantity of Swiss francs _ at a price agreed upon in advance. Prosecutors said Mosky used the stolen customer profits _ sometimes as small as $12.50 per trade _ to pad his own account and to repay Scheck and Zatz for illegally accepting the financial liability for his trading errors. Defense lawyers argued their clients had done no wrong. They contended the government's star witness, undercover FBI agent Randall Jannett, was so ill-prepared for his role as a trader that in the seeming chaos of the trading pit he mistook the defendants' legitimate actions for improprieties.

Stock prices drifted lower today as the market looked for direction. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials stood at 2,908.17 at noon on Wall Street, down 5.94 from Monday's close. DOC.HEAD: Washington, Bonn Near Compromise on Environment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 6 grafs new with possible summit deal on environment; pickup pvs 3rd graf, Although.
DOC.TEXT: The United States and West Germany appeared headed today toward a summit agreement on environmental concerns that sought to obscure their sharp differences over global warming. Negotiators from Washington and Bonn sought to strike a conciliatory deal stressing a united front on protecting tropical rain forests and playing down their dispute over what should be done about pollutants that contribute to warming of the Earth's climate, summit sources said. Details of the forest protection accord were unavailable in advance of an afternoon session of the seven-nation economic summit dealing with the environment. The agreement is to be included in the final summit communique that will be issued Wednesday. Word of the negotiating bid for harmony on the environmental issue emerged one day after West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and White House chief of staff John Sununu exchanged critical jabs over their countries' divergent approaches to global warming. Sununu accused the West Germans of being leaders in global warming rhetorics. Kohl took aim at President Bush's call for further study of the problem rather than hasty action that might cause needless economic damage. U.S. officials had gotten the impression in pre-summit talks that the Germans might take a flexible stance at the summit on their calls for specific goals for reducing emissions of carbon dioxide and other ``greenhouse gases'' blamed for an increase in the Earth's temperatures. Although environmental policy was not scheduled for summit discussion until this afternoon, the French and German leaders pointedly addressed it in their opening presentations on Monday. And East European environmentalists appealed to the summit leaders at a news conference to help their countries clean up. ``In the past, money was pumped into the government without economic or environmental concern,'' said Zbigniew Bochniarz, a member of the Polish Ecology Club. ``Now we must create a new approach and build conditions that will modernize outdated pollution standards.'' Kohl said in his opening session pitch that ``decisive measures are needed to reduce the greenhouse effect,'' a term referring to the gradually warming climates around the world. ``A lack of scientific knowledge about the causes and effect cannot justify slowing down the taking of concrete measures,'' Kohl told his colleagues at the summit. The statement was clearly aimed at Bush, who contends that more study is needed on global warming before taking dramatic steps urged by Germany and other Europeans to cut the carbon dioxide emissions from burning of fossil fuels, said to be the principal cause of global warming. Kohl said, however, that ``what is foremost required is drastic reduction of carbon dioxide emissions ...'' The Houston summit should give ``a clear and concrete signal for the effective protection of mankind and environment,'' Kohl said. French President Francois Mitterrand joined Kohl in calling for specific steps, according to his spokesman Hubert Vedrine. Mitterrand said the summit leaders should not be satisfied with simply a general declaration on the environment. ``There should be specific commitments to reduce pollution and save forests,'' the spokesman quoted Mitterrand as saying. Earlier, Sununu was asked about an environmental group's scorecard which rated West Germany much higher than the United States regarding steps to protect the environment. Sununu replied that ``West Germany got a lot of good grades for rhetoric.'' ``If you take a good look at what the United States has actually done in terms of cleaning up our environment ... I don't think the United States has to take a back seat to anyone,'' he said. Sununu and others in the administration contend that committing to carbon dioxide reduction goals would devastate the U.S. economy because of the heavy dependence on fossil fuels. He told a news conference that the administration is concerned that specific reduction targets amount to a ``perpetual stabilization,'' and that ``continued economic growth ... requires that you continue to use energy, and that any growth at all then would not be permitted.'' The Germans have led the way in Europe by pledging to cut carbon dioxide releases by 25 percent by the year 2005.

DOC.NOTE: $adv12
For Release AMs Thursday, July 12
DOC.HEAD: Turning Up The Heat On Bush
DOC.TEXT: Who said: ``There is no quicker way to kill prosperity than to raise taxes?'' Perhaps a clue would help. He's the person who also said, ``When the government raises a dollar in revenues, Congress spends a dollar fifty.'' And who said, ``The surest way to kill the recovery is to raise taxes.'' George Bush isn't being let off easily by those who thought they had read ``no new taxes'' on his lips. Economist Daniel Mitchell, for example, reminds us that Bush is the author of all three quotes. Mitchell is a fellow of the Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank whose ideas have been listened to by officials in both the Reagan and Bush administrations. Mitchell's words suggest his fury. To wit: ``If George Bush had pardoned Willie Horton, or burned Old Glory on the lawn of the White House, it would hardly have rivaled the flip-flop committed on taxes.'' To him, ``The battle over taxes is a battle not only for the economy; it is a battle for the integrity and character of the Bush presidency.'' Only slightly less upset were David Makarechian and Bryan Riley of Citizens for a Sound Economy, who followed Bush's explanation for his apparent change of mind _ the need to reduce the deficit _ with an explanation of their own. ``President Bush's June 26 announcement that tax revenue increases must be included as part of the deficit reduction package now being negotiated in the budget summit is superfluous,'' they stated. No qualifications, whatever. The sole purpose for including tax increases in a deficit reduction package, they said, ``is to allow faster spending growth than if the government relied upon spending restraints alone.'' The Wall Street Journal observed that it was impossible to determine which of several ``wacko tax proposals'' are likely to be enacted, and suggested President Bush was losing control of his own economic policy. ``The last time a national leader lost control of economic policy,'' it said in an apparent reference to former President Carter, ``we suffered a malaise not suffered in this country for more than a decade.'' The Journal seemed especially upset at what seems to be a contradiction in regard to stock transactions: a cut in the capital gains tax rate on stocks that are sold after having risen in value, but a new tax on stock transfers. The Bush administration has not formally proposed the latter, but rumors have circulated that it is considering doing so. It prompted the Journal to comment that ``we are tempted to dismiss this proposal as patently absurd, except that with lip reading out of style we can take nothing for granted.'' The intensity of feeling is noteworthy because most of it comes from those who have endorsed the President's reluctance to add to the tax bill, and most seem to offer the same rationale, that new taxes simply mean new spending. At the same time, the President's stance is not a surprise to them. Two weeks before the President's comment about tax revenues increases, the Tax Foundation, a private research organization, issued this comment: ``Only 10 of the last 62 budgets paid their own way without deficit spending, and in none of the last 21 years has the budget been balanced. ``Unfortunately, by the light of recent budget summit history, any deficit reduction deal could be a bad deal for taxpayers.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv AMs Thursday, July 12.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Close Lower

DOC.TEXT: Stock prices closed lower on London's Stock Exchange Tuesday, after a disappointing performance on Wall Street. British stocks spent the whole session in negative territory. ``We were looking for a rise in Wall Street but it didn't happen,'' one trader said. The day's main feature was sterling's continued strength, which caused a number of British stocks with heavy overseas earnings to be downgraded by analysts, dragging the entire market lower. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed down 10 points, or 0.4 percent, at 2,327.5. Its high was a drop of 4.3 points, its low a loss of 14.4 points. DOC.HEAD: Five Gulf OPEC Ministers Consult Ahead of July 25 Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia Oil Minister Hisham Nazer held a meeting for four of his OPEC counterparts on Tuesday to discuss ways to ease the oil price slump in preparation for the cartel's July 25 session. The gathering followed instructions from King Fahd to work for the success of the meeting that will be held in Geneva at the end of the month, according to statements issued after the weekly cabinet session. Present with Nazer in the Saudi summer capital of Jiddah were Rashid al-Ameeri of Kuwait, Mana Saeed Otaiba of the United Arab Emirates, Sheik Abdullah bin Khalifa Al Thani of Qatar and Issam al-Chalabi of Iraq. The 13-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has not been able to maintain a lid on the output of member states within the 21.086 million barrel per day aggregate ceiling, and the glut has been pushing prices down, threatening an oil price crash similar to the one that occurred in 1986. The Geneva meeting will provide a forum to discuss future production and pricing strategy. Reports have indicated the meeting may be devoted only to the next three months and then be reconvened in September. The main culprits for the overproduction are Kuwait and the U.A.E. Iraq has been leading the pressure on both its Gulf neighbors to conform to the production levels. Iraq also rejects demands by Kuwait and the U.A.E. to have their OPEC-decreed production ceilings increased. Saudi Arabia, the dominant party within the cartel, is reported to be keen to preserve the current ceiling because of its static defense for the OPEC reference price of $18 a barrel. Saudi Arabia also is pledged to demand a barrel for a barrel in case quota levels are increased, insisting its share of OPEC production ceilings must be 24.45 percent in line with its huge reserves. Nazer's meeting with his four counterparts was preceded by a tour he made of each of their capitals to deliver letters to respective leaders from King Fahd. Nazer has also conferred with the OPEC chief Sadek Boussena, who was recently on a tour of the Gulf OPEC states and demanded they adhere to their production quota levels.

DOC.HEAD: Pound Surges On Speculation That Britain Will Join Mechanism
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be updated with late rate by 1700 GMT.
DOC.HEAD: Graphic
DOC.TEXT: The pound surged to an 18-month high Tuesday on continuing speculation that Britain would soon join Europe's currency-steadying exchange rate mechanism. The British government is trying to talk up sterling to fight inflation and bring the currency into the mechanism at a high level, analysts said. The exchange rate mechanism, known as ERM, is built into the European Monetary System and limits the fluctuations of nine of the 12 European Community currencies. Britain, Portugal and Greece are the outsiders. Joining the mechanism would reduce sterling's volatility and help curb inflation, the system's proponents say. The pound, which moved higher during the day, finished at $1.8155 in Europe late Tuesday, up 1 cent from late Monday. That was the pound's highest level since it finished at $1.8270 on Jan. 3, 1989. Buying was extremely heavy, dealers said. ``There has been a lot of good solid investment demand for sterling,'' said Geoffrey Dennis, an economist at the London investment firm James Capel and Co. The pound has gained 21.5 cents, or 13 percent, since mid-March, when it fetched $1.6005. It also has risen strongly against the German mark and the Japanese yen. Analysts predicted sterling's four-month climb is likely to continue. ``The pound has quite a lot of room on the upside, especially against the dollar,'' said Paul Chertkow, chief currency strategist at Citibank in London. Dennis said the pound could fetch as much as $1.87 in coming weeks. Chertkow expects it to reach $1.90 within three months. The pound also has been sustained by Britain's 15 percent interest rates, which are nearly double West Germany's and are designed to fight inflation, now running at 9.7 percent. Speculation about entry into the ERM ``has gotten more and more intense,'' Dennis said. ``In a series of comments, statements, speeches, announcements, the government gradually has drip-fed the market information to encourage them to believe that sterling is going to join.'' ``They have talked up the pound specifically to get it at a certain level at which they would like to join,'' he continued. ``It takes away the downside for sterling.'' The pound got an added boost from Britain's top Treasury official, Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major, who said Monday that the pound's climb was sustainable and that no interest rate cuts were planned. Inflation must improve before interest rates come down, Major told reporters at the Group of Seven meeting of major industrialized nations in Houston. He reiterated that Britain wouldn't join the mechanism until Britain's inflation is more in line with the European Community's. That is the major outstanding condition outlined by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who has committed Britain to joining but has not set a timetable. Analysts expect Mrs. Thatcher to link the pound to the ERM in the autumn, well before the next general election, which must be called by mid-1992 but could come in a year. The government says that excluding mortgage rates, inflation is 7 percent and closer to the EC's average of 5 percent. The government is believed to want to enter the mechanism with a strong pound so that Britain can cut interest rates before voters go to the polls. A stronger pound in effect adds up to tighter monetary policy. It fights inflation by making it difficult for companies to grant wage increases and forcing them to keep down costs to retain export markets. But a strong pound increases pressure on companies already struggling with high interest rates, stock traders said. British stocks have fallen in recent days amid concern that the pound's rise would hurt British exports and corporate profits.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Property Rights in Organ Research
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS last graf with response from doctor's attorney. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The state Supreme Court ruled that patients have no right to share in profits if their blood or organs become the source of lucrative scientific research. In a major victory for the U.S. biotechnology industry, the court said that John Moore, a leukemia victim whose spleen was removed for medical reasons, could not sue researchers and commercial laboratories on the claim that his personal property was being misused. He did, however, win limited rights to sue on more narrow grounds. The 5-2 decision Monday said that researchers used the victim's spleen without his knowledge to develop a blood protein with multibillion-dollar medical potential. Allowing such a suit ``threatens to destroy the economic incentive to conduct important medical research,'' said the opinion by Justice Edward Panelli. The multibillion-dollar industry relies heavily on a plentiful supply of human cell lines, thousands of which exist in tissue repositories throughout the country. The court unanimously allowed Moore, of Seattle, to maintain his suit on a more limited basis, a claim that the doctor who removed his spleen and later withdrew blood samples over several years had failed to disclose his personal interests before getting Moore's consent to the procedures. That part of the ruling should encourage a more open doctor-patient relationship in the future, said Cynthia Fruchtman, a Los Angeles lawyer and expert in genetic engineering. ``It's going to facilitate a dialogue between participants in research and researchers themselves, so that the public knows what's going on,'' said Fruchtman. After Moore's suit was filed, she said, some research hospitals changed their consent forms to specify that tissues removed may be used in research. ``If nothing else, it allows the patient to ask questions about what's going on,'' Fruchtman said. ``One of John Moore's complaints, as I understand his suit, was that he wasn't given that information and the opportunity to ask those questions.'' The disadvantages to Moore in such a suit are that he cannot sue the laboratories, unless he can show that they were involved in the failure to disclose facts, and that under normal legal rules he could recover damages only for whatever losses he suffered, without sharing in any profits. ``It would appear that a justifiable sigh of relief should go up from the scientific community,'' said Richard D. Godown, president of the Industrial Biotechnology Association, a trade group of 107 companies. A defendant in the case, Sandoz Pharmaceuticals Corp., had warned in papers filed with the court that ``the field of biomedical research will be plunged into a state of chaos for years'' if the court allowed a suit for ``conversion,'' or use of Moore's property without his consent. However, Moore's lawyer, Sanford Gage, said the limited claim allowed by the court could still include a share of the profits. A doctor who operated on Moore without proper consent, and companies that knowingly took part in non-disclosures over the following years, could be required to ``disgorge ill-gotten gains,'' Gage said. He said he considered the limited decision a victory because ``this allows us to proceed and it does protect patient rights.'' Moore was a 31-year-old Alaska pipeline surveyor in 1976 when he sought treatment for a type of leukemia called hairy-cell leukemia at the University of California, Los Angeles. Dr. David Golde removed Moore's spleen, a standard treatment, and the disease has not recurred. While testing the removed spleen, Golde discovered it contained unique blood cells that produced a blood protein called GM-CSF, which is now in experimental use as a drug to stimulate the immune system to fight certain cancers and possibly AIDS. For nearly seven years, Moore's suit said, Golde and others brought Moore from Seattle to Los Angeles for blood tests and other procedures _ never telling him of his cells' value _ while they developed Moore's cells into a self-perpetuating cell line to mass-produce GM-CSF. The Regents of the University of California patented the cell line in 1984, naming Golde and a research assistant, Shirley Quan, as the inventors. The same year, Moore sued Golde, Quan, the UC Regents and the two companies working on the product, Sandoz and Genetics Institute Inc. The suit estimated the potential value of the product as $3 billion. It said Golde and others had gotten $3 million worth of Genetics Institute stock. Golde's lawyer, Donn Dimichele, said today that he was pleased that the court had rejected Moore's main claim but uncertain about the effect of the section that would allow suits for failure to disclose a researcher's interests.

DOC.HEAD: Girard May Renew Proxy Battle for Pic 'N' Save if No Buyer Emerges
DOC.TEXT: The investment group Girard Partners L.P. reiterated its plans to start a proxy fight for control of Pic 'N' Save Corp. if the close-out chain is unable to find a buyer by Sunday. In a filing Monday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Girard gave no assurance it will bid for Pic 'N' Save. Analysts estimate Pic 'N' Save, based in the Los Angeles suburb of Dominguez, is worth up to $16 per share, or $560 million. Girard, headed by investor David H. Batchelder, said it needs additional equity beyond the $18 million its partners have committed, as well as debt financing, if it is to buy Pic 'N' Save. La Jolla-based Girard previously threatened a proxy fight, but Batchelder and Pic 'N' Save agreed in June to wait until July 15 so that the company's management could review buyout proposals.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Investments Helping South, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: Japanese investments could prove a bonanza for southern states in terms of jobs, tax revenues and business know-how, according to a new study. Japanese investment is a means by which the South can replace jobs lost through import competition, said the report released Monday. Transplant companies also have had some positive effects on U.S. firms, pushing them to match or exceed foreign standards of excellence, says the study from the Southern Growth Policies Board, a public, interstate agency that examines economic issues facing the South. The Japanese rank second to the British among foreign investors in the United States, according to 1988 figures compiled in the report. Japanese-owned assets totaled $450 billion, representing about 1.7 percent of all U.S. assets. Japan was only the seventh largest foreign investor in 1980, the authors noted. If present trends continue through the 1990s, Japan will likely supplant the British as the largest foreign investor. Japanese companies differ from their competitors, the report said. They invest more heavily in training and retraining employees, allow for more decision-making at the point of production and tend to use more highly automated machinery. On the minus side, Japanese plants create fewer jobs than would might because they tend to be highly automated, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Domino's Signs One-Year Test for Pizza in Four Burger Kings
DOC.TEXT: You won't be able to have it your way just yet, but this September Burger King will begin test marketing 6-inch Domino's pizzas at four South Carolina hamburger restaurants. The one-year experiment is aimed at McDonald's Corp.'s test of its own pizza in 200 of its eateries. A licensing agreement was signed last week between Burger King, the nation's second largest fast-food chain, and Domino's newly created Pizzazz Division. It calls for test marketing at four restaurants in Columbia, S.C., Domino's spokesman Burke Cueny said Tuesday. Cueny said toppings for the pizzas have yet to be determined and the four stores will offer two or three kinds of pies at the start. ``There may be a point where we will offer larger-style pizzas down the road,'' he said. There are 22 Burger King outlets in the Columbia area, which is home of the University of South Carolina. McDonald's, the nation's largest fast-food chain, currently sells 14-inch pizzas in about 200 restaurants located in and around Evansville, Ind., Las Vegas, Hartford, Conn., and Fresno, Calif., said company spokesman Chuck Ebeling. ``The test is going very well and we think the future of that product looks bright,'' he said. Ebeling refused to say when McDonald's would decide whether to expand the program. McDonald's pizzas, which the company makes itself, come with cheese, sausage, pepperoni or a combination of those toppings. They cost between $6 and $10, depending on toppings and markets, Ebeling said. Burger King, bought last year by Grand Metropolitan PLC, has about 6,000 stores nationwide. Domino's, which owner Tom Monaghan has said is up for sale, has about 5,000 kitchen and delivery outlets, and is the largest pizza delivery company in the nation. ``Whether the company is being sold or not, we're making some good long-term decisions,'' said Pizzazz Vice President Glenn Mueller. ``(Domino's President) Dave Black and the management at Domino's Pizza is getting back to growth. They're trying new and innovative ways.'' Domino's hopes Pizzazz will add 1,000 new outlets and $500 million in annual sales by 1993. Some of Domino's Pizzazz stores will have tables and chairs, some will be drive-through and others may offer carryout services.
