DOC.TEXT: Dow Jones & Co. Inc. said Tuesday its second-quarter profit skidded 27.9 percent because of costs related to its acquisition of Telerate Inc. and weakness in the market for information services. The company, which publishes the Wall Street Journal and Barron's magazine, said it earned $34.9 million, or 3itution will be seized by the government. Agency officials plan to test the program with 10 institutions over the next two or three months. After that, they estimate that 155 to 180 of the 260 S&L failures expected in the next year could be handled in the accelerated program. Private analysts are cautiously endorsing the strategy, although they note that the RTC has yet to deal with nearly 250 institutions that failed previously. It has handled more than 200 failed thrifts in its first 11 months. ``I think, in principal, it's a good idea. The only question is whether they are so overloaded now with all the clearly insolvent institutions,'' said Robert Litan of the Brookings Institution, a liberal research group in Washington. ``You're going to be using scarce resources for (marginally insolvent) thrifts ahead of other institutions that are clearly in much worse shape,'' he said. However, Litan said taxpayers might save money by bailing out an institution on the edge of insolvency, when its owners may be most tempted to gamble. A deeply insolvent S&L under government control often is not in danger of further deterioration, he said. ``If you're in the government, the thing to do is not to focus on past losses but to focus on how to prevent future losses from occurring,'' he said. Economist James Barth of Auburn University said the program might be a better way of handling the loans, real estate and other assets of a failed thrift. In the conventional S&L bailouts so far, the government has been stuck with about half of the assets, which it hopes to sell later. Officials hope in accelerated resolution deals, the new owner rather than the government will get most of the assets. ``The RTC has so many assets it has to try new and different things to get those assets back into the private sector,'' Barth said. ``If they're not careful, they're going to wind up with the worlds' largest troubled savings and loan and its going to be called the Resolution Trust Corp.''

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Finish Higher
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures ended higher in active trading Tuesday, led by another sharp gain in unleaded gasoline prices. Traders said seasonal demands and concerns about supplies were largely responsible for gasoline's surge, which helped boost other petroleum products. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the August contract for wholesale unleaded gasoline settled up 1.01 cents to 57.86 cents a gallon, following a 1.44-cent advance on Monday. Other contract months also rose in price. The contract for August delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude oil, rose 36 cents to $16.94 a 42-gallon barrel. The contracts for delivery through November also settled higher. Among other refined products traded on the Merc, August home heating oil, which gained 0.60 cent on Monday, settled at 49.28 cents a gallon, up 0.38 cent. In natural gas trading, the August contract rose to $1.500 per 1,000 cubic feet from $1.493 on Monday. Peter Beutel, a trader with Merril Lynch Energy Futures, said some dealers were concerned that last week's explosion at an Arco Chemical Co. plant near Houston might effect gasoline supplies at a time when demand is high. Arco was a major producer of methyl tertiary butyl ether, a high-octane blending component used instead of lead in gasoline. ``Refiners may have to refine more crude oil to get the same amount of octane,'' Beutel said. Also lifting energy futures Tuesday was speculation that the latest American Petroleum Institute report, due out after the market closed Tuesday, would show a drop in crude oil stocks, traders said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-S&L Bailout, Bjt
Government Sells $5 Billion in 30-Year Bonds for S&L Bailout
DOC.TEXT: The government sold $5 billion of 30-year bonds Tuesday to help finance its bailout of the savings and loan industry. The bonds were sold at an average yield of 8.93 percent and will carry a coupon interest rate of 8~ percent, with a $10,000 bond selling for $9,942.70. The Resolution Funding Corp., or Refcorp, received bids totaling $15.5 billion. In two previous auctions this year, Refcorp received bids totaling $8.90 billion for a $3.5 billion issue last April and $8.17 billion in bids for $5 billion last January. Both earlier auctions involved 40-year bonds, marking the first time in 35 years the government had sold paper of more than 30 years' maturity. The April bonds were sold at an average yield of 8.89 percent, up from 8.60 percent at the January auction. Refcorp's first auction last October sold $4.5 billion in 30-year bonds with an average yield of 8.15 percent. The agency thus has sold $18.5 billion. Legislation last August authorized the government to borrow $30 billion through Refcorp, an arrangement that keeps the spending out of the federal budget deficit.

DOC.HEAD: Study Shows Continuing Decline In Union Membership In Manufacturing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs, Grant Thornton... to DELETE extraneous word `and' in name of study. Picks up 6th graf, The study's...
DOC.TEXT: Membership in labor unions that represent workers in manufacturing registered its biggest drop in three years in 1989, according to a forthcoming report by the Grant Thornton consulting firm. The reason: greater demand for high-tech workers. ``There are fewer unions in the high-tech area, and those that are are not organizing as effectively,'' said Selwin Price, a partner at Grant Thornton. High-tech workers ``are better educated, higher skilled, and management might keep them happier.'' He divided manufacturing into two categories: ``low-tech,'' such as the steel, automobile and garment industries; and high-tech, such as computers. Grant Thornton is a Chicago-based accounting and management consulting firm. Its statistics on unions are contained in its annual Manufacturing Climates Study to be released Aug. 16. Price is in charge of the study. The study's figures show labor union membership in manufacturing fell by 153,000 workers last year. That represents a 3.2 percent drop from union membership of 4.771 million in 1988 and the largest yearly decline since 1986. That year there was a decline of 199,500 card-carrying industrial workers, a 3.8 percent drop. By contrast, total manufacturing jobs showed a slight increase at the same time, rising 1.0 percent in 1989 and 2.3 percent over the past three years, the firm said. Grant Thornton has been following union membership in manufacturing jobs since 1984, when 27.26 percent of all workers in industrial occupations belonged to unions. In 1989 that number was down to 23.84 percent. Michigan was the only state last year where more than half, 51.7 percent, of manufacturing workers belonged to unions. New York was second, with 47.23 percent. Florida was the only state to register an increase, adding 700 union members, the study found. States with the lowest percentage of union membership were South Dakota, 2.34 percent; South Carolina, 2.95 percent; and Arizona, 3.69 percent. Figures for the study were based on average, annual full-time dues-paying members and gathered from financial reports that unions filed with the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. ``It surely does not portend good for unionism, because we've seen a decline every year, Price said. ``This decline has caused unions to realize their future could be in jeopardy,'' he said. ``On the other hand, maybe if there were no unions, maybe the companies wouldn't have the incentive to treat their employees so well.'' Rex Hardesty, an AFL-CIO spokesman in Washington, agreed with some of Price's conclusions. For one, high-tech workers are harder to organize into unions, he said. ``There's no strong union tradition'' in high-tech, Hardesty said. In addition, he said, many of those jobs are in the South, where resistance to union organizing is strong. But he also said many former industrial workers now earn their living in the service industry or in occupations that have no union. ``We have twice as many former union members as we have union members. (A former line worker is) now a cement finisher with his brother-in-law or putting on seat covers,'' Hardesty said, ``and that represents a shift from manufacturing, mining, and construction and railroads into the service industry.'' Hardesty noted that when the AFL-CIO was formed 35 years ago, 58 percent of Americans made their living in manufacturing, mining and construction. Today that proportion is 25 percent, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls As British Pound Continues To Surge; Gold Slides
DOC.TEXT: The pound took center stage in foreign exchange trading Tuesday, sending the dollar to an 18th-month low against the British currency. Gold prices, meanwhile, fell sharply on reports of heavy Middle East selling. ``The British pound is the whole story,'' said Robert Ryan, chief foreign exchange dealer with Bank of New York Co., summing up the day. Sterling's rise came amid continuing speculation that Britain will soon join Western Europe's currency-steadying exchange rate mechanism, known as the ERM. Built into the European Monetary System, the ERM limits the fluctuations of nine of the 12 European Economic community countries. Britain, Greece and Portugal are the three countries still outside the system. In London, the pound rose by 1 cent from Monday to $1.8155 _ its highest rate against the dollar since Jan. 3, 1989, when it reached $1.8270. At its peak Tuesday, the pound reached $1.8270 and buying was extremely heavy, dealers said. In later New York trading, sterling also advanced sharply, rising to $1.8220 from $1.8080 late Monday. The dollar also fell sharply against the Japanese yen. The yen rose after a Washington-based advisory firm, Smick Medley International, predicted the Bank of Japan will raise interest rates during the next few months. Foreign exchange dealers said that forecast, on the back of concern over the relative place of U.S. interest rates in the world market, forced down the dollar's exchange rate against the Japanese currency. The dollar plunged to 148.225 yen in New York from Monday's 151.15. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar dropped to 149.60 yen from 150.70 yen late Monday, and it was quoted lower in London at 148.85 yen. Ryan said the currencies of other countries with higher interest rates, including Australia and Canada, were also benefiting from their superior yields. The U.S. dollar slumped to 1.15695 Canadian dollars from 1.15855 late Monday. In Europe earlier, it fell to 1.1570 Canadian dollars from 1.1590. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's late prices, included: 1.64185 West German marks, down from 1.6528; 1.3930 Swiss francs, down from 1.3965; 5.51225 French francs, down from 5.5460; and 1,203.00 Italian lire, down from 1.21125. DOC.HEAD: Middle East Selling Gives Gold Market A Scare
DOC.TEXT: Signs of new Middle Eastern bullion sales triggered an early slide in gold futures prices Tuesday but the market partially recovered after traders learned the amount of physical gold sold was relatively small. On other commodity markets, energy futures advanced; sugar futures rallied; cotton slipped further; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mixed. Gold futures settled $2.70 to $3 lower on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in August at $357.10 a troy ounce. The lightly traded July contract finished at $355.50. Silver futures settled 1 cent to 1.4 cents higher with July at $4.811 a troy ounce. Gold prices plunged about $5 an ounce early in the session amid rumors of new bullion sales from the Middle East. The talk stirred fears that Saudi Arabia was again dumping large amounts of gold onto the market, as it is believed to have done on three occasions this year. The previous events prompted steep declines in gold prices, which were around $420 an ounce in mid-February. Peter Cardillo, director of commodity research with the futures brokerage Jesup, Josephthal & Co., said the Middle Eastern gold sales on Tuesday appeared to have originated in the Soviet Union, not Saudi Arabia, and the amount of gold offered for sale was relatively small. When fears of another huge Saudi sale were discounted, ``I think it took away the panic feeling,'' Cardillo said. Petroleum futures rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange after Saudi Arabia Oil Minister Hisham Nazer held a meeting for four of his OPEC counterparts to discuss ways to ease the oil price slump in preparation for the cartel's July 25 session. Crude oil futures also were supported by expectations that the American Petroleum Institute's weekly stocks report would show a drop in U.S. crude supplies of more than 3.5 million barrels. The report, which was issued after the close, showed a drop of 3.7 million barrels in the latest week. Gasoline stocks fell by a larger-than-expected 1.7 million barrels; supplies of distillates rose 2.6 million barrels, which was above market expectations. West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures settled 22 cents to 36 cents higher with August at $16.94 a barrel; heating oil was .15 cent to .55 cent higher with August at 49.28 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .30 cent to 1.01 cents higher with August at 57.86 cents a gallon. On the New York Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange, near-term sugar futures regained a portion of the ground lost Monday in a steep sell-off sparked by signs of increasing supplies. But sugar for delivery next May and beyond slipped slightly. Sugar ended .04 cent lower to .20 cent higher with October at 12.10 cents a pound. Near-term cotton futures fell sharply on the New York Cotton Exchange for the third straight day as profit-taking continued to erode the strong gains posted over the last six months. Cotton settled 1.91 cents lower to .63 cent higher with October at 74.83 cents a pound. Near-term pork belly futures fell sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, partly reflecting slack demand for bacon. Hog futures ended narrowly mixed while cattle futures were mostly lower amid profit-taking. Live cattle settled .08 cent to .28 cent lower with August at 74.07 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent lower to .05 cent higher with August at 85.27 cents a pound; hogs were .23 cent lower to .30 cent higher with July at 61.02 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.6 cents lower to 1 cent higher with July at 50.57 cents a pound. Grain and soybean futures prices closed mixed in lackluster trading on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat futures ended slightly lower amid selling linked to the advancing winter wheat harvest. Corn and soybean markets were narrowly mixed with near-term soybean futures supported by indications the Soviet Union recently bought up to 100,000 metric tons of U.S. soybean meal. Wheat futures settled } cent to 3{ cents lower with July at $3.05{ a bushel; corn futures were 1 cent lower to 2 cents higher with July at $2.82} a bushel; oats were { cent to 2 cents higher with July at $1.29 a bushel; soybeans were 1\ cents lower to 4 cents higher with July at $6.15} a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Second Quarter Results Up 10 Percent at Food, Real Estate Company
DOC.TEXT: Castle & Cooke Inc. said Tuesday its second quarter profits rose 10 percent, largely because of increased revenue in both of its divisions. The real estate and food company said it earned $38.9 million, or 66 cents per share, in the quarter ended June 16, compared with $35.2 million, 59 cents per share, in the same period in 1989. Revenue rose from $693 million to $792 million. Castle & Cooke credited rising home sales in Hawaii and higher banana prices at its Dole Food Co. unit for the gains. For the first six months of the year, earnings rose 19 percent from $47.7 million, or 80 cents per share, to $57 million, or 96 cents per share. Revenue rose 15 percent from $1.26 billion to $1.45 billion. David H. Murdock, chief executive and board chairman, also announced Tuesday that David A. DeLorenzo, a 20-year veteran with Dole, had been promoted to president of Dole, replacing Robert W. Fisher, who resigned last month. DeLorenzo previously was president of Dole Produce Co. DeLorenzo also will hold the title of executive vice president in the office of the chairman of Castle & Cooke. Castle & Cooke was forced in May to delay the planned spinoff of its Dole division to stockholders. The company said acceptable bank financing was not available. Murdock said then the company remained committed to a separation of the food and real estate operations.

DOC.HEAD: Textron Spins Off New Division
DOC.TEXT: Textron Inc. announced Tuesday it was splitting off a division of one of its subsidiaries into a new company to be called Textron Filtration Systems Inc. The company formerly was part of the parent firm's HR Textron subsidiary. B.F. Dolan, Textron chairman and chief executive officer, said the new company was created to reflect ``Textron's growing importance in advanced filtration products for aerospace and industrial markets.'' He said Textron officials hoped the new company would enable the management of both Textron Filtration and HR Textron to focus their energies on specific markets. Richard J. Millman will continue as president of HR Textron Inc., which is based in Valencia, Calif. Jan O. Johnson, currently vice president and general manager of filter operations of HR Textron, was appointed president of Textron Filtration Systems Inc. The ew company will be based in Newbury Park, Calif. Textron, the parent company, is a conglomerate based in Providence with operations primarily in aerospace technology, commercial products and financial services.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Use in Work Place on the Decline, Company Says
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Drug use in the workplace appears to be declining, a private company said in a report released Tuesday. SmithKline Beecham Clinical Laboratories said the number of workers and job applicants who tested positive had fallen from 18 percent to 13.8 percent in three years. Drug experts, however, said the figure remained too high. ``That's still three out of every 20 workers,'' said John Tysse, a Washington labor lawyer who specializes in cases involving drug use in the workplace. ``While a trend downward, if there is one, is encouraging, that still is an awfully high percentage,'' Tysse said. ``I would take little comfort from that that we've licked the drug problem.'' A spokesman for William Bennett, the president's drug policy director, called the results ``unacceptably high'' but still ``an indication of the positive turn on the war against drugs.'' Ben Banta said SmithKline's reported decline probably also indicates that drug testing is deterring Americans from using drugs before or during work. Harry Groome, president of SmithKline, said attention on drug use in the workplace appears to have led to a decline. SmithKline said that of the 1 million workers and job applicants it has tested in the first six months of 1990, 13.8 percent tested positive for drug use. Of a similar number tested during all of 1987, SmithKline found that 18.1 percent tested positive. In separate tests of about 65,000 workers in ``safety sensitive'' transportation jobs, 3.1 percent tested positive, the Philadelphia-area company said. The results reflect findings of tests conducted over the past six months since the federal government began requiring testing of airline and railroad employees, bus drivers and others in the transportation industry. About 4 million American transportation workers fall under the new requirements. SmithKline Beecham owns five of the 50 laboratories the federal government has certified to run tests on transportation workers. Transportation Department spokesman Bob Marx said the company's 3.1 percent finding ``appears high ... based on our own experience.'' Marx said random drug tests of agency employees in safety sensitive jobs found that less than 1 percent had tested positive. After medical review, about half of those who test positive are found to have legitimate reasons for testing positive for prescription drugs. SmithKline's figures did not include post-medical review figures. John Mazor, a spokesman for the 40,000-member Air Line Pilots Association, called the company's findings ``an interesting exercise ... there are a lot of limitations in their data.'' He noted that the company had not broken down transportation employees into pilots, air traffic controllers, mechanics and other jobs and predicted there would be widely varying drug use among job categories in the industry. The pilot's association has filed one of about 20 lawsuits challenging the federal government's drug testing requirements. According to SmithKline Beecham, workers in all industries _ those in transportation and in the general work force _ who tested positive were found most frequently to be using cocaine or marijuana, the company said. Of those testing positive in the transportation industry, 43.6 percent showed traces of marijuana, while 25.2 percent tested positive for cocaine. An additional 20 percent had used opiates such as morphine or codeine. In the overall work force of those who tested positive, 39 percent had used marijuana, 21.8 percent had traces of cocaine and 9.5 percent had traces of opiates. Transportation workers were tested for five illegal drugs _ marijuana, cocaine, amphetamines, opiates and phencyclidine, or PCP. Workers in the rest of the work force were also tested for several other drugs that are often abused, such as barbiturates, Valium and methadone.

DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts Plan Would Tax Everything but Kitchen Sink
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to DELETE reference to Muzak
DOC.TEXT: In its last-ditch effort to close a $1 billion budget gap, the Legislature has proposed taxing virtually everything but the kitchen sink. Taxpayers may be puzzled over some of the 594 new levies on services. Who, for instance, has ever seen a telephone booth cleaner? And how many trampoline operations are there? Some professional groups _ like lawyers _ lobbied hard against the sales tax expansion to their business. But fortune tellers and vendors of piped-in music, who would also be taxed, weren't much in evidence during the tax debate. David MacNeill, vice president of a company that sells background music to malls and supermarkets, said he is concerned about the tax. The waiting-room music industry, like everything else, is feeling the squeeze from Massachusetts' slumping economy. ``Things are tight. Everybody's hustling like hell to keep going,'' said MacNeill, of WCRB Sound System in Waltham. Stella Davis, a palm reader from Saugus, was surprised to learn she and her colleagues face a 5 percent sales tax on any fortunetelling bills that exceed $30. ``When you pay a tax and buy butter, you're getting something. This is just a reading. They're not taking anything home except just knowledge,'' Davis said. Davis said she is unlikely to pay the tax, since most of her readings cost $10. But Davis' remark reflects a potential problem with the sales tax _ a problem Gov. Michael S. Dukakis wants resolved before he will sign the tax bill, aimed at raising $1.3 billion in its first year. Under the Massachusetts Constitution, only commodities can be taxed. Opponents of expanding the sales tax say services don't fall under the definition of commodities. Dukakis has asked the state's highest court to rule on the matter before he signs the bill. The state culled the list of services to be taxed from a list of professions put out by the U.S. Census Bureau. ``The advantage of using it even though it seems silly when you list them out is that it puts it all in black and white,'' said Betsy Houghteling, a Department of Revenue spokeswoman. Although she acknowledged it may be difficult to track down every last fortuneteller and yoga teacher, Houghteling said the more obscure professions would bring in little money anyway. ``If we missed a palm reader, and that person didn't come forward voluntarily, would the commonwealth miss a lot of money? No,'' Houghteling said. But the lengthy list of services has left the impression with some that everything is being taxed. Among the services whose clients would be subject to a 5 percent tax: sponging textiles for tailors and dressmakers; cleaning and reglazing of baking pans; mattress renovating and repair shops; tent repair shops. ``There's no fortunetelling lobby so they can tax them,'' said Peter Blanchard of Shrewsbury. ``How much money can that bring in? I don't like it.'' But Caroline Clark, who works for an accounting firm, had little problem with taxing palm readers. ``I feel that's fairly frivolous,'' Clark said.

DOC.HEAD: Pickens Takes Koito Battle To Summit
DOC.TEXT: Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens says he seeking help at the economic summit of the world's richest nations for his efforts to crack the lineup of a Japanese company's board of directors. ``When I started out 16 months ago I said I wasn't asking for help. I was just reporting my experience to Washington and to Congress and people in the administration,'' Pickens told a news conference Tuesday. ``About 16 months later I guess I am about ready to say I would like to have some help.'' Pickens said he planned to meet with summit delegation members from the United States and Japan, but admitted that so far he ``wasn't on anyone's agenda.'' His private investment firm, Boone Co., owns 26 percent of Koito Manufacturing Co., a Japanese auto parts maker. Pickens unsuccessfully has tried to gain a voice in the company by landing four of Koito's 20 board seats. Pickens claims he has been shut out of Koito by Japan's ``keiretsu'' system, in which companies have formed closed links through shared stock, financial and personnel links and corporate strategies. He alleges Koito is part of the keiretsu surrounding Toyota Motor Co., which is its second largest shareholder and the largest buyer of its parts. At a June 28 Koito shareholders meeting, Pickens was denied board seats and was defeated on other proposals, including larger dividends and having shareholders vote on salary and retirement benefits for board members. Koito claims Pickens is trying to ``greenmail'' the company into buying his stock at premium prices. Company officials also contend Pickens is acting on behalf of Japanese investor Kitaro Watanabe, who they say has twice tried to greenmail them. When asked if he was in Houston seeking the help of Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, Pickens replied: ``There's no doubt about it. He could help my cause. If he put any pressure on the Toyota-Koito group and said, `Put the guy on the board and let's see if he would be a good board member,' sure I would like to see that call made by Kaifu. But I don't have any way to apply that kind of pressure.'' Pickens said he is more determined to buck the Japanese system since being told ``Remember Pearl Harbor'' and ``Yankee go home'' at Koito's annual shareholders meeting last month. ``It was very shocking to me to go to a meeting where you own 26 percent of the company and be told things like that,'' he said. ``It's obvious the way they feel towards Americans. They don't want anyone seeing how they run their business.''

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Says It Will Cut 4,300 Jobs
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said Tuesday that the number of employees in its Network Services Division facing layoffs had been reduced to 4,300 because many workers in the unit had opted for early retirement. The cuts, beginning in September, will affect workers in all states except Alaska, Delaware, Hawaii, Idaho and Vermont, said AT&T spokeswoman Lynn Newman. In New Jersey, where AT&T is based, 139 jobs would be cut. There are 30,000 employees in the Network Services Division, 2,700 of them in New Jersey, Ms. Newman said. She said AT&T expects to pare the division's work force to 26,000 by next March. AT&T, based in Basking Ridge, announced in March that it would lay off about 6,000 Network Services workers as part of a streamlining move. Network Services employees maintain AT&T's long distance network, attend to customer service chores and do clerical work. AT&T said automation had made some of the jobs obsolete. Ms. Newman said Tuesday that 1,600 workers accepted early retirement in May, leaving about 4,300 ``surplus workers'' facing layoffs. Laid off workers will be given the first chance at 2,200 vacancies in technical and clerical posts within the division, Ms. Newman said, if they can qualify for jobs. The Communications Workers of America, which represents union-covered Network Services employees, said the layoffs would mean reduced services for customers. ``Obviously we are distressed, disturbed and repulsed at AT&T bowing at the altar of technology at the expense of customers and employees,'' said Jim Irvine, a CWA vice president. AT&T announced at the beginning of the year that it would eliminate 13,000 jobs systemwide. The company has 280,000 employees around the world, with 265,000 in the United States. AT&T reported first-quarter earnings for 1990 of $668 million on revenue of $8.9 billion. That compares with $594 million in earnings on revenue of $8.6 billion in the same period last year.

DOC.HEAD: Analyst Fired Over Trump Remarks Files Suit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with comment from Trump spokesman, Janney Montgomery president; EDITS througout; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A securities analyst fired for making neative remarks about Donald Trump's new casino sued the real estate tycoon in federal court Tuesday claiming Trump made defamatory comments about him. Marvin B. Roffman, formerly a vice president with the Philadelphia brokerage firm Janney Montomery Scott Inc., is seeking more than $2 million in punitive and compensatary damages. Roffman, 50, was fired March 23, three days after a negative critique in The Wall Street Journal about Trump's Taj Mahal Casino Resort in Atlantic City, N.J. His case has raised questions about the independence of securities analysts, who frequently comment about companies and business developments. Roffman told the Journal that Trump's casino would flourish immediately after it opened in April, but ``once the cold winds blow from October to February, it won't make it. The market just isn't there.'' According to the lawsuit, filed in U.S. District Court, Trump sent a letter to Janney Montgomery President Norman T. Wilde that said, ``For a long while I have thought of Mr. Roffman as an unguided missile.'' The lawsuit contends Trump's letter ``contained false and defamatory material'' because Roffman's comments ``were not outrageous; he is not a unguided missile, unprofessional ... and a bad analyst.'' Martin Sobol, Roffman's attorney, said his client believes he was fired from his job because ``he was honest.'' ``He feels he was wronged,'' Sobol said. Roffman declined to comment. John Barry, a Trump spokesman, said the lawsuit ``has absolutely no basis'' and that Trump was free to express himself. ``This is still America. Mr. Trump is entitled to express his opinion,'' he said. ``If Mr. Roffman thought the statements were defamatory, why isn't he suing the publications in which they appear?'' The lawsuit quotes publications that reported Trump's comments about Roffman as evidence of defamation. In the April 2 edition of Barron's, Trump said of Roffman: ``He's a very unprofessional guy, a hair trigger.'' In the May 7 edition of Fortune, Trump is quoted as saying: ``They got rid of a bad analyst, a man with little talent,'' the lawsuit said. Trump threatened to sue Janney Montgomery unless Roffman publicly retracted the comments or the firm fired the 16-year veteran securities analyst. Roffman initially signed a letter of apology, but withdrew it in a second letter and then was fired. Janney Montgomery contended Roffman was dismissed because he violated company policy by issuing statements to the press that had not been cleared or disseminated to the firm's clients. Wilde said in a statement that although Roffman violated company policy about talking to the press, he was fired because he disobeyed a supervisor's orders by sending the second letter to Trump retracting his apology. ``In dismissing Mr. Roffman, we took measures to uphold industry standards concerning the professional integrity of security analysts,'' the statement said. Sobol said Roffman also would file a wrongful discharge claim against Janney Montgomery with the New York Stock Exchange seeking arbitration. Sobol said papers outlining the claim were mailed Tuesday. Janney Montgomery is a wholly owned subsidiary of Penn Mutual Life Insurance Co. The firm has 1,050 employees and 40 offices. Roffman's firing stirred widespread comment and turned him into a highly sought subject for interviews, especially after it was disclosed in recent weeks that Trump faced a cash crunch. Trump made a last-minute deal with bankers June 26 that allowed him to meet the $43 million payment to holders of high-yield junk bonds backing another casino, the Trump Castle.

DOC.HEAD: Hilton Second-Quarter Income Down 9 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Hilton Hotels Corp. said Tuesday that a sharp decline in gaming income contributed to a 9 percent drop in quarterly profits. For the three months ending June 30, the hotel-casino concern earned $38.2 million, or 79 cents per share, compared with $42 million, or 87 cents per share, in the same period a year earlier. Revenue rose 3 percent to $274 million from $265 million. Overall income from hotels rose 3 percent to $44.8 million from $43.6 million. Gaming income fell 21 percent to $29 million from $36.8 million. Chairman Barron Hilton said results were mixed. In Chicago and New York, one hotel did better while another declined. The Hilton Hawaiian Village had excellent results, but the San Francisco Hilton still hasn't recovered business lost from last fall's earthquake, he said. The Flamingo Hilton in Las Vegas benefited from a guestroom tower addition, with room occupancy and income both up markedly. But results at the Las Vegas Hilton, the company's other property in Las Vegas, fell 56 percent. ``The property had exceptional results in the 1989 period, and we recognized the quarterly comparison would be further challenged by the increased competition in Las Vegas,'' Hilton said. For the first six months, Hilton profits rose 15 percent, to $63.3 million, or $1.31 a share, from $55.1 million, or $1.14 a share. Revenue rose 10 percent to $539 million from $490 million.

DOC.HEAD: Martin Marietta Sues Over Bungled Satellite Launch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs to UPDATE with details on launch; INSERTS 1 graf after 5th graf, `The suit... with Intelsat comment; PICKS UP 6th pvs, `In 1987...
DOC.TEXT: Martin Marietta Corp. has sued the Intelsat consortium over who will pay for the bungled launch of a $157 million communications satellite. In the lawsuit, filed in U.S. District Court, Martin Marrietta asks that it not be held liable for the fouled March 14 launch involving one of its Titan rockets, which was sent into a low, useless orbit. The company has accused the Washington-based Intelsat of making ``unlawfully coercive demands,'' and says Intelsat should be held responsible for the mishap. ``The contract terms provided that Intelsat clearly had the financial risk,'' said Philip Giaramita, a spokesman for Bethesda, Md.-based Martin Marietta. ``That's really the heart of the matter.'' The suit, filed Friday, says Intelsat, a satellite operating company, had threatened on July 3 to sue if Martin Marietta did not pay damages for the launch. Intelsat is expected to argue that Martin Marietta was grossly negligent in conducting the launch. Intelsat spokesman Tony Trujillo said the consortium would comment only in its court reply to the chares, which must be made within 60 days. In 1987, Martin Marietta signed a $112 million contract to launch the satellite using a Titan booster. Intelsat paid separately for the satellite. Satellite operators often take out commercial insurance against a failure, but Intelsat did not, opting instead to set aside funds of its own to cover such a contingency. The rocket lifted off routinely on March 14, but once it reached space it failed to separate from the satellite. It was stranded in a low, useless orbit. Intelsat is negotiating with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to have space shuttle astronauts attach a rocket to the satellite that would send it up to its proper orbit. That would cost the company about $90 million. Martin Marietta has blamed the failure on faulty electrical engineering in its Titan booster, but contends its financial responsibilities ended at liftoff. The suit said the contract allowed Intelsat to request a replacement launch at a stipulated price if the first one failed, and it has not done so. The suit said if Martin Marietta loses the lawsuit, if may withdraw from the commercial space launch business.

DOC.HEAD: McDonnell Douglas Helicopter Announces Reorganization
DOC.TEXT: McDonnell Douglas Helicopter Co. said Tuesday it is reorganizing its management structure because of financial problems due to reduced defense spending. ``The company's financial performance in the past year makes it clear that a change in the way we do business is necessary,'' McDonnell Douglas Helicopter President Tom Gunn said in a statement. Andrew Wilson, a spokesman for McDonnell Douglas Corp. of St. Louis, said the helicopter subsidiary recently reported a profit of only 1{ percent so far this year. McDonnell Douglas Helicopter said it would create separate divisions for its four helicopter lines. Management also has accepted the resignation or early retirement of five executives. Other actions being taken include significant cost and budget cutting measures, Gunn said, but he did not provide details.

DOC.HEAD: Southmark Says Unsecured Creditors Approve Reorganization Plan
DOC.TEXT: Southmark Corp. said Tuesday preliminary results indicate unsecured creditors have approved a bankruptcy court reorganization plan that would leave the company as little more than a Texas savings and loan. Southmark said final results of the voting would be released Wednesday at a hearing on confirmation of the plan. ``If the plan is confirmed by the court, Southmark could emerge from Chapter 11 later this month, just one year after its original bankruptcy filing,'' the company said in a statement. The agreement is ``major hurdle number one,'' Southmark spokeswoman Susan A. Seiter said. Creditors also have filed several objections that must be dealt with in the confirmation hearing, which she said could last several days. The reorganization plan would repay some unsecured creditors as much as 30 cents on the dollar to less than 10 cents on the dollar. Common stock holders would be left with little if anything. Unsecured creditors also would receive securities in the reorganized Southmark. Creditors also will select new management for the company. The plan also includes an agreement with federal thrift regulators to inject $100 million in new capital into San Jacinto Savings Association, the Houston-based thrift that would form the core of the reorganized Southmark. Southmark became the nation's largest publicly traded real estate company in the 1980s by buying and selling partnerships. Much of the growth was financed with some $2 billion in high yield bonds issued through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., itself currently in bankruptcy proceedings. Southmark sought Chapter 11 protection from creditors last year after failing to make interest payments on about $700 million in bonds.

DOC.HEAD: Lomas To Sell Three Life Insurance Companies For $165 Million
DOC.TEXT: Lomas Financial Corp. said Tuesday it would sell its three life insurance companies to an Indiana insurance company for $140 million in cash and $25 million in securities. The deal must be approved by the U.S. Bankruptcy Court, which is overseeing Lomas under Chapter 11. ``The life insurance businesses were performing well, but we have determined that all of our resources should be focused on Lomas's core businesses, principally mortgage banking and information and systems services to the mortgage finance industry,'' Lomas Financial Chairman Jess Hay said. ``Over the past several months we have been working to more sharply focus, better define and grow our mortgage banking business,'' he said. The firms involved are Jefferson National Life Insurance Co. of Indianapolis; Union Life Insurance Co. of Little Rock, Ark.; and First Continental Life & Accident Co., Salt Lake City. The companies were sold to Conseco Capital Partners Limited Partnership, formed by Conseco Inc., a life insurance and annuity company based in Carmel, Ind. Lomas said it would retain office buildings valued at about $15 million that had housed some of the insurance operations.

DOC.HEAD: USX, Two Steel Officials Convicted of Pension Scam
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with possible penalties, details on 1983 contract, pensions, union reaction; EDITS throughout; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury Tuesday convicted USX Corp. and two United Steelworkers officials of conspiring to give the union officials company pensions in exchange for approval of a key labor contract. USX was convicted of all 14 counts of conspiracy, violating federal labor law and mail fraud. Union District 36 director Thermon Phillips and subdirector E.B. Rich each was convicted of one count of conspiracy and one count of violating federal labor law. Rich, 60, was acquitted of 10 counts of mail fraud. Ten mail fraud charges against Phillips, 62, were dismissed earlier. The verdict came on the 10th day of deliberations in U.S. District Court. USX faces a maximum penalty of $4.1 million. Phillips and Rich each face a maximum 10 years in prison and $500,000 in fines at sentencing Aug. 20. ``I think it shows the labor community that the public is not going to sit still for skulduggery. They're going to demand honest, upright labor negotiations,'' First Assistant U.S. Attorney Buddy Kelly said. USX said it would appeal the verdict to the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. In a statement, the company maintained the charges were ``the products of strained and erroneous interpretations of complex statutes.'' The government claimed at the 17-week trial the union officials engaged in illegal negotiations in exchange for approval of a work contract that cut wages and benefits but allowed USX's Fairfield Works plant in Birmingham to reopen. The government alleged Phillips and Rich, former steel company employees, illegally negotiated pensions for themselves and four other union officials during talks in 1983. The government said Rich received a pension based on about 31 years of work but only worked there 13 years. Phillips' pension was based on about 38 years of employment but he worked for the company only from 1946-51, prosecutors alleged. Defense attorneys contended the pensions were not negotiated during the talks and the defendants did not try to conceal them. They said Rich and Phillips never made pensions a condition of resolving the Fairfield negotiations. In 1984, USX, then U.S. Steel, changed its longstanding policy against giving pensions to former employees who became labor representatives. The company paid more than $300,000 in pensions to Phillips, Rich and the other four union officers until the practice was halted in 1988. Union president Lynn Williams and the union's top lawyer testified that they read and filed a March 1985 U.S. Steel letter reporting the pension policy change and the granting of six pensions to unidentified union officers. Other union representatives testifying for the government said they did not learn of the change, under which they may have been eligible for company pensions, until 1987. The union said in a statement it expected the charges against Rich and Phillips to be overturned on appeal, based on numerous trial errors. Williams said the trial was ``more of an inquisition than a search for the truth.''

DOC.HEAD: Offers Early Retirement to Older U.S. Employees
DOC.TEXT: Schering-Plough Corp. said Tuesday it would offer early retirement to U.S. employees 55 years and older who had been with the company at least 10 years. The voluntary plan would add five years of age and five years of service in calculating pension benefits for about 900 eligible employees, or 6 percent of the domestic work force. Schering-Plough develops, manufactures and markets pharmaceutical and health care products worldwide. The company said similar plans would be offered on a limited basis to employees in international subsidiaries. Executives and Schering-Plough HealthCare Products hourly workers would not be eligible. Most domestic employees who retired after Dec. 30, 1989, and Maybelline employees who retired before the company's July 2 sale of Maybelline, also will be eligible for the enhanced benefits, the company said. The Maybelline division was sold to an affiliate of buyout specialist Wasserstein Perella Partners LP.
